abstract: We really know no reason why the Judges of the Superior Court should sacrifice their lives in order to gave the City the expense of providing decent, well-ventilated rooms for the discharge of their official duties.
lead_paragraph: We really know no reason why the Judges of the Superior Court should sacrifice their lives in order to gave the City the expense of providing decent, well-ventilated rooms for the discharge of their official duties. One Judge, at least, has already succumbed to the influences of the foul atmosphere by which the court-rooms at present in use are pervaded during the entire day; another has recently been compelled to go to Cuba for three or four months in order to recruit his shattered health, and unless those who still remain at their posts are more than human, they are steadily undermining their constitutions every hour they occupy the Bench. The two rooms which are most crowded, those devoted to the Special and Trial Term, are not larger than good-sized parlors in an average dwelling-house, and their ceilings are lower than those to be found in any average private house in the City built within the last ten years. There is no means of ventilation except that afforded by throwing the windows wide open; a remedy which in Winter weather is of course much worse than the disease it is meant to relieve. The result is, that from 10 A.M. to the rising of the Court, the air is not simply bad, it is pestiferous. Jurymen and witnesses suffer enough from it, but their tortures at least do not last long. For a judge there is no release. He must sit, day after day, calm, collected, good-tempered, with all his senses awake, all his faculties in full activity, swallowing deadly poison at every breath.

abstract: The Republican State Central Committee met at Congress Hall this evening, and agreed to call a State Convention, composed of two delegates from each Assembly District, to meet at Syracuse on the 19th day of April, to elect delegates to the Republican National Convention. abstract: The expected election of Speaker did not take place yesterday. It has been confidently proclaimed on the Democratic side that the only difficulty in the way of the organization of the House was the persistence of the Republicans in the support of a candidate for Speaker who was obnoxious to the conservative sentiment of the country by his indorsement of the Helper book.
lead_paragraph: The expected election of Speaker did not take place yesterday. It has been confidently proclaimed on the Democratic side that the only difficulty in the way of the organization of the House was the persistence of the Republicans in the support of a candidate for Speaker who was obnoxious to the conservative sentiment of the country by his indorsement of the Helper book. On Monday, to escape an anticipated defeat in case they obstinately insisted on SHERMAN, the Republicans reluctantly consented to drop him and take up Mr. PENNINGTON, a well-known conservative, against whom no similar objection could be urged; but it seems that our Democratic friends are in equal consternation at the prospect of his election, and, at the appeal of Mr. ASHMORE that another vote would secure the inevitable result, they insisted upon an adjournment, to see if some combination could not be effected which would wrest the victory from the Republicans. It was no doubt unwise for the Republicans to continue their adhesion to Mr. SHERMAN so long, especially as they have been compelled to give him up at last; but the proceedings of yesterday pretty clearly evince that his connection with the Helper book was not the only secret of the violent opposition which he has encountered. The head and front of his offending, of course, has been that he is a Republican. The indignant eloquence which has been expended in denouncing him for contributing to the circulation of a campaign document which he had been thoughtless enough to indorse without reading, has not been purely patriotic. Something of its energy must be credited to the violent spirit of party which has been manifested on both sides of the House in this whole contest for the Speakership. It is this spirit of party which has inspired the factious and disorganizing scenes which have been witnessed in the Hall of Representatives during the past eight weeks, which openly avows, as in the columns of the Tribune, that its policy is "to rule or ruin," and which, unless it shall be effectually rebuked by the people, will eventually leave them nothing of liberty but the name, and establish a practical despotism, which, under the forms of Republican institutions, will give us over to the sway of vociferous demagogues and the control of irresponsible factions.

abstract: Mr. JAQUES' bill, now before the Legislature, settling the manner in which the Common Council may make grants for railroads in this City, at last provides that all such grants shall be put up at auction. This is exactly what is wanted to put an end to the jobbery, which has hitherto attended all applications for these privileges, and which has furnished the ene- ...
lead_paragraph: Mr. JAQUES' bill, now before the Legislature, settling the manner in which the Common Council may make grants for railroads in this City, at last provides that all such grants shall be put up at auction. This is exactly what is wanted to put an end to the jobbery, which has hitherto attended all applications for these privileges, and which has furnished the enemies of City railroads with their strongest ground of objection. No more grunts of lines of railroad in our streets must be made to any individuals by name. To make such profitable monopolies the prize of successful lobbying is a gross and inexcusable outrage upon the people of the City. There are two or three such applications before the Legislature at this moment; but we warn all whom it may concern that anybody who attempts, while we are groaning under our present weight of taxation, to appropriate the streets for the benefit of individuals, without giving the Municipality a reasonable share in the profits, must have a greater contempt for public opinion than any legislator can well afford to entertain, or at least to expose. The men who are to pocket their thirty or forty per cent. from any railroads to be hereafter laid in the streets of New-York City, must be the men who have paid most for the opportunity at public auction.

abstract: As Mr. RAYMOND remarked, in his Union speech at Albany, "Agitation on the one side creates and stimulates agitation on the other." We see this truth illustrated every day throughout the country. Our Buchaniers, however, do not care to recognize and respect it. They look for light and guidance to Mr. O'CONOR rather than to Mr. RAYMOND.
lead_paragraph: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Monday, Jan. 23, 1860.

abstract: The House of Representatives yesterday came almost as near the election of a Speaker, as on Friday, when Mr. SMITH was so sadly disappointed. The absentees numbered seven, five of them being Democrats. Mr. SHERMAN having moved that the House proceed to vote viva voce, the vote was taken, several gentlemen interpolating speeches as it proceeded.
lead_paragraph: The House of Representatives yesterday came almost as near the election of a Speaker, as on Friday, when Mr. SMITH was so sadly disappointed. The absentees numbered seven, five of them being Democrats. Mr. SHERMAN having moved that the House proceed to vote viva voce, the vote was taken, several gentlemen interpolating speeches as it proceeded. Mr. SMITH, of North Carolina, spoke, declining to run longer as a candidate. Mr. REAGAN spoke, nominating Mr. MCCLERNAND in the stead of Mr. SMITH. Mr. HILL (American) would not support MCCLERNAND. Mr. ETHERIDGE (American) was quite ready to support him. Mr. MILLSON entreated the conservatives to rally to the new candidate, and an animated debate ensued. Mr. DAVIS, of Maryland, voted for Mr. PENNINGTON. Other South Americans threw away their votes, promising to recover and use them when they could be made effective. Mr. ASHMORE, of South Carolina, exhorted these and the other South Americans to sustain MCCLERNAND, if they feared to see a Republican in the Chair. As 233 members voted, 117 were necessary to a choice. Mr. PENNINGTON received 116, Mr. MCCLERNAND 91; the remainder scattering. The Democrats moved an adjournment, which after some resistance on the part of the Republicans, was carried; there being an understanding that another vote should be had immediately upon the meeting of the House today. In the Senate, Mr. HUNTER spoke upon the resolutions of Mr. DOUGLAS. He reviewed the relations of the North and South; showed the industrial dependence of the former upon the latter, asserted that the entire energies of the Federal Government had been devoted to fostering Northern prosperity, referring for evidence to the several protective tariffs, and to the creation of the United States Bank at Philadelphia; and argued that the present tendencies of Northern sentiment were irreconcilable with the safety and dignity of the South. As to any design of the North to prevent forcibly a Southern attempt at secession, he desired to know how the States invaded by Northern armies were to be held -- whether as subjugated provinces or as sovereign States in a sort of Federal tutelage. He could see no constitutional provision for the compulsion threatened; and therefore declared that the very first belligerent act of the Northern defenders of the Constitution, would be a departure from and violation of that instrument. The remarks of Mr. HUNTER occupied the entire session.

lead_paragraph: The weekly report from the institutions to the Board of Governors yesterday showed that the number of inmates remaining Jan. 28 was 8,394, an increase of 122 as compared with the number reported at the previous meeting. While the Clerk was reading the requisitions, the Board was informed that two more foundlings had been left in charge of the Governors. The infants were turned over to the fatherly care of Mr. KELLOGG, Superintendent of Outside Poor.

abstract: In yesterday's TIMES we published an account of a conspiracy on the part of JAMES STEPHENS and FELIX SANCHEZ, two of the condemned murderers in the Tombs, to kill their keepers and escape from confinement. Upon further investigation it has been ascertained that STEPHENS alone originated the plot, and that SANCHEZ did not wholly enter into it, as it was he who revealed the matter, and thus most probably prevented the murder of the keepers.
lead_paragraph: In yesterday's TIMES we published an account of a conspiracy on the part of JAMES STEPHENS and FELIX SANCHEZ, two of the condemned murderers in the Tombs, to kill their keepers and escape from confinement. abstract: BUSINESS UPON THE WHARVES.--Much activity is observable along the wharves, particularly in the vicinity of the piers from which the great bulk of merchandise is shipped upon the different steamer and sailing lines. The Sound steamers are doing as much business now as during the same months last year.
lead_paragraph: BUSINESS UPON THE WHARVES.--Much activity is observable along the wharves, particularly in the vicinity of the piers from which the great bulk of merchandise is shipped upon the different steamer and sailing lines. The Sound steamers are doing as much business now as during the same months last year. The passenger traffic by these lines is also increasing. The steamers of the various Southern lines continue to go fully freighted, there being a marked augmentation in shipments to the principal ports, the first fruits of the Spring business. At one of the down town hotels there were yesterday about sixty guests from Alabama, Mississippi and Tennessee, the majority merchants and traders who have come North to purchase Spring goods. Of the five Southern lines, employing an aggregate of twenty steamers, only one, the Alabama, is unemployed, and she is having new boilers put in, and undergoing thorough repairs, to take her place on the line in about two week. All these vessels are profitably employed, with a fair prospect of enlarged occupation during the two succeeding months. The large passenger steamers of the different Hudson River lines are in the hands of the mechanics, being painted and otherwise refitted for the approaching Summer campaign. From the present mild weather, they anticipate an early opening of navigation to Albany. The New World will take her place on the old route as soon as navigation opens, thoroughly refitted and restored. The smaller steamers, which have been interrupted in their business by the ice, and the usual cessation of travel during the Winter months, are undergoing repairs for the renewal of the Spring travel. The steamer Long Island has been and is now running upon her old line to the different towns on the north shore of Long Island. In the Spring there will be an accession of two or three new steamboats of a small class to be employed in the business of harbor towing.

abstract: ITEMS. -- MARGARET SCULLY, a resident of No. 12 Franklin-place, died yesterday from the effects of intemperance and exposure, according to the verdict of a Coroner's Jury ....JOHN LOGAN, carman, fell from a dray on Fulton-street, yesterday, and broke one of his legs. He was taken to the City Hospital.... The alarm of fire at about 12 o'clock Monday night proceeded from a building corner of Fulton-avenue and Gold-street, occupied as a drug store. The fire was discovered in the basement and was extinguished in time to prevent much damage....House No. 27 Douglass-street, occupied by J. DERBECKER, was robbed Monday night of clothing valued at $50.... A Skating Club has recently been organized in this city ....There are only about 700 men at work in the Navy Yard now....A woman named HAMMOND was held for trial by Justice CORNWELL on a charge of opening a letter addressed by her husband, who is in Rio de Janeiro, to another woman....A man named SIMMONS was discharged from the Penitentiary a few days since and as he was leaving he stole several articles of clothing. He was arrested, and yesterday was sent back to ids old quarters for 60 days.
lead_paragraph: ITEMS. -- MARGARET SCULLY, a resident of No. 12 Franklin-place, died yesterday from the effects of intemperance and exposure, according to the verdict of a Coroner's Jury ....JOHN LOGAN, carman, fell from a dray on Fulton-street, yesterday, and broke one of his legs. He was taken to the City Hospital.... The alarm of fire at about 12 o'clock Monday night proceeded from a building corner of Fulton-avenue and Gold-street, occupied as a drug store. The fire was discovered in the basement and was extinguished in time to prevent much damage....House No. 27 Douglass-street, occupied by J. abstract: We have recently received a communication from one of our African correspondents which contains some interesting details touching the traffic in slaves. For more than half a century this odious commerce has withstood the denunciations of successive philanthropists; the proscriptive legislation of mighty States; ...
lead_paragraph: We have recently received a communication from one of our African correspondents which contains some interesting details touching the traffic in slaves. For more than half a century this odious commerce has withstood the denunciations of successive philanthropists; the proscriptive legislation of mighty States; the incessant surveillance, and destructive attacks of hostile squadrons -- yet it is still prosperous, still flourishing. Every letter from the African coast brings us intelligence of the capture of one or more of the vessels engaged in it -- our present correspondent announces that of five; but the profits accruing from the trade are so enormous that even these disasters cannot deter the losers from following their horrid avocation, one fortunate venture out of every four being sufficient to indemnify and remunerate them for all risk, all failure. Nor are the wholesale dealers in their fellowmen unmindful of the convenience of their customers. From Cape Palmas to Loando, according to our informant, there is one barracoon, or slave-depot, to every twenty miles of the coast, so that on the slightest relaxation of the vigilance of the cruisers, the traders can readily take in their human cargo, and be off with them to Cuba or Brazil. Now, the plain inference from all these facts, and from the ill success of the attempts hitherto made, both by England and the United States, at vast expense, as well as sacrifice of life, to suppress it, is that the African Slave-trade cannot be put down while there exist countries which desire and are willing to pay a high price for negroes. It is a fundamental axiom of political economy, not less applicable to the present than to other cases, that the supply and value of any article are ultimately regulated by the demand; with the increase of that, the supply and value of the given commodity will increase; with the decline of that, they will diminish. As long as the slave-dealer has a market, where he can obtain $800 or $1,000 a head for his cargo of 500 or 600 Africans, he will brave all dangers in the prosecution of a commerce which, despite of risk and loss, will make him quickly rich. But let him be shut out from this emporium, and confined to markets where few slaves suffice, and their price is low, and he will soon tire of hazarding life and capital in a business so unremunerative; let him be excluded from all marts, and his occupation, like Othello's, is at once gone. Now if the nations that are in vain essaying to annihilate the African Slave Trade, would see their efforts crowned with success, they must employ all their influence to obtain the cooperation of those States which at present foster and sustain it. True, they may fail of this object. The said States may refuse to cooperate with them in the godly work, on the ground that slave-labor is essential to the cultivation of their fields, and that their legislating against it would convert those fields into a wilderness. For these reasons, we say, the Governments that still continue to patronize the African Slave-Trade may decline to become parties to its proscription, yet the attempt to induce them to do so ought to be again and again made, as without their cooperation, that traffic will in the future, no less than in the past, prove irrepressible.

abstract: Mr. HUNTERS of Virginia, occupied the attention of the Senate, on Tuesday, with an elaborate defence of Slavery. Mr. DOUGLAS' bill for assuring peace between the States was the order of the day, but in the report of the speech we cannot find so much as an allusion to this wise and conservative measure.
lead_paragraph: Mr. HUNTERS of Virginia, occupied the attention of the Senate, on Tuesday, with an elaborate defence of Slavery. Mr. DOUGLAS' bill for assuring peace between the States was the order of the day, but in the report of the speech we cannot find so much as an allusion to this wise and conservative measure. Mr. HUNTER's whole argument was given apparently to prove that the "peculiar institution" is the highest form of civilization -- "the normal condition of society" -- "the black-marble keystone of the mighty arch of the Union," and "that there is no nation known to history that has not built up its foundation on this system." All this may be perfectly true or perfectly false, keystone, foundation and all, and we know no reason why Mr. HUNTER should not air his theories -- provided they do not interfere with the public business. Since the commencement of the Session, Senators have had abundant leisure to speak in this way, there having been nothing to do in the way of legislation while the House remained unorganized. And surely they might well spend their time much worse. An ingenious argument, even when we do not accept its conclusions, sets us a-thinking, and a sophism, the fallacy of which demands never so slight an exercise of acuteness to detect, is positively refreshing. But we cannot in conscience say that Mr. HUNTER has gratified our reasonable hopes of entertainment. He has neither impressed us by the philosophy, nor startled us by the novelty of his notions. His historical statements were not fortified by fact, and his theories were sadly bare of illustration. It was the same old glorification of Slavery which we are all of us, Northerners and Southerners both, beginning to know by heart, relieved at intervals by some very passable flourishes of rhetoric, and concluding with the stereotyped eulogy on the stars and stripes, and the fervent, and no doubt honest, prayer for the perpetuity of the Republic.

abstract: Mrs. Sarah McCormack, a lady residing at Hempstead, L.I., whose husband is a Ship captain, went to Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday, and made a...
lead_paragraph: Mrs. Sarah McCormack, a lady residing at Hempstead, L.I., whose husband is a Ship captain, went to Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday, and made a complaint against Melinda Myers, a delicate-looking, middle-aged female, whom she charged with having stolen jewelry, consisting of gold bracelets, ear-rings and breast-pins, besides a valuable crape shawl, and other property, valued at $300. Melinda is a widow, and has managed to obtain a precarious living by sewing wherever she could find work. Two months since she was engaged by Mrs. McCormack to live with her at Hempstead as nurse and seamstress. She seemed so trustworthy that Mrs. McCormack placed the greatest confidence in her, and last week, when the captain was about to start on a voyage, left home, as usual, to spend a few days with him in the City. The opportunity, she alleges, was improved by Melinda to pack up all the valuables in the house, with which she started for New-York, leaving the three children, the eldest of whom was but eight years of age, to get along as best they could. On Monday, when Mrs. McCormack returned, she found her house deserted. She was fortunate enough to find her little ones at a neighbor's, where they had wandered, after having spent a a day or two by themselves. Mrs. McC. subsequently returned to the City, and made the case known to Detective McDougal, who yesterday succeeded in apprehending the delinquent nurse at a house in Lewis-street, where a part of the stolen property was found. The woman afterwards gave information which led to the recovery of the rest from parties to whom she had disposed of it. The prisoner was taken before Justice KELLY, to whom she acknowledged her guilt, adding that she must have been crazy at the time of its commission. She was held to answer for her supposed lunacy.

abstract: Early yesterday morning, Rev. Mr. KNAPP, the spiritual adviser of JAMES STEPHENS, the murderer, receiced a telegraphic dispatch from Gov. MORGAN, in which the latter announcces his intention of allowing STEPHENS' sentence of death to be carried into effect, and declines any further respite.
lead_paragraph: Early yesterday morning, Rev. Mr. KNAPP, the spiritual adviser of JAMES STEPHENS, the murderer, receiced a telegraphic dispatch from Gov. MORGAN, in which the latter announcces his intention of allowing STEPHENS' sentence of death to be carried into effect, and declines any further respite. Mr. KNAPP immediately communicated the Governor's decision to the condemned man, with whom he had a long private interview. STEPHENS did not make the promised statement to the reporters yesterday, in reference to the manner in which he procured the pistol. He is said to have been exceedingly morose all day, refusing to communicate with any person but his counsel and Mr. KNAPP. He will be executed this morning.

abstract: FIRST BALLOT.--On the first ballot, Mr. GROW, (Rep.,) of Pennsylvania, received 43 votes. He then withdrew his name.
lead_paragraph: FIRST BALLOT.--On the first ballot, Mr. GROW, (Rep.,) of Pennsylvania, received 43 votes. He then withdrew his name. The scattering vote on this ballot was divided among eleven candidates. Mr. GILMER, (American,) of North Carolina, received three votes on the first ballot; was dropped after the seventh; came up again on the seventeenth, and received votes on nearly all the subsequent ballots, notwithstanding his definite withdrawal after the eighth.

abstract: THE REGATTA MARCH BETWEEN ENGLAND AND AMERICA--THE ENGLISH CHALLENGE ACCEPTED.--There was a meeting of the Empire City Regatta Club at the St. Mark's-place Restaurant, last evening, to consider the challenge issued through Bell's Life, some six weeks ago, from ROBERT CHAMBERS, the champion of the Thames, to the champion of America, to row a match for $2,500 a side, single pair of sculls.
lead_paragraph: THE REGATTA MARCH BETWEEN ENGLAND AND AMERICA--THE ENGLISH CHALLENGE ACCEPTED.--There was a meeting of the Empire City Regatta Club at the St. Mark's-place Restaurant, last evening, to consider the challenge issued through Bell's Life, some six weeks ago, from ROBERT CHAMBERS, the champion of the Thames, to the champion of America, to row a match for $2,500 a side, single pair of sculls. STEPHEN ROBERTS, President of the Empire City Club, read, to the meeting a letter from the Secretary of the Regatta Association of Newburgh, where JOSHUA WARD, the champion of America, resides, stating that they had accepted the English challenge, on condition that the race Should come off in Newburgh Bay, the Newburgh Association agreeing, according to the terms of the Challenge, to pay the English champion $500, for his expenses to this country. The meeting then voted to cooperate with, the Newburgh Association in rendering any assistance they might require, and, in case their conditions were declined by the English champion, that the challenge should be accepted by the Empire City Club. It is expected that the match will come off some time in June.

abstract: The jury in the case of John Crummins, indicted for the murder of Dennis McHenry, remained in deliberation during Tuesday night, and came into  Court yesterday moring with a verdict of "Guilty of murder, with a recommendation to mercy."
lead_paragraph: The jury in the case of John Crummins, indicted for the murder of Dennis McHenry, remained in deliberation during Tuesday night, and came into Court yesterday moring with a verdict of "Guilty of murder, with a recommendation to mercy." They were severally polled by the counsel for the prisoner, and each answered that such was his verdict They were then discharged with the thanks of the Court, and the prisoner was remanded for sentence.

abstract: From the Boston Post, Feb. 1.  A fatal accident occurred on the Western Railroad, yesterday afternoon, which resulted in the death of one person and the injury of many others more or less seriously.
lead_paragraph: From the Boston Post, Feb. 1. A fatal accident occurred on the Western Railroad, yesterday afternoon, which resulted in the death of one person and the injury of many others more or less seriously. The last car but one of the New-York mail train, from Hartford and New-Haven, was thrown off the track at a point about a quarter of a mile this side of Wilbraham and four miles from Palmer, while the train was going at the rate of thirty miles on hour, and rolled down an embankment about fifty feet high.

abstract: Our attention has been called to the fact that the Inspectors of Manure are appointed by the Finance Department, and not by the Inspector's Department, as we stated inadvertently yesterday. If these officials should be removed during the suspension of street-cleaning operations, it is for the Comptroller's "Superintendent of Market Rents and Fees," and not for the City Inspector, to give them their walking papers. The City Inspector employs Inspectors on dumping grounds, whose duty it is to keep account of every load of ashes, rubbish and dirt from the street brought to the dumping-grounds, and to see that full loads and public dirt only are brought there. These have not been discharged, because the removal of ashes and garbage requires their constant supervision, but a number of "laborers on the beat" have been suspended from pay and duty, until the street cleaning commences again.
lead_paragraph: Our attention has been called to the fact that the Inspectors of Manure are appointed by the Finance Department, and not by the Inspector's Department, as we stated inadvertently yesterday. abstract: Mr. BUCKLE'S rule of averages is busy with the railways. This Oxford philosopher, as the reader knows or ought to know, avers that when one white hat is seen on the boulevards, a certain number of other white hats must have made their appearance at the same time; and the law which determines how many gentlemen shall eat omelettes aux fines herbes at...
lead_paragraph: Mr. BUCKLE'S rule of averages is busy with the railways. This Oxford philosopher, as the reader knows or ought to know, avers that when one white hat is seen on the boulevards, a certain number of other white hats must have made their appearance at the same time; and the law which determines how many gentlemen shall eat omelettes aux fines herbes at their breakfast in New-York on a given day, is just as fixed as the principle which controls the stars in their courses. There is, then, we may be sure, a discoverable rationale of the simultaneous slaughters which are now constantly going on all over this country on our various railroad lines. Pending the discovery thereof, we beg leave, however, to suggest that in all these instances, one identical trait reappears which ought to suffice for all practical, if not for all philosophical purposes in dealing with them, and that is a certain stolid and frigid recklessness of human life and the common obligations of duty, which has apparently assumed the character of a chronic malady with our common carriers. It demands for the patients' sake, as well as for our own, a sharp and speedy remedy.

abstract: We think it not at all improbable that the establishment of gymnasia at our two principal seats of learning--Harvard and Yale--within the last few months, is an event which, little attention as it excites, will influence the future of the country a good deal more than the "organization of the House."
lead_paragraph: We think it not at all improbable that the establishment of gymnasia at our two principal seats of learning--Harvard and Yale--within the last few months, is an event which, little attention as it excites, will influence the future of the country a good deal more than the "organization of the House." The political institutions of a nation have of course not a little to do with its destiny, but the health and happiness of the individuals who live under them have a great deal more. Constitutions and acts of Congress, and decisions of Courts, are after all but paper and ink. They owe, we were going to say, all their real value to the mental and moral characteristics of the men who are to obey them.

abstract: This Board held a meeting at the Mercantile Library last evening, the President, GEO. OPDYKE, in the chair. Hon. AMASA WALKER, of Boston, read a paper upon the character and increase of Bank Deposits, which was well received.
lead_paragraph: This Board held a meeting at the Mercantile Library last evening, the President, GEO. OPDYKE, in the chair. Hon. AMASA WALKER, of Boston, read a paper upon the character and increase of Bank Deposits, which was well received. He divided these deposits into different classes, and said they were equivalent to credits -- notes, checks and other bank bills being received and placed to the account of customers. First -- Compulsory deposits formed a large item, which customers are compelled to make in order to secure loans. Second -- Fiduciary deposits, consisting of trust-funds, &c. Lastly -- The actual deposits made by the mass of business men solely for business purposes. These last deposits furnished the main profits to the banks; but being transient in their nature, were liable to be suddenly withdrawn in panics, obliging the banks to suspend payments. They constitute about three-fifths of the total deposits. The loss of the whole circulation in 1857 ($214,000,000) would have been small compared with its inconvertibility into specie on demand. What guarantee does the Bank Superintendent at Albany give us that the whole tragedy will not again be enacted.

abstract: The long-drawn battle for the Speakership is happily brought to a close. Upon the first ballot yesterday, 233 being present and 117 necessary to a choice, Mr. BRIGGS, of New-York, added his vote to those which Mr. PENNINGTON had secured the day before, and Mr. PENNINGTON having thus 117 votes was declared elected. He was conducted to the chair by Messrs. SHERMAN and BOCOCK, and the...
lead_paragraph: The long-drawn battle for the Speakership is happily brought to a close. Upon the first ballot yesterday, 233 being present and 117 necessary to a choice, Mr. BRIGGS, of New-York, added his vote to those which Mr. PENNINGTON had secured the day before, and Mr. PENNINGTON having thus 117 votes was declared elected. He was conducted to the chair by Messrs. SHERMAN and BOCOCK, and the oath of office having been administered, the members were also sworn in. After a scene of much confusion, a Committee was appointed to inform the Senate that the House was ready to proceed to business, and then an adjournment to Friday was carried. The Senate, after the transaction of unimportant business, went into executive session and subsquently adjourned.

abstract: A German named FISHER was killed on the Hudson River Railroad, at Low Point station, Fishkill, Monday afternoon. He was struck by the locomotive while crossing the track, and his body severed completely in two. FISHER was discharged from the Poughkeepsie jail the same morning, after a ten days confinement for vagrancy.

abstract: At the meeting of the Board of Education, last evening, a communication was received from the School officers of the Seventeenth Ward, asking an appropriation of $7,832, to alter, repair and heat School No. 19. lead_paragraph: At the meeting of the Board of Education, last evening, a communication was received from the School officers of the Seventeenth Ward, asking an appropriation of $7,832, to alter, repair and heat School No. 19. The work had been advertised for and the contracts awarded, amounting in the aggregate to the sum named. It was stated that some of the work had not been awarded to the lowest bidder, and a motion was made to refer the communication back to the School officers. That was lost, and a motion to refer it to the Committee on Finance was carried.

abstract: The sash and blind factory of P.M. WILSON, No. 117 Prince-street, caught fire between 3 and 4 o'clock yesterday morning. The following losses were experienced: Mr. WILSON, on stock, machinery, and building, $3,500; insured for $1,500 in the Safeguard Company. Mr. DUSENBURY, proprietor, of two frame buildings in the rear, which were occupied as a brass foundry, and were crushed in by the falling walls of the sash and blind factory, suffered $800 loss. On the second floor of the these buildings were DANIEL LUTTICH, manufacturer of cabinet ware, and HUBER & KEMPF, who lose respectively $400 and $ 500, with no insurance. RIX & Co., on the third floor, makers of hoop skirts, suffer to the extent of $1,000; not insured. The rest of the losses were unimportant.
lead_paragraph: The sash and blind factory of P.M. WILSON, No. 117 Prince-street, caught fire between 3 and 4 o'clock yesterday morning. abstract: The Joint Committee of the Common Council, appointed to consider the propriety of passing an ordinance prohibiting the throwing of salt in the streets, for the purpose of melting the snow, met in Room No. 8, City Hall, at 3 P.M. yesterday, Alderman DARRAGH presiding. The majority of the Committee resolved to report in favor of the passage of such an ordinance, excepting from the action thereof the City Railroad Companies. Alderman DARRAGH dissented from this decision, and said he should present a minority report in favor of passing such an ordinance without excepting the railroad companies from its action. The reports will probably be presented at the next meeting of the two Boards.

abstract: The Academy held its regular semi-monthly meeting on Wednesday evening, at the University, with the President in the Chair. After the reading of the minutes a long and somewhat acrimonious discussion...
lead_paragraph: The Academy held its regular semi-monthly meeting on Wednesday evening, at the University, with the President in the Chair. After the reading of the minutes a long and somewhat acrimonious discussion took place between Dr. VANKLEEK, the Chairman of the Committee on Admissions, and Dr. MCNULTY, respecting the election of a candidate, who, it was alleged, was desirous of becoming a member merely as a matter of political capital. After some hard talking on both sides, and scarcely admissible personalities, the matter was, on motion, laid on the table.

abstract: The Special Committee appointed by the Board of Aldermen to investigate the subject of the contested seats of the Second and Eighth Districts met at 2 P.M. yesterday in the Chamber of the Board. The friends of the contending parties were present in great force. The name of Ex-Councilman GEORGE P. BICKFORD, who contests Alderman BARRY's seat in the Second District, was called, but the call was not responded to; his case was therefore laid over, and the Committee considered the claim of PETER MITCHELL to the seat of Alderman RUSSELL, of the Eighth District. A. OAKEY HALL, Esq., who, with Ex-Judge DEAN, appeared for the two incumbents of the contested seats, demurred to the generality of the charges made in the affidavits presented by the contestants, and asked that the counsel on the other side be directed to file specifications.

abstract: St. LOUIS, Mo., Thursday, Jan. 26, 1860. The unfortunate and apparently chronic dead  lock at Washington keeps the political pool in this quarter in a state of almost total stagnation.
lead_paragraph: St. LOUIS, Mo., Thursday, Jan. 26, 1860. The unfortunate and apparently chronic dead lock at Washington keeps the political pool in this quarter in a state of almost total stagnation. The only ripple which stirs its waters, never so gently, arises from the puffing of divers favorites as candidates for the next Presidential campaign, through the columns of those sonorous oracles of their respective parties or f(r)actions in both State and City -- the Republican and the Democrat. In most cases these are doubtless employed merely as tubs for the public whale to play with, and knock about with his iron flukes, or crush into oblivion in his cavernous jaws. In one instance, however, there is a studied and consistent advocacy which will carry weight with it at the proper time and point of operation -- I allude to the Republican's espousal of the "little giant." By the way, there is a singular misnomer in the titles of both the journals alluded to -- the Democrat being the Republicans' organ, and the Republican that of the Democrats; hence a stranger is likely to be very prettily mystified and confused between names and principles. Among the names proposed for the opposition nag, against the favorite of Charleston course, are several "good men, and true," such as EVERETT, of Massachusetts, BATES, of Missouri, and BELL, of Tennessee, but you will probably agree that the chance of a nomination for either, alongside of the favorite of New-York, grows daily "small by degrees and beautifully less." It would indeed be a fortunate and happy day for the country were the conservative counsels of the people to succeed in placing the "Washingtonian" EVERETT at the post of immortal honor and high responsibility, and so have said many in my hearing, since his name was proposed, but I feel the popular appetite will require higher seasoned food, even at the risk of a long fit of indigestion, or even a twinge or two of the gout itself.

abstract: Mr. H.H. VANDYCK, the Superintendent of Public Instruction, states in his Annual Report, that the whole number of reported School Districts in the State exclusive of cities is 11,358; being an increase of 49 during the past year. The average number of persons between the ages of 4 and 21 years in each district, is 79 5/8. The average number attending school in each district is 53.

abstract: MEETING OF THE SANITARY ASSOCIATION.-- AT a regular meeting of the Sanitary Association held at the Cooper Institute last evening, Dr. HENRY GUERNSEY read an interesting paper, entitled, "A San  itary Survey of the Eighth Aldermanie District," being the results of a personal inspection of the Sanitary condition of that part of the City. He described the
lead_paragraph: MEETING OF THE SANITARY ASSOCIATION.-- AT a regular meeting of the Sanitary Association held at the Cooper Institute last evening, Dr. HENRY GUERNSEY read an interesting paper, entitled, "A San itary Survey of the Eighth Aldermanie District," being the results of a personal inspection of the Sanitary condition of that part of the City. He described the tenement-houses of the District at length, giving their location, the number of their occupants, with the names of their owners and agents. Alluding to the character and competency of the officials who have the sanitary condition of the City under their charge, the speaker gave the following list of the Health Wardens of New-York: Clerk, 1; speculator, 1; emigrant-runner, 1; barkeeper, 1; policy-dealer, 1; plumber, 1; stonemason, 1; bricklayers, 2: ship-carpenters, 1; house carpenters, 2; hatter, 1; laborer, 1; barber, 1; rumsellers, 3; carman, 1; butcher, 1; livery-stable keeper, 1; and one man who, until his appointment as Health Warden, had no previous business. Mr. HALLIDAY also read a paper upon the condition of the tenement-houses in the region of the Five Points. Dr. GRISCOM made some remarks upon the subject treated of in the papers that had been read, and was followed by Dr. BELL, of Brooklyn, who spoke of the progress of sanitary reform in that city, and announced that Rev. Dr. BELLOWS had consented to address the Brooklyn Sanitary Association on the 15 inst. Some discussion took place relative to the health bill now pending before the Legislature, the general features of which were indorsed by the Association. After the discussion of other topics of but little public interest, at a late hour the meeting adjourned.

abstract: The arrival of the America at Halifax, after an extremely protracted passage, supplies us with Liverpool advices to the 14th ult., and, by way of Queenstown to the 15th. The intelligence is of
lead_paragraph: The arrival of the America at Halifax, after an extremely protracted passage, supplies us with Liverpool advices to the 14th ult., and, by way of Queenstown to the 15th. The intelligence is of interest. The reported resumption of the scheme of a Congress appears to have had origin in the visit of Lord COWLEY to London. Lord COWLEY was, it seems, the bearer of a proposition from the French Government, to the effect that England should join in a circular addressed to the Courts of Europe, insisting upon non-intervention in the affairs of Central Italy, and making intervention a casus belli. The principle was accepted by the English Cabinet, with a reserve of the belligerent alternative, the sanction of Parliament being necessary to authorize a step involving among its consequences a declaration of war. In the absence of this clause the idea of a diplomatic communication was relin-quiushed, and that of a General Congress resumed. This state of affairs is regarded by the London Times as eminently auspicious for the cause of Italy; while the Paris Pays declares the situation. to be entirely satisfactory, and even intimates that the Pope is willing to make the desired concessions. On the other hand, there are indications of indisposition on the part of Austria to abandon the cause of the expatriated Dukes -- a temper that may yet cause trouble. There is nothing of striking moment from the Continent. WALKER, the fugitive Captain of the pirate yacht Wanderer, had arrived at Liverpool, and had been arrested for obtaining goods upon false pretences. The long anticipated meeting of the shareholders of the Great Eastern had been held, but nothing definite had transpired prior to the departure of the steamer. The intelligence from India and China is later, but unimportant.

abstract: At about 10 o'clock yesterday morning, a boiler in the distillery of Messrs. FURMAN  POLLY, on North Fourth, near First-street, exploded, destroying a large portion of the main building, killing two men at work on the premises, and injuring two others at work in the vicinity. The explosion was so violent that fragments of the boiler and portions of the building were thrown a distance of several hundred feet.
lead_paragraph: At about 10 o'clock yesterday morning, a boiler in the distillery of Messrs. FURMAN POLLY, on North Fourth, near First-street, exploded, destroying a large portion of the main building, killing two men at work on the premises, and injuring two others at work in the vicinity. The explosion was so violent that fragments of the boiler and portions of the building were thrown a distance of several hundred feet.

abstract: Joseph Townsend, one of the persons arrested for an attempted murder in Fiftieth-street on Friday evening last, was yesterday released by Justice QUACKENBUSH, on $7,000 bail, his accomplice, Jno. Noe, having been previously released on $3,000 bail. Mr. Green, the victim of the murderous assault, still lies very low, but it is thought that his wounds will not prove fatal. As the facts relative to the affray have been very meagerly, and, in some respects, erroneously reported, we have been requested to give the following statement of the affair, as sworn to before Justice QUACKENBUSH, at Jefferson Market Police Court. Mr. Edward Hammond arrived in this City from Westchester County on Friday morning, and stopped at the residence of his brother, No. 22 West Fiftieth-street, near Eighth avenue. During Friday he met his wife -- with whom he has had some difficulty, and who now resides in this City -- in the street, and, after talking with her a short time, they separated. About 9 o'clock in the evening, while sitting in the house of his brother, Mr. Jno. Green, an acquaintance being also present, a boy rang the bell, and inquired if Mr. Edw. Hammonn was in. On being answered in the affirmative, he said that his brother-in-law was at a public-house in the Eighth-avenue, and wished to see him. Mr. Hammond immediately started for the place designated, but had not gone more than three doors from the house when he was assaulted by two men, one of whom seized him by the throat while the other drew a knife and attempted to stab him in the breast. The knife penetrated through his coat and vest and just grazed the skin. He wrested himself from the grasp of the ruffians and ran, crying "murder" at the top of his voice. His brother and Mr. Green, hearing the cry, came out of the house, when they were immediately attacked by the two men. Mr. Hammond soon got the better of his antagonist, but Mr. Green was not so fortunate, and during the contest he received three dangerous slabs in the body. Policemen soon arrived, and took the ruffians into custody, who turned out to be Joseph Tounsend and Jno. Noe, both of whom were acquaintances of Edward Hammond, and the latter of whom had been more or less mixed up with his difficulty with ms wife. They are both residents of the east side of the town, near First-avenue. There can be no doubt that this was a deliberate and cold-blooded attempt to assassinate Mr. Hammond, and that Mr. Green, the sufferer from the plot, was not the victim intended.

abstract: NEW-HAVEN, Thursday, Feb. 2, 1860. At 11 o'clock to-day Prof. JOHNSON continued  his subject commenced yesterday. The points on
lead_paragraph: NEW-HAVEN, Thursday, Feb. 2, 1860. At 11 o'clock to-day Prof. JOHNSON continued his subject commenced yesterday. The points on which he discoursed this morning are "The Proximate Organic Principles of the Plant -- Cellulose. Starch, Dextrine, Sugar, Gluten, Albumen, Casein, Vegetable Oils and Acids." Water composes a large share of the vegetable kingdom, amounting sometimes, as in the case of turnips, to ninety per cent. Water is not chemically combined with the plant, but is mechanically held there. It can be driven off by heat, leaving the chemical constituents of the plant by themselves. These remains are subdivided into organic elements, or those which are the result of organized life, and inorganic or mineral. The former are also divided into carbo-hydrates, albumenoids, oils and acids. Some of these names are high-sounding, but they are necessary to the proper classification of substances. The carbo-hydrates, comprising the first four named, and a few others, are composed of carbon, hydrogen and oxygen. Cellulose, starch, inulin and dextrine, are precisely alike in their chemical constitution, though widely different in appearance and function. Cellulose -- known also as woody fibre -- is the staple of all plants; it is, speaking generally, the wood of the plant. It can be extracted, as in the case of paper, this article being almost pure cellulose; is insoluble in water, but is soluble to a certain degree in the stomachs of the herbivorous animals. Man could make but little use of the woody fibre of hay, though the ox manages to extract some nutriment therefrom. Starch exists in the cells of all plants, and is obtained by breaking these cells and washing. It is, though insoluble in nature, readily digested by the fluids of the stomach. Its presence in any body can readily be told by an application of iodine, this substance turning it to a bluish purple, which no other substance will do. Inulin exists in many vegetables, and is abundant in the Jerusalem artichoke, thereby making this vegetable an excellent article for the farmer. Dextrine is the substance known in the shops as British Gum. Mucilage and gum also belong to the organic elements; the former being seen in the jelly of seeds, and the latter often seen exuding from the tree. It seems to be a sort of excrement, or something which the plant has no further use for. There are three kinds of sugars: the cane, being the products of the cane, the maple, the beet and other plants, and distinguished from the other two by crystalizing; the fruit and the grape sugars are slightly different in their composition from the cane, and are not found in a solid state.

abstract: There is a bill before the Legislature, introduced by Mr. ROBERTSON, which proposes to make some important changes in the Metropolitan Police system as it now exists.
lead_paragraph: There is a bill before the Legislature, introduced by Mr. ROBERTSON, which proposes to make some important changes in the Metropolitan Police system as it now exists. The principal changes are the exemption of Westchester, Richmond and Queens Counties from all taxation for the support of the Police force in this City; the reduction of the Commission to three members, and the exclusion of the Mayors of New-York and Brooklyn from the Board. This bill lodges the appointment of the Commissioners in the hands of the Governor and Senate, fixes their term of office at six years, and raises the Superintendent's salary to $5,000.

abstract: To-day, between the hours of 9 and 12, has been appointed as the time for the execution of JAMES STEPHENS, the murderer of his wife. The peculiar
lead_paragraph: circumstances attending this murder -- the condemned man not having been charged with the crime until nearly a year had-elapsed from the time of the death of his victim -- the exhumation of her body, and a chemical analysis of the remains which resulted in, finding a quantity of-arsenic, have invested the case throughout with extraordinary and singular interest.

abstract: The sales of Cotton in the Liverpool market, for the week, added up 76,000 bales -- of which 5,000 bales were to speculators, and 10,500 to exporters. All qualities had slightly declined, and holders were pressing their stocks on the market. The decline ranged from 1-8d.@3-16d. The sales on Friday were 8,000 bales -- of which 2,000 were on speculation and for export, the market closing quiet at the following authorized quotations: Orleans fair, 7 1/2d.; Orleans middling, 6 3/4d.; Mobile fair, 7 1/8d.; Mobile middling, 6 5/8d.; Uplands fair, 6 7/8d.; Uplands middling, 6 3/8d. The stock was 576,000 bales -- of which 418,500 were American.

abstract: About 11 1/2 o'clock, yesterday morning, a gentleman who was passing the corner of Hudson and Grove streets discovered that the roof of Ward School No. 3 was on fire. He then entered the school-house and quietly asked to see the principal, Mr. DAVIN PATTERSON, to whom he stated the circumstance. Mr. PATTERSON informed the other teachers of the fact, and as it was near a recess it was determined to dismiss the children by sections, commencing with the Boys' Department on the third floor. Accordingly the scholars, of whom there were 1,100 in the building, were all dismissed without confusion, and the moment the last section had reached the street the alarm was given, and the firemen extinguished the flames. A large hole was burned in the roof, and the damage amounts to about $300. The fire is supposed to have been caused by a defect in the chimney. The school-house is an old-fashioned structure, three stories in height, with narrow and badly constructed staircases, and but for the presence of mind of the teachers no doubt a terrible catastrophe would have taken place. This school-house has been on fire three times within two years.

abstract: In yesterday's TIMES there appeared an extract from the San Antonio (Texas) Ledger, which, under the head of "Remarkable Developments," states that a large portion of the stock stolen from Texas is purchased by traders...
lead_paragraph: In yesterday's TIMES there appeared an extract from the San Antonio (Texas) Ledger, which, under the head of "Remarkable Developments," states that a large portion of the stock stolen from Texas is purchased by traders from New-Mexico, who penetrate nearly to the frontier settlements of Texas to supply these Indians with everything they need, in exchange for stock brought from these forays against the Texas borders. This trade is carried on openly and extensively. Instead of its being frowned down and the traders punished, it is fostered and encouraged. The Ledger concludes its exposition of what it considers remarkable facts, with the remark, "that so long as they find a ready market for the spoils obtained in this manner, and can procure the necessary supplies to carry on offensive operations in exchange, there is small hope of a change for the better."

abstract: Between seven and eight o'clock, last evening, a fire broke out in the basement of a double six-story tenement house, No. 142 Elm-street. The fire originated in a bakery, and the flames shot up the stairway with great rapidity, and extended to the upper floors, which were occupied by twenty-four families.
lead_paragraph: Between seven and eight o'clock, last evening, a fire broke out in the basement of a double six-story tenement house, No. 142 Elm-street. The fire originated in a bakery, and the flames shot up the stairway with great rapidity, and extended to the upper floors, which were occupied by twenty-four families. The moment the alarm was given the scene of confusion that ensued was of the most exciting character. The stairway was burned away, and of course all chance of escape in that direction was cut off. Men women and children could be seen, by the spectators on the sidewalk, clustered at the windows, screaming for assistance, and wringing their hands in the agony of their despair. Some of them mustered courage enough to jump from the windows, and escaped with slight injuries. The fire-bells quickly gave the alarm for the Fifth District, and the firemen repaired to the spot. Ladders were immediately elevated to the windows, but the longest of them could not reach above the fourth floor. The firemen rescued some of the occupants, but were obliged to abandon all hope of saving the poor creatures in the two upper stories, and it is supposed that they all perished. As the firemen stood on the ladders, they could see many women and children lying prostrated on the floor, surrounded by the flames, which rendered all attempts to approach them ineffectual. The burning building extended four stories above any of the surrounding structures, and it must have been instant death for any of the poor creatures on the upper floors to have jumped from the roof, where a great many of them had clustered.
headline: {'main': 'CALAMITOUS FIRE.; Tenement House on Elm-street Destroyed. abstract: The election of Speaker seems to give all parties a certain sort of satisfaction. Even those who might have been expected to find in the cup a flavor of bitterness profess to see in it something wherewith to sweeten the draught. The Republicans, of course, having
lead_paragraph: The election of Speaker seems to give all parties a certain sort of satisfaction. Even those who might have been expected to find in the cup a flavor of bitterness profess to see in it something wherewith to sweeten the draught. The Republicans, of course, having won the nominal victory and its immediate fruits, in the shape of offices and profit, can well afford to be contented, though it has been a sore trial to their pride to take down the flag under which some of their loudest leaders had declared that they would march to victory or death. The Democrats congratulate themselves that they have defeated the election of Mr. SHERMAN, though the recollection is dashed with a mild regret that, in order to accomplish this end, they had to cast their entire vote for a man outside of their own party organization. The Americans plume themselves upon having held the balance of power, and boast that the decisive vote which turned the scales in favor of the present incumbent of the Chair was cast by one of their own number. The Anti-Lecompton Democrats lay the flattering unction to their souls that they have administered a tremendous rebuke to the present Administration, and indulge the hope that, though the first prize in the lottery of Congressional organization has not fallen to them, they will assuredly draw the second. And the country, whose feelings and interests have been least consulted in the strife, rejoices, most of all, that the House, after six weeks' tedious manufacture of political capital and a great deal of superflous talk, has at length been organized by the election of a worthy and conservative Speaker, and daringly hopes that the business of the nation will now be attended to, and sectional agitation give place to practical legislation. All parties have had something to do with the result, either by their votes or their influence, by their suffering or their strength. So close has been the contest, that every man who voted for Mr. PENNINGTON may have his sense of individual importance increased by the reflection that his single vote, as Mr. BRIGGS declared of his own in the House, elected the Speaker, and everyone who voted against Mr. PENNINGTON may be relieved by appropriating to himself almost as decisive an influence in the defeat of Mr. SHERMAN.

abstract: M.J. O'Donnell vs. William E. Curtis and Thomas Boese--This is the application in the Supreme Court on behalf of one of the teachers in the Public Schools for a mandamus against the Board of Education, to cumpel payment of the teachers' salary.
lead_paragraph: M.J. O'Donnell vs. William E. Curtis and Thomas Boese--This is the application in the Supreme Court on behalf of one of the teachers in the Public Schools for a mandamus against the Board of Education, to cumpel payment of the teachers' salary. The proceeding is instituted as a test suit to determine the right of the Board to insist upon the reading of the Bible in all the schools. The Board, it is understood, have determined to abide by the decision of the Supreme Court in this case, whatever it might be.

abstract: In the Supreme Court, at Albany, before Judge GOULD,the case of The People of the State of NewYork vs. The Mayor, Aldermen, and Commonalty of
lead_paragraph: In the Supreme Court, at Albany, before Judge GOULD,the case of The People of the State of NewYork vs. The Mayor, Aldermen, and Commonalty of the City of New-York came on last Tuesday for a hearing, upon an application for a perpetual injunction restraining the Common Council of New-York from granting to the New-York and Yonkers Railroad Company the right to lay and operate a railroad in Broadway and other streets of the City. A temporary injunction was obtained on behalf of the State, on the application of R.F. ANDREWS, Esq., on the 27th day of December last, and was served on the Common Council on the 30th day of the same month, just as they were about to pass (over Mayor TIEMANN's veto) the grant to this Company. The injunction was, also, on the 2d day of January last, served on Mayor WOOD and the newly elected Common Council for 1860. abstract: Early on Friday morning, Patrick Madden alias Mead, and Abraham McDonald, both young men, were detected by Officer Anderson, of the Seventh Precinct, as they were breaking into the office of Marshall B. Shaw, a lumber dealer at No. 92 Market-street, for the purpose of stealing $400 which the desk contained. Madden was arrested and locked up in the Station-house. His confederate escaped at the time, but was subsequently taken into custody at the Station-house, as he was filing the bars of the window of Madden's cell with the object of liberating him. Justice STEERS detained the friends on charges of burglary.

abstract: Hon. C. J. FAULKNER, of Virginia, who has been, appointed Minister to France to succeed Mr. MASON, has been staying several days at the New-York Hotel in this City, and leaves for the scene of his labors in the steamer Fulton to-day. Whatever may be his ...
lead_paragraph: Hon. C. J. FAULKNER, of Virginia, who has been, appointed Minister to France to succeed Mr. MASON, has been staying several days at the New-York Hotel in this City, and leaves for the scene of his labors in the steamer Fulton to-day. Whatever may be his knowledge of the French language, or his capacity as an untried diplomat, his Democracy has not been questioned. Therefore the Young Men's Democratic Union Club paid him a congratulatory visit last evening. There were present Mr. H.P. CARR, Mr. JOHN H. HARNETT. Mr. JOHN E. WHITE, Mr. BENSON, and about twenty other gentlemen of the Club, to our reporter unknown. About 10 o'clock Mr. FAULKNER, who had been dining with Mr. SOHELL, was waited upon by the delegation, whom he welcomed individually with great cordiality.

abstract: The twenty-four hours which were introduced by the disastrous explosion of a boiler in Williamsburgh, proved frightfully prolific of calamities. The fire in Elm-street, with its holocaust of unwarned victims, followed; and other fires-fortunately, so far as this City is concerned, unattended with loss of life--resulted in a deplorable loss of property.
lead_paragraph: The twenty-four hours which were introduced by the disastrous explosion of a boiler in Williamsburgh, proved frightfully prolific of calamities. The fire in Elm-street, with its holocaust of unwarned victims, followed; and other fires-fortunately, so far as this City is concerned, unattended with loss of life--resulted in a deplorable loss of property. A fire, however, which in the interval occurred in Luzerne County, Pennsylvania, was less sparing: the house of Mr. EARLY, at Hyde Park, taking fire in the absence of that gentleman, and three children perishing in the flames. Mrs. EARLY, with three other children, leaped from a second story window and saved themselves, not without serious injury. The fatal period ended, as it began, with a revolt of that dangerous servant of industry, steam. Between 7 and 8 o'clock, yesterday morning, a boiler in the hat factory of Messrs. AMES & MOLTEN, on Sandford-street, near Myrtle-avenue, Brooklyn, exploded, throwing down the walls of the building and burying twenty of the operatives beneath them. Seven men were instantly killed; another was fatally injured and subsequently died; and fifteen others are seriously wounded. The police and firemen speedily extricated the killed and wounded from the ruins. Most of the latter were taken to the Hospital.

abstract: The "Almighty Dollar" has turned engineer, ignoring physical laws, professional formulae and the practice of all time, and is astonishing the world with his brilliant achievements. Nor do they want the scenic complements of flames and crashes, blood and thunder.
lead_paragraph: The "Almighty Dollar" has turned engineer, ignoring physical laws, professional formulae and the practice of all time, and is astonishing the world with his brilliant achievements. Nor do they want the scenic complements of flames and crashes, blood and thunder. Here a railway train tears through the bottom of his bridge, and a score of people are crushed with flying timbers; there his thin walls and eccentric pillars hurl down a lofty mill like an avalanche, jamming men and women into jelly by the hundred, and tearing them limb from limb. Here he flings a locomotive into a standing train, bursting it into splinters and crushing its passengers into shapeless corpses; there he hurries a car over a precipice into the river. In the bottom of the sea are his monuments, careened and moss-grown, full of rotten splendor and dead men's bones; his dismasted hulks batten on every shore, and the bones of his victims are mingled with the soil of every land. But yesterday he roasted a house full of beings in his combustible cage, and hurled a factory full of men, scorched, peeled and bleeding, amid bricks and timbers, into the air, with his exploding boiler.

abstract: Yesterday, at the opening of this Court, John Gilbert, the clerk of Frank Fowler, convicted of swindling Christian Heine of $35, by selling him a worthless passage ticket on the Bremen and NewYork line of steamships, pleaded guilty to complicity ...
lead_paragraph: Yesterday, at the opening of this Court, John Gilbert, the clerk of Frank Fowler, convicted of swindling Christian Heine of $35, by selling him a worthless passage ticket on the Bremen and NewYork line of steamships, pleaded guilty to complicity in that offence, and was sentenced by Judge INGRAHAM to the City Prison for three months. Fowler, it will be recollected, was sentenced on Thursday to two years and three months in the State Prison.

abstract: -- A meeting of the Common Council of Rochester was held on Tuesday night, to determine whether the city should make overtures for having the next State Fair at that place. Mr. MOORE read a letter from the President of the State Agricultural Society, stating that $1,200 must be raised to defray incidental expenses, wherever the fair should be held. Other expenses, Mr. MOORE thought, would reach $5,000 or $6,000, and bonds must be given for compliance with the conditions laid down. The hotel keepers and livery stable proprietors did not seem to enter into the project very enthusiastically, so, after a protracted discussion, the Council adjourned without reaching any decision.
lead_paragraph: -- A meeting of the Common Council of Rochester was held on Tuesday night, to determine whether the city should make overtures for having the next State Fair at that place. abstract: Almost every day brings something to light which tends to demonstrate that the sympathies of the French Emperor are altogether with Italy. The latest and most decisive evidence of this is his recent proposition to the British Government for securing the rights of ...
lead_paragraph: Almost every day brings something to light which tends to demonstrate that the sympathies of the French Emperor are altogether with Italy. The latest and most decisive evidence of this is his recent proposition to the British Government for securing the rights of the Italian people and obviating the necessity of a Congress. One of the objects of Lord COWLEY's visit to London, according to the intelligence just received by the America, was to sound the feelings of that Government, on the part of NAPOLEON, touching the advisability of the French and English Cabinets addressing a collective note to the various European Powers, in which it should be declared that any infraction of the principle of non-intervention would be regarded by said Cabinets as a casus belli. Now here was an excellent opportunity for England and her Government to get rid of that Congress to which they look forward with so much apprehension, it being evident that no such assembly would be needed to deliberate on Italian affairs if the Western Powers should agree to cut the gordian knot by thus boldly assuming the championship and protectorate of Italy and her people. If, then, the British Government are in reality so alarmed lest England should be caught in the meshes of that dreaded Congress, why did they not assent to the bold and wise proposition made to them by LOUIS NAPOLEON through their own representative? Why did they not at once agree to become parties to such a note? Why hesitate? why decline to accept for their country the glorious office of protectress of liberty? Could they not appreciate the merits of the policy proposed? Could they not perceive that by its adoption the Italian question would be instantly set at rest?

lead_paragraph: THE FIRST BALL OF THE SEVENTY-NINTH REGIMENT, HIGHLAND GUARD.--On Thursday night the members of the Seventy-ninth Regiment, Highland Guard, Col. THOS. W. MCLEAY, gave their first ball, at the City Assembly Rooms. As the Regiment was not organized until June 20, 1859, the officers did not anticipate a very numerous attendance. They were therefore, most agreeably surprised when before the hour for commencing the dance had arrived, they were informed that the two rooms used as dressing-rooms for the ladies were packed with furs, shawls, bonnets, &c., so that another room had to be obtained for the accommodation of many, who, as they could not get in, were standing in the hall-way. Soon after 10 o'clock there were nearly 2,000 persons present, and the ball was opened. At 11 o'clock the Regiment formed in the ball-room. The companies are as follows:

abstract: FELLOW-CITIZENS: The American Revolution is justly considered not merely as the most memorable event in our own history, but as one of the most important events in the history of the world. The birth of a new member into the great family of Nations, with political institutions more favorable, as we believe, ...
lead_paragraph: FELLOW-CITIZENS: The American Revolution is justly considered not merely as the most memorable event in our own history, but as one of the most important events in the history of the world. The birth of a new member into the great family of Nations, with political institutions more favorable, as we believe, to the rights and happiness of the masses of mankind than had ever been established in any large and powerful State, must certainly be regarded as a most momentous occurrence. It is nothing less than the transmutation of Colonies, receiving the law from a Monarchical Power beyond the Atlantic, into self-governing States, united into an Independent Republican Confederacy. An event like this, which, at the moment of is occurrence, arrested the attention of the civilized world, has gained immeasurably in importance, by the experience of more than eighty years of prosperity, on the part of the States thus ushered into existence.

abstract: Before Mr. BUCHANAN perfects his noble scheme of two Pacific Railroads, he would do well to consider some feasible plan far building one. Senator GWIN'S bill proposes to involve the Government to the extent of thirtyfour millions, and forty thousand square miles ...
lead_paragraph: Before Mr. BUCHANAN perfects his noble scheme of two Pacific Railroads, he would do well to consider some feasible plan far building one. Senator GWIN'S bill proposes to involve the Government to the extent of thirtyfour millions, and forty thousand square miles of land, and to allow twelve years for the completion of the road. So far as now appears, this sum may be swelled to sixty millions by interest; three millions per year will have to be paid in transportation, or the debt will continue to increase indefinitely. Contractors and speculators may get paid, but the Government's chances of getting their money back through the transportation of troops, mails, etc., are more dubious, and the land will be alienated.

abstract: The disastrous fire and loss of life which occurred at No. 42 Elm-street, on Thursday evening, was the theme of painful remark in the City yesterday, and the Vicinity of the terrible catastrophe was visited by curious crowds during the day to view the ruins, which required the presence of a strong force of the ...
lead_paragraph: The disastrous fire and loss of life which occurred at No. 42 Elm-street, on Thursday evening, was the theme of painful remark in the City yesterday, and the Vicinity of the terrible catastrophe was visited by curious crowds during the day to view the ruins, which required the presence of a strong force of the Police to control. Cords were stretched across the street, to prevent interference with the work of removing the ruins. The search for the bodies supposed to have been buried beneath them commenced at an early hour, under the superintendence of the Police. Mr. CARPENTER employed twenty live laborers to assist. About 5 o'clock the body of a woman and child, charred almost beyond the power of recognition, was discovered in the front part of the building, near the door of the bakery. The intense heat which prevailed it was thought, would so completely destroy the bodies that it would be impossible to discover them. Few of the unfortunate tenants who escaped were able to return to view the wreck of their former home; most of them either being injured in their efforts to escape from the building, or were scattered in different parts of the City, endeavoring to provide, as best they might, for their families. Nothing whatever was saved by the sufferers, except the scanty clothing they had on when the alarm was given. Many of the children were in bed, and were carried thence into the street. The severity of the season greatly aggravates the disaster of these poor people, who must be dependent upon the kindness of neighbors or friends for temporary shelter. The actual loss of life, we are happy to state, has been exaggerated, if the accounts thus far obtained are reliable, and probably does not exceed nine or ten. A list of the tenants, furnished by Mrs. SCHAUSS, the wife of the agent, shows that there were:

abstract: -- Mr. PHILLIP H. SEARS, Chairman of the Committee for examination of the students in Harvard College, in intellectual and moral Philosophy, has submitted a report to the Board of Overseers. The Committee thinks that the students have made the study of these branches too much an exercise of the memory rather than of the understanding, and recommends that more time should be given to them in the College course. STEWART's Active and Moral Powers of Man, and REID's Intellectual Powers, should be studied in the first and second terms of Sophomore year; HAMILTON's Lectures on Metaphysics through first term of the Junior year; KANT's Metaphysics of Ethics in the first term of the Senior year; and BUTLER's Analogy and PALEY's Evidences in the second term of the Senior year.

abstract: At 7:40 o'clock yesterday morning those who inhabit near the junction of Myrile and Nostrand ave  nues, Brooklyn, were started by the loud sound of an explosion, which shook the buildings in the vicinity from chimney to foundation stone. People rushed out of doors and hastened to ascertain the cause.
lead_paragraph: At 7:40 o'clock yesterday morning those who inhabit near the junction of Myrile and Nostrand ave nues, Brooklyn, were started by the loud sound of an explosion, which shook the buildings in the vicinity from chimney to foundation stone. People rushed out of doors and hastened to ascertain the cause. The large hat factory recently erected between Myrtle, Park and Nostrand avenues and Sanford-street was in ruins, and beneath the rubbish were buried -- some alive and some dead -- a score of the employes of the establishment. The factory, which belonged to Messrs. AMES & MOLTEN, manufacturers of hats, No. 35 Broadway, New-York, was opened about two weeks ago, and about two hundred persons, of whom sixty were females, were employed there. Messrs. WOODRUFF & BEACH, of Hartford, Conn., furnished the engine and boilers which kept the machinery in the building in motion. Mr. ABEL EASTMAN, an experienced engineer, had been sent by the manufacturers from Hartford to superintend the erection of the engine and boilers, and to take charge of them until they were fairly in working order. It was the explosion of one of these boilers which tore the building to pieces, cost the engineer and at least four others their lives, and injured seriously a great many others.

abstract: FUNERAL OF LIEUT. ROGERS.--The funeral of the late THOMAS J. ROGERS, of the New-York Volunteers, who died on Friday last, took place yesterday, at noon. The part taken by the deceased in the Mexican campaign, and his recent connection with the Fire Department, caused him to be known and respected by a large circle of friends, who turned out ...
lead_paragraph: FUNERAL OF LIEUT. ROGERS. -- The funeral of the late THOMAS J. ROGERS, of the New-York Volunteers, who died on Friday last, took place yesterday, at noon. The part taken by the deceased in the Mexican campaign, and his recent connection with the Fire Department, caused him to be known and respected by a large circle of friends, who turned out in great numbers to pay their last respects to his remains. The religious ceremonies took place at his late residence, No. 36 North-Moore-street. At 1 o'clock, the procession, headed by the Scott Life Guard, and by the New-York Volunteers, in citizens' dress, formed in the Park, and proceeded up Broadway to the junction of Grand-street. Columbian Engine Company, No. 14, and many members of the Fire Department were also in the procession. The remains were buried at Cavalry Cemetery. The flags on the City Hall were set at half-mast. On Saturday evening there was a meeting of the friends and comrades of the deceased at the Hone House, over which Col. JAMES C. BURNHAM presided, and Maj. A. FARNSWORTH acted -- as Secretary. A series of resolutions were adopted, expressive of the high regard in which the deceased was held, and of regret at the loss sustained by his death.
