abstract: The correspondence between Cardinal ANTONELLI and Mr. STOCKTON, our Minister at Rome, touching the outrage upon the family of Mr. PERKINS, at Perugia, which we published last week, furnishes a curious illustration of the style of diplomacy adopted just now by the Papal ...
lead_paragraph: The correspondence between Cardinal ANTONELLI and Mr. STOCKTON, our Minister at Rome, touching the outrage upon the family of Mr. PERKINS, at Perugia, which we published last week, furnishes a curious illustration of the style of diplomacy adopted just now by the Papal Court. Our readers may remember that when all Italy rose in arms against the Austrians in 1848, and called on PIUS IX., as the leader in Italian reform, to join in the movement, he refused, on the express ground that he was priest as well as prince; that the Austrians were therefore his children as well as the Italians, and that, consequently, he could not assail them with carnal weapons. On this same ground he expressly proclaimed his neutrality at the outbreak of the war last Summer. Soon after the Austrians evacuated Ancona, the Papal legate followed their example, and the Romagna was left in the hands of her own people. She made common cause with the Allies, set up a popular government, and the flower of the young men poured into Sardinia, and swelled the ranks of the volunteer levies. All this time the Pope and ANTONELLI were praying and protesting. Their souls were filled with grief at what was going on; the shock of arms disturbed their devout meditations, but their duty was clear. They were men of peace -- their kingdom was not of this world, and they could only offer up their supplications for the restoration of harmony and tranquillity amongst the nations of the earth. All belligerents were earnestly requested to keep themselves and their sinful weapons at as great a distance as possible from the sacred vicinity of the Vatican.

abstract: The rulers of France, who for a thousand years have claimed to represent the imperial line of CHARLEMAGNE, in virtue of that claim have styled themselves "the eldest sons of the Church." NAPOLEON III. is evidentiy determined ...
lead_paragraph: The rulers of France, who for a thousand years have claimed to represent the imperial line of CHARLEMAGNE, in virtue of that claim have styled themselves "the eldest sons of the Church." NAPOLEON III. is evidentiy determined to make this honor his own by a stronger than a merely traditional title. He is manifesting towards the Church, in the person of her Head, a practical filial piety of the most exalted character. At great trouble to himself, and in the face of a storm of such poignant obloquy as only priests and women have the gift of raining upon those who differ from them in opinion, the French Emperor perseveres in keeping up for Pro NONO a temporal throne which His Holiness, if left to himself, would tumble headlong into the Tiber within a week, and in saving the Catholic world from the scandal, and mankind from the misfortune, of a new war of religious passions, kindled in the odious attempt to prove that the "right divine to govern wrong" is an inherent prerogative of him who professes himself the Vicar of Christ.

abstract: Mr. MATHEW, Secretary of the British Legation in Mexico, has forwarded a report on the state of that country to the Foreign Office in London, which appears in a parliamentary blue-book issued a day or two before the departure of the City of Baltimore.
lead_paragraph: Mr. MATHEW, Secretary of the British Legation in Mexico, has forwarded a report on the state of that country to the Foreign Office in London, which appears in a parliamentary blue-book issued a day or two before the departure of the City of Baltimore. Mr. MATHEW commences by regretting that the deplorable state of anarchy and disorganization in which the country is plunged prevents him from carrying out, in the way he desired, the instructions received from the Foreign Secretary. The Government in the capital are without any returns of trade from the ports, which are held by their opponents, and he has reason to believe that, owing to the total interruption of communication, the letters addressed by him to Her Brittanic Majesty's consular functionaries on the coast for information, had, in many instances, failed to reach them. In referring to the probability of the population having remained stationary since the census of 1857, Mr. MATHEW expresses the opinion that the number of foreign residents has diminished one-third, and adds: "It cannot be doubted that extensive immigration, both from Europe and the United States, would take place under a stable and liberal government; but the insecurity of life and property, and, above all, the want of religious toleration, have hitherto caused the failure of every scheme to promote it."

abstract: A series of European arrivals, of which that of the Asia at this port was the last, places us in possession of foreign advices to Jan. 23. The news is more than ordinarily interesting. The Emperor NAPOLEON has announced by a letter addressed to M. FOULD his desire to substitute a system of approximate Free-Trade ...
lead_paragraph: A series of European arrivals, of which that of the Asia at this port was the last, places us in possession of foreign advices to Jan. 23. The news is more than ordinarily interesting. The Emperor NAPOLEON has announced by a letter addressed to M. FOULD his desire to substitute a system of approximate Free-Trade for the narrow protective principle which has heretofore governed French commercial intercourse; and intimates his design to inaugurate the new economical era as early as may be consistent with agricultural development. At the same time, the fact of a commercial treaty of reciprocity between France and England having been negotiated is affirmed; so that the relations of the two countries, it is understood, will be relieved at once of excessive restrictions. The change has been productive of general satisfaction both in France and England. By these arrivals we are also furnished with a remarkable letter addressed by the French Emperor to the Pope. In it he deplores the state of affairs in Central Italy, ascribing it by no indirect implication to the unwillingness of his Holiness to adopt reforms demanded by the condition of the people, and pointing out the only alternative which the actual position of affairs seems to present. It consists in the abandonment of the Romagna, upon condition, to be guaranteed by the Great Powers, of undisturbed property in the remaining States. With what reception this decisive measure met, we are not informed. From Sardinia we have word that the Ratazzi ministry has resigned, and that Count CAVOUR has been summoned to form a new cabinet. It is uncertain whether he will prove successful; but the presumption is that with the aid of the King, and the now openly-acknowledged sympathy of NAPOLEON III., he will be able to surround and sustain himself with the proper political forces. Rumors of new and confidential arrangements between Austria and Russia are rife, but lack confirmation and probability. In England, all parties were preparing for the opening of Parliament, and for the discussion of the Ministerial Reform bill immediately after the opening. The several meetings of the shareholders of the Great Eastern resulted in a vote adverse to the Board of Directors; and the appointment of a Committee of Inquiry. Renewed offers from Mr. LEVER had been rejected. The additional news from India and China is of slight interest.

abstract: -- The little sparring match between Messrs. BOWEN and BAILEY, at the last meeting of the Police Board, with reference to the "bargain" between Mr. WOOD and the Commissioners, reveals the fact that, if there be not a bargain, there is at least an arrangement by which we presume the Mayor agrees, on his part, to furnish his good will and keep tolerably quiet if the Commissioners will, on their part, permit him once more to surround himself with a chosen body of his retainers, and make any other disposition of the force that his fertile fancy may suggest. We presume he will gradually establish diplomatic relations of the same sort with all the other boards and bodies in the City, and the community will be duly sacrificed as usual in order to make him refrain from doing mischief. We have only to compliment Mr. BOWEN and his colleagues upon their skill in compromise. We could wish, however, that they could find some other means of making their peace with Mr. WOOD than the sacrifice of the discipline of the Police. We are satisfied he is not half so implacable a divinity as they take him for, and that a much less valuable offering would have propitiated him. The Police Commissioners, like one or two other public bodies we could name, seem to have the profoundest contempt for the policy of doing right. They seem to think it almost an indication of insanity to suggest doing their duty, and letting professional politicians do their worst. Any dodge, or arrangement, or bargain, or compromise, seems better in their eyes than the honest discharge of a plain obligation. What if they try this new plan for once, and administer their offices with a view to the catching of thieves, and nothing else?
lead_paragraph: -- The little sparring match between Messrs. abstract: The advocates of "Woman's Rights" have rallied HENRY WARD BEECHER to their standard, and made last week another fervid appeal for justice to the sex. Mrs. LUCY STONE went through the long list of female wrongs with her usual ardor and ability, but confined herself ...
lead_paragraph: The advocates of "Woman's Rights" have rallied HENRY WARD BEECHER to their standard, and made last week another fervid appeal for justice to the sex. Mrs. LUCY STONE went through the long list of female wrongs with her usual ardor and ability, but confined herself in the main to the consideration of the legal impediments to woman's full enjoyment of her property. It was left to Mr. BEECHER to say whatever there is to be said in vindication of woman's right to vote, and the subject certainly did not suffer in his hands. About women's right to the full possession and enjoyment of their property, there is now so little question amongst those who have given the subject any consideration whatever, and the obstacles which prevent it, in this State at least, are now so few in number, that we may promise Mrs. STONE, as far as this portion of her case is concerned, an early and an easy victory. But when we are asked to give the elective franchise to every adult female, as a right, we are under the painful necessity of commencing the discussion by denying that anybody, either man or woman, has any abstract right whatever to vote at elections. Who shall have a vote, and in what manner he shall exercise it, are questions, not of right, but of expediency, which society has to decide, not so as to please everybody, but so as to secure its own happiness and safety. When this object is best accomplised by excluding anybody from the exercise of the suffrage, it excludes them without compunction or remorse. Manhood suffrage is established by law in this State, not because every man is believed to have a right to vote, but because every man's voting, or being allowed to vote, is considered the best means of securing tranquillity, order and good government. This is the only theory upon which the exclusion of negroes, resident aliens, and persons under twenty-one years of age, is for a moment justifiable. We deny them the suffrage, simply because we think, whether rightly or wrongly, that the rest of the community will be benefited by their privation. Moreover, no one contests the right of the majority of the people of the State to meet in convention to-morrow, and amend the Constitution by affixing a condition to the exercise of the franchise, either in the shape of a property or an education qualification, that would cut off a fourth of those who now vote. All this goes to show that women have no more abstract right to take part in elections than any other class of the community. Sex is a distinction of which the Constitution may take notice with quite as much justice as age, or color, or place of birth. The point on which the advocates of woman's rights have to satisfy us is, whether the State of New-York would be made happier, richer, or more prosperous or tranquil, by the addition of two or three hundred thousand females, as females now are, to the list of voters.

abstract: On Saturday night, about 11 o'clock, a sad accident occured at the Volksgarten, No. 45 Bowery. Mrs. JOSEPHINE HENSKEL, a favorite danseuse, whose professional denomination was Mile. JOSEPHINE LOUISETTE, was announced to terminate the night's amusements ...
lead_paragraph: On Saturday night, about 11 o'clock, a sad accident occured at the Volksgarten, No. 45 Bowery. Mrs. JOSEPHINE HENSKEL, a favorite danseuse, whose professional denomination was Mile. JOSEPHINE LOUISETTE, was announced to terminate the night's amusements by a rope ascension from the stage to the gallery. She was a pupil of Mons. DE LAVE, the noted rope-walker, and first made this ascension on Thursday last, at the Volksgarten, on the occasion of that gentleman's benefit. On Saturday night, having again successfully accomplished the feat, she was in the act of stepping from the cross-tree, to which the end of the rope was attached, to the stage, when the gauze dress which she wore came in contact with one of the foot-lights and was immediately in a blaze. The excitement among the audience was intense. The husband of the unfortunate woman, who was a musician in the orchestra, leapt upon the stage, followed by other musicians, and, aided by employes of the theatre, who rushed from the rear of the scenes, endeavored to extinguish the flames. In her fright, the sufferer rushed wildly about, funning them into fiercer action by the draft, and in this way every vestige of clothing was destroyed. She was promptly removed to her residence, No. 85 Forsyth-street, and attended by doctors, but her injuries were of such a serious nature that she lingered only till 9 o'clock yesterday morning, when she died. The unfortunate woman was but recently married. She was born in Livingston County, New-York, in 1837, and took to the stage, as a profession, on the death of her father, that she might not only support herself, but furnish assistance to her mother, and educate her brother and sister. She has had engagements, as a ballet dancer, at Laura Keene's and Niblo's Garden. Her mother had always objected to her performing on the rope, fearing that some evil would be the result. This apprehension, which had often been expressed, was recalled to the mind of the sufferer upon the occurrence of this fatal casualty, for almost the last words she uttered were, "Mother, I would not have gone on the rope, but I wanted to make money for you and the children."

abstract: WASHINGTON, Friday, Feb. 3, 1860.  "Order reigns in Warsaw," and the late beligerents appear perfectly satisfied and happy. The word of peace has breathed over our Congressional waters, and the chaotic party-elements begin to separate and crystallize. It is a blissful consummation, and the gentleman in the Chair will no doubt give due satisfaction.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Friday, Feb. 3, 1860.

abstract: The details of the dreadful loss of the clipper ship Flora Temple, Capt. JOHNSON, master, from Macao for Havana, have come to hand, from which it will be seen that the whole of the unhappy creatures on board, ccolie laborers, numbering 850, perished.
lead_paragraph: The Flora Temple was a first class ship, and having been chartered for the conveyance of coolies, sailed from Macao on the morning of the 8th of last October. Her crew, including officers, were about 50 men, and four days after leaving port they encountered a heavy gale of wind from the south-west, and Capt. JOHNSON declined making more sail, being apprehensive that a current might set the ship to the eastward, in the direction of reefs which were marked upon the chart. The sights obtained at noon were good, and the position of the ship appeared to be so far (36 miles) to the westward of the most westerly reefs in the latitude in which they then were, that the captain, having directed a good look-out to be kept, apprehended no danger from standing on until 8 P.M., at which hour he had given instructions that the vessel should be put about. At 7:20 P.M. he came on deck, from the tea-table, and in answer to inquiry, was informed by the officer of the watch that a good look-out had been kept from the topsail-yard. The officer was sent forward to see, however, and had barely reached the forecastle, when the cry of "Hard up" was heard from the look-out. The helm was immediately put hard up, and the spanker lowered, and no sooner was this done, than "Hard down" was heard from the officer, who by this time had come aft again to the gangway. It was then discovered that the ship was within a short distance of the breakers, which could now be distinctly seen and heard, and which extended in a curved line from about four points on the starboard bow to about three points on the port bow. It seemed impossible a long ship like the Flora Tempte could escape them, and although the yards were braced round, and the ship hove aback, she struck first slightly, and then very soon afterwards several times with a tremendous crash, the breakers running very high alongside. Pieces of her timber and planking floated up on her port side, and after some more very heavy bumps she remained apparently immovable, with a heavy list to port, and the water rapidly increasing till it reached between the decks, where the coolies were. It was found impossible to extricate her.

abstract: -- The Young Men's Christian Association of Troy, through a Committee, recently addressed the different Engine Companies, asking the use of their houses for prayer-meetings, two-or three times a week. The Foreman and President of the "General Wool" Hose Company reply, refusing the request, but on grounds of propriety, and because the ordinances prohibit the assemblage of persons in these houses who do not belong there. They do not think the Firemen of Troy are wanting in principles tending to good order, and if they are, there are churches where prayer may be offered up for them. Then, what would a Fireman do, they ask, in case the alarm-bell should ring while these devotional exercises were in progress. The lawyer might be requested to surrender his office, or the sculptor his studio, as well as the fireman his house.

abstract: The announcement of Lord COWLEY's return to Paris was premature. He did not arrive there till the 17th. On his arrival he had a long audience of the Emperor. A telegram says, the Emperor requested Lord COWLEY to declare to the English Cabinet that although desiring an intimate understanding with England, on the basis of non-intervention, it was to be understood that he always considered himself bound by the engagements of Villafranca and the treaties of Zurich.

abstract: The Overland Mail, which reached Malloy's Station on Saturday, and the news of which was circulated in Washington before made public here, brings San Francisco advices of the 14th. The name of Gov. LATHAM was, it appears, employed by the opponents of the Democratic regency which has hitherto ruled in California, to defeat Gov. WELLER.
lead_paragraph: The Overland Mail, which reached Malloy's Station on Saturday, and the news of which was circulated in Washington before made public here, brings San Francisco advices of the 14th. The name of Gov. LATHAM was, it appears, employed by the opponents of the Democratic regency which has hitherto ruled in California, to defeat Gov. WELLER. The election excited general surprise, and much satisfaction. It was effected on the very day of his inauguration as Governor. Senator LATHAM was to proceed to Washington upon the steamer of Feb. 5. The gubernatorial chair for the ensuing two years will be occupied by Liuet.-Gov. DOWNIE. The attempt of the six Southern Counties to separate themselves from the North had been discouraged by the Governor, who deemed the authority of Congress requisite. Serious Indian outrages were reported from Mendocino County. The steamer Northerner was wrecked on the 6th ult. near Cape Mendocino. Eighteen passengers and as many more of the crew were lost. The Northerner belonged to the Pacific Mail Steamship Company, and was the favorite steamer employed on the route to Portland, in Oregon. She was built in this City in 1847, and was thoroughly repaired about two years ago. There was an insurance for $75,000 upon her.

abstract: The steamer Northerner, whose loss on the Pacific Coast, with thirty-five of her passengers and crew, has been reported by the Overland Mail and telegraph, belonged to the Pacific Mail Steamship Company, and is the first total loss of a steamer which has ever overtaken that company. She was built in this City in 1847, by Wm. H. BROWN, for Messrs. SPOFFORD & TILESTON's Charleston line, in which she was employed as a mate to the Southerner, until 1850. She was then purchased by Mr. HOWARD, and sent to the Pacific, in command of Capt. WATERMAN. In 1851 she was sold to the Pacific Mail Company, and was, for some time, used between San Francisco and Panama. Afterwards she was placed on the route between San Francisco and Oregon, carrying the mails and passengers, and has always been the favorite steamer running to the Columbia River. Upon discoveries of gold at Frazer River, she was employed in that trade. Capt. DALL, her commander, was one of the oldest and most experienced officers in the service of the Company. The vessel was about 1,000 tons register, and was considered a sound and sea-worthy ship in every respect. She was insured for $75,000, her full value. The Atlantic, due at this port about the 10th inst., with California dates of the 20th of January, will bring full particulars of the sad disaster.
lead_paragraph: The steamer Northerner, whose loss on the Pacific Coast, with thirty-five of her passengers and crew, has been reported by the Overland Mail and telegraph, belonged to the Pacific Mail Steamship Company, and is the first total loss of a steamer which has ever overtaken that company. abstract: Cardinal Antonelli passed the evening or Dec. 31 at the palace of the French General commanding in Rome, to see the old year out and the new year in. The principal entertainment provided by the worthy General for his distinguished guests, comprising several members of the Sacred College and the French and Austrian Ambassadors, was the performance of a celebrated conjuror, who is now going the professional round of the principal salons in Rome. The Cardinal Secretary of State occupied the centre place of honor in the first row of seats, exactly opposite the Professor of Magic, and condescended to furnish rings, pocket handkerchiefs, &c., for the various tricks.

abstract: An inquest was held yesterday by Coroner JACKMAN upon the bodies of nine of the victims of the recent catastrophe in Elm-street. The proceedings took place in the Coroners' private room, No. 4 Centre-street, and a large number of interested parties were present.
lead_paragraph: An inquest was held yesterday by Coroner JACKMAN upon the bodies of nine of the victims of the recent catastrophe in Elm-street. The proceedings took place in the Coroners' private room, No. 4 Centre-street, and a large number of interested parties were present. After hearing evidence as to the circumstances of the fire, the efforts of the inmates to escape, and the construction of the building, a verdict censuring the proprietor was rendered. Attached to it was a recommendation to the Legislature, asking the enactment of a statute prescribing means of escape for the occupants of similar structures in case of fire. No other bodies were found yesterday. One of those recovered on Sunday, and taken to the Fourteenth Precinct Station-house, was yesterday identified by means of a gold chain around the neck as the remains of Mrs. CASPAR STORCH, who, with her three children, perished. Her remains, as well as those of four other persons, three of whom were doubtless her children, were all taken in charge by Mr. STORCH for interment.

abstract: ANOTHER UNION FERRY COMPANY. -- The Roosevelt-street and Peck-slip Ferries were yesterday united. The Board of Directors will consist of seven -- four from the former company and three from the latter. The capital stock is $835,000. It is understood that the rate of fare for foot-passengers will be two cents.

abstract: The Governor of South Carolina has done himself credit by an act equally politic and humane, which deserves to be chronicled with commendation, whether it proceeded from the head or from the heart, or from a judiciously combined action of both these organs.
lead_paragraph: The Governor of South Carolina has done himself credit by an act equally politic and humane, which deserves to be chronicled with commendation, whether it proceeded from the head or from the heart, or from a judiciously combined action of both these organs. He has pardoned a white man, MICHAEL PORTER, of the steamer Marion, running between this port and Charleston, who had been tried and sentenced to death for aiding, slaves to escape on board of the vessel to which he was attached.

abstract: FIVE PERSONS BURNED TO DEATH. -- We learn from the Delhi (N.Y.) Gazette that on Friday night, Feb. 3, the house of Mr. LUTHER BRIGGS, of Davenport, in that County, was consumed by fire, and five of his children perished in the flames. Mr. and Mrs. BRIGGS went to spend the evening at a neighbor's, about half a mile off taking with them an infant child, leaving six at home -- the oldest a daughter, 17, and the youngest 3 years. The children went to bed before the parents returned, and the fire is supposed to have originated from the stove. The oldest and youngest slept below, and the others up stairs. The girl waking up, finding the house on fire, ran up stairs to wake her brothers -- the oldest of which, a lad of 15, jumped out of the window, and the girl, it is supposed, attempted to go downstairs for the child in her bed. The boy opened the door from the outside, when the flames burst in his face and burnt him severely, but it is thought not fatally. The agony of the parents when they first discovered the fire can hardly be imagined, not described. It is said Mrs. BRIGGS is quite deranged.
lead_paragraph: FIVE PERSONS BURNED TO DEATH. -- We learn from the Delhi (N.Y.) Gazette that on Friday night, Feb. 3, the house of Mr. LUTHER BRIGGS, of Davenport, in that County, was consumed by fire, and five of his children perished in the flames. Mr. and Mrs. BRIGGS went to spend the evening at a neighbor's, about half a mile off taking with them an infant child, leaving six at home -- the oldest a daughter, 17, and the youngest 3 years. The children went to bed before the parents returned, and the fire is supposed to have originated from the stove. The oldest and youngest slept below, and the others up stairs. The girl waking up, finding the house on fire, ran up stairs to wake her brothers -- the oldest of which, a lad of 15, jumped out of the window, and the girl, it is supposed, attempted to go downstairs for the child in her bed. The boy opened the door from the outside, when the flames burst in his face and burnt him severely, but it is thought not fatally. The agony of the parents when they first discovered the fire can hardly be imagined, not described. It is said Mrs. BRIGGS is quite deranged.

abstract: On Sunday evening one John McElroy, who claims to be a private watchman, was detected by Officer Fitzsimmons, of the Twentieth Ward, as he sought to conceal himself in a shutter-box at the corner of Sixth-avenue and Twenty-third-street. McElroy appeared to be much intoxicated, so he was told that he had better go home, and the officer left him. Scarcely had Fitzsimmons proceeded a dozen steps, however, when McElroy drew a revolver and discharged one barrel at him, fortunately without hitting the intended victim. The report attracted the attention of Officer Sharkey, who came up and assisted in securing McElroy. Yesterday the prisoner was held by Justice QUACKENBUSH on a charge of felonious assault.

abstract: THE BEECHES, Saturday, Jan. 28, 1860. I said, in my last letter, that we were about to  fold a Union meeting which would be worth all others, and we have held it, and such a meeting, you may live long and never see. It was no artificial affair, but one of those events Providence sends us to foreshadow and secure the future.

abstract: Coroners' juries are not commonly held in high repute, and, as is usually the case with all men and all bodies of men, their reputation has been mainly of their own making. In nine cases out of ten in which their services are demanded, they oscillate between a verdict of "nobody to blame," which is only comparable to the kitchen-maid's cat that breaks all the
lead_paragraph: Coroners' juries are not commonly held in high repute, and, as is usually the case with all men and all bodies of men, their reputation has been mainly of their own making. In nine cases out of ten in which their services are demanded, they oscillate between a verdict of "nobody to blame," which is only comparable to the kitchen-maid's cat that breaks all the china, and a verdict of Providential interference, modeled upon that complacement philosophy which charges Heaven with the Borgia and the Cataline. The jury impanneled in the case of the fearful calamity which shocked this City on Thursday evening last, have courageously departed from the traditions of their order. The burning to death of half a score of human beings at 8 o'clock on a bright moonlight evening in the very heart of this great City, and in the face of the assembled fire-companies of the surrounding district, certainly is no commonplace event, even in this age and land of social recklessness. To assume that such a disaster could happen and nobody be accountable for it, would be simply absurd, and yet we venture to say that many of our readers will be astonished to find that this absurd thing has not been assumed by the jury of inquest.

abstract: VERA CRUZ, Tuesday, Jan. 24, 1860. The latest accounts from the City of Mexico  state that MIRAMON was still there. lead_paragraph: VERA CRUZ, Tuesday, Jan. 24, 1860.

abstract: A few days since we discussed, in general terms, the question presented by the bill now before the Legislature of this State for reimposing the Canal tolls upon our Railways. We put forward as one great element of this question the competition which exists outside the State, and over which we have no control for the business of all our channels of commerce, both railroads and canals.
lead_paragraph: A few days since we discussed, in general terms, the question presented by the bill now before the Legislature of this State for reimposing the Canal tolls upon our Railways. We put forward as one great element of this question the competition which exists outside the State, and over which we have no control for the business of all our channels of commerce, both railroads and canals. We will! now set forth more in detail the nature and extent of this competition, which leaves us no other alternative, if we would retain our relative commercial position, but to extend every encouragement to all our works, and relieve them of every burden not absolutely necessary to their efficient and economical action.

abstract: The confidence in the innocence of STEPHENS which has been expressed by Messrs. KNAPP and SKINNER, his spiritual advisers in his last moments, appears from their statement to have no other or better foundation than his own assertion at the foot of the gallows. The value of such testimony, unluckily, is seriously diminished by the notorious fact that but a
lead_paragraph: The confidence in the innocence of STEPHENS which has been expressed by Messrs. KNAPP and SKINNER, his spiritual advisers in his last moments, appears from their statement to have no other or better foundation than his own assertion at the foot of the gallows. The value of such testimony, unluckily, is seriously diminished by the notorious fact that but a small percentage of criminals executed for murder have ever avowed their guilt through convicted on evidence of the clearest kind. Moreover some of the most unquestionable criminals of history have been amongst the most remarkable for religious fervor, as soon as all hope was gone. In what manner they arrange matters between their consciences and their protestations, we must leave to a higher than human judgment to determine. The mental operations by which a murderer justifies himself in his own eyes, are, no doubt, somewhat complicated, and not easily to be explained or understood by the rest of mankind. One motive is generally supposed, and probably with reason, to influence them powerfully, and that is, affection for surviving relatives. If a flat denial of his guilt can relieve a murderer's kinsmen from any portion of their heavy burden of disgrace and grief, it is not surprising that even a murderer should seek to open for them this last and feeble source of comfort. what effect STEPHENS' interest in his little daughter may have had in producing his somewhat ostentatious declaration in the jail yard, it is impossible for any man to say. That it had a great deal to do with it, and that he relied, as people of his stamp are apt to rely, upon the effect of rapid repentance at the supreme moment to atone for whatever guilt this final falsehood might involve, the criminal records of all countries furnish us with ample grounds for presuming.

abstract: At the monthly meeting of the Historical Society, last evening, the Committee appointed to secure for the Society the Abbot Collection of Egyptian Antiquities, reported that from the collections thus far made, it seemed almost certain that these valuable relics would eventually become the property of the Society. In order to further this object, the Committee proposed that three lectures be delivered in the
lead_paragraph: At the monthly meeting of the Historical Society, last evening, the Committee appointed to secure for the Society the Abbot Collection of Egyptian Antiquities, reported that from the collections thus far made, it seemed almost certain that these valuable relics would eventually become the property of the Society. In order to further this object, the Committee proposed that three lectures be delivered in the Library of the Society, the proceeds of which shall go towards the purchase of the antiquities. The report also stated that Mr. R.K. HAIGHT had presented to the Society his valuable collection of Egyptian drawings, comprising about 150 volumes, and valued at about $5,000.

abstract: The House of Representatives was not in session yesterday. In the Senate, Mr. WILSON introduced a resolution calling for a Select Committee, to inquire into existing abuses of Executive patronage. The Post-office Deficiency bill was taken up, and amendments proposed by the Finance Committee considered. The first, which provided for blanks, wrapping-paper and twine, was adopted without
lead_paragraph: The House of Representatives was not in session yesterday. In the Senate, Mr. WILSON introduced a resolution calling for a Select Committee, to inquire into existing abuses of Executive patronage. The Post-office Deficiency bill was taken up, and amendments proposed by the Finance Committee considered. The first, which provided for blanks, wrapping-paper and twine, was adopted without debate. The second, excluding the last quarter from the payment of interest, declaring the interest to be in lieu of all claims for damages, and withholding it from any but the contractors themselves, provoked some discussion, but was finally adopted. The third provided for the abolition of the franking privilege, to take effect in May, with the reservation, that members of Congress shall not be required to prepay postage on letters addressed to their constituents. Messrs. COLLAMER and HAMLIN were opposed to the introduction of so important a measure, as an appendage of this hurried bill. Mr. TRUMBULL was for the amendment; but to make it more thorough, moved to strike out the non-prepayment clause. The motion, after debate, was rejected, and the further consideration of the bill postponed until to-day. The Senate went into Executive session, and early in the afternoon adjourned.

abstract: -- The Auditor-General of Massachusetts has completed his annual report. The ordinary expenses of the year were $999[???]358, against $1,014[???]548 in 1858, and $1,236,204 in 1857. The unproductive property belonging to the State -- consisting of the State House and grounds the lunatic hospitals and other public institutions, &c., estimated at the actual cost from their commencement -- is invoiced at upwards of five millions of dollars. The productive property -- consisting principally of the bonds and mortgages of sundry railroad corporation, railroad stocks, Back Bay lands, Western Railroad stock [???]king [???]an almshouse and other funds, &c -- is stated in the schedule at $3,645,742, which is about its Present market value. This is exclusive of the funds whose income is specifically appropriated, and which now amounts to nearly two millions of dollars.

abstract: The Message of Gov. HOUSTON to the Legislature of Texas, transmitting the secession resolutions of the State of South Carolina rises quite above the common level of Gubernatorial effusions. Terse and vigorous in style, comprehensive a in argument, patriotic and national in tone, it thoroughly dissects all the pretexts offered for disunion, and shows that
lead_paragraph: The Message of Gov. HOUSTON to the Legislature of Texas, transmitting the secession resolutions of the State of South Carolina rises quite above the common level of Gubernatorial effusions. Terse and vigorous in style, comprehensive a in argument, patriotic and national in tone, it thoroughly dissects all the pretexts offered for disunion, and shows that while the very suggestion is virtual treason against the Constitution, its accomplishment would only aggravate the evils of which it is proposed as the . JoFw Brow's raid upon Ferry. so far from affording the veters,n Texan ,just cause for the dissolution of the Confederacy, has, in his opinion, " furnished abundant proofs of the utility of our present system of Government, in the fact that the Federal powers have given an evidence of their for the constitutional rights of the States, and have stood ready to defend them. "He asks, with great pertinency, if the Southern States, should yield to the suggestions of South Carolina and establish a Southern Confederacy, what guaranty could this State give for its duration. "From whence are to come the elements of a more perfect Union than the one formed by the men of the Revolution? Where are the patriotism, the equality, the republicanism to form a better Constitution?" Governor HOUSTON also argues that if the Union is dissolved, the border States will suffer the most terrible consequences of dissolution, while South Carolina, "with the sea upon one side, and a cordon of Slave States between her and danger," would have comparatively little cause of apprehension from the assaults of Abolitionism; and that, therefore, the States which are really most aggrieved while in the Union, and which are destined to act as buffers after disunion, between the Abolitionists and the Palmetto Kingdom, should be allowed first to propose so desperate a remedy for existing evils. After quoting from WASHINGTON, JEFFERSON, MADISON, JACKSON, and other distinguished men of the Republic, in deprecation of any attempt, for any cause, to destroy the unity of the Government, and in denial of the right of peaceable secession, the soldier-statesman concludes with recommending "the adoption of resolutions dissenting from the assertion of the abstract right of secession, and refusing to send deputies for any present existing cause, and urging upon the people of all the States, North and South, the necessity of cultivating brotherly feeling, of observing justice and attending to their own affairs."

abstract: Wm. Cole was apprehended on Monday evening by officer Jenniss, of the Twenty-first Ward, on suspicion of having broken into the stable of Mr. F. Nugent, in Thirty-second-street, near Third-avenue, on Sunday night, and stolen a set of silver-mounted harnese, valued at $25. The lad was searched, and a large number of skeleton keys were found in his
lead_paragraph: Wm. Cole was apprehended on Monday evening by officer Jenniss, of the Twenty-first Ward, on suspicion of having broken into the stable of Mr. F. Nugent, in Thirty-second-street, near Third-avenue, on Sunday night, and stolen a set of silver-mounted harnese, valued at $25. The lad was searched, and a large number of skeleton keys were found in his pockets. Subsequently the same officer arrested Owens Soden, another small boy, on the supposition that he too was implicated in the same burglary, and from him also a lot of false keys were taken, one of which fitted the lock of the stable. Soden then admitted that Cole and himself were guilty, and said that the harness had been sold to Thomas Cogan, the keeper of a junk-shop, fifty cents, and that he had agreed to pay them just as liberally for any goods they might sell to him. Cogan was sent for, and finally confessed to having purchased the harness, which was found in a cellar where he had concealed it. All the prisoners were taken before Justice QUACKENBUSH. The boys were held for burglary, and Mr. Cogan, being unable to furnish $1,000 bail, was committed for trial as a receiver of stolen goods.

abstract: Shortly after 12 o'clock on Monday night a fire broke out in a frame building, situated on the corner of Fifty-fourth-street and Ninth-avenue, owned by a Mr. WEST, and occupied as a hat factory by JOHN DIENHART. The building and contents were totally destroyed. The building was worth about $400; not insured. Mr. DIENHART's loss is about $1,500; insured for $900 in the Standard Insurance Co. The cause of the fire has not been discovered.

abstract: If the agitation of the Slavery question has accomplished nothing else, it has at least had the effect of relieving the Southern States from a very uncomfortable weight of veneration. It has led Southern politicians to overhaul the claims of a vast number of defunct celebrities upon the respect of mankind, and to dispose of them summarily by consigning them to the
lead_paragraph: If the agitation of the Slavery question has accomplished nothing else, it has at least had the effect of relieving the Southern States from a very uncomfortable weight of veneration. It has led Southern politicians to overhaul the claims of a vast number of defunct celebrities upon the respect of mankind, and to dispose of them summarily by consigning them to the contempt of all bar-rooms south of Mason and Dixon,s line. WASHINGTON, MADISON, JEFFERSON, RUTLEDGE, GEORGE MASON, and various other revolutionary fathers, have been already convicted -- not certainly of bad intentions, but of most egregious blunders with regard to the comparative merits of free and slave labor, and have received condign chastisement in being visited with the pity of Mr. KEITT, of South Carolina, and Messrs. ROGER A. PRYOR and O. JENNINGS WISE, of Virginia. Even Mr. CLARK, of Missouri, we believe, looks back on these misguided men with compassion. Having thus disposed of our native celebrities, the attention of the South and its loudest-voiced friends was next turned to the foreign enemies of the institution, and COKE, MANSFIELD, BLACKSTONE and BROUGHAM having been discovered to be in the number of these obscurantists, the poor creatures were at once handed over to the tender mercies of CHARLES O'CONOR, Esq., of the New-York Bar. This gentleman made short work of them. He found COKE to be a hypocritical rascal; MANSFIELD to be a silly, conceited, voluble old fellow; BLACKSTONE a stupid prig and dunderhead, and BROUGHAM nothing more than a mouthing Scotch rhetorician. Not one of them, indeed, appears to have been worth the thunder which Mr. O'CONOR has thrown away upon them.

abstract: DEATH OF A RETURNED CALIFORNIAN. -- Coroner HULEWOOD, of Richmond County, held an Inquest at Quarantine on Monday, on the body of JAMES R. MURRAY, a passenger per Northern Light, from Aspinwall, who had returned from California for his wife and family. The jury found that congestion of the brain was the cause of Mr. MURRAY's death.

abstract: Whenever one in an elevated position of command or control stoops to the performance of details which can properly be done alone through the agency of subordinates, it shows either that the system which he pretends to control is in a very bad condition, needing regeneration, or that the person himself so intermeddling is incapable of the duties of his position; for no one in military authority can become en
lead_paragraph: Whenever one in an elevated position of command or control stoops to the performance of details which can properly be done alone through the agency of subordinates, it shows either that the system which he pretends to control is in a very bad condition, needing regeneration, or that the person himself so intermeddling is incapable of the duties of his position; for no one in military authority can become entangled with small details, and at the same time preserve that the freedom of thought and action which is necessary to a liberal and just control of a large command. The proper time for attending to details is when one is still in a subordinate position. It is then that must be acquired that knowledge which enables one when advanced to a higher position to see at a glance if details are rightly performed, and know whom to hold accountable if they are not. The commanding officer of an army must indeed see that details are carefully performed, but he cannot perform them himself and at the same time attend to his own duties as a General.

lead_paragraph: At the appointed hour or thereabouts, Dr. C.W. GRANT, the famous cultivator of the Delaware grape, at Iona, N.Y., commenced his lecture on grape cul ture. He began by saying that we had no absolute knowledge of the vine as it came from the hands of the Creator, but we may suppose it to have been like circumstanced with man himself, and like him susceptible of vast improvement. There is no subject of the vegetable kingdom so dear to man as the vine -- none so tractable in his hands, and none by its product so fitted to bear the spirit upweard in gratitude and love to the Father.

abstract: Dr. PERCY has enjoyed the use of our columns for the purpose of correcting the injustice which he alleges was done to him in our review of the New-York Academy's last report on Swillmilk. The only aim of that review was to show that it was essentially wanting in originality, the quality deemed most praiseworthy in all such matters; that it had servilely followed its prede
lead_paragraph: Dr. PERCY has enjoyed the use of our columns for the purpose of correcting the injustice which he alleges was done to him in our review of the New-York Academy's last report on Swillmilk. The only aim of that review was to show that it was essentially wanting in originality, the quality deemed most praiseworthy in all such matters; that it had servilely followed its predecessors, without having added to or subtracted from -- except as it corroborated -- statements made. Now, the result of the family consultation held upon this review has not enabled the astute vindicator of this report to mention any "fact or evidence" not stated in the report of 1847, or even inferential proofs of the unwholesomeness of Swill-milk, except such as have been obtained by the policemen furnished by the Mayor's orders.

abstract: ITEMS.--The Commencement Exercises of the Brooklyn Normal School will take placs in the Washington-street Methodist Episcopal Church, this evening....RICHARD A. WILLIAMS, late foreman of Hose Company No. 2, W.D., has been presented with a gold watch by the members of that Company,
lead_paragraph: ITEMS. -- The Commencement Exercises of the Brooklyn Normal School will take placs in the Washington-street Methodist Episcopal Church, this evening....RICHARD A. WILLIAMS, late foreman of Hose Company No. 2, W.D., has been presented with a gold watch by the members of that Company, as a token of their regard....A skating club was organized in south Brooklyn Monday night, by the election of the following officers: Wm. FREFFEN BURGH, President; D.M. TREADWELL, Vice-president; D. CROCKER, Secretary....The St. Vincent de Paul (R.C.) Association have applied for Per mission to instruct the children of Roman Catholic parents in the Truant Home. The matter is in the hands of the Truant Law Committee....The City Railroad Company, in response to the action of the Common Council, say that as to the matter of reducing fares, they do not acknowledge the authority of the Board to direct them in the matter, but they nevertheless will try the experiment of four cent fares, but will take the liberty of charging five cents again whenever the Company deem it for their interest to do so. As to the matter of increasing their accommodations they propose to do just as they please, consulting their own convenience and interest rather than that of the people, or obeying the orders of the Aldermen....The patentees of "Dickerson & Sickles' cut-off" have warned the authorities of this city not to use the "cut-off" on the pump engine at East New-York....The Board of Aldermen, at their last meeting, adopted a resolution asking the Legislature to pass a bill, now before that body, authorizing the authorities of this city to raise $1,000,000 on bonds to construct a public market....WILLIAM INGLISS, formerly a well-known resident of this city, has recently been sentenced to the Illinois State Prison for ten years, upon conviction of forgery at Chicago.

abstract: Mr. R.G. PARDEE, of New-York City, gave his first lecture this afternoon on the Strawberry. He came, he said, to speak of facts, not theories. He had tried to grow strawberries for many years by high culture, but without success. He determined to experiment
lead_paragraph: Mr. R.G. PARDEE, of New-York City, gave his first lecture this afternoon on the Strawberry. He came, he said, to speak of facts, not theories. He had tried to grow strawberries for many years by high culture, but without success. He determined to experiment till he should discover the cause of the failure. He had done so, and could now grow them as cheaply as potatoes. The following, according to his experience, is the best method: Select a warm, moist, but exposed situation; for early berries, let it slope to the East or South; for late ones, to the North. The soil should be a fine, gravelly loam. Avoid high, barren soils, and those which are wet. To prepare the soil, make it clean; underdrain, leaving the drain open at both ends to allow the circulation of air. Pulverize at least two feet in depth, making 10 per cent, of the soil as fine as superfine flour. For manures, apply 30 bushels of unleached ashes and 12 bushels of lime slacked with water holding 3 bushels of salt in solution to the acre. Transplanting should be done with great care, and the rootlets of the plant injured as little as possible. The best time to transplant is in the Spring, though with care it may be done any time during the Summer. The lecturer said he would, in starting a new bed, place the plants three feet apart each way, and allow them to spread till they were only twelve inches from each other. Nearer than this they should never grow. The beds should be mulched with tan bark, straw or some such material to the depth of half an inch, no more. This keeps down weeds and keeps all but the strongest runners from taking root. Water may be added with great advantage in large quantities, except during the flowering and ripening periods, provided always it does not stand and become stagnant on the soil. After this preparation little attention is needed. The hoe should never be used about the plants, as it injures the roots. Field culture differs little from garden culture. The productiveness of the strawberry about New-York does not average more than 40 bushels to the acre. There is no difficulty in raising 150 bushels under the cultivation he recommended. In the Winter the plants should be lightly covered.

abstract: My attention was this morning attracted to an article in your paper from the pen of GEORGH WOOD, which, owing to the eminent position among the Bar of the writer, will necessarily command the careful and attentive perusal of those interested in the question therein discussed. Not having seen the previous article referred to, I propose to make a few comments upon the positions claimed to be established by this.
lead_paragraph: My attention was this morning attracted to an article in your paper from the pen of GEORGH WOOD, which, owing to the eminent position among the Bar of the writer, will necessarily command the careful and attentive perusal of those interested in the question therein discussed. Not having seen the previous article referred to, I propose to make a few comments upon the positions claimed to be established by this. From the legal distinction between an act malum in se, and one malum prohibitum, I do not propose to dissent. That a distinction exists somewhere between that offence which intuitively suggests itself as a wrong against the conscience, and that which experience and reason only prove to be productive of evil results, there can be no question; but it does not follow that, when ascertained, the one may not be as strictly a wrong to be suppressed as the other. In fact, the dividing line is not so distinct as might be supposed, nor would the division be, to all minds, alike. To o[???] highly conscientious many wrongs would be organized under the first class, which to one less so would fall into the second. So that it is not true that there is a certain class of offences to be thus distinguished capable of a well-defined, obvious boundary. Gambling has come be almost a universally conceded vice, and to many would be an obvious offence against conscience, while to others it would clearly arrange itself among the offences known only as malum prohibitum. Instances might be multiplied, and I think I am not going too far in classing Slavery as one of those offences clearly occupying that debateable ground. But it matters not under which of these divisions it be placed, if essentially an offence. Whether so ascertained by conscience or reason, and whether it is such offence, is really the question to be discussed; for if an offence, it should be discouraged -- if not, it should be encouraged.

abstract: Two Grand Juries cannot be impanneled in the same county at one time. abstract: COMMISSIONERS. -- Messrs. Charles Howard, William H. Gatehell, Charles D. Hinks and John W. Davis, on Monday, took their oaths to fulfill, faithfully, the duties devolving on them as Commissioners of Police for the city of Baltimore. On Saturday they invited Mayor SWAN to meet and act with them. He thanked them for their invitation to meet them, but said as the City Council had instructed him to contest the constitutionality of the law just passed, and authorized him to employ counsel to protect the city in case her rights were violated, he could do no more than to respectfully decline to meet the Commissioners while this case was a matter of litigation. He further said, that when the case was brought to an issue, and in the event of the Courts deciding that the law was constitutional, he would be found ready and willing to do all in his power, cheerfully, to carry out its provisions. Mr. COLEMAN TELLOTT has declined to act as counsel for the city, and it is said that Messrs. Jonathan Meredith, William Price, William Schley and Thomas S. Alexander are to undertake the case.

abstract: The introduction of cheap Burgundy and claret into Great Britain, under the Emperor NAPOLEON'S free trade programme, will effect, no doubt, as great a change in the drinking habits of Englishmen as was brought about by the commercial treaties with Spain and Portugal fifty years ago. At the beginning of the present century, claret was more generally used at the tables
lead_paragraph: The introduction of cheap Burgundy and claret into Great Britain, under the Emperor NAPOLEON'S free trade programme, will effect, no doubt, as great a change in the drinking habits of Englishmen as was brought about by the commercial treaties with Spain and Portugal fifty years ago. At the beginning of the present century, claret was more generally used at the tables to bre found, and actually warning the Emperor to remember that Guyenne was, of all those who drank any wine at all, particularly in Ireland and Scotland, than any other beverage. The drinking bouts of Scotch and Irish gentlemen about the time of the French Revolution and the Rebellion of '98, were generally carried on in Bordeaux and Burgundy. It was to get merry over claret that convivial Catholic hosts used to lock the dining-room door, and it was after having grown too merry over it that convivial Catholic guests used to sink under the table. It was casks of claret imported too freely and dispensed too lavishly that laid the foundation of the misfortunes which, within ten years, have brought so many an ancestral hall of the fine old Milesian gentry under the hammer of the Encumbered Estates Court. It was over brimming stoups of claret, too, that Scottish Tory "lairds," in the great days of HARRY DUNDAS, used to pledge the Church and the King, and consign the Jacobins and radicals to outer darkness. Every gentleman's cellar contained barrels of the generous vintage of the Garonne, and instead of being daintily sipped, as now, from fragile graceful glasses, it was drunk in flowing tumblers filled, from mighty magnums.

abstract: Early yesterday morning a German, named DAVID SCMMERS, who resided at No. 144 Church-street, where he also kept a shoe-shop, committed suicide by cutting his throat with a shoe-knife. He died at the New-York Hospital in about three hours after he had inflicted the wound. Deceased was about 50 years of age, and it is believed that he was prompted to self-destruction in consequence of having been deserted by his wife a few months since. Coroner O'KEEFE held an inquest.

abstract: The announcement that the Committee on Streets would meet at 2 o'clock P.M., yesterday, to consider the propriety of widening Ann-street, called together a large number of property-owners at the appointed hour. None of the members of the Committee, however were present, and after waiting some time, the Clerk rose and stated that it was not probable that the Committee would hold a meeting on this occasion, as two of the members of it had gone to Albany and the third had left the City Hall in a coach about two hours before. At this announcement there was some grumbling, and in response to inquiries as to when the Committee would meet, the Clerk stated that it would be called together by the Chairman. Mr. GEORGE G. SICKLES, father of Hon. DANIEL E. SICKLES, asked all who were in favor of the proposed alteration of Ann-street to hold up their hands. To this there was no response. Then Mr. SICKLES requested those who were opposed to it to do likewise, and nearly all present signified their opposition to the measure.

abstract: -- We are informed that the Commissioner of Patents, having some time since formally requested that that office might be relieved of the important and increasing duties in relation to agriculture, confided to it by the annual appropriations of Congress for several years past, and which the Commissioner regards as incompatible with the varied and sufficiently onerous and responsible legitimate duties of his position, the Secretary of the Interior yesterday responded by assenting to the request preferred, and directing the affairs of the Agricultural Division of the Patent Office to be arranged for transfer as early as practicable. We are also informed that the Secretary announced to the Commissioner the appointment of Hon. THOS. G. CLEMSON as the future Superintendent of the Agricultural Division, with instructions to report at once to the Commissioner, in order that he may be enabled to familiarize himself with the affairs involved in its opertaions, and receive the records and other effects pertaining thereto. The gentlemen employed in this branch of the service are also required to report to Mr. CLEMSON for duty, and to be directed by him, under the authority of the Commissioner of Patents, until such time as the proposed transfer shall be consummated, when the management will devolve exclusively upon the Superintendent, under the immediate direction of the Secretary of the Interior. In accordance with these arrangements, Mr. CLEMSON yesterday entered upon the preliminary duties of his office, and will. no doubt, be for some time engaged therein, and especially in maturing plans for future operations. -- Constitution, Feb. 7.

abstract: The annual election of officers of the Liquor Dealers' Association was to have taken place yesterday and the polls were open from sunrise to sunset at the Metropolitan Rooms, No. 160 Hester-street. The Association, whose members number about 6,000, was divided into two parties in the support of rival candidates for Treasurer and some of the minor offices:
lead_paragraph: The annual election of officers of the Liquor Dealers' Association was to have taken place yesterday and the polls were open from sunrise to sunset at the Metropolitan Rooms, No. 160 Hester-street. The Association, whose members number about 6,000, was divided into two parties in the support of rival candidates for Treasurer and some of the minor offices: both supported the same candidates for President and for the other offices. The party which favored the reelection of all the officers of the last year was composed mostly of Germans and Americans, and outnumbered their adversaries by a large majority. Most of the opposing party were Irish. The following statement which the latter had caused to be circulated among the voters defines their position: --

abstract: The Mexican Treaty will doubtless be discussed in the Senate on some day of the current week, and the discussion, we anticipate, will take a wider range, and prove more important and interesting than is generally imagined. It is possible that some new and curious features in our national politics may then be presented. A full and free debate on
lead_paragraph: The Mexican Treaty will doubtless be discussed in the Senate on some day of the current week, and the discussion, we anticipate, will take a wider range, and prove more important and interesting than is generally imagined. It is possible that some new and curious features in our national politics may then be presented. A full and free debate on the Mexican question will perhaps show that our Southern statesmen, either from stronger instincts of State-craft or superior knowledge, have for years completely outwitted their Northern cotemporaries. We venture to assert that in the development of the opinions and policy of leading Southern Senators -- such as Mason, HUNTER, TOOMBS and DAVIS, who are following out the line of policy inaugurated by Mr. CALHOUN -- it will be found that the Federal Government has been under the control of men who well understand the resources and capacity of Mexico, the true characteristics of her people, the nature and quality of peon labor, and the absolute impossibility of introducing negro slavery into that Republic. While the filibustering rabble of the South has ever been ready to throw itself upon Mexico, in the belief that the peculiar institution could be planted there, leading Southern statesmen, beginning with CALHOUN, have understood the matter better, and it can be proved by the record that they have steadfastly opposed the acquisition of Mexican territory, with the knowledge that it must inevitably be settled as free territory, and that all their efforts have been devoted to the extension of Slavery in another direction, and through territories already acquired. Mr. CALHOUN, in 1848, declared that Mexico was �forbidden fruit.� Mr. TOOMBS voted against the appropriation for the purchase of California, in the belief that it must come into the Union as a Free State. The South had complete and quiet possession of Mexico in 1848. They had their own man, Mr. POLK, for President, and they held the Federal Government by a large majority. Our Army was withdrawn from Mexico, and the country was abandoned, because leading Southern men who had control knew it would prove �forbidden fruit,� so far as Southern Slavery was concerned. Had Mr. POLK and his advisers believed that the institution of Slavery could have been planted in Mexico, that country, or the greater part at least, would have been retained by is in 1848.

abstract: WASHINGTON, Monday, Feb. 5. Interesting accounts of the war in Morocco  have been received here. It is stated that there were 60,000 Moors at the battle of Castellegos. Col. TASSARA, about thirty years of age, younger brother of  the Spanish Minister at Washington, distinguished himself greatly at the head of his regiment of Hussars, and was wounded in the engagement. Most of the high officers of the Spanish army are young men.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Monday, Feb. 5.

abstract: The Philadelphia North American says: "From present appearances, Capt. MOSES, the "Charity Ship" man, will evade punishment. The only money be is Known to have obtained by his enterprise) was the sum of five dollars, and even that was sent anonymously. Of its receipt there is no legal proof except the admission of the man MOSES. The anonymous note signed "Morocco," in which it was inclosed, is in the hands of the magistrate, but this, we believe, is no legal evidence. The gravest interpretation of the offence is then, a misdemeanor, or an attempt to obtain money by fraud. A clergyman, who visited "MOSES" yesterday at Moyamensing prison, informs us of his belief that the prisoner is crazy. If this be the case, there is a marvelous degree of system in his mania. He was smart enough to perceive that his letters of introduction to the Sons of Malta here, were entirely too noncommittal to suit his purposes, and to forge others that were as strong as he desired. Subsequent revelations show that he practised the very same game in New-York, and with a degree of adroitness that nearly amounted to success. Strange to say, although confronted by abundant testimony that he is an impostor though repudiated by the persons to whom lie referred for indorsement of his character, he still maintains that he intended no fraud, and that he was really about to send a vessel to Gibraltar, laden with stores for the relief of the Jews and Christians, driven from their homes by the Moors.

abstract: As announced yesterday morning, the election, on Tuesday evening, for Chief Engineer of the Fire Department, resulted in the choice of Mr. JOHN DECKER by a large majority over both of his competitors, JOHN C. CHEGIER and Ex-Chief ALFRED CARSON. The importance of this contest to those concerned was evinced by the strong excitement which preceded it; the ...
lead_paragraph: As announced yesterday morning, the election, on Tuesday evening, for Chief Engineer of the Fire Department, resulted in the choice of Mr. JOHN DECKER by a large majority over both of his competitors, JOHN C. CHEGIER and Ex-Chief ALFRED CARSON. The importance of this contest to those concerned was evinced by the strong excitement which preceded it; the sharp electioneering for the favorite men; the charges of "bribery and corruption" made against one of the candidates and his friends, and the exultation of the successful party, which found expression in jubilant huzzas, the firing of cannon and other demonstrations. The voting began at the various Engine houses at 7, and closed at 9 o'clock P.M. The returns wore received up to 12 o'clock, midnight, and the canvassing occupied the succeeding two hours. The hall in Seventh-street, near Third-avenue, was thronged by an eager crowd all the evening, which grew more and more excited until the result was known. A platoon of Police entered the place about 11 o'clock. They packed the room almost to suffocation, but took no effective measures to enforce the request of the Tellers to allow the reporters the use of the desk for taking notes. A six-pounder, placed at the door of the building, was discharged every few minutes, smashing the windows. The crash of glass which followed each explosion, with the shouting and occasional fights inside of the hall, made the place a scene of indescribable confusion and uproar. At 2 o'clock the canvassing closed.

abstract: An observing foreigner or a traveled citizen, in contemplating "the finest street in the world," with its commercial palaces and its showy architectural effects, is strangely perplexed for the moment that his admiration wanes and his enthusiasm chills far short of the theoretically proper standard.
lead_paragraph: An observing foreigner or a traveled citizen, in contemplating "the finest street in the world," with its commercial palaces and its showy architectural effects, is strangely perplexed for the moment that his admiration wanes and his enthusiasm chills far short of the theoretically proper standard. Here, indeed, are lofty walls and elaborate facades, brilliant marble, sober granite, and the mellow richness of many colored free-stones; here are gathered, almost in detail, types of the art of all ages, queerly mixed but wonderfully striking. What is it that veils their beauty, dims our sight and offends our taste? -- what false medium distorts their proportions and makes uncouth chaos of them all with its multiplied refractions?

abstract: Senator HUNTER yesterday reported in the Senate from the Finance Committee an amendment to the Post-office Appropriation bill providing a remedy for that great and growing abuse, the franking privilege. As at present made use of, this privilege of the members of Congress simply amounts to the levy of a collossal tax on the national revenues for the prosecution of personal and partisan objects.
lead_paragraph: Senator HUNTER yesterday reported in the Senate from the Finance Committee an amendment to the Post-office Appropriation bill providing a remedy for that great and growing abuse, the franking privilege. As at present made use of, this privilege of the members of Congress simply amounts to the levy of a collossal tax on the national revenues for the prosecution of personal and partisan objects. Every mail which leaves the Federal City fairly groans with masses of documents dispatched all over the country by members of the National Legislature, at the behest of the leaders of the several parties to which they belong. Half the electioneering of an ordinary Presidential campaign is thus done at the expense of the nation, and that which was at first designed to ease individual members of the burdens imposed on them by their necessary correspondence has degenerated into a sheer piece of partisan machinery. Our postal expenses far outran our postal income, and Mr. HUNTER did his duty as a statesman in endeavoring to relieve us of the most unnecessary and extravagant, which is also not the least considerable, item of this enormous outlay. In doing this, the Senator from Virginia bore well in mind the real objects of the franking system and proposed to substitute for the present arrangement a provision securing transit in the mails of all correspondence sent by members of Congress at tie capital, during the sessions of that body without the formality of prepayment This is all that can be reasonably asked by the members.

abstract: There are two measures at present before the Legislature at Albany--both introduced by the party having the majority there--which, when brought face to face, do not exhibit the family resemblance generally supposed to exist between children of the same parents. One is a Personal Liberty bill, and the other a series of resolutions avowing entire devotion to the Union, and a determination to preserve it.
lead_paragraph: There are two measures at present before the Legislature at Albany--both introduced by the party having the majority there--which, when brought face to face, do not exhibit the family resemblance generally supposed to exist between children of the same parents. One is a Personal Liberty bill, and the other a series of resolutions avowing entire devotion to the Union, and a determination to preserve it. The Personal Liberty bill is the same in substance with that passed by the Assembly last Winter, which was lost in the Senate. Among various other provisions, section 9 declares that "No person, while holding an office of honor or trust and emolument under the laws of this State, shall, in any capacity, issue any warrant or other process or grant any certificate under or by virtue of an act of Congress passed the 12th day of February, 1793, entitled 'An act respecting fugitives from justice and persons escaping from the service of their masters." &c. Section 10 provides that every officer who does issue such warrants shall be deprived of his office, and shall "thereafter be ineligible to any office of trust, honor or emolument under the laws of the State."

abstract: CARRINGTON WILSON, an aged man, died on Tuesday, at his residence, No. 251 Ninth-avenue, in consequence of severe burns received on the evening of the 12th ultimo. Deceased, while bathing his injured hip with alcohol, accidentally brought the flannel that he was using in the operation in contact with the range, and soon his entire clothing was in ablaze.

abstract: The veto of the bill for deepening the channel over the St. Clair flats is another instance of that deliberate disregard of the popular will and that bland indifference to the great interests of the country, for which the present Administration has been preeminently distinguished.
lead_paragraph: The veto of the bill for deepening the channel over the St. Clair flats is another instance of that deliberate disregard of the popular will and that bland indifference to the great interests of the country, for which the present Administration has been preeminently distinguished. But, then, Mr. BUCHANAN has constitutional scruples to signing the bill, and this fact ends the discussion. The President has the right to have his scruples; it is an especial guaranty of the Constitution which provides that if he does not approve a bill presented to him for signature, he shall return it with his objections to the House in which it originated. And not only does he possess this right; its exercise is a great convenience when no other objection can be found to an act of legislation. It is so easy to have scruples when they fall in with the current of one's prejudices and feelings. The Constitution, which at one time is so elastic as to comprehend all sorts of doubtful powers of government, at another time be comes so rigid that it can hardly be made to embrace the vital and essential interests of the country. Mr. BUCHANAN has found it much easier to obey these scruples than to give reasons for their existence which shall even seem to be logical and consistent enough to prove satisfactory to the country -- at least, we judge so from the perusal of the veto message which he has sent in to the Senate. This message throws no new light upon the question, and it will scarcely increase its author's reputation as a statesman. Its only effect, we apprehend, will be, in certain States, to add poignancy to the regret, bitter enough already, that their electoral votes were cast for the present incumbent of the Presidential chair. Mr. BUCHANAN would scarcely have received those votes if the people of these States could have anticipated that he would use the power with which they have entrusted him to thwart their wishes and to strike a blow at their prosperity.

abstract: It is, no doubt, a very gratifying reflection to every inhabitant of the City, that if his house takes fire in the night, some hundreds of men whom he never saw before will rush madly to the rescue, and, for pure love of excitement, drag him out of the window, and extinguish the flames in floods of cold water.
lead_paragraph: It is, no doubt, a very gratifying reflection to every inhabitant of the City, that if his house takes fire in the night, some hundreds of men whom he never saw before will rush madly to the rescue, and, for pure love of excitement, drag him out of the window, and extinguish the flames in floods of cold water. That there should be so many thousands of young men in New-York who do this in all weathers and at all seasons, is also, no doubt, very creditable to New-York human nature. It is, unquestionably, a fine thing to have any service of danger and difficulty rendered to the public without fee or reward. Like trial by jury, the Fire Department is, no doubt, a popular educator. It promotes courage and self-sacrifice amongst young men, and is the greatest enemy to effeminacy to be found amongst our institutions.

abstract: QUEBEC, Wednesday, Feb. 1,1860. The Legislature of Canada passed a Fishery act  about two years since for the regulation, protection and encouragement of the inland as well as the gulf fisheries; and two Superintendents of Fisheries were appointed--one for Upper, one for Lower Canada-- each with a staff of suitable overseers,  The Upper Canadian official has made but little progress in his duties; the Lower Canadian a great deal.
lead_paragraph: QUEBEC, Wednesday, Feb. 1,1860.

abstract: ALBANY, Wednesday, Feb. 8, 1860--8 P.M. The Senate has now been in Executive Session  for seven hours. The contest upon the confirmation of Harbor-Masters and Port-Wardens has been very severe. At 7 o'clock, A. D. BARBER and ROBERY B. MURRAY had been confirmed as Harbor-Masters. The vote on confirming RAN VAN VALKENBRON stood 16 to 16.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY, Wednesday, Feb. 8, 1860--8 P.M.

abstract: The annual election of officers, managers and Committees of the American Institute will be held this afternoon, between 3 o'clock and 7, at the rooms in Cooper Institute.
lead_paragraph: The annual election of officers, managers and Committees of the American Institute will be held this afternoon, between 3 o'clock and 7, at the rooms in Cooper Institute. Much more than the usual interest attaches to this election, in consequence of the many complaints that have been made in relation to the recent management, and a feeling on the part of certain members that some changes are absolutely necessary, in order to rescue the Institute from its present condition, and restore it to its former efficiency and usefulness.
