abstract: Last evening two genteel-looking men were arrested at the corner of Broadway and. Broome street, by Officer Fitzmaurice, of the Second Precinct, on a charge of passing several counterfeit bills. The men were observed at an early hour in the evening going from one store to another making small purchases, in every case getting a bill changed, and it was surmised that they were engaged in passing counterfeit money. Calling on detectives Poole and Wilson to assist him, Officer Fitzmaurice apprehended the men as above stated in a lager bier saloon. On searching them at the Police headquarters, $27 in counterfeit bills of different banks were found in their possession, and. from secret information received by Deputy-Superintendent Carpenter some time since, both the arrested parties are thought to be members of an organized gang, whose head quarters are a few miles up the Hudson River. The prisoners gave the name of Louis Meisler and Carl Miller and were identified as having passed counterfeit bills at the Everett House, and also at several groceries in Broadway.

abstract: The annual meeting of the Board of Trustees of the New-York State Inebriate Asyium was held on Monday, at the office of the institution, No. 97 Clinton-place. The following Trustees were present: Dr. John W. Francis, Wm. E. Dodge, Esq., Charles Butler, Esq., Hon. Edward A. Lambert, Noah Norvall, Esq., Lorenzo Draper, Esq., Dr. Jacob s. Miller, ...
lead_paragraph: The annual meeting of the Board of Trustees of the New-York State Inebriate Asyium was held on Monday, at the office of the institution, No. 97 Clinton-place. The following Trustees were present: Dr. John W. Francis, Wm. E. Dodge, Esq., Charles Butler, Esq., Hon. Edward A. Lambert, Noah Norvall, Esq., Lorenzo Draper, Esq., Dr. Jacob s. Miller, J. Edward Turner, New-York; Edward F. Shonnard, Esq., Yonkers; Hon. Vincent Whitney, Binghamton; and Henry A. Brewster, Esq., Rochester. The President, Reuben H. Walworth, being absent, Wm. E. Dodge was elected Chairman. The following officers were unanimously reelected for the ensuing year: Hon. Reuben H. Walworth, of Saratoga, President; Hon. Wm. T. McCoun, of Long Island, Vice-President; Hon. Josiah B. Williams, of Ithaca, Second Vice-President; J.H. Ransom, Esq., of New-York, Treasurer; J. Edward Turner, New-York, Corresponding Secretary; and T. Jefferson Gardiner, of New-York, Register.

abstract: It does not often happen that the "Barber" attracts so full and fashionable a house as that which assembled last night to witness its performance at the Academy. Although one of the most famous of operas, and comic at that, it seldom contributes to the pecuniary success of the season. The interest which attaches to all the new parts undertaken by an artist so peculiarly gifted as Miss PATTI explains in a great measure this sudden awakening to the merits of ROSSINI's music. Our Rosinas have usually been matronly, both as regards age and bearing; a young and charming representative of the part is so decided a novelty that it is worthy of the best recognition. Miss PATTI acts well -- indeed, the improvemen she shows in this important respect should bring burning blushes to the cheeks of some of the male members of the company, whose angularities increase in the precise ratio of their popularity. The music presents no difficulties to a singer so florid; indeed Miss PATTI increased those difficulties voluntarily by the introduction of frequent high staccato passages. Rosina is decidedly one of the lady's most successful efforts, musically and dramatically. In the singing lesson Miss PATTI introduced an echo song, and the Scotch ballad "Comin' through the Rye;" the latter was vehemently applauded, and narrowly escaped an encore.
lead_paragraph: It does not often happen that the "Barber" attracts so full and fashionable a house as that which assembled last night to witness its performance at the Academy. abstract: The steamships City of Washington and North Briton, from Liverpool on the 25th ult., arrived last night, the former at this port, and the latter at Portland. The news is of interest. Parliament was opened on the 24th ult. by the Queen in person. In the speech, Her Majesty referred to the course of negotiation in regard to the Italian question, stated that no day had been fixed for the meeting of a Congress, but expressed her confidence that, whether with or without the interposition of a Congress, Italy would be left mistress of her own destinies. The commercial treaty with France, the Chinese Expedition, and the Hispano-Moorish War, were all alluded to. In regard to the San Juan difficulty, satisfaction was expressed that a serious collision in circumstances so threatening had been avoided; a result which her Maesty ascribed to the judicious conduct of her naval officers, and to the conciliatory action of the American Government. The usual address was moved in both Houses, and carried without a division. The news from the continent is of secondary interest.
lead_paragraph: The steamships City of Washington and North Briton, from Liverpool on the 25th ult., arrived last night, the former at this port, and the latter at Portland. The news is of interest. abstract: The appointment of a Committee, by the Board of Councilmen, to report as to the expediency of erecting a new iron building on the site of Washington Market, has created much excitement among the shopkeepers of that locaity. The sentiment is by no means unanimous as to the propriety of constructing the new edifice.
lead_paragraph: The appointment of a Committee, by the Board of Councilmen, to report as to the expediency of erecting a new iron building on the site of Washington Market, has created much excitement among the shopkeepers of that locaity. The sentiment is by no means unanimous as to the propriety of constructing the new edifice. The all-important question asked is: Where can the market-men be accommodated while the new market is in progress? Already the neighboring sidewalks, and, for the greater portion of the day, the principal part of the roadway, are occupied by the demands of the vast traffic in the necessaries of life. There is no place in the vicinity capable of affording sufficient room, while to take the trade away altogether would be an almost insufferable inconvenience. So far as giving greater facilities for the transaction of business is concerned, the market-men claim that as many stands as possible are at present accommodated. The only benefit, therefore, it is claimed, will be the improved appearance of the market. Whether that would pay for the loss by delay is, of course, a question for the consideration of the Committee. There can be but little doubt that the market-men would vote down the proposition for a new building, by a large majority.

abstract: TROW'S NEW PRINTING OFFICE.--The new and splendid five-story and basement brick building, with fire-proof front vaults, erected on lots Nos. 40, 48 and 50 Greene-street, between Grand and Broome streets, and one block from Broadway and Canal-street-the best and most central location in this City--has been ...
lead_paragraph: TROW'S NEW PRINTING OFFICE.--The new and splendid five-story and basement brick building, with fire-proof front vaults, erected on lots Nos. 40, 48 and 50 Greene-street, between Grand and Broome streets, and one block from Broadway and Canal-street-the best and most central location in this City--has been leased for a term of years by JOHN F. TROW, Esq., the celebrated book and job printer of Directory celebrity, and for many years established -- one of the oldest houses in this City -- who will remove on or before the 1st of May next his immense establishment from Nos. 377 and 379 Broadway to this superior building, which, has been erected under the direction and superintendence of GRIFFITH THOMAS, Esq., the celebrated architect of this City, and no expense has been spared to make it what it really is, one of the finest and most substantial buildings in this City, with steam power attached. The foundations are of the best blue quarry stone, and not less than 12 inches in thickness. Foundation walls are 24 inches thick, of blue stone, and laid in cement. The principal front is Philadelphia brick, with heavy brown-stone coping, sills, courses, &c., &c. The rear and side walls are of selected North River brick. The rear brick wall is 2 feet 4 inches thick up to second story beams, all other walls are 16 inches in thickness. MARC EDLIZ, the enterprising mason, has given this job his special attention, and one has only to look at this splendid building to become satisfied that all is well done, and of the best material. The immense quantity of timber in this building was ordered from the Calais Mills, and cut expressly for this job. The beams are 4 inches by 12 inches, and 16 inches from centres. The girders are in two lengths, 10x12 inches and only twenty feet apart, resting upon two rows of columns, fourteen on each floor, iron in basement and yellow pine on first, second, third, fourth, and fifth floors. The girders are doweled with heavy iron dowels running through, and resting on iron caps and bases. The front windows are arched and of the French style, six on each story, with nine in rear, making some twenty-one windows on each floor, which has over 5 000 feet, and lighted on all sides. That all is of the very best material, and done in the most workmanlike manner, and strictly within the Fire Laws, it is only necessary to add that JAMES L. MILLER is the master carpenter. The first-story front is iron, with seven massive iron columns, iron lintel course, sills, &c., &c. There are six openings, two leading up stairs, two to the first floor, and the others are two immense windows, filling the entire space. Heavy iron shutters on rear and sides. There are two very heavy iron lintel-courses running across the entire rear, making, with the massive brick walls, one of the strongest and safest buildings in this City. The building and all throughout has been strongly fastened and anchored, and all the iron is of the very best material, and done in the most workmanlike and strongest manner, as the books of MICHAEL GROSZ will bear testimony, as he furnished all in the iron department. A superior steam engine, 18-inch cylinder and 4-foot stroke, with cut off and every improvement, is being made and put up by FALCONER & THOMPSON, who guarantee it shall be every way superior. There will be two boilers, two 16-inch flues in each, 30 by 30, and 48 in diameter, made by SAMUEL SECOR, from the very best material, selected with great care, and warranted a most perfect and safe job. They will be placed in the rear, and entirely distinct from main building, furnace-room, chimney, &c., &c., all being in the rear, and made fire-proof. The building will be healed with steam-pipes running around on the walls; some four thousand feet of pipe is required for same. There will be a steam hoist, and every improvement, as no expense has been spared in its erection, or will be in its completion, making it one of the finest and safest buildings in this City.

abstract: Tne New-Orleans Picayune says of the election of a Republican Speaker:  "Mr. PENNINGTON shares in the opprobrium of having supported and voted for SHERMAN, either as approving his course, or as accepting the lame extenuations with which it has been attempted to lessen the deep guilt of his association with the incendiary schemes of party tactics, of which the Helper book was an accepted part.
lead_paragraph: Tne New-Orleans Picayune says of the election of a Republican Speaker: "Mr. PENNINGTON shares in the opprobrium of having supported and voted for SHERMAN, either as approving his course, or as accepting the lame extenuations with which it has been attempted to lessen the deep guilt of his association with the incendiary schemes of party tactics, of which the Helper book was an accepted part. The force of a concentrated Southern opinion has compelled the Republican members of the House to abandon their candidate, and for the sake of conciliating an outside support from members not of their party, to centre upon a man whose title to election is that he is not personally identified with Mr. SHERMAN in this particular, that his name is not found in the first degree as recommending the Helper call for insurrection, but only in the second degree, as in the ranks of those who support it with explanations and qualifications, who confess that there is something in it to be disavowed, for the sake of peace. The election of PENNINGTON, therefore, as the defeat of SHERMAN, is worth something, as the sign that the Republicans, when most united, may be compelled, in the lace of an outspoken public opinion, to change their tactics, if not their principles, and to give back before the determined will of the South.

abstract: TRAVIS publishes in the Memphis papers a pistol challenge, for $500 or $1,000 a side, to be shot as follows: With pistols, thirty shots a side, at ten paces distance; the target to be shut at a copper cent; my opponent to shoot at deliberate aim, with the aid of one hand only -- string measurement, from centre to centre. I ask that my opponent shall give me five hit cents out of thirty shots; or, in other words, I will shoot twenty-five shots against his thirty. I shall require him to shoot his shots by daylight, I will shoot my shots in any bark night he may select, or in a dark room devoid of light. The match to take place in the City of New-York, in New-Orleans. Memphis or Nashvillo, within thirty days after it is made.

abstract: Mr. PENNIGTON has begun to find the Speaker's mace a bauble dearly bought. He has already provoked a great clamor of hostility at Washington by his appointments to the Standing Committees of the House. The State of Texas, in the persons of her two Representatives, has utterly refused to accept the position
lead_paragraph: Mr. PENNIGTON has begun to find the Speaker's mace a bauble dearly bought. He has already provoked a great clamor of hostility at Washington by his appointments to the Standing Committees of the House. The State of Texas, in the persons of her two Representatives, has utterly refused to accept the position assigned to her -- Mr. REAGAN and Mr. HAMILTON declaring that they "could be of no earthly service to their constituents" -- the one in the Committee on Private Land Claims and the other in the Committee on Revolutionary Pensions. We must admit that there is a certain show of reason in this. Mr. HAMILTON was one of the most prominent candidates for the seat which Mr. PENNINGTON now fills, and might, therefore, fairly have expected some special consideration at the hands of his successful competitor; while it can hardly be supposed that Texas contains any very enormous number of Revolutionary Pensioners. Mr. BOCOCK, of Virginia, too, has been rather too emphatically shelved in the Committee on Naval Affairs, and several other leading men of the Democratic party have fared no better with Mr. PENNINGTON than the Republican leaders usually have both in the Senate and in the House whenever they have been compelled to accept the law from their political conquerors. On the other hand, we can recall no instance in which, under any Democratic organization of either House, the conspicuous men of the opposition have been on the whole so handsomely dealt with as have the antagonists of Mr. PENNINGTON by the new Speaker. Mr. GILMER, of North Carolina has the Chairmanship of the Committee on Elections; Mr. ETHERIDGE, of Tennessee, the Chairmanship of the Committee on Indian Affairs. Mr. SMITH, of North Carolina -- SMITH, not of the egg-nogg, but of the slip "'twixt cup and lip," -- appears in the important Committee on Commerce. Mr. MILLSON of Virginia, and Mr. PHELPS of Missouri, are in the Committee on Ways and Means. In the Committee on Territories, where, if anywhere, an intense partisan spirit might have been expected to triumph absolutely, only one -- decidedly prominent Republican (Mr. GROW) has been named to rule over Mr. SMITH of Virginia, Mr. VALLANDIGHAM of Ohio, and Mr. CLARK of Missouri, the Knight who rode down the Republican standard-bearer, Mr. SHERMAN, in the long conflict just terminated. The Committee on Foreign Affairs is very evenly balanced between the Ins and the Outs: and, on the whole, we do not see that there is any reason for denying to Mr. PENNINGTON the praise of a more than ordinary impartiality in the distribution of legislative honors and duties.

abstract: -The St. Louis Democrat Feb. 7, says: "At about 8 o'clock on Sunday night last, a young man named JOHH SAMUEL ACRES, while under the influence of liquor, went into a bar-room, kept by D. REESE, on the Manchester Road, near Rock Spring. He became very noisy and quarrelsome, and at last gave a severe beating to the proprietor. The female portion of the family succeeded, however, in driving him away. He received at this encounter a blow on the head, and walked some distance off to another bar-room kept by one CHRISTOFELT, who, seeing him bloody, humanely put a bandage around his head. There he remained for some time, until two of his friends called and invited him home. He left with them, and took the Clayton Road. A short time before this a young German butcher named Henry SHOENWALD, in the employ of Mr. JOSEPH KALLIS, had called in at REESE's, and there being informed of the row which had just taken place, said: "Why did you not send for me," brandishing; at the same time a long and sharp knife. He then inquired who was the fellow who had beaten REESE, and where he had gone. He left and called at CHRISTOFELT's a short time before the party above-named had left. He followed them on the Clayton road, and overtaking them said: "Here is the fellow that had the muss at REESE's." Deceased having thus turned to HENRY, a struggle took place. Deceased having thus turned to HENRY, a struggle took place. Deceased fell under his assailant, and a sharp noise was heard by deceased's friends. Deceased then jumped up, ran about a hundred yards in a vacant let, returned to the road, where he fell, and expired in a few minutes, bathed in blood. The murderer has escaped.

abstract: The Roman correspondent of the London Times, writing on the 14th ust., says:  It is supposed, and very rationally, as it seems to me, that French protection will go so far as to secure for the Pope the possession of Rome and of its ...
lead_paragraph: The Roman correspondent of the London Times, writing on the 14th ust., says: It is supposed, and very rationally, as it seems to me, that French protection will go so far as to secure for the Pope the possession of Rome and of its immediate territory -- but will go no further. For the rest the Pope must rely upon his own means, both to guard himself against his own subjects and to ward off the attacks of the emancipated Romagnese. Now the Pope's own means at the present day, I have positively ascertained, do not extend beyond 5,500 men stationed at Pesaro, 1,700 men quartered at Urbine, and the scanty garrison at Ancona, besides the 1,500 men who still do jailer and hangman's work at Perugia. The fine Dragoon regiments which paraded so gallantly the streets of Rome last Carnival are reduced to about 200 horsemen, 90 of whom are at Pesaro; the rest are still lodged in their barracks near the Vatican. By way of compensation the gendarmes are very numerous; handsome men, finely appointed, and, whatever may be said of their moral character, to be relied on both for courage and loyalty. The other native troops are worthless rabble; the Swiss are riotous and mutinous, and between all these and the new Austrian and South German recruits there is very bad blood -- soldiers' quarrels are events of daily occurrence at Pesaro. All these particulars may be safely depended on. Now, supposing that the French Emperor abides by his semi-official pamphlet and official articles; supposing that his intimation goes forth with sufficient clearness that beyond Rome and its Campagna the French troops will not be used as the Pope's soldiers -- that beyond the personal security of the Pontiff he does not choose to be instrumental in staying the national Italian movement -- what chances are there that the Pope may, I will not say recover what he has lost, but even retain what he still holds? Let it be under-stood where the French mean to draw the line beyond which they will not pass, and we may hear of out-breaks at Orvieto, at Viterbo, at Macerata, wherever the scanty forces of the Pope cannot muster is sufficient masses to overawe the multitude, -- even supposing that bands of Tuscans and Romagnese, who have depots of arms at various points on the borders, do not, as soon as they are not forbidden by France, begin to scour the country, directing their attacks against those disheartened and discordant Papal hire-lings, who hardly need an onset to break up and go asunder.

abstract: About three weeks ago an altercation occurred between Jobn Morrissey, the pugilist, and the distinguished William Mulligan, late of California, in which the latter threatened, it is alleged, to shoot his opponent with a revolver. Morrissey subsequently made a charge of felonious assault against Mulligan, who was arrested, and held to bail to appear for trial yesterday, at the Courtof Special Sessions.
lead_paragraph: About three weeks ago an altercation occurred between Jobn Morrissey, the pugilist, and the distinguished William Mulligan, late of California, in which the latter threatened, it is alleged, to shoot his opponent with a revolver. Morrissey subsequently made a charge of felonious assault against Mulligan, who was arrested, and held to bail to appear for trial yesterday, at the Courtof Special Sessions. At the opening of the Court a large number of the friends of the respective parties were present, and Mulligan's name was loudly called for by the Clerk, but it probably did not suit the convenience of the defendant to make his appearance, and the magistrates postponed the trial until Saturday, when it is hoped the distinguished individual will comply with the polite request of the Court to appear before it for trial.

abstract: Two English Catholics of the highest social and personal consideration--Sir JOHN SIMEON and Mr. PETRE--both converts from the Church of England--both men of weight and mark, whose words will find an echo in the hearts of all the most intelligent and upright of their fel
lead_paragraph: Two English Catholics of the highest social and personal consideration--Sir JOHN SIMEON and Mr. PETRE--both converts from the Church of England--both men of weight and mark, whose words will find an echo in the hearts of all the most intelligent and upright of their fellow-believers -- have signalized themselves by protesting openly against the atrocious absurdities advanced in behalf of the Papal rule over the Romagna by the ultramontanist clergy. As a great English landed proprietor, and a member of the British Parliament, Sir JOHN SIMEON, doubtless remembers that the Catholic barons who wrung Magna Charta from their stubborn King, and founded thus the freedom of the Anglo-Norman race, were not the worse sons of the Church for refusing to endure a Papal interference with their civil rights as Englishmen; and he naturally, therefore, shrinks with honorable disgust from the proposition, that, free himself, he should lend his voice to blacken the character and arrest the progress of men who are bent only on securing civil liberty to themselves and to their children.

abstract: -On Friday, Feb. 3, at about 12 P.M., the house of JOHN KERR, at Jeanesville, Penn., was discovered on fire. When the flames were first seen the neighbors assembled and found the door fastened. KERR himself was outside the building, while his wife was inside. After the door was burst open she was discovered lying upon a bed, her arms and legs burnt off, eyes burnt out, but the body uninjured. A handkerchief was tied round her neck in such a way as to induce the belief that she was murdered. KERR has a bad reputation. Both him and his wife are from Ireland.
lead_paragraph: -On Friday, Feb. 3, at about 12 P.M., the house of JOHN KERR, at Jeanesville, Penn., was discovered on fire. abstract: The advocates of Woman's Rights will be glad to learn that the finishing touch is just being given to the reform of the law relating to the properly of married women. The act of 1848 was the first inroad upon the old common law doctrine which vested the ownership of everything that a woman possessed at the time
lead_paragraph: The advocates of Woman's Rights will be glad to learn that the finishing touch is just being given to the reform of the law relating to the properly of married women. The act of 1848 was the first inroad upon the old common law doctrine which vested the ownership of everything that a woman possessed at the time of her marriage, or which she afterwards acquired either by gift or bequest, or purchase or labor, in her husband's hands. Under that rule a woman's only mode of saving whatever she might own at her wedding, from passing at once to her husband and becoming liable for his debts, was by a special deed of settlement; and that is the only means to which women in England, as well as in many States of the Union, can resort at this moment to secure themselves against the pecuniary risks of wedded bliss. In New-York, what a single woman posesses at her marriage now remains her own after her marriage, and whatever she subsequently acquires, by gift or devise, comes under the same category. But by a strange anomaly the act of 1848 did nothing to secure her in the possession of the earnings of her labor, though the women who are obliged to labor are unquestionably those who stand in greatest need of legal protection, and though a woman's acquisitions made in that way are more indisputably and decidedly her own than any others whatever. A drunken, idle or vagabond husband might regularly despoil a most industrious wife of the fruits of her toil -- might seize and retain her weekly wages, and leave herself and their children destitute, and she had no redress. True, if anybody left her a legacy, or made her a present, she might keep it, and bid the conjugal spoiler defiance; but the women who have worthless husbands, and have to work hard for a living, are rarely blest with bilious uncles from India, or old bachelor cousins delighting in Christmas generosity. The reform in the law, therefore, though it certainly was a reform, and a great one, did little for that class of women which the common law doctrine most sorely oppressed. That twelve years should have elapsed between the first move towards the emancipation of women and the bill now before the Legislature, is a singular illustration of the slowness with which a legal change, when it interferes seriously with social prejudices, is always brought about. The abolition of the Court of Chancery was accomplished in far less time than it has taken to secure a poor washerwoman in the enjoyment of the fruits of her own toil, and protection from the most cruel of robberies.

abstract: LECTURE BY WM. CURTIS NOYES, ESQ.--A. Lecture, introductory to a a course on Criminal Jurisprudence in America previous to the Revolution, was delivered last evening to the Students of the Law Department of Columbia College, in No. 37 Lafayetteplace, by WM. CURTIS NOYES. After some prefatory remarks, he observed that, for a thorough comprehension of the subject, it was necessary to acquire a perfect...
lead_paragraph: LECTURE BY WM. CURTIS NOYES, ESQ. -- A. Lecture, introductory to a a course on Criminal Jurisprudence in America previous to the Revolution, was delivered last evening to the Students of the Law Department of Columbia College, in No. 37 Lafayetteplace, by WM. CURTIS NOYES. After some prefatory remarks, he observed that, for a thorough comprehension of the subject, it was necessary to acquire a perfect knowledge of the code of laws of the mother country, because these laws were virtually the laws adopted by the Colonists. In illustration of this he cited the cases of the Trinity and Dutch Churches. He alluded, en passant, to the witch trials in New-England, (of which so much has been written and said,) by way of showing the inconsistency of the administration of the laws at the time when those cases occurred, and gave additional interest to his remarks by the introduction of numerous ludicrous jokes. He narrated the variations in the practice of the several Courts established in this country, while still subject to British rule, and showed how they were influenced by the introduction of Dutch laws, customs, and usages. The origin of the old saying, that "when the rope breaks, the criminal is free," (which is an error still very prevalent among the ignorant,) he accounted for by referring to an old Dutch law which provided, that in the event of the breaking of the rope no attempt should be made at repairing or replacing it until another criminal should be adjudged to undergo the punishment of which the rope is the instrument. He concluded by exhibiting the popular advantages which accrued to this State, when, having been subjected to the English by conquest from the Dutch, it acquired the right to trial by Jury. This course of lectures will be continued at stated intervals throughout the Winter season.

abstract: ALBANY, Thursday, Feb. 9. 1860. The House is considering the Pro Rata bill, in Committee of the Whole, to-day. It was made the special order a week ago, but you might know it was up, even though you did not know the House had so long ago ordered it "on deck. The interested parties are all "to the fore."
lead_paragraph: ALBANY, Thursday, Feb. 9. 1860.

abstract: The London Athenaum says: Nothing final, we hear, has yet been done about separating the collections in the British Museum. The difficulties which obstruct any decision are great, though the ultimate saving of a vast sum of money by removal to Kensington is now apparent.
lead_paragraph: The London Athenaum says: Nothing final, we hear, has yet been done about separating the collections in the British Museum. The difficulties which obstruct any decision are great, though the ultimate saving of a vast sum of money by removal to Kensington is now apparent. By a mistake of the Press last week, we were made to state this saving at £1,100,000, instead of £400,000. The error of figures was obvious from the text, and from all our previous calculations of relative cost.

abstract: In the United States Court this morning the recent death of Judge INGERSOLL, of the Connecticut District, was announced in a few remarks by Judge ROOSEVELT, the United States District-Attorney. He made no extended remarks in relation to his character and attainments, leaving them, as he said, for others, at a more fitting season. He moved that the Court adjourn until Monday next as a token of respect to the deceased, and that the proper entry be made upon the records of the Court, and communicated to the family of the deceased.

abstract: Mr. A.J. De Witt, of Ottavia City, Ohio, had his attention attracted by cries which appeared to come from a long distance out on Lake Erie. Procuring assistance he got a boat and following the direction of sound found on a cake of ice, about a mile form the shore, Capt. Henry Fox. While walking on the ice the portion on which Capt. Fox chanced to be, broke from the main body and carried him out on the Lake.

lead_paragraph: In the Senate, the Post-Office Deficiency bill, after submission to various amendments, embracing that abolishing the franking privilege, was finally passed, and sent to the House. In the latter body the standing committees were announced by the Speaker; and, as is usually the case, created much dissatisfaction. The Texan members were especially indignant at the unimportant places to which they were assigned. They demanded to be excused from serving, and were excused.

abstract: The Legislature of Maryland have paid NewYork the high compliment of enacting a police law for the government of Baltimore similar in its main features to that under which we have been living for the last three years.
lead_paragraph: The Legislature of Maryland have paid NewYork the high compliment of enacting a police law for the government of Baltimore similar in its main features to that under which we have been living for the last three years. The emphatic declaration of the conviction that such an ordinance will be sufficient to check the rowdyism which has given Baltimore a reputation so extended and unfortunate, is the best practical testimony to the efficiency which our Department of Police has attained, despite the partisanship which has at times interfered with its working. And the people of New-York will therefore have more than one reason for watching with interest the progress of the experiment now making in Baltimore.

abstract: EFFICIENT FIREMEN--The management and action of the Brooklyn Fire Department at the Recent fire in Water-street, have elicited the highest praise from all who were present during the conflagration and who are familiar with the locality. It was generally apprehended when the fire was discovered that the entire block would be destroyed, as it was thought the oil in Mr. FLANDER'S establishment would...
lead_paragraph: EFFICIENT FIREMEN--The management and action of the Brooklyn Fire Department at the Recent fire in Water-street, have elicited the highest praise from all who were present during the conflagration and who are familiar with the locality. It was generally apprehended when the fire was discovered that the entire block would be destroyed, as it was thought the oil in Mr. FLANDER'S establishment would spread and carry the names wherever it should go. But, although it was after midnight when the alarm was given, there were five powerful streams of water brought to bear on the building in a very few minutes, and by judicious management and energy the fire was confined to the building in which it originated. While the building was burning, information was conveyed to Franklin Engine Company No. 3, JOSEPH APPLEYARD, foreman, that Mr. FLANDER's books and papers were all inside and in danger. Mr. APPLEYARD and some of his men entered the building immediately, and rescued the books and papers at the risk of their lives.

A number of these interesting hopes of the Virginian Church, banded together as the "Young Men's Christian Associa
lead_paragraph: The early Christians of Virginia are evidently by no means so verdant as some of the esculents which that venerable Commonwealth supplies to the New-York market at the opening of the Spring. A number of these interesting hopes of the Virginian Church, banded together as the "Young Men's Christian Association, of Richmond," have just proved that the children of this world are not always wiser in their generation than the children of light. They have shown themselves more than a match for the Ulysses of the New-York Tribune, Mr. BAYARD TAYLOR, who has traveled in all manner of countries, and observed all manner of men, only to be astonished at this late day by the astute sons of the "Old Dominion."

abstract: At 2 o'clock this afternoon Mr. PARDEE continued his lectures on the small fruits. The raspberry was spoken of first. Few persons, he said, had ever seen a first-rate one.
lead_paragraph: At 2 o'clock this afternoon Mr. PARDEE continued his lectures on the small fruits. The raspberry was spoken of first. Few persons, he said, had ever seen a first-rate one. The gardeners about our cities do not know how to grow it in perfection. This fruit likes a moist, cool situation, such as the north slope of a hill or the north side of a fence. The soil should be made very rich; you cannot overfeed the raspberry. The strawberry has a multitude of fine fibrous roots, and as it grows little woody fibre, it requires little manure; the raspberry, on the contrary, produces considerable wood, and as it has few fibrous roots with which to take up nourishment, these should be well supplied. The soil should be made very fine. Plant about four feet apart, and cut the canes to within one foot of the ground. At the time of planting, stake with strong stakes. Those which will last forever may be made by the French burnettizing process, which is as follows: soak the stakes six or seven days in a solution of blue vitriol and water, in the proportion of one pound of vitriol to twenty pounds of water. Berries raised on canes which have been carefully tied to stakes are much finer than those which have been left to be blown about by the wind. As soon as the raspberries have all ripened, remove the wood on which they grew and allow the sap to flow into the new canes, which will bear another year. Keep the ground clean. In the winter lay the shoots on the ground and cover lightly with earth. Brinckle's Orange Seedling is one of the very best varieties, and is wonderfully productive. The Falstaff, Franconia and Red Antwerp are very fine. Most of those sold as Red and Yellow Antwerp's are bogus. The best ever bearing varieties are the Ohio Seedling, the Merveille de Four Seasons, and the Belle de Fontenay.

abstract: Alexander Matthews vs. The Mayor, &c., of New-York. -- This action was brought to restrain the City Corporation from executing a lease of a lot owned by plaintiff, and sold for non-payment of an assessment. The lot in question is situated in Twenty-sixth-street, near Ninth-avenue, and was sold at auction for a term of years, for non payment of an assessment for opening Twenty-sixth-street. Before the lease was executed, the owner brought this suit to enjoin the giving it, on the ground of fraud and irregularities in the proceedings of the Commissioners, on which the assessment was founded.

abstract: The Fire Department vs. Crawford. -- This action was brought by the Fire Department to recover two penalties alleged to have been incurred by defendant upon two buildings, front and rear, erected by him. The penalties were claimed under section 1 of the Act of April 14, 1856, for erecting two buildings on a lot in Twenty-seventh street, between Sixth and Seventh avenue. The statute referred to requires all the walls of buildings to be constructed of stone, brick or iron, and that they shall be started and built on foundations of stone or brick. The Fire Department alleged that some of the walls of the buildings in question were built of wood.

abstract: At 1 1/2 o'clock this morning, intelligence was communicated to the Police Head-quarters, that a most brutal and bloody murder had shortly before been committed in the First Ward. The dead body of a man was found in State-street, on the pavement, in front of No. 14. An officer, passing by on his beat, observed something on the walk, and stooping to see what it was, found the cold and lifeless body of a man. It was at first thought that some drunkard had fallen, but a full examination of the remains satisfied all of the unhappy man's real fate.

abstract: Mary Doyle was arrested yesterday on complaint of Mr. Thomas L. Harris, of No. 522 Broadway, who charges her with having stolen from his store six pieces of silk vesting, valued at $60. Mr. Harris alleges that the prisoner, in company with another woman, visited his store about a month ago, and committed the offence while pretending to purchase goods. The evidence, it is thought, is not strong enough to convict the accused......John H. Beckmedde, a German, residing at No. 183 West Forty-second-street, was arrested on Thursday, by Officer Ruck, on complaint of Deputy-Sheriff Thomas Dunlap, who charges him with having stolen two horses, a wagon and a truck, upon which he had levied to satisfy an execution. Beckmedde had not, it is said, a shadow of claim to the property. The animals and vehicles were recovered, and the prisoner was held for examination by Justice OSBORN.

abstract: The Harper's Ferry Committee of the Senate seems to have been turned into a regular debating club. A few days since, upon the examination of Mr. GIDDINGS, a lively discussion took place about the general theory of Government and the abstract right of Slavery.
lead_paragraph: The Harper's Ferry Committee of the Senate seems to have been turned into a regular debating club. A few days since, upon the examination of Mr. GIDDINGS, a lively discussion took place about the general theory of Government and the abstract right of Slavery. Mr. ANDREW, of Boston, by whom the fund was raised for the employment of counsel to defend JOHN BROWN and his confederates, has since been put between the upper and nether stones of the Committee's mill, and forced to emit his views of the Kansas troubles, of the comparative importance of the outrage perpetrated by BROWN upon the sovereign State of Virginia, and that inflicted by Mr. BROOKS upon the individual cranium of Senator SUMNER; of the propagation of Anti-Slavery sentiments by violence, and other matters equally pertinent to the investigation.

abstract: Yesterday afternoon, those who were rendered destitute by the recent calamity in Elm-street met at the Five Points House of Industry, to be present at the distribution of the money and clothing which have been collected by the different committees. Messrs. HALLIDAY and BARLOW, of the Five Points House of Industry, had collected over $600; the German Committee in the Fourteenth Ward over $200, and Deputy-Superintendent CARPENTER had received $130. While those who were assembled were searching a basket containing tools and valuables which the police had recovered from the ruins, to see whether any of their property had escaped from the flames, Mr. HALLIDAY walked about among the crowd, inquiring into the circumstances of the different individuals, and then the distribution commenced, each person receiving the amount allotted him in an envelope, and being required to sign a receipt for it. The following is a list of the moneys paid out by all the committees:

abstract: The recent dreadful calamity in Elm-street, which has aroused the Press, the people, and even the Legislature, to take serious thought for the social condition of a largo and neglected class of our population, and to devise measures for preventing the future recurrence of catastrophes so shocking in themselves and so disgraceful to our civilization, has also excited a very general and very praiseworthy movement of practical sympathy with the individual sufferers in this cruel case. We have already chronicled the charitable offerings of many private persons to these unfortunate people; and we learn with pleasure, though not with surprise, that Mr. FREDERIC MANNSTEIN, the accomplished actor-manager of our agreeable little French Theatre in Broadway, has set apart Thursday evening of next week for a performance in aid of the same beneficiaries. The brilliant dramatic talent which Mr. MANNSTEIN directs with so much skill and taste could hardly be better employed, and we cordially invite the attention of our readers to this very creditable proceeding.

abstract: Two duels were fought on the 28th ult. near New-Orleans. The first was at the Oaks, with small swords, between a young man named QUERY, and another whose name is not mentioned. The latter received a slight wound in the right side. The other was back of the Half-way House, between Messrs. ERNEST CANONGE and VICTOR GERODIAS; the weapons, shot-guns loaded with ball; the distance, forty paces. GERODIAS received his adversary's bail in the fleshy part of his leg, back of the knee, the ball passing through and grazing the front part of the right leg, and inflicting a wound which may render amputation necessary.

abstract: The bark Holland, which went ashore near Barnegat on the 7th instant, was a new vessel of 399 tons register, built at Port Jefferson, was about four months old, and was owned by C.G. KOLFF, of this City. She was greatly admired for her beauty of model, strength, and speed as a sailor. She was partially insured in this country. Her cargo consisted of 10,000 bushels of salt, hides, wood, &c., and was consigned to KOLFF & PERSUHN. The freight money was probably not insured.

abstract: The gale which broke over the City on Thursday night, and which continued yesterday, was one  of the most severe which we have experienced for years. Serious injury was done to innumerable structures through the City. The roofs of buildings were torn off and carried for long distances; chimneys...
lead_paragraph: The gale which broke over the City on Thursday night, and which continued yesterday, was one of the most severe which we have experienced for years. Serious injury was done to innumerable structures through the City. The roofs of buildings were torn off and carried for long distances; chimneys were hurled to the pavements, and the materials of which they were made dashed into fragments, to the imminent peril of all passers by. In the harbor vessels were swept from their moorings, or beaten against the piers; some being sunk, and others narrowly escaping this fate. The incidents which are recorded of the effects of this tornado, in this vicinity, are but indicative, we fear, of worse reports from abroad. Already the telegraph brings us from cities along the seaboard intelligence of the severity of the gale elsewhere, and days must elapse before the apprehension that disasters upon distant parts of the coast have occurred, will pass away.

abstract: The appointment of the committees in the House of Representatives must fill any one who has perused the debates of that body, previous to its organization, and even felt inclined to give the members the credit for believing what they said, with the deepest alarm.
lead_paragraph: The appointment of the committees in the House of Representatives must fill any one who has perused the debates of that body, previous to its organization, and even felt inclined to give the members the credit for believing what they said, with the deepest alarm. As long as the war between Republican and Democrat was carried on from opposite sides of the House, and the members of the contending factions were not brought into close proximity, there was always a chance for friends to interfere before enraged antagonists closed in combat, and the mere distance which separated them, small as it was, exercised its usual influence in mollifying animosities. But even this pacific influence, we all know, did not furnish a complete guarantee against the occurrence of a fight. There were few of us who would at any time have been surprised at seeing an announcement that one of the ballots for Speaker had been preceded by a lively "set-to" with the naked fists, followed up by a dropping fire of small arms. Considering that all the Southern members professed to see in the Republican members one hundred and sixteen conspirators for the assassination of themselves, their wives and families, and the kindling of a servile war, the wonder is that they ever kept their hands off them so studiously. The manner in which several Southern gentlemen showed them up, contained plenty of charges which ordinary human nature would light upon as a complete justification of the most dreadful scattering of wigs, hurling of spittoons, kicking and cuffing, that ever occurred on the floor of a Legislative Assembly. Mr. CLARK, of Missouri, in particular, if he believed one-half what he said, is deserving of the highest commendation for refraining from making a desperate attempt on JOHN SHERMAN's life; and how it is that a person of Mr. KEITT's political views and clearness of intellect, could have been guilty of anything so illogical as not plunging a bowie-knife into somebody's abdomen, we confess we are at a loss to conceive.

abstract: MARY HART, an infant about 6 months of age, whose parents reside at No. 233 Elizabeth-street, pulled a cup of hot tea from the table, on Saturday, and was so severely scalded that she died yesterday.... Some rag-pickers yesterday discovered the dead body of a male infant in an ash-box in Monroe-street. Coroner JACKMAN held an inquest in this case as well as in the former, but the cause of the death of the child was not determined.

abstract: In view of the hopeful condition of Italian affairs, the unanimous devotion of the people of Italy to the cause of Italian independence, and the spirit of moderation, patience, self-sacrifice and self-control which has marked their counsels and efforts for this end, the undersigned, believing that the timely expression of sympathy from the people of the United States with the people of Italy, in their struggles and hopes for Freedom, would strengthen and animate Italian patriots and other Europeans who sympathize with their cause, do hereby respectfully invite their fellow-citizens to convene, for the purpose of such an expression, at the City Assembly Rooms, No. 448 Broadway, on Feb. 17th instant, at 7 1/2 o'clock P.M.
lead_paragraph: In view of the hopeful condition of Italian affairs, the unanimous devotion of the people of Italy to the cause of Italian independence, and the spirit of moderation, patience, self-sacrifice and self-control which has marked their counsels and efforts for this end, the undersigned, believing that the timely expression of sympathy from the people of the United States with the people of Italy, in their struggles and hopes for Freedom, would strengthen and animate Italian patriots and other Europeans who sympathize with their cause, do hereby respectfully invite their fellow-citizens to convene, for the purpose of such an expression, at the City Assembly Rooms, No. 448 Broadway, on Feb. 17th instant, at 7 1/2 o'clock P.M.

abstract: At the regular meeting or the Police Commissioners, held yesterday afternoon, five members of the old force were reinstated. A resolution was adopted asking the Common Council to increase the accommodations at the Stationhouse in the Second Precinct. The Surgeons were directed to report all members of the Police force who were so disabled as to be incapacitated for further service. It was also resolved that the policemen detailed in the Courts be henceforth under the direction of the Deputy Superintendent. A communication was received from Capt. Porter, of the Twelfth Precinct, stating that eight mounted patrolmen had been employed in his Precinct, extending from Seventy-ninth-street to King's Bridge, with great success. The expense of each one, including salary, is $1,000 per year. The Captain suggests that a distinct uniform be adopted for this force. The discussion which was laid over from the last meeting, in regard to the transfer of power from Gen, PILSBURY to the Mayor, was postponed on account of the absence of Mayor POWELL.

abstract: The New-York Herald, having reduced Mr. BUCHANAN to a state in which he is literally good for nothing excepting to plague Mr. FORNEY withal, has devoted itself to destroying what small remains of political life are still left in Mayor WOOD, by vehemently urging that functionary upon the allegiance of the Democracy. It announces the Mayor's arrival at Albany on a political mission as something corresponding in the world to the recent earthquake in South Carolina, and it proclaims his purpose of forming a league with Commodore VANDERBILT, and going to Charleston on board one of that enterprising individual's steamers, with the air of the Monteur publishing an intended Imperial excursion to England.
lead_paragraph: The New-York Herald, having reduced Mr. BUCHANAN to a state in which he is literally good for nothing excepting to plague Mr. FORNEY withal, has devoted itself to destroying what small remains of political life are still left in Mayor WOOD, by vehemently urging that functionary upon the allegiance of the Democracy. abstract: The Ultramontanist Clergy having made themselves heard in America through such organs as they could command, in behalf of Papal misrule, Austrian intervention and popular degradation in Italy, it is but fair that the voice of enlightened American public feeling should be raised in reply.
lead_paragraph: The Ultramontanist Clergy having made themselves heard in America through such organs as they could command, in behalf of Papal misrule, Austrian intervention and popular degradation in Italy, it is but fair that the voice of enlightened American public feeling should be raised in reply. And we are glad, therefore, to see that a meeting has been called, to be held in this City on some day of next week, for the purpose of expressing the unfeigned admiration which the manly and sensible attitude preserved by the Italians throughout this great crisis of their national destiny has excited in the hearts of free and intelligent men all the world over. America must have sympathized in any event with a great people struggling to assert its natural place among the nations; and had the conduct of the people of Central Italy been marked, as it might well have been expected that it would be, by all the excesses so common in the history of outraged races rising for their rights, we should still have felt for them and with them in their supreme hour, and hoped even against hope, that liberty would bring them law at last. But we have not been forced to make any allowances for the past, in commending the present of the Italian State, The men who but yesterday were the chasing subjects of the Austrian sword, for years the only real sceptre of the Peninsula, have approved themselves at once the free citizens of a free commonwealth. In the records of the great year 1859, the one mad outbreak in which the cruel ANVITI expiated with his life an atrocious career of years among the people of Parma, will be more than balanced by the brutal sack of Perugia in the name of order and the Vicar of Christ. And it will be set down in the chronicles, that while the revolutionists of Parma did sure and speedy justice upon the lawless executioners of a despot's minion, the Holy Father honored with the crosses of the Church the mercenaries who had put a fair city to pillage and to rapine beneath the banner of St. Peter.

abstract: The North Atlantic Steamship Company's steamer Atlantic arrived yesterday morning, bringing the passengers and specie list of Jan. 20 from San Francisco, making the through trip in a trifle over twenty days.
lead_paragraph: The North Atlantic Steamship Company's steamer Atlantic arrived yesterday morning, bringing the passengers and specie list of Jan. 20 from San Francisco, making the through trip in a trifle over twenty days. The passengers who left this port by the Atlantic on the 20th December, made the trip to San Francisco in twenty days and six hours, being the quickest outward trip yet accomplished. The receipt of treasure from California by this arrival is $1,476,000. The letters of our correspondent at San Francisco give very interesting details of the election of Gov. LATHAM to the United States Senate, and of the means by which that event was accomplished. The announcement of the result, so unexpected in itself, appears to have created the greatest astonishment in San Francisco. A letter from Capt. DALL, late commander of the steamship Northerner, gives full particulars of the wreck of that vessel, with complete lists of the persons lost and saved. The total loss of life was 38 persons, of whom only 17 were passengers.

abstract: Several of our artists, says the Albany Evening Journal, have some fine specimens of their skill at the art exhibition in Troy. Palmer has three pieces, the statue of the "Little Peasant," and busts of Gov. Morgan and "Spring." G.H. Boughton has pictures of "Twilight," "Sharp Frost," "Nightfall," and "Leed's Bridge." T. Smith has "The Frozen Stream," " Winter," "Christmas Eve," and "Winter Evening." These are all highly creditable productions, and attract very general attention. The Harts have also some fine specimens on exhibition.

abstract: The first case tried to-day in this Court, Recorder BARNARD presiding, was that of Charles Wood, an old gentleman of respectable appearance and demeanor, charged with stealing, on the 24th August, 1859, two promissory notes, the property of Peter McLeod. One note was for the sum of $3,317, the other for $2,530. As it appeared from the evidence of Mr. Reuben C. Stone, to whom they were given to sell, that the offence was not one of larceny, but of breach of trust, the Recorder instructed the jury that, under the indictment, they must render a verdict of "not guilty," which they did, to the infinite satisfaction of the accused.

abstract: PANAMA, Thrusday, Feb. 2, 1860. We have dates from Bogota by mail only up  to Dec. 26. A letter has been received by a late member of Congress, resident here, from a gentleman in Carthagena, which says that a revolution broke out in Bogota in the early part of last month; but I do not attach much credit to the report.
lead_paragraph: PANAMA, Thrusday, Feb. 2, 1860.

abstract: PANAMA, Wednesday, Fer. 1, 1860. The British mail steamship Bolivia arrived at  Panama Jan. 22. She brought dates from Valparaiso and Santiago, Chile, to Jan. 1, from Bolivia to the 4th, and from Callao and Lima to the 13th. The Bolivia brought $345,000, principally for England. She did not touch at Guayaquil.
lead_paragraph: PANAMA, Wednesday, Fer. 1, 1860.

abstract: ALBANY, Saturday, Feb. 11, 1860. There was a scene between "ye Senate and As  sembly" to-day, which, as far as I recollect, was never before enacted. It is the rule of the Senate to elect a President problem., who is President de facto in the absence of the Lieutenant Governor. In pursuance of this rule, some days Senator NATHAN LAPHAM was elected President.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY, Saturday, Feb. 11, 1860.

abstract: We are indebted to a recent number of the London Chronicle for the facts contained in the following historical sketch of the Franking Privilege and its abuses in England--a subject of peculiar interest just now, when our own ...
lead_paragraph: We are indebted to a recent number of the London Chronicle for the facts contained in the following historical sketch of the Franking Privilege and its abuses in England--a subject of peculiar interest just now, when our own Franking Privilege is about to share the fate of its British prototype. The Franking Privilege had no existence in England in the good old times of feudalism, or in the days of the early STUARTS. It originated under the Commonwealth -- becoming part of the law of the land in 1660, during the Parliamentary session of which year a proviso was added to the Post-office bill of Col. TITUS, which exempted the letters of members of Parliament from postage while attending to their public duties. The proviso met with very hard usage in passing through the House. One honorable gentleman called it "a poor mendicant proviso;" the Speaker, when putting it from the Chair, declared that "he was ashamed of it;" nevertheless, the majority supported it, and, the lords ratifying their decision, the "poor mendicant proviso" remained in the bill, and grew in time to be so popular that the friends of honorable members and noble Peers, as well as honorable members and noble Peers themselves, freely took the benefit of it; may, gradually learned to apply it to purposes which were certainly never contemplated by its author. The term "letters" in those days had a more comprehensive meaning than is now assigned to it, being equally applied to what we call "letters," and to "parcels." Of this comprehensiveness British Senators were not slow to take advantage, and thus the franking privilege in England soon became the source of abuses to which our comparatively modern system can furnish no parallel. Not only were dresses, boots, shoes, window-curtains, lace, books, partridges and pheasants regularly transmitted through the British Post-office under cover of this privilege, but even haunches of venison, entire bucks and packs of hounds! To put a stop to these abuses, an act was passed in the middle of the last century restricting the number of "letters" which members of Parliament could frank to ten a day, and fixing the limits of their size and weight. Said act did not, however, apply to members of the Government, who were still allowed to exercise the privilege ad libitum; so that even in the present century GEORGE CANNING, by virtue of this exemption, could send a whole copy of CLARENDON's History, free of postage, to a friend in Ireland, and Mr. POULETT THOMPSON, afterwards Lord SYDENHAM, three haunches of venison to his constituents at Dover!
headline: {'main': 'The Franking Abuse in England.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Franking Abuse in England.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Pro NoNo has given another epistle to the Press--an address to the Archbishops and Bishops of France explanatory of the motives which led him to refuse the advice of the Emperor touching the Romagna. The" motivas" ...
lead_paragraph: Pro NoNo has given another epistle to the Press--an address to the Archbishops and Bishops of France explanatory of the motives which led him to refuse the advice of the Emperor touching the Romagna. The" motivas" of His Holiness, being of the old stereotyped cast, require no consideration, but the address is of importance as indicating that the Pope is still obstinately determined not to accept the terms of compromise offered him in the ingeniously respectful letter of NAPOLEON. The hereditary maxim of the Ultra-Montanists, "Sit ut est, aut non sit," is still the maxim of PIUS. Change is the great immutable law to which all things in the material and immaterial universe are subject; nevertheless this infatuated old man and his satellites impiously rebel against their Maker's ordinance, and proclaim their treason in the face of earth and Heaven. The Pope will not give up the Romagna! But who asks him to give up the Romagna? The Emperor of the French was hardly so unreasonable as to ask his Holiness to surrender what he does not possess. The French Sovereign merely urged him, for the sake of Europe, of Italy, and of the Church, to accept accomplished facts. The conduct of his own Government has hopelessly alienated the people of the Papal States. He is simply, therefore, called upon to bow to the popular will, in his capacity of temporal Prince. Will his American Bishops dare to contend that this demand is exorbitant? The Pope assumes that it is, and clings to his sterile royal right to reconquer the Romagna, and the Emperor NAPOLEON has never questioned his right to achieve even this un-Christian enterprise, if he could achieve it with his own forces His Holiness is at perfect liberty, so far as NAPOLEON and France and Europe are concerned, to march his mercenaries as soon as he pleases into the revolted provinces, and bring about their reduction. But in accepting the undertaking he must accept the consequences. Should he enter upon this campaign and fail to accomplish his purpose -- as fail, undoubtedly, he would -- he must not think of repairing his fortunes by means of foreign auxiliaries. He must not look either to the South or to the North, neither to the despot of Naples, nor to the despot of Austria for succor. For their assistance, even if they had the temerity to give it, could serve no other purpose than to consummate his ruin. Were the Neapolitan monarch to march to his aid, VICTOR EMANUEL, of Sardinia, would at once enter the arena as the ally of the Romagnoli. Were the Austrian autocrat to espouse his cause, the French Emperor would again take the field as the champion of Italy, would of course withdraw his garrison at once from Rome and leave the stubborn and intractable Pontiff to his fate. Whether then is it better for Pro NONO to accept the compromise offered to him by NAPOLEON, and to secure by doing so the future possession, perhaps, of his cis-Apennine provinces -- certainly of the world's respect -- or to enter on a course which must entail the most lamentable disasters on the country which he professes to rule in the name of Christ, and lead to the utter destruction at least of his temporal and very possibly of his spiritual power also? Every intelligent Catholic must see that it would be madness in the Pontiff even to think, in his present circumstances, of attempting the reconquest of the Legations; and that the very best thing he can now do, as well for his own interests as for those of the church, is to accept the offer of the French Emperor, abandon a right which he has lost the power to enforce, and avoid while it is yet time a collision of which no man, not an "Archbishop or Suffragan of the Province of New-York," will rashly attempt to prophesy the long and terrible results.

abstract: The multitudinous attractions at the Academy of Music are so strangely crowded into unexpected nooks and corners of the week, and the announcements of the managers are so clamorous with the word "last."--which should always read "first,"-- ...
lead_paragraph: The multitudinous attractions at the Academy of Music are so strangely crowded into unexpected nooks and corners of the week, and the announcements of the managers are so clamorous with the word "last." -- which should always read "first," -- that it is by no means an easy matter to keep the critical "run" of matters there. In the way of brief and hasty resume, we may mention that WEBER's "Freischutz," -- ever an unwelcome work with the American public, -- was given on Friday to a house mainly composed of Germans. A great deal of excellent commendation has at various times been bestowed on this work and so far as relates to orchestration, and occasional choral morceaux, not undeservedly. It is remarkable in some of these respects. But the vitality of an opera depends simply and purely on its adaptability to the voice of singers, and on a sufficiency of purely vocal themes. Here and there in "Der Freischutz" are admirable bits of singable condescension, but the bulk of the music is vocally impossible; a collection of passages that degenerate naturally into screams, and, however well executed, provoke uneasiness. For these reasons -- and for the additional one that it is difficult to decide which are the dullest, the original German dialogues which connect the pieces, or the intermediate recitatives of HECTOR BERLIOZ, which leave them centuries apart -- the opera enjoys but little popularity out of Germany. All the leading artists on Friday were good, COLSON, STIGELLI and JUNCA. Owing to their exertions, there is a prospect of an early repetition.

abstract: Previous to the construction of the Erie Canal, a Committee of the Legislature, to which was referred the urgency of this work reported the cost of transporting a ton of merchandise between Buffalo and Albany to be one hundred dollars, and the time required ...
lead_paragraph: Previous to the construction of the Erie Canal, a Committee of the Legislature, to which was referred the urgency of this work reported the cost of transporting a ton of merchandise between Buffalo and Albany to be one hundred dollars, and the time required therefor twenty days. Such rates, of course, were an effectual bar that turned all the products, not only of the interior, but of a large portion of our own State, from us to other markets. So late as 1820 the wheat of Western New-York was sent down the Delaware and Susquehanna Rivers to the cities of Philadelphia and Baltimore! The turning of this tide to New-York was simply the result of our improved highways. Of these works, the Erie Canal brought to us, in 1858, according to the late report of the Auditor of the Canal Department, 1,273,000 tons of merchandise from the Western States alone. At the rates which prevailed before the opening of the Canal, the cost of sending this tonnage from Buffalo to New-York would have been $127,300,000! -- a sum exceeding twice its value delivered in this City.

abstract: SKAYING AT THE CENTRAL PARK.--Those who are accustomed to indulge themselves in skatting at the Central Park did not stop to ask, on Saturday, whether the fearful blasts of the day preceding were the cause of the cold weather which immediately succeeded, or if the strong wind was produced by the ...
lead_paragraph: SKAYING AT THE CENTRAL PARK. -- Those who are accustomed to indulge themselves in skatting at the Central Park did not stop to ask, on Saturday, whether the fearful blasts of the day preceding were the cause of the cold weather which immediately succeeded, or if the strong wind was produced by the destruction of equilibrium in the atmosphere. It was enough for them to know that Jack Frost had again asserted his supremacy. The elevation of the ball at the Central Park Observatory was sufficient inducement to draw to the Skating Pond crowds of schoolboys, and those of larger growth, who were glad enough of the opportunity to enjoy a half holiday. Ladies, too, found it necessary to indulge in more violent exercise than a quiet promenade along Broadway, in order to counterbalance the sudden transition from Spring to Winter. As the thermometer went down, every one who could went up to Central Park, and a merry time there was until late in the evening, when the darkness put an end to the sport. Despite the fact that yesterday was the Sabbath, the Pond was again thronged. To be sure, there was a change in the complexion of the crowd. Boys who had parents to keep them at home, wickedly wished that the Sabbath might have been postponed for another day. But they had to reconcile themselves to attending Sabbath School and Church, while those whom the necessity of daily labor deprive of any other holiday, took their places at the Pond. The cars on the Third and Sixth avenues were thronged, and, as heretofore, those who could not get seats or standing-room inside these vehicles, were obliged to suffer their fingers to become benumed by hanging on wherever they could find the space. How long the thermometer may labor under the depressing influences from which it suffers at present it is impossible to predict; but the Winter is nearly gone, and. it is hardly probable that the ice will be as firm and glassy again as it is at present. Every one who can should improve the present opportunity.

abstract: A CORRECTION. -- We called attention on Saturday to the performances of one of Mayor WOOD's retainers, sentenced by Judge INGRAHAM to spend a year in the Penitentiary, for throwing a cleaver at one of his acquaintances who had refused to vote for the candidate of his own choice. It appears that this devoted henchman, JARED R. COOK by name, adorned his possible manslaughter by a positive falsehood. He gave himself out in court for a "brother-in-law" of Mr. WOOD, and on the faith of the law reports was so treated of by us. We are assured, on the best authority, that this was a mere burst of Mr. COOK's diseased imagination, and that he is no way whatever connected with the family of our aspiring Chief Magistrate. It is due, therefore, to the relations by blood and marriage of Mr. WOOD, to relieve them of the opprobrium thus unwittingly brought upon them. The kinsmen of Mayor WOOD are not the kinsmen of Mr. COOK, whose only connexion with the immaculate FERNANDO seems to be that he first voted for him, then threw a cleaver at one of his political opponents, and finally told a scandalous lie to excuse this devoted partisanship.

abstract: Some additional items of European news are forwarded from Boston, where the Europa arrived on Saturday, at noon. Every demonstration of respect was paid to the remains of the late Capt. HARRISON, on the occasion of their removal from Southampton to Liverpool. Capts. JUDKINS,
lead_paragraph: Some additional items of European news are forwarded from Boston, where the Europa arrived on Saturday, at noon. Every demonstration of respect was paid to the remains of the late Capt. HARRISON, on the occasion of their removal from Southampton to Liverpool. Capts. JUDKINS, LANG, and others of the Cunard Steamship Company, were among the pall-bearers, and the American Consul was in the procession. Fuller particulars of the commercial treaty between France and England are furnished. M. THOUVENEL had assumed office as Minister of Foreign Affairs in France. In a circular which he had issued, he pledged his best efforts to maintain and consolidate friendly relations with England. The Moors had suffered a severe reverse in an attack upon the advanced redoubt of the Spaniards on the Tetuan river. From Italy we learn that the Marquis of MARSAN D'AZEGLIO had been appointed Governor of Milan, and that RATAZZI had left for Nice.

abstract: About 8 o'clock on Saturday evening, Mr. Frederick Brown, of Wickford, R.I., while sauntering through Water-street, was accosted by two strangers whose friendly demonstrations won his confidence. They induced him to accompany them on board a ...
lead_paragraph: About 8 o'clock on Saturday evening, Mr. Frederick Brown, of Wickford, R.I., while sauntering through Water-street, was accosted by two strangers whose friendly demonstrations won his confidence. They induced him to accompany them on board a vessel lying at a pier in the neighborhood for the purpose of drinking to their better acquaintance. Scarcely had they stepped on deck when Brown's quondam friends, to his intense surprise, seized him by the neck, and demanded his money or his life. Having secured his breast-pin and other valuables, the highwaymen sought to escape. Officer Craig, of the Fourth Precinct, however, arrested the flight of one of them, who gave his name as Timothy Murphy, and Justice OSBORN held him for trial. His confederate escaped.

abstract: The correspondent of the Philadelphia Evening Bulletin, writing from Caracas on the 20th ult., says that the Government troops attacked Gen. GU[???]VARA's entrenchments in Moron, only four leagues from Venezuela, on the 30th Dec., but were repulsed with a loss of twelve killed and forty wounded. On the 1st of January another attack was made under MENENDEZ, when Moron was taken, with three killed and ten wounded. The faction was altogether destroyed and driven to the woods, and, they say, GU[???]VARA and his son killed, which is generally believed to be correct, as his correspondence, clothes, &c., were taken, and nothing had been heard of him since. The true result his been kept secret and mysterious for some cause, by the chiefs. It is supposed he was caught and dispatched.

abstract: Mr. MURPHY has introduced an excellent bill in the State Senate, giving suits for servants' wages ink the District Courts a preference on the calendar--prohibiting the exaction of any costs beyond ten cents to the clerk, fifty cents
lead_paragraph: Mr. MURPHY has introduced an excellent bill in the State Senate, giving suits for servants' wages ink the District Courts a preference on the calendar--prohibiting the exaction of any costs beyond ten cents to the clerk, fifty cents to the constable, and the usual jury-fee, if the case is tried by a jury. The extent to which servants and laborers are swindled out of small sums would appear almost incredible if put in figures on paper. Five, or ten, or twenty dollars, is a very large sum for a poor man or woman, but it is a sum of which their employers may in most instances deprive them, if so disposed, with perfect impunity. The costs of proceeding for the recovery of such sums in the Justices' Courts at present, form an enormous percentage on the debt even if its recovery were certain. A dollar has to be paid at the ontset for a summons, and then the unfortunate plaintiff has to sacrifice his time, which, in most cases, means his daily bread, dancing attendance at Court until the cause is reached. If he is so lucky as to be able to prove his case, or get a judgment, he is three dollars out of pocket before the constable proceeds to levy, and then he may find at the close that there is nothing that can be levied on. The servant may, for instance, have been hired by the husband, and have served the whole family faithfully, and yet may find, on taking out execution, that the whole property is vested in the lady, who, of course, is not liable for her husband's debts.

abstract: -- A woman named ELIZABETH WILLIAMS, residing on Eighth-street, near North Third, on Saturday afternoon went to a window on the third story of the house to throw out a pail of water, when she lost her balance and fell head foremost to the ground. She was taken to the City Hospital, having sustained serious, if not fatal, injuries.....JOHN J. SIMPSON, laborer, on Saturday last fell into the hold of the ship John J. Boyd, at PIERREPONT's dock, and was so seriously injured that he was taken to the City Hospital for treatment.

abstract: The circumstances attending the death of Mr. WILLIAM S. TUERS, a night-watchman in the Customs' Department, who was found dead in State-street on Friday night, are still enveloped in mystery. Deceased...
lead_paragraph: The circumstances attending the death of Mr. WILLIAM S. TUERS, a night-watchman in the Customs' Department, who was found dead in State-street on Friday night, are still enveloped in mystery. Deceased was seen a few minutes before 11 o'clock, in company with a female, passing down Broadway on the left-hand side, nearly opposite Morris-street. Mr. CHARLES COPPING, also a Custom-house watchman, residing at No. 53 Lispenard-street, who observed them, says that he was on his way to the Barge-office to report for duty at the time, and as they walked at a slow pace he overtook and passed them. He had, however, not been in the office more than five minutes when word was brought that Mr. TUERS had been found murdered.

lead_paragraph: Coroner SCHIRMER held an inquest on Saturday on the body of JOHN THOMAS CHESTER, an Irishman, 33 Years of age, who died at Bellevue Hospital, in consequence of taking a large quantity of laudanum with the intention of ending his existence. It seems that on Friday afternoon deceased entered the place of Mrs. MCCARMELL, No. 185 First-avenue, where, after drinking with some of his friends, he produced a small bottle of laudanum and swallowed its contents before any person could interfere to prevent him. His unpleasant domestic relations seem to have impelled him to the act, as the following letter, found upon his person and addressed to his brother, indicates:

abstract: The deliberations of the Supreme Court in the case of HENRY D. STONE, of Worcester, resulted in an order for his discharge from custody, which was sent to Worcester yesterday, and Mr. STONE was set at liberty. His affairs were immediately brought before the Court of Insolvency, Judge MATTOON, of Franklin County, presiding, and a warrent issued against his estate, on the petition of GEO. HORBS. The Spy says it is believed by many that the new proceedings in case will lead to some compromise which the creditors will accept. -- Boston Journal, 11th.
