abstract: To the United States Senate the death of Hon. DAVID C. BRODERICK was yesterday announced, by Senator HAUN, of California, who spoke of the departed Senator in terms of high eulogy. Messrs. SEWARD, CRITTENDEN, FOSTER, FOOT and TOOMBS also added their ardent panegyrics, after which the Senate adjourned.
lead_paragraph: To the United States Senate the death of Hon. DAVID C. BRODERICK was yesterday announced, by Senator HAUN, of California, who spoke of the departed Senator in terms of high eulogy. Messrs. SEWARD, CRITTENDEN, FOSTER, FOOT and TOOMBS also added their ardent panegyrics, after which the Senate adjourned. The House made two ineffectual attempts to choose a Printer, -- a resolution having previously been adopted requiring a committee to designate the terms upon which the work shall be executed. The most prominent candidates were Messrs. DEFREES, of Indiana, the nominee of the Republicans, and GLOSSBRENNER, late Sergeant-at-Arms of the House, proposed by the Democrats. Two votes were taken, upon the last of which Mr. DEFREES had 90, Mr. GLOSSBRENNER 89; necessary to a choice 92. At this moment the death of Mr. BRODERICK was announced by a message from the Senate, when Messrs. Burch, Burlingame, Haskin, Hickman, Morris of Illinois, and Sickles paid cordial tributes to the memory of the deceased. The House then adjourned.

abstract: PARIS, Thursday, Jan. 26, 1860. The tardy manner in which the American mail is  delivered in London and Paris each time the Boston steamer stops at Cork, has very justly excited loud reclamations in both these cities. When the steamers went directly to Liverpool, the mail was always, on a normal passage, delivered in London on Mon  day and in Paris on Tuesday.

abstract: The feeling of the House of Representatives indicates that the Senate amendment to the Post-office Appropriation bill, abolishing the franking privilege, will be rejected. The plea put forward is, not that the abuse of this privilege, by which the mails are flooded with worthless matter, to the detriment of the regular ...
lead_paragraph: The feeling of the House of Representatives indicates that the Senate amendment to the Post-office Appropriation bill, abolishing the franking privilege, will be rejected. The plea put forward is, not that the abuse of this privilege, by which the mails are flooded with worthless matter, to the detriment of the regular service, and at an immense expense to the country, should not be corrected, but that a radical change in the system should be introduced in a separate bill, and thoroughly discussed and matured. We cannot see the force of this argument. That a reform is needed is generally conceded, and if this be so, the form of legislation by which it is to be effected really seems to be of very secondary consequence. It will be easy enough to alter any of the details of the proposed system as its practical working may show to be expedient. The great end to be gained is to put a stop, in the quickest practicable way, to a costly and growing evil. Besides, the whole subject lies in a nutshell, and may be comprehended, even by an average member of Congress, in all its bearings, with but little reflection. It cannot require much deliberation for any man to make up his mind upon the simple question whether the country shall pay the enormous cost of supplying individuals with information upon all conceivable topics -- information too which, in most cases, is of but little value in itself, and that little not made available to the persons for whom it is provided. The newspapers of the day contain everything of interest in all the departments of popular information about public affairs, and they are full to overflowing with the merely partisan political matter which is now circulated under the frank of members of Congress. Newspapers have become a necessity to the reading community, and no rational creature can think of supplying their place by public documents, which lack their freshness, their variety, and their comprehensiveness.

abstract: Shortly alter our going to press on Saturday morning a most disastrous fire occurred n the building occupied as a saw and planing mill situate on the wharf, foot of Shackamaxon-street, and used and occupied by the Messrs. RUE, RHODES & Co. The building belonged to the Boone estate. The building was filled with lumber and other combustible material, and the flames raged with great fury, spreading to the boat-yard and sheds of GEORGE SHEPPERD adjoining, and consuming a considerable amount of lumber and several small skiffs, boats, &c., some of which belonged to other parties. A small steam yacht belonging to Hon. JOHN B. FLOYD, Secretary of War, was also destroyed -- her value was three thousand dollars. The sheds, and brick workshops belonged to WM. S. BAKER, whose loss is comparatively trifling, and is fully covered by insurance. The flames thence communicated to some small outbuildings and lumber on the premises, and burned with great fury, at one time threatening the entire destruction of the adjacent mills and other valuable property, and nothing but the untiring exertions of the firemen, seconded by their steam fire-annihilators, prevented such a result. The loss of Messrs. SLOAT & Co., was trifling, and is covered by insurance. About $2,000 worth of lumber belonging to S. BOLTON & Co., and GASKILL & GARVIN was also destroyed; other damage was done of a trifling nature. But the most dreadful portion of our narrative was a loss of life resulting in this wise: The Kensington engine was proceeding to the scene of conflagration, and was about turning from Beach-street into a passage-way leading to SLOAT & Co.'s mills, when a man who had hold of the rope, became apprehensive that he would be struck by the tongue of the apparatus. He let go his hold of the rope and ran to one side of the passage-way, where the lever of the engine struck and jammed him against the wall. He was assisted into a neighboring tavern where he died in about fifteen minutes. The deceased proved to be JAMES YARDLEY, who resided in Allen-street above Marlborough, in the immediate vicinity of the fire. He was about forty years of age, and leaves a wife and six or seven children. He was a book-binder by trade.

abstract: Mr. HAMMOND introduced a bill to amend the act concerning the Salt Springs and the manufacture of salt. It provides that there shall be collected and paid on all salt manufactured in this State a duty of three cents per bushel, which duties shall be paid into the general fund. The Superintendent may appoint...
lead_paragraph: Mr. HAMMOND introduced a bill to amend the act concerning the Salt Springs and the manufacture of salt. It provides that there shall be collected and paid on all salt manufactured in this State a duty of three cents per bushel, which duties shall be paid into the general fund. The Superintendent may appoint the following deputies, to wit: One Receiver, who shall reside and keep his office in Syracuse, and who shall also be chief clerk. One Inspector of Salt to reside in each district. One Overseer of Pumps, Aqueducts and Reservoirs; and four clerks. There shall be paid to these officers the following annual salaries: Superintendent, $1,500; Receiver, $840; to each of the Clerks, $600. The Superintendent is authorized to employ such additional laborers as may be necessary, with the assent and approval of the Comptroller, excepting in cases of accident or such emergency as requires instant action, in which case he is empowered to employ the necessary laborers or assistants in his discretion, and continue the same until opportunity may be had to obtain the assent and approval of the Comptroller.

abstract: -- A regular meeting of this Board was held last night. A number of vetoes were received from the Mayor; one on the election of DAVID R. SIMPSON as Assistant Engineer of the Western District Fire Department, he not having served the necessary length of time in the Fire Department of this city; also the resolution appropiating $80 to each of the Fire Departments for banners, on the ground that the Board had no authority for making the appropriation; also the resolution giving the Grand-streeet Railroad grant to the New-York & Flushing Railroad Company, because they were not bidders. The vetoes were ordered on file. A communication was received from the Young Men's Christian Association, remonstrating against the petition of the St. Vincent and St. Paul Roman Catholic Society for permission to send a priest to the Truant Institution -- for the reason that the ground is now occupied, and denying that they teach sectarianism. Referred to the Committee having the matter in charge.

abstract: Robert Williams, George Soule, Edward Kelly and George Bristow were arrested about 4 1/2 o'clock yesterday morning charged with playing "bluff" for cash stakes at the billiard saloon of Louis Shaenfield, in Broadway, between Thirty-fourth and Thirty-fifth streets. The first intimation which they had that clubs were trumps, was given when players, pool and gambling paraphernalia passed into the hands of the Police. Shaenfield, the proprietor of the place, was arrested also, and Justice QUACKENBUSH held the quintette to await examination.

abstract: A number of indignant correspondents urge us to call public attention to the extreme improbability which exists that any steps will be taken to inflict a proper punishment upon Mr. WARING, the owner and architect of that miserable man-trap miscalled a tenement house, ...
lead_paragraph: A number of indignant correspondents urge us to call public attention to the extreme improbability which exists that any steps will be taken to inflict a proper punishment upon Mr. WARING, the owner and architect of that miserable man-trap miscalled a tenement house which was consumed by fire in Elm-street the other day, and in which ten human beings lost their lives. The Coroner's jury, indeed, did their duty in the premises, and fixed the responsibility for this holocaust upon the person who ought really to bear it. But our correspondents think the matter ought not to rest here. They do not think that manslaughter by wholesale ought to be dismissed with a mere vote of censure, while manslaughter by retail is dealt with in a more peremptory and positive fashion.

abstract: We wait with some impatience to see whether the House of Representatives will take any action about the assault committed upon one of its members--Mr. HICKMAN, of Pennsylvania. It is time something was done, ...
lead_paragraph: We wait with some impatience to see whether the House of Representatives will take any action about the assault committed upon one of its members--Mr. HICKMAN, of Pennsylvania. It is time something was done, and done effectually, to prevent the recurrence of these outrages, which are a disgrace equally to Congress itself and to the country. If the Parliamentary proprieties of Congress cannot protect its members from personal violence, whether for words spoken in debate, or for speeches which, in the exercise of their discretion, they may see fit to make in the Capital of the country, we may as well accept the laws of barbarism at once, and request our representatives to defend themselves as best they may. The protection of Congress should be extended to its members, not only while they are in the halls of legislation, but should follow them so long as they remain within its exclusive jurisdiction in the performance of their official duties.

abstract: The erroneous announcement that the funeral of the late WILLIAM E. BURTON would take place from St. Thomas' Church, yesterday afternoon, attracted quite a crowd to that point, consisting of actors, authors and artists, and others drawn to the spot by mere curiosity. Even the police, with unusual vigilance.
lead_paragraph: The erroneous announcement that the funeral of the late WILLIAM E. BURTON would take place from St. Thomas' Church, yesterday afternoon, attracted quite a crowd to that point, consisting of actors, authors and artists, and others drawn to the spot by mere curiosity. Even the police, with unusual vigilance, came to the spot in large force, prepared to regulate the crowd which it was anticipated would be present. But no signs of opening the church were apparent and, after loitering about the vicinity for some time, the assemblage gradually dispersed -- various explanations being given of the mystery. It was asserted positively that Mr. BURTON had been interred on Sunday morning; that, owing to the peculiar domestic relations of the deceased, the services were held privately, to avoid a scene; that Mr. BURTON had requested his physicians to cover his corpse with a sheet immediately upon his death, and not to allow any one -- even of his family -- to view it.

abstract: The mystery surrounding the circumstances attending the death of Mr. WILLIAM S. TUERS, the Custom-house watchman, who was murdered in Statestreet on Friday night, has not yet been solved. An investigation of the matter was commenced yesterday by Coroner JACKMAN, and a number of witnesses were examined, none of whom however, testified to ...
lead_paragraph: The mystery surrounding the circumstances attending the death of Mr. WILLIAM S. TUERS, the Custom-house watchman, who was murdered in Statestreet on Friday night, has not yet been solved. An investigation of the matter was commenced yesterday by Coroner JACKMAN, and a number of witnesses were examined, none of whom however, testified to anything tending to point out the perpetrator of this brutal murder. The proceedings were conducted in the Seventh Precinct Station-house, and the interest which the case excites was manifested by the attendance of a numerous audience. On Sunday night, SARAH J. MCCLESTER, a young married woman, residing at No. 176 East Twenty-eighth-street, was apprehended on the supposition that she was the person who had been seen in company with the deceased a few minutes before his death. JOSIAH MCGARR, a stage-driver on the Fourth-avenue line, testified positively to the identity of this woman with one who rode in his stage from the corner of Whitehall and Front-streets about the time the murder is supposed to have been committed. The woman and her husband, however, just as positively deny that she was out of the house at all on the night in question, except to visit a friend, and that she returned home before nine o'clock. Mrs. MCCLESTER was nevertheless detained until the matter should be further investigated, as her character, from the representations of other witnesses, is such that her veracity may be impeached. The testimony of Dr. CHARLES MARSH, the family physician of deceased who was present at the post-mortem examination conflicts with that of the other physicians as to the manner in which the blow was struck which resulted in Mr. TUERS' death. Dr. MARSH is of opinion that the injuries to the face were inflicted with a set of "metallic knuckles," a formidable instrument, usually carried by highwaymen, made to fit the fingers of the right hand, and that the injury to the back part of the head was the result of the fall. Drs. BEACH and WETJE are said to entertain views upon the point directly the reverse of these. The funeral of Mr. TUERS took place yesterday, from his late residence, No. 243 Monroe-street. It was numerously attended, not only on account of the extraordinary circumstances connected with his death, but as a testimony of respect to his memory by those to whom he was well known. The following is the testimony which was taken yesterday:

abstract: The seventieth Annual Report of the NewYork Dispensary has just appeared, bringing with it the most gratifying proofs that after three-score years and ten of unremitting usefulness in an everwidening field of practical philanthropy, the natural strength of this most excellent institution is by no means abated. And it is well that this is so.
lead_paragraph: The seventieth Annual Report of the NewYork Dispensary has just appeared, bringing with it the most gratifying proofs that after three-score years and ten of unremitting usefulness in an everwidening field of practical philanthropy, the natural strength of this most excellent institution is by no means abated. And it is well that this is so. For, although several new Dispensaries have sprung up around this parent body, and all have been administered with zeal and fidelity, the area of suffering and disease grows steadily with and even beyond them all; and within the special circle covered by the original charity, the gradual shifting of the better classes of our citizens upward and westward on the Island continually intensifies the demand on the services of the New-York Dispensary by pouring new swarms of wretched and demoralized people into the spaces successively vacated by the more industrious and orderly. The Five Points and the busiest wharves depend upon this institution entirely, and from the nature of their population can do almost nothing to support it. The catalogue of the diseases treated by its physicians offers the most eloquent commentary upon the depth of the social degradation and misery into which these missionaries of mercy are daily descending; and if we spare our readers the recital of details which might well disturb the tranquil content of their morning hour, it is only on condition that they will give themselves the trouble to think seriously how much they are now doing to lessen the sum of human wretchedness around them, and that they will no longer take it for granted that "the authorities" take care of everybody who cannot take care of himself.

abstract: -- The question of the Republican nomination at Chicago may be considered settled. The Courier and Enquirer has pronounced for WM. H. SEWARD, and declares that, should either BELL, CRITTENDEN or BATES "ask to become the standard-bearer, in the name of the Republican Party it must respectfully decline the honor intended to be conferred upon it, and bolts in advance!" In other words, the Courier and Enquirer will deal with anybody but Mr. SEWARD precisely as it dealt with Mr. HASKIN when that gentleman was nominated for Congress -- leave him to be elected by other people. Perhaps, remembering the fate of Mr. HASKIN, the Republicans will not be seriously discouraged by this prospect. We pity the misguided creatures if this should be the case. The Courier and Enquirer may have small influence in New-York; but in the Union at large its power is literally tremendous. This power, too, is impregnable, having been handsomely earned by a strict regard to all the decencies of life. In the very proclamation to which we now allude, the noble qualities of the Courier and Enquirer shine forth conspicuously. A miserable correspondent of the NEW-YORK TIMES having dared to hint that there was talk among the Republicans at Washington of BATES as their candidate for the Presidency, is promptly put down as a "corrupt and unprincipled knave," and we ourselves are demolished for harboring the malicious wretch, by being informed that we are "propagating an infamous falsehood." The sense, spirit, courtesy and courage displayed in these brave words are their own recommendation; and they should inspire in the Republican heart a fresh terror at the thought that a single misstep at Chicago will inevitably cause their author to "bolt."

abstract: In the House of Commons on the 27th ult., Mr. M. MILNES said his noble friend at the head of the Foreign-office would not be surprised at his rising to ask what effect had been given to the address of this House presented to her Majesty on the 2d of August last, with respect to cases of violence and cruelty committed on board of American ships engaged in the traffic between this country and the United States. The picture, he regretted to say, had since been considerably darkened, and acts of gross and cruel murder had been added to the catalogue of crimes. A few days after the address was presented occurred the case of the sailor ANTONIO, who died in the hospital at Liverpool. Upon the inquest a solicitor appeared on the part of the American Government, denying altogether the jurisdiction of the Court, and saying, not without acuteness, "That it was an American transaction on board an American ship, and with which no one but Americans had anything to do. If they had killed the man then and there the case might have been one of murder or manslaughter within American jurisdiction; but, as he had died at Liverpool in consequence of injuries inflicted in the course of the voyage, the jury could bring in no other verdict than 'Found dead.'" And that was the result of the inquest. He would not trouble the House with a recital of these frequent occurrences, but there was one which occurred only on the 14th of January last. Two American mates of the bark Anna were brought before the magistrates of the Isle of Wight, charged with having put to death, under circumstances of-great cruelty and violence, no less than six sailors between America and England, or one-half the whole crew. A gentleman, who represented himself as the agent of the American Government, appeared and put in question the jurisdiction of the Bench. He claimed that the mates were American subjects, and that if they had committed any offence it was upon the high seas, or more than a league from the British coast. The magistrates had been blamed, and he thought unjustly, for having discharged to sailors. It was wrong to say that they were guilty of the horrible crimes charged against them, but it was a very significant fact that a smile passed over their faces when the non-jurisdiction of the Court was established. There was no doubt that the impunity attending such grave crimes was telling mort detrimentally upon our own merchant service. In a case of great violence the other day, it was given in evidence that the captain said: "How I regret I am under English law! If I were under American law I could do anything I chose to my men." The American Chamber of Commerce at Liverpool had represented the matter as strongly as possible to their fellow-counter men at home. Great interest was felt upon the subject in America, and no doubt the American Government would cooperate with the English Government in trying to find a remedy for a grave and growing evil. The noble lord, the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, was not one likely to lack zeal in the cause of humanity. The right honorable gentleman, the Secretary of State for the Home Department was no tyro in matters of international legislation, and between the two he trusted something would be accomplished.

abstract: A NEW MOVEMENT FOR SAVING LIFE AT FIRES. -- A Preliminary meeting was held last evening at No. 140 Hester-street, the object of which was to discuss the propriety of forming a Fire Company to be called the "Life Protectors," upon the plan of the P[???]piers of Paris. These organizations are conducted upon military principles, each division being thoroughly drilled in the particular part assigned it. There is no excitement, and no noise, everything being done by signs, or by well understood rules of proceeding. By the use of ingeniously contrived ladders the tallest building is scaled, ropes are dropped, and the escape bag hauled up to any desired point of the burning building; the inmates are then sent down, one after the other, safely to the street. A variety of models were shown, intended to facilitate escape from burning dwellings. They consisted, among others, of a form of bucket to be attached to each window frame, from which the occupants of a house can be lowered by means of a pulley and basket, when other modes of escape have been cut off; a variety of ladders, capable of being extended so as to reach any story from the street; a permanent iron ladder to be hung upon the outside of the house from a window; contrivances to be attached to the inside of any window, with pullies and canvas buckets to lower persons from the upper stories. There is also a kind of "snake," through which a rope is run, and by which a person can graduate his descent to the ground. None but a practiced person, however, could use it, and to a notice it would be worse than useless as a means of safety. The projector of this movement is Mr. STRUMINGER, who has had large experience in this kind of engineering, and who was employed in various parts of Germany in drilling these Zouaves of the flames for their peculiar duties. No organization has yet been made. Experiments are first to be tried, and should due encouragement be given, in due time the Company will be formed.

abstract: The Senate's amendment to the Post-Office Appropriation bill was rejected yesterday in the House by a decisive vote--the Republicans generally voting against it. The effect of this rejection will be to delay indefinitely the passage of the bill. It must now go back to the Senate, and, with renewed discussion and Committees of Conference, and all the compli
lead_paragraph: The Senate's amendment to the Post-Office Appropriation bill was rejected yesterday in the House by a decisive vote--the Republicans generally voting against it. The effect of this rejection will be to delay indefinitely the passage of the bill. It must now go back to the Senate, and, with renewed discussion and Committees of Conference, and all the complications of legislation, weeks may elapse before final action can be taken on it. In the meantime, the creditors of the Government must manage to get along as they can without their pay, and the country must be reconciled, as best it may, to the probability that a salutary measure of reform, the adoption of which on its own merits, public sentiment, if public sentiment were regarded, would have made compulsory on members, will be defeated, at least for this session of Congress, on merely and baldly technical grounds.

abstract: A narrative of the expulsion of the Rev. Mr. FEE and tome Seventeen friends of his from Kentucky, because of their well-known Anti-Slavery proclivities, was delivered last night by Rev. Mr. ROGERS, himself one of the exiles, in the Baptist Church in Twenty-eighth-street, near Broadway. The services were conducted by Rev. D.M. GRAHAM, the Pastor. At first the audience was
lead_paragraph: A narrative of the expulsion of the Rev. Mr. FEE and tome Seventeen friends of his from Kentucky, because of their well-known Anti-Slavery proclivities, was delivered last night by Rev. Mr. ROGERS, himself one of the exiles, in the Baptist Church in Twenty-eighth-street, near Broadway. The services were conducted by Rev. D.M. GRAHAM, the Pastor. At first the audience was so meagre that it did not number twenty persons, all told. In the hope that by delay the attendance would be enlarged, the pastor gave out several hymns. Eventually the congregation increased to about fifty, of whom three-fourths were ladies. Rev. Mr. ROGERS (who is quite a young man) offered prayer. His address was prefaced by some remarks of the pastor, who alluded to Slavery as an utter barbarism, "the sum of all villaines," the oppression of our fellow-beings under the form of what they call, in some of the States; the corner-stone of Republican liberty.

abstract: The announcement of the death of Senator BRODERICK in the Senate on Monday, besides calling forth the eulogies due to the character of the deceased, led to a small discussion between Mr. FOSTER, of Connecticut, and Mr. TOMMBS, of Georgia, upon the subject of dueling. Mr. FOSTER somewhat inappropriately took occasion, in concluding
lead_paragraph: The announcement of the death of Senator BRODERICK in the Senate on Monday, besides calling forth the eulogies due to the character of the deceased, led to a small discussion between Mr. FOSTER, of Connecticut, and Mr. TOMMBS, of Georgia, upon the subject of dueling. Mr. FOSTER somewhat inappropriately took occasion, in concluding his testimony to the late ex-Senator's virtues, to discharge his conscience by an expression of doubt as to whether the manner of Mr. BRODERICK's death did not render him an unfit subject for the posthumous laudations of the body to which he had belonged. The question, he said, was, "Should the Senate pay a tribute to a man who had willfully risked his life in violation of the laws of God and man?"

abstract: Mr. Ranney, the well-known gift bookseller, was again taken into custody yesterday; this time on complaint of Valentine Yehling, who charges that the accused engaged him to act as collecting and office clerk, requiring a deposit of $160 as surety for the faithful discharge of his duties. In a day or two [???] he desired Mr. Yehling to undertake an agency in Pennsylvania, requiring him to sell books by subscription and without samples, transmitting all orders to New-York. This the complainant declined to undertake, and desired to dissolve connection with his employer, Mr. Ranne[???] gave him his [???] for the $100 which he had d[???]d with him, and allowed it to go to protest, th[???] foundation for the complaint of procuring money by false representations, on which accused was arrested. At Police Headquarters Mr. Ranney was confronted by Augustus wolfing, of Williamsburgh, who alleges that he swindled him out of a deposit of $50; by Francis Porcella, of No. 17 Baxter-street, who says that he has lost $98 by Mr. Ranney, having deposited with him $105, and received only $7 for services performed; and by Geo. Rule, of No. 221 William-street, who charges that he was swindled by the accused out of $100. Mr. Wright, of Charleston, S.C., also states, by letter, that he ordered $30 worth of books from Mr. Ranney. The letter inclosing the money was registered at Charleston, and its receipt acknowledged at the New-York office; but Mr. Wright states that he has never heard from Mr. Ranney in reply. The accused is held for examination.

lead_paragraph: Ever since my "Aromatic Schiedam Schnapps"--the purest and best Gin for medical purposes--became sully appreciated throughout this country, I have been constantly solicited by druggists, apothecaries and large numbers of the most eminent physicians, in all parts of the Union, to add to my Gin importations pure Brandies and Wines, and to bottle them the same as I am and have been doing with the Schnapps; to seal with my seal and give my certificate guaranteeing their undoubted purity.

abstract: A recent number of the Avalanche, a paper published in Memphis, is overwhelming in its contempt of the Union meetings which have been held at the North. Our terrible contemporary thinks that it should be made "an indictable offence to sing hallelujahs to the Union, not that an honest patriotic laudation of the Union is objectionable of itself, but because the
lead_paragraph: A recent number of the Avalanche, a paper published in Memphis, is overwhelming in its contempt of the Union meetings which have been held at the North. Our terrible contemporary thinks that it should be made "an indictable offence to sing hallelujahs to the Union, not that an honest patriotic laudation of the Union is objectionable of itself, but because the mouths of demagogues and notoriety-seekers should be stopped in spite of themselves," and hence goes on to remark with singular point and force that "an indecent libation of praise is not the way to preserve the Union." It is a matter of profound regret that our Southern contemporary should not be better pleased with the attempts of conservative men in this section of the country, to assure the South of their sincere desire to secure it in the full enjoyment of all its rights under the Constitution, and to maintain fraternal relations with it; but we venture timidly to suggest that the fault is not altogether with ourselves. The Avalanche, we fear, itself somewhat at fault in the matter -- does not want to be pleased, and takes a tempestuous pleasure in chaos and calamity.
headline: {'main': 'An Avalanche on Adoration.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'An Avalanche on Adoration.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

lead_paragraph: We are once more enabled to lay before our readers the draft in full of an important National Treaty, in advance of its official publication. The Treaty and conventional articles negotiated with Mexico by Mr. McLANE, and now awaiting confirmation by the Senate, will be found to-day in the columns of the TIMES A careful perusal of the provisions of these most interesting documents will, we think, convince the most skeptical of the gravity of the interests which are involved, and of the skill with which this great negotiation has been conducted by our Minister.

lead_paragraph: The jury in the case of David Beach, alais Leach, charged with forging a check on the Nassau Bank, for $3,146, purporting to be drawn by Robert Bonner, of the Ledger, in favor of A.M. Davis, and indorsed by Davis and Bonner, were unable to agree, after having been absent many hours. The Recorder seat them cut of Court to renew their deliberations, but they again returned, after a considerable interval, and stated that there was no likelihood of their agreement. They were, therefore discharged. The defendant in this case was remanded to the Tombs, and will be tried again.

abstract: The South is threatening vigorously to annibilate the North by non-intercourse unless it speedily alters its opinions on the subject of Slavery. Goods of all kinds are to be imported direct to Norfolk and Charleston from France and England, and thence distributed to all the towns, cities and villages of the Slave States. Not a yard of calico, or flannel, or broadcloth,
lead_paragraph: The South is threatening vigorously to annibilate the North by non-intercourse unless it speedily alters its opinions on the subject of Slavery. Goods of all kinds are to be imported direct to Norfolk and Charleston from France and England, and thence distributed to all the towns, cities and villages of the Slave States. Not a yard of calico, or flannel, or broadcloth, is to grace the person of a Southern knight or dame which, on this side of the Atlantic at least, has passed through the tainted hands of Abolitionists. The Southern seaports are to become great importing centres, and to be entirely managed by Southern men. Moreover, the whole country south of Mason and Dixon's line is to be studded with manufactories. The hum of the cotton-gin is to be sweetly blended with the rattle of the power-loom. In sight of every plantation is to rise the tall chimney of a factory, and the cunning hands that are to weave and spin therein are to be the hands of docile and dexterous Africans; unlike the white operatives of New-England in this, that they will be contented with their lot, and confident about their future. To complete the picture: All these mighty enterprises are to be lodged in the hands of Southern men. The scheming, conspiring Yankees are to be driven home to their native rocks and sands, and the great web of industry that is to cover the sunny South, like a rich and gorgeous veil, is to be the work of Southern hands -- of weavers whose contempt for the children of Ham will be as unchangeable and steadfast as the curse which was laid so long ago upon the heirs of Canaan, the "bender of knees."
headline: {'main': 'The South and Non-Intercourse.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The South and Non-Intercourse.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: ITEMS.--The annual distribution of certificates to the pupils of Public School No. 15, took place in the Westminster Presbyterian Church yesterday. The
lead_paragraph: ITEMS. -- The annual distribution of certificates to the pupils of Public School No. 15, took place in the Westminster Presbyterian Church yesterday. The Trustees of this School are making arrangements to have it continued in temporary quarters until the building recently destroyed can be rebuilt......A carman was convicted before Justice CORNWELL yesterday for violating a city ordinance by obstructing the City Railroad cars.......A woman named ROSE fell from one of the South Eighth-street ferry-boats on Monday night, as the boat was entering the slip, and would have been drowned but for the prompt assistance rendered by the officers of the boat.... The alarm of fire at 11 o'clock yesterday, in the Eastern District, proceeded from the stable of GEORGE MERKLES, No. 50 Montrose-avenue. Loss, $50.... The fireman, GALLAGHER, injured at the Sanford-street explosion, was considered better yesterday, and there is a chance for his final recovery. The Coroner's Jury will reassemble today.... A man named O'HARA was arrested on Monday night by officers TONNEY and BROWN, of the Third Precinct, for firing a store at the corner of Van Brunt and Carroll streets. He will be arraigned for examination to-day .... The regular monthly meeting of the Young Men's Christian Association was held last evening, when an essay was read and the usual discussion followed, after which the subject of establishing a gymnasium was considered. A majority of the members present were decidedly in favor of carrying the project into effect

abstract: Great excitement has existed in and around Port Ewen, Ulster County, during the last two or three days, in consequence of a shocking and bloody affray which occurred on the ice opposite that village on Saturday afternoon last, about 3 o'clock. The facts are as follows: Two brothers, named
lead_paragraph: Great excitement has existed in and around Port Ewen, Ulster County, during the last two or three days, in consequence of a shocking and bloody affray which occurred on the ice opposite that village on Saturday afternoon last, about 3 o'clock. The facts are as follows: Two brothers, named RILYEA, with a friend, all residing at Esopus. Ulster County, were sailing in an ice-boat on the river on Saturday afternoon. After amusing themselves for sometime, they fastened the boat to the dock at Port Ewen, and went into a tavern to drink. While there, three Irishmen took possession of the boat, loosed it from the dock, and sailed to the middle of the river, where they were observed by one of the brothers, who instantly went to them and demanded the boat. The Irishmen refused to surrender it, and angry words ensued. During the altercation, young RILYEA unfastened the tiller and threatened to drive out the occupants of the boat. Upon this, one of the Irishmen drew a knife from his pocket and stabbed the unfortunate youth in the heart, inflicting a fatal wound. The remaining brother and his friend witnessed the transaction from the shore, and immediately started for the scene of the affray. Before they arrived at the boat, however, they came to the place where the elder RILYEA lay, and seeing that he was dying, rushed towards the boat to take revenge. After a short fight, one of the Irishmen seized the titter and struck the friend of the brother a severe blow upon the head, which felled him senseless. HIRAM RILYEA then repaired to the tavern where he procured a pistol, and returning to the boat shot one of the Irishmen, killing him instantly. He then turned and ran for the shore in the direstion of Rondout, followed by the remaining Irishmen, where he arrived in advance of them, and instantly gave himself up to the authorities. The brothers RILYEA were 20 and 22 years of age respectively. The one who was killed was buried on Sunday. Both the offenders have been arrested.
headline: {'main': 'Bloody Affray on the Ice at Port Ewen.; TWO MEN KILLED, ONE FATALLY WOUNDED, AND ANOTHER BADLY HURT.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Bloody Affray on the Ice at Port Ewen.; TWO MEN KILLED, ONE FATALLY WOUNDED, AND ANOTHER BADLY HURT.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The treaty concluded with the Liberal Government of Mexico by Hon. ROBEAR McLANE, as Plenipotentiary of the United States, Dec. 14, 1859, is now awaiting ratification in the Senate. Conceiving it to
lead_paragraph: The treaty concluded with the Liberal Government of Mexico by Hon. ROBEAR McLANE, as Plenipotentiary of the United States, Dec. 14, 1859, is now awaiting ratification in the Senate. Conceiving it to be equally important that the public should be prepared to pass not only upon the stipulations of this Convention, but upon the action of the Senate in regard to it, we this morning lay the authentic text before the readers of the TIMES. Having been the first to present to the world a synopsis of these negotiations, it is quite proper that we should also be the first to make public the entire instrument.

abstract: The United States vs. Two Packages containing Jewelry.--The testimony in these two cases was continued to-day. Mr. Archer, another inspector, testified that he was one of the officers who boarded the Asia, and that he saw Gorospe and Lizardi there; that he saw a jewel case on Lizardi's person, and after he came off the ship he asked him if he had anything on his person, to which Lizardi said he had not;
lead_paragraph: The United States vs. Two Packages containing Jewelry.--The testimony in these two cases was continued to-day. Mr. Archer, another inspector, testified that he was one of the officers who boarded the Asia, and that he saw Gorospe and Lizardi there; that he saw a jewel case on Lizardi's person, and after he came off the ship he asked him if he had anything on his person, to which Lizardi said he had not; that the officer insisted however on searching him, and found a diamond bracelet, and also a case of jewelry, which Lizardi said belonged to his friend. He also testified that there were a couple of traveling bags on board, in the Purser's room, which, on inquiry, Lizardi said were not his, and then that they were his, and then that one was his, and one was not, and that jewelry was found in the bags.

abstract: -- A proposition is before the Legislature of Maryland to forbid future manumissions of slaves, and to give free colored people the option to leave the State or be reenslaved The Baltimore Daily Exchange opposes both branches of this measure, and observes of the latter: "In Anne Arundel, Baltimore, Carroll, Frederick, Hartford and Washington counties, there are over 43,000 free blacks who are employed in menial services and in agricultural operations. Of these there are in Baltimore County alone more than 7,000 males, between fifteen and sixty years of age. The withdrawal of such a proportion of the laboring class could not but be severely felt by all, and to many of the smaller farmers it would be absolutely ruinous. The demand for laborers, thus suddenly created, could not possibly be supplied in time to prevent the most disastrous consequences."

abstract: Whether the good St. Valentine was a burly bishop, or but a simple priest, still remains an open question; but all the world is agreed, we believd, that he was a kind and gentle saint as ever lived, and for his many deeds of love and charity became the unconscious patron of emotions which we are unfortunately bound to believe his own ascetic heart was never suffered to indulge.
lead_paragraph: Whether the good St. Valentine was a burly bishop, or but a simple priest, still remains an open question; but all the world is agreed, we believd, that he was a kind and gentle saint as ever lived, and for his many deeds of love and charity became the unconscious patron of emotions which we are unfortunately bound to believe his own ascetic heart was never suffered to indulge. The martyr of CLAUDIUS has played the Friar to all the Romeos and Juliets of Christendom for thrice five hundred- years -- a friar most Christian and democratic -- disdaining no condition in life, but rapping with an equal double knock at the hut of the peasant and at the palace of the prince. He has been the carrier-pigeon of centuries; the derider of locksmiths has invoked him in every land which owns a chapel or a saint, and turned to the fourteenth of February as the true May-day of the lover's year. Verily, if the good old confessor himself was, from his own honest heart, disposed to exclaim, with POFE's Eloise.

abstract: The London Money market drain of bullion from the Bank of England continued on even a larger scale; the reported withdrawal since the date of the last return, amounting to no less than £592,000. An active demand for discount also sprang up at the Bank on the 30th. Under these circumstances, at the commencement of business on the 31st, the announcement went forth that the minimum rate of discount was advanced from 3 to [???] cent. The rise was regarded with general satisfaction, but did not stop the drain of gold, the withdrawals for that day amounting to £80,000. A fresh advance was considered certain in a short time, should the draw continue. The demand for Money at the Bank was extremely active, notwithstanding the advance of 1 [???] cent. On the Stock Exchange, where loans had a day or two previously been done at 2 1/2 cent., 5 [???] cent. was demanded.

abstract: Mr. QUINBY last evening spoke on the Honey Bee, and began by showing that bee-keeping was more profitable, with the same capital, than most other kinds of business. In 1856, he said that 800 hives, on an area of ten square miles, collected 42,000 pounds of honey, and increased to 1,200; and yet it is probable that not a tithe of the honey was collected. Mr. QUINBY estimated the average yield of 100 "stocks" at over 3,000 pounds, and this would give a profit over all expense of ten cents to each pound. These could be kept on an area of four square miles, and one man could take the entire charge of them.

abstract: Mrs. BURNS, who is now giving readings with Little ELLA in Philadelphia, was on Monday served with a writ of habeas corpus, based upon facts set forth in the petition of Mrs. E.F. ELLET and others, requiring the immediate production of Little ELLA in Court, there to show cause why she should not be returned to her natural guardian. The friends of Mrs. BURNS gave the required security, and the further hearing of the case was postponed until Friday, to-morrow These proceedings seem to be a repetition of those had in this City some months ago, when, as all will remember, the claims of Mrs. BURNS to the custody of the child were considered stronger than those of the father of Little ELLA.
lead_paragraph: Mrs. BURNS, who is now giving readings with Little ELLA in Philadelphia, was on Monday served with a writ of habeas corpus, based upon facts set forth in the petition of Mrs. E.F. ELLET and others, requiring the immediate production of Little ELLA in Court, there to show cause why she should not be returned to her natural guardian. The friends of Mrs. BURNS gave the required security, and the further hearing of the case was postponed until Friday, to-morrow These proceedings seem to be a repetition of those had in this City some months ago, when, as all will remember, the claims of Mrs. BURNS to the custody of the child were considered stronger than those of the father of Little ELLA.

abstract: -- The Oxford (Me.) Democrat gives the following account of an affray between two schoolmates: "RIDLON, one night after school, tore up a seat and ripped off some boards from the ceiling of the school-house. WADSWORTH, who, with one other boy, was present, desired him not to destroy the house, and on reaching home told his adopted father of the in jury to the building. The father warned RIDLON to discontinue such practices. The next day, after they had eaten their dinners at noon, RIDLON approached WADSWORTH, saying, 'Now, I have got you,' and kicked him several times. WADSWORTH, after the first kick, begged him to desist, saying, 'You have broken my side in.' WADSWORTH immediately went home, in much distress, and died a week from the day he was injured. A Coroner's inquest was held. The physicians made a report upon the appearance of the corpse and the immediate cause of death, but did not decide whether this was produced by the injuries inflicted. The verdict of the jury was in accordance with the report of the post mortem. The verdict was not satisfactory, and RIDLON was arrested on the charge of murder, and, after a lengthy examination, committed for trial."
lead_paragraph: -- The Oxford (Me.) abstract: -- A correspondent of the Illinois State Journal, writing from Sumner, Ill., says: In the New Light Church, last Sunday, a young man named WILLIAM BARLOW, seated in the congregation, attempted to commit suicide by cutting his throat with a pocket knife. He first cut the principal artery in each arm, and then inflicted a horrible gash in the throat, aiming, no doubt to cut the jugular vein, but not knowing its precise location, missed it. When first discovered he was seen holding his head on his left hand, while the blood was trickling down the side of his neck and arms. When asked about it, he insisted that nothing was the matter, and requested to be let alone. He was carried out and soon fainted. On being restored to consciousness, he called for the knife, saying: "I will soon finish it." The unfortunate man assigned no reason for his rash act, but the general impression is that he was laboring under a fit of insanity.
lead_paragraph: -- A correspondent of the Illinois State Journal, writing from Sumner, Ill., says: In the New Light Church, last Sunday, a young man named WILLIAM BARLOW, seated in the congregation, attempted to commit suicide by cutting his throat with a pocket knife. abstract: -- The St. Louis Republican, Feb. 13, says: "We learn that the State Savings Association of this city dispatched two messengers -- Messrs. MCCLUNEY and PRESCOTT -- in charge of some $55,000 in bills on the Chillicothe Branch of the State Bank and on one of the Banks at St. Joseph, with directions to demand the specie for it. The amount on the Chillicothe Bank was $29,000. Yesterday the Cashier of the State Savings, Mr. ROSENFELD, heard from these messengers by telegraph from Chillicothe. In their dispatch they inform him that they could not get a dollar in specie, that the citizens prevented, and that mob law was in the ascendant.

abstract: At the meeting of the Board of Education last evening, the School Board of the Twenty-first Ward applied for an appropriation of $2,000 for hot-air furnaces to heat the school building on Twenty-seventhstreet. The general subject of heating and ventilating these structures was then considered, many members declaring that there is not one public school building in the City properly heated and ventilated. Finally, the following resolution was offered:

abstract: Vence vs. Speir. -- This was an action in trespass for taking away and disposing of the plaintiff's furniture. The questions before the jury were: First -- Did the plaintiff establish that this was his property? Second -- Did the defendant participate in taking it away? The plaintiff's wife, it appears, had obtained a legal separation from him for alleged cruel treatment -- after first arresting and imprisoning him. After the arrest, she ordered her furniture to be sold by Henry H. Leeds & Co., the auctioneers, as her own separate estate. Leeds & Co. paid over the proceeds to the defendant, the counsel of plaintiff's wife, who afterwards accounted to her for it. It appeared that the defendant had acted as the counsel and adviser of the plaintiff's wife for a long time prior to her marriage with the plaintiff, and up to the time of the separation.
lead_paragraph: Vence vs. Speir. -- This was an action in trespass for taking away and disposing of the plaintiff's furniture. The questions before the jury were: First -- Did the plaintiff establish that this was his property? Second -- Did the defendant participate in taking it away? The plaintiff's wife, it appears, had obtained a legal separation from him for alleged cruel treatment -- after first arresting and imprisoning him. After the arrest, she ordered her furniture to be sold by Henry H. Leeds & Co., the auctioneers, as her own separate estate. Leeds & Co. paid over the proceeds to the defendant, the counsel of plaintiff's wife, who afterwards accounted to her for it. It appeared that the defendant had acted as the counsel and adviser of the plaintiff's wife for a long time prior to her marriage with the plaintiff, and up to the time of the separation.

abstract: At the debate this morning, ASHBEL FULLER, Esq., of Vermont in the chair, Judge FRENCH was called to the stand to be questioned. In answer to queries concerning the repairs of drains, he advised every farmer to make and keep a plan of his drains in order that he might know just where to find them in case he wanted to get at them. It is true, he said, that a farmer who put in his own drains would have a general knowledge [???] and the bursting out of the water would indicate in case of obstruction nearly the precise spot, but by means of an accurate plan he could at once strike the exact spot he wanted. System is essential to perfect work of any kind. If springs intervene between your regular lines, don't vary your lines, but put in a short drain to the spring from the nearest line. Silt basins are sometimes put in but generally are not necessary, inasmuch as drainage-water is usually clear.
lead_paragraph: At the debate this morning, ASHBEL FULLER, Esq., of Vermont in the chair, Judge FRENCH was called to the stand to be questioned. In answer to queries concerning the repairs of drains, he advised every farmer to make and keep a plan of his drains in order that he might know just where to find them in case he wanted to get at them. It is true, he said, that a farmer who put in his own drains would have a general knowledge [???] and the bursting out of the water would indicate in case of obstruction nearly the precise spot, but by means of an accurate plan he could at once strike the exact spot he wanted. System is essential to perfect work of any kind. If springs intervene between your regular lines, don't vary your lines, but put in a short drain to the spring from the nearest line. Silt basins are sometimes put in but generally are not necessary, inasmuch as drainage-water is usually clear.

abstract: The Arago, at this port, and the Prince Albert at Saint John's, Newfoundland, extend our foreign advices to Feb. 4. The news is without striking interest. In the House of Commons, Lord JOHN RUSSELL had declined to produce the papers relative to the annexation of Savoy to France, but said that Count WALEWSKI, prior to his resignation, had given assurances that no such project was enter- ...
lead_paragraph: The Arago, at this port, and the Prince Albert at Saint John's, Newfoundland, extend our foreign advices to Feb. 4. The news is without striking interest. In the House of Commons, Lord JOHN RUSSELL had declined to produce the papers relative to the annexation of Savoy to France, but said that Count WALEWSKI, prior to his resignation, had given assurances that no such project was entertained by France. On a question of appointing a Committee to investigate the miscellaneous expenditures of the country, the Ministry had been beaten by a majority of 28. The London Post, the organ of the Premier, announces that England and France are allied on the Italian question, and that no intervention will be permitted. It is also stated that the consolidation of Central Italy with Sardinia is regarded by both Governments as the only proper solution of the Italian problem. The discontent in Hungary was becoming so serious as to excite grave apprehensions at Vienna.

abstract: On Saturday night a disturbance occurred in a house of ill-repute, No. 41 Thomas-street, where degraded negroes and whites indiscriminately conduct their orgies. lead_paragraph: On Saturday night a disturbance occurred in a house of ill-repute, No. 41 Thomas-street, where degraded negroes and whites indiscriminately conduct their orgies. During its continuance, one Mary Stewart, a white woman, was so severely beaten that she was rendered insensible, in which condition she remained until her death resulted in consequence of the injuries she had sustained. The police knew nothing of the affray until Tuesday evening, as the parties interested have endeavored to keep it secret. As soon as Capt. Hutchings was informed of it he dispatched Officer Fields to inquire into the circumstances, and, yesterday, he arrested Ephraim Huso, Enoch Folks, James Griffiths, negroes, and Ann Styles, a white woman, on suspicion of having been engaged in the fight. The woman Styles says that Huso was the person who beat the injured female, but Elenora Jackson, Huso's daughter, says that Folks confessed to her that it was he who struck the blows. The police have been unable to ascertain how the brawl originated. The prisoners were committed by Justice CONNOLLY to await the result of the Coroner's inquest, which will take place to-day.

abstract: Commerce is beyond question the most powerful bond of peace that can unite nations together. The case of England and America illustrates the truth of this assertion. The business connections and necessities of these two countries are stronger guarantees for the continuance of amicable relations between them than even those sacred ties of blood, re- ...
lead_paragraph: Commerce is beyond question the most powerful bond of peace that can unite nations together. The case of England and America illustrates the truth of this assertion. The business connections and necessities of these two countries are stronger guarantees for the continuance of amicable relations between them than even those sacred ties of blood, religion and language which eloquent gentlemen are so fond of invoking after public dinners, when the wine is in and the wit comes freely out. Since the war of 1812, our commercial intercourse has become so intimate, our commercial interests so intermingled and amalgamated, that war between us seems all but impossible, and, should it ever arise, would prove almost equally disastrous to both of the infatuated belligerents. The conviction of this truth sinks yearly deeper into the public mind on each side of the Atlantic; and hence the nervous anxiety shown by the Governments and citizens of our respective Empires to settle San Juan disputes and naval outrages, even faster than a busy Press or hair-brained officers can create them. It is but fair, therefore, to the Emperor of the French to assume that his new economical policy has originated as much in his desire of binding France and England to each other by the ties of reciprocal interest, as in his avowed motive of developing the resources, fostering the industry, and swelling the opulence of the people committed to his care. That NAPOLEON, in initiating his commercial programme, had the former not less than the latter object in view, is, indeed, conclusively demonstrated by his own conduct. Hardly had his letter to M. FOULD, on the principles of free trade as the basis of public policy, been given to the world, than its indefatigable author hastened to put himself into communication with Lord COWLEY touching the provisions of a new treaty of commerce between England and France -- a treaty which should open the ports and markets of both countries to the staple productions and manufactures of each, and prepare the way for the annihilation of all those restrictive enactments which have inflicted so many positive injuries on the industry of each, in return for very questionable advantages, and have educated their inhabitants to a perpetual forgetfulness of their own great stake in the preservation of peace. The moment the Emperor had exchanged views with the British Ambassador, and agreed with him as to the terms of the contemplated treaty, he urged that functionary to proceed immediately to London, and submit these terms to the consideration of his own Government. Lord COWLEY did as he had been requested; and the Foreign Secretary and Premier having approved of the instrument, their representative repaired once more to Paris, and, on the 23d ult., signed on the part of his sovereign a treaty, which, if fairly carried out, will prove in the future a source of innumerable blessings both to France and to England.

abstract: The new steamship R.R. Cuyler, of H.B. Cromwell & Co.'s Savannah line, which left this morning on a trial trip, when off the S.W. Spit, brose some portion of her machinery, and owing to the N.E. gale drifted ashore on the Stone Heap, between Sandy Hook and the Spit. She afterwards floated off, and the last seen of her was at 4:20 P.M., when she was in tow of the steamers Huntress and Underwriter, between the Spit and the Hook. She will, no doubt, anchor under the lee of the Hook, as it is snowing and blowing heavy.

abstract: A special meeting of the Common Council was held last evening. The Mayor's communication, vetoing the action of the Board confirming the election of Mr. SIMPSON as Assistant Engineer of the Fire Department, for the reason that he had not served the full time required by law in the Brooklyn Department, was called up for consideration, and a motion that the Board adhere to its former action; notwithstanding the veto of the Mayor, was lost. Another veto of the action giving the Grand-street Railroad route to the Flushing and New-York Railroad Company, was not called up, as there was an injunction served upon the Board. The Clerk was directed to readvertise for proposals to construct a railroad on Fifth-avenue and Grand-street. A report was received from the Water Commissioners, in which they say that 119 miles of supply pipe have been laid, and three miles of force-pipe. There are 681 single and 154 double fire hydrants. [???],678 permits have been issued, and the daily average delivery is now 2,000,000 gallons. There are 154 licensed plumbers. The following balance-sheet of the old Board of Water Commissioners was presented, which brings the transactions of the Department up to Nov. 10, 1859:

abstract: -- In accordance with a call from Hon. MILLARD FILLMORE, Chairman of the meetings which have previously been held in Buffalo with reference to the Germain steamship, another meeting was held on Saturday the 11th Inst. The Committee reported that it thought a steamship built in accordance with the theories of Mr. GERMAIN might attain a speed of 30 or 35 miles per hour. Resolutions were adopted thanking the Committee for its report, and declaring it to be the duty of Buffalo to take the lead in constructing such vessels. Before putting a motion to adjourn, Mr. FILLMORE considered it due to himself to state, lest his position in this matter should be misunderstood, that he was in a great measure unacquainted with the merits of the project under consideration, and that his part in the proceeding taken with regard to it had been accepted by himself, not from a knowledge of its practicable importance, but because he considered it a duty to assist in securing for it careful attention and thorough investigation, and because he was always anxious to take part in any movement directed to the promotion of the interests of Buffalo.

abstract: Kansas is again knocking for admission into the Federal Union. The Wyandotte Constitution was introduced into the Senate on Tuesday, and Senator SEWARD moved its reference to the Committee on Territories. The rumors of an intended opposition to the new State which had reached us from Washington were confirmed by the interposition of a resolution ...
lead_paragraph: Kansas is again knocking for admission into the Federal Union. The Wyandotte Constitution was introduced into the Senate on Tuesday, and Senator SEWARD moved its reference to the Committee on Territories. The rumors of an intended opposition to the new State which had reached us from Washington were confirmed by the interposition of a resolution by Senator BROWN, instructing the Committee to inquire whether the provisions of the English bill had been complied with, and by the remarks of Senator MASON, who took the ground that Kansas could not be admitted as a State without a violation of the law which required that a census of the population should be taken antecedent to the formation of a Constitution. It is also currently reported that should an act for the admission of Kansas pass both Houses of Congress, it will receive the veto of the President.

The defendants called as witnesses Mr. Tiffany, of the firm of Tiffany & Co., and Mr. Marcus, with Ball. Black & Co., who testified that they had examined the jewelry seized in these cases, and that almost all of the pieces had been worn, though some of it had such an appearance as that an ordinary observer would not notice that it had been worn; and that the amount of jewelry was by no means a large one for such a family, especially a Mexican family. With this testimony the defendants rested their case.

abstract: Mr. ROBERT S. COLLINS, a prominent Whig and Republican politician, who was found lying in Thirteenth-street insensible on Monday morning last, died at the New-York Hospital on Tuesday night. Coroner GAMBLE investigated the circumstances of his death yesterday afternoon. It appeared from the evidence that deceased went in a carriage to the public house on the corner of Hudson and Bar
lead_paragraph: Mr. ROBERT S. COLLINS, a prominent Whig and Republican politician, who was found lying in Thirteenth-street insensible on Monday morning last, died at the New-York Hospital on Tuesday night. Coroner GAMBLE investigated the circumstances of his death yesterday afternoon. It appeared from the evidence that deceased went in a carriage to the public house on the corner of Hudson and Barrow streets about 12 o'clock on Sunday night. At that time he was under the influence of liquor, but persisted in taking several additional drinks, and in about three-quarters of an hour he left, as he said, to go up town. When he was assisted to the carriage the driver was privately notified by the proprietor of the saloon to convey Mr. COLLINS to his own residence. This request, the driver testifies, he attempted to comply with, but on opening the carriage door on arriving in Lispenard-street, where deceased lived, he discovered his vehicle to be empty, and the opposite door open. It is supposed that Mr. COLLINS, discovering that he was traveling in a direction contrary to that which he desired, jumped out of the vehicle without the driver's knowledge, and thus received the injuries which resulted in his death. That he was discovered so far up town in so short a time after leaving the public house in Hudson-street, is only accounted for by the supposition that he rode up in a car after leaving the carriage. A post mortem examination resulted in showing that death had been produced by compression of the brain, caused by a fracture of the skull. The jury rendered a verdict in accordance with the facts, and recommended that measures be taken to provide medical attendance at the Station houses for persons confined while in a condition similar to that in which deceased was when brought in.

abstract: The Senate yesterday, by an almost unanimous vote, passed the bill introduced by Mr. GWIN, entirely abolishing the franking privilege. Various amendments were offered, but the, determination of Senators was evident either to have total abolition or nothing. The fate of the bill in the House is regarded at Washington as doubtful.
lead_paragraph: The Senate yesterday, by an almost unanimous vote, passed the bill introduced by Mr. GWIN, entirely abolishing the franking privilege. Various amendments were offered, but the, determination of Senators was evident either to have total abolition or nothing. The fate of the bill in the House is regarded at Washington as doubtful. The members of the House stand in a more intimate relation to their constituents than do the Senators, and they are more open to influences which would be likely to operate against the proposed reform. Elected directly by the people, and for a shorter term, they will naturally be more anxious to enjoy the facilities of communication which the privilege affords with those whom they represent, that they may thus increase the chances of reelection. It is to be hoped, however, that they will be willing to give the system of universal payment of postage a fair trial. We are satisfied that after a session's experience of relief from the drudgery of the everlasting franking of documents and of correspondence with everybody who thinks he has something of interest to communicate to "our member," or who has business with the Departments, that he would on no account be willing to saddle himself with a burden which prevents his giving proper attention to his legislative duties, and seriously interferes with his comfort and convenience. We regard the abolition of the frank as even more important in this view of it than as a measure of economy to the country; while it will establish in practice the only correct principle of requiring those to pay for the benefits of the mail service who receive them, and in the proportion in which they are received. The country will be the gainer by the change, by the enlarged mail facilities which the saving of the transportation of the great bulk of the matter which is now carried in the mails will afford, and possibly, at no very remote period, in a further reduction of postage.

abstract: TRIAL TRIP OF STEAMER R.R. CUYLER.--This new steamer, belonging to Cromwell's Line, went on a trial trip yesterday, having a large party of invited guests aboard. The heavy northeast snow-storm Which commenced about noon, interfered greatly with the pleasure of the excursion. The Cuyler was built by SAMUEL SNIDEN after the most approved models, and is 230 feet long, 33 wide and 16 deep.
lead_paragraph: TRIAL TRIP OF STEAMER R.R. CUYLER.--This new steamer, belonging to Cromwell's Line, went on a trial trip yesterday, having a large party of invited guests aboard. The heavy northeast snow-storm Which commenced about noon, interfered greatly with the pleasure of the excursion. The Cuyler was built by SAMUEL SNIDEN after the most approved models, and is 230 feet long, 33 wide and 16 deep. Her frame is diagonally strapped on the outside of the timbers, giving extra strength to her hull. The engine was built by the Allaire Works, under the super-intendance of Mr. BAIRD, and is of 70 inches diameter of cylinder, 48 inches stroke, and direct-acting. Her cabins are fitted up in substantial and even elegant style, to accommodate about two hundred passengers. The dining-saloon is separate from the state room deck, from which it is reached by a broad flight of stairs; and a handsome parlor, conveniently adjoining the dining-saloon, is set apart for the ladies. The forward and after cabins are connected by wide passages.

abstract: Mr. HICKMAN having practically "retired from business" as a hero, some of the partisan Republican journals are desperately trying to set him up again as a martyr. We do not think the operation likely to prove successful. The facts in the case of Mr. EDMUNDSON'S recent assault upon the member from Pennsylvania, while they are sufficiently discreditable to ...
lead_paragraph: Mr. HICKMAN having practically "retired from business" as a hero, some of the partisan Republican journals are desperately trying to set him up again as a martyr. We do not think the operation likely to prove successful. The facts in the case of Mr. EDMUNDSON'S recent assault upon the member from Pennsylvania, while they are sufficiently discreditable to the hot-headed Virginian offender, are very far from justifying the parallels which have been drawn between his conduct and that of Mr. BROOKS, of South Carolina, in the "SUMNER outrage." Mr. HICKMAN, not at all in debate on the floor of the House, but simply on his private responsibility, made a speech from a hotel-window at Washington to a crowd rejoicing over the election of Mr. PENNINGTON to the Speakership. In this speech he took occasion to taunt the whole State of Virginia with cowardice, and to caricature the events of the raid at Harper's Ferry in a way singularly offensive both to good taste and good feeling, and widely at variance with the truth. Mr. EDMUNDSON, one of the oldest members of the House from Virginia, it appears read this speech, as reported in the journals, with-natural indignation, and suffered himself to be stung by it into a state of rather superfluous excitement. Meeting Mr. HICKMAN in the Capitol grounds, he gave vent to his feelings after a very semi-civilized fashion, by slashing the offending Pennsylvanian across the face with a small twig, as little like the murderous bludgeon of gutta-percha with which the champion of South Carolina fell upon the unarmed Senator from Massachusetts, as Mr. HICKMAN's reckless post-prandial provocations were like the solemn and measured denunciations of Mr. SUMNER's famous oration.

abstract: Great excitement was created in Rochester, on Monday, by a cowhiding fracas. Mr. CPARLES PACKER, a dry goods clerk, invited a young lady, who is the cousin and ward of Mr. ELLIOTT, a carriage-maker, to attend a lecture with him. While on the way to the hall in a carriage which Mr. PACKER, had procured, and which the distance did not render necessary, he offered indignities to the young lady, which elicited such violent resistance and screams that the young man found it necessary to take her immediately home. On reaching there she alighted and entered the house without assistance. This circumstance, together with her short absence, attracted the attention of the lady with whom she boarded, and after close questioning she persuaded the young lady to make a statement of the facts, which was immediately communicated to her guardian. After thinking the matter over for a day or two he determined to chastise the offender publicly. PACKER's employers on being informed of the origin of the difficulty immediately dismissed him.
lead_paragraph: Great excitement was created in Rochester, on Monday, by a cowhiding fracas. abstract: MEETING OF THE MASTER BAKERS. A meeting of the master bakers of this City, Brooklyn and Williamsburgh, numbering about two hundred, met at No. 160 Heater-street, last evening, the object, as defined by the call, being "to adopt measures of selfprotection against the system of monopoly inaugurated by Mr. JOHN HECKER."
lead_paragraph: MEETING OF THE MASTER BAKERS. A meeting of the master bakers of this City, Brooklyn and Williamsburgh, numbering about two hundred, met at No. 160 Heater-street, last evening, the object, as defined by the call, being "to adopt measures of selfprotection against the system of monopoly inaugurated by Mr. JOHN HECKER." It appears that in consequence of large capital, and more extensive faculties, Mr. HECKER has been enabled to place the smaller bakers at a disadvantage in the size of the loaf which he sells, and in other ways to injure the business of the bakers. Being a manufacturer of flour, and, at the same time, carrying on the baking business, with agencies in almost every part of the City, the effect is damaging to the smaller capitalists, who have hard work to earn a living for their families. They state that Mr. HECKER places, his flour in the market with a Variety of brands, by which they are unable to distinguish it from any other flour, and they are thus often obliged to buy his flour, giving patronage to the man who is doing his best to break them down, and who declares it to be his intention to supply the entire City with his bread. Various plans of resistance were proposed. One, that the bakers should combine, and by going into the market with large capital, be able to purchase flour at as low rates as Mr. HECKER can manufacture or buy it. It was stated that the price now paid by bakers for the best flour was $6 50 per barrel, while at the rate Mr. HECKER sells his bread, it cannot cost him over $4 50 per barrel. It was also proposed that the bakers cease to purchase flour of those de[???]ers who bought Mr. HECKER's flour, and sold it to them under other and fictitious brands. Mr. SWANEY, who said he had been a baker for over thirty years, was in favor of using persuasive measures to obtain a redress of their grievances; and, after they had failed, to adopt the coercive plans proposed. He suggested that a Committee from the bakers be appointed to wait upon Mr. HECKER, and request him to give up his baking business, and confine himself to making flour, which was his legitimate business. During the effort to select this Committee, a proposition was made to adjourn, until they should have further time for consultation. The Chairman was authorized to call another meeting.

abstract: -- A match has been made between the Messrs. DOSWELL, the great turf representatives of the Old Dominion, and Maj. BACON, well known as one of the most popular and liberal sportsmen of Carolina, to run their two slashing three year old colts, Exchequer and Jonce Hooper, against each other at the Fall meeting on the Hawthorne Course, Camden. S.C., for the large stake of $10,000 a side. Exchequer has been running with rather chequered luck this season, twice defeating Nes Taylor at Savannah, and twice yielding; to Congaree at the late Charleston meeting. Jonce Hooper has not distinguished himself since entering upon his third year. He was sent to Savannah, but it is supposed got tampered with on the road, and was unable to appear at that meeting or since.

abstract: There is an ordinance in preparation to establish a Building Inspection Bureau, the expense of which shall not exceed $7,500 per annum. It is proposed to place it under the charge of a Superintendent and assistants, who shall be appointed by the Mayor. It will be the duty of the Inspectors to examine buildings within the limits of the City, and make quarterly reports, and all persons proposing to build will be required to file a notice with the Inspectors, giving a full description of the proposed structure, a statement of the use to which it is to be put, and when the work is to be commenced. A failure to give notice will be punishable by a fine of $1,000 -- one half to go to the informer. One of the object; for which the Bureau is to be created, is to collect information through which the erection of unsafe buildings may be prevented.

abstract: BENJAMIN REYBURN, who has been on trial at Westchester, Penn., charged with killing SUSAN EMMA REYBURN, was on Saturday, the 11th inst., convicted of murder in the second degree. The trial lasted more than a week. The circumstances of the the case were as follows: On the 25th of October last, in the southwestern part of Westchester County, the little girl in question disappeared after being seen in the vicinity of the field in which BENJAMIN REYBURN was plowing; on the next day a trail of blood and displaced leaves, a bloody stone of ten pounds weight, and the place of an apparent struggle were discovered in the margin of the woods adjoining the field in which REYBURN had been working; the trail led to a mill-pond in which, at a distance of forty feet from the shore, the body was discovered in the water, which was, at that place, some four feel deep; when the body was drawn upon the bank finger marks were found upon the throat, the head gashed and bruised in many places, and the person generally bearing marks of violence.
lead_paragraph: BENJAMIN REYBURN, who has been on trial at Westchester, Penn., charged with killing SUSAN EMMA REYBURN, was on Saturday, the 11th inst., convicted of murder in the second degree.
