abstract: The life of EDWARD BATES presents, in its outline, a resemblance to that of CLAY, JACKSON and others, who, born at the South, on the eastern side of the Alleghanies, and possessed of no inheritance save that of indomitable energy of character, crossed the mountains at an early age, and taking an active part in the movement of society around them rose with the rising tide to fame, if not to fortune.

abstract: This case assumed new interest yesterday.  Ira S. Chase, assistant to Mr. Holbrook, Special Post-office Agent, searched defendant's premises with the detective policemen, McDougall and Lefferts. Mrs. McNominy was present during the search; he...
lead_paragraph: This case assumed new interest yesterday. Ira S. Chase, assistant to Mr. Holbrook, Special Post-office Agent, searched defendant's premises with the detective policemen, McDougall and Lefferts. Mrs. McNominy was present during the search; he kept an eye on the servant girl while the search was going on; went next day and examined defendant's trunk, and found some memorandum books and one paper -- an assignment of a sewing-machine patent. Papers produced and identified.

abstract: Long before the opening of this Court, yesterday, the Court-room was crowded by citizens of all classes, anxious to witness the continuation of the trial of Wm. J. Lane, Jr., the alleged Fulton Bank defalcator.
lead_paragraph: Long before the opening of this Court, yesterday, the Court-room was crowded by citizens of all classes, anxious to witness the continuation of the trial of Wm. J. Lane, Jr., the alleged Fulton Bank defalcator. On the Judge taking his seat, the direct examination of Mr. Ronald M. Buchanan, Paying Teller of the Bank, was resumed by the assistant counsel for the prosecution, employed by the Bank -- not the Assistant District-Attorney -- as follows: There was a change made in the manner of payments to Lane, Jr., on account of making collections; the check (No. 8) was paid by me; it was drawn by W.J. Lane, Sen., and indorsed by the defendant, W.J. Lane, Jr.; there had been some objection to the way of payment, and the defendant was told that hereafter the checks would be placed to his father's credit, and entered on his father's check book; the date of this check (No. 8) is Feb. 15, 1859; the defendant prior to this date had been in the habit of receiving payment from the second Teller by tickets, for several years, for collections on "foreign" notes, in favor of A.B. Dean, usually, if not altogether; I do not know of any other notes entered on the "Foreign Register," to the credit of anybody but A.B. Dean; I refer to collections to the credit of W.J. Lane, and W.J. Lane, Jr.; these notes were purporting to be payable to A.B. Dean; I know of no others but those purporting to be payable to A.B. Dean; the defendant had charge of this "Foreign Register" during all the time that these entries were made; the second-teller tickets were made from the "Foreign Register" by the defendant; in crediting collections made for discounting bills, the notes were put on the "discount tickler;" from that "tickler" the amount of bills discounted was put on the General Ledger of the Bank; from the "tickler" to the note-book, and from the note-book to the General Ledger; they got from the "Foreign Register" to the "tickler," through the medium of the ticket. [Witness examined several entries in the ledger, and pronounced them to be the handwriting of the defendant.]

abstract: A gentleman who recently retired from a highly-respectable Manchester house, in consequence of the deep involvement of his private affairs, died a few days ago, with liabilities to the amount, as currently reported, of £70,000, towards meeting which there will be very few assets; £43,000 of his liabilities consisted of money borrowed from a single individual. His life was insured to the amount of £10,000, but some of the policies were mortgaged to creditors. He is said to have died from disease of the heart, but there is no doubt that the involved state of his affairs hastened his death.

abstract: Whatever be the amount of evil which, in the opinion of many persons, the French laws restricting the liberty of the Press may work, there are very few, we fancy, who will not have experienced the satisfaction which a display of poetic justice always inspires, on witnessing the extinction of the Paris Univers, by the very weapons which it has so often invoked against its own enemies.
lead_paragraph: Whatever be the amount of evil which, in the opinion of many persons, the French laws restricting the liberty of the Press may work, there are very few, we fancy, who will not have experienced the satisfaction which a display of poetic justice always inspires, on witnessing the extinction of the Paris Univers, by the very weapons which it has so often invoked against its own enemies. No one who remembers the infuriate ravings which this organ of the Middle Ages directed against EDMUND ABOUT, and the clamor with which it called on the Police for the suppression of his terribly witty book on Rome, can regret its being treated to a dose of its own medicine, and sent to defend its masters in exactly the same latitude to which ABOUT was exiled for assailing them.

abstract: The annual assay at the United States Mint in this city, commenced at 10 o'clock this morning. The following named gentlemen form the special commission appointed for the purpose by the President of the United States: Dr. H.W. Gibbs, of Columbia, N.C. Dr. J.C. Hall, of Washington City; Hon. James M. Porter, of Easton, Pa.; Dr. T.A.P. Barnard, President of the University of Mississippi; Dr. Zina Pitcher, of Michigan; Prof. Thos. C. Porter, of Lancaster, Pa.; Prof. Robt. Bridges, M.D., of Philadelphia; Dr. Henry J. Anderson, of New-York; Hon. Asa Packer, of Mauch Chunk. Pa. The ex officio Commissioners consist of the Hon. John Cadwalader, Judge of the United States Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania; James C. Vandyke. Esq., United States District Attorney for the same district, and Joseph B. Baker, Esq., Collector of the port of Philadelphia. The Assay usually occupies two or three days, during which time the Mint will not be open to visitors. -- Evening Bulletin, 13.

abstract: At noon, yesterday, Mr. STEPHEN WHITNEY, one of the oldest and wealthiest of our citizens, died at his residence in Bowling-green. Some of his intimate friends state that he was but 70 years of age, while others affirm that he had completed his 80th year. He entered business, in this City, at an early period of his life, and has always been considered strictly upright in his dealings, but at the same time close and sharp in effecting bargains. These characteristics laid the foundation for a fortune which has accumulated of late years, until it is estimated at the enormous amount of $8,000,000. Much of this immense property consists of real estate, a large proportion of which is situated in the First Ward. He also had large amounts of money invested in productive mortgages, and stocks and bonds of various descriptions. Up to the time of his decease, Mr. WHITNEY devoted his time to a great extent to collecting rents and to supervising the repairs which it was found necessary to make in the numerous buildings which he owned. Busied in this manner he was seldom seen on. 'Change. In fact, he was not of a speculative character and it is said that the misfortunes which a few years since overtook some of his relatives, who were engaged in the grain trade, involved him only to a limited extent. Perhaps no fact exhibits this conservative element of his character more forcibly than his persistent refusal to follow his old acquaintances and neighbors who, years ago, resigned their downtown mansions to look for more quiet and fashionable homes in the upper part of the City. For the last fifty years Mr WHITNEY has resided on Bowling-green. In politics he was one of the oldest of the Old-Line Whigs, and a warm supporter of HENRY CLAY, for whose advantage he is said to have contributed liberally. Mr. WHITNEY leaves a large number of children and grandchildren. His eldest son-in-law. Hon. J. PHILLIPS PHOENIX, retired from business many years ago, after having acquired a large fortune, and died at his residence, which was in the immediate vicinity of the home of Mr. WHITNEY, twelve or fourteen months ago.

abstract: - On Tuesday afternoon, as the debate on the Betterment law was progressing in the Hall of Representatives at Boston, Mr. JAMES CLARK, who was sitting on one of the rear benches, listening to the remarks made by the different gentlemen, was observed to rise from his seat and to fall backwards. Those in the vicinity endeavored to assist him, but it was announced that be was dying, and the House immediately adjourned. Mr. CLARK lived but 45 minutes after he was attacked. The physicians, who were immediately summoned, judged that he had been seized with a fi[???] of apoplexy, though he was not predisposed to the disease. He was for many years of the firm of SCOTT & CLARK, pump and block makers, in Ann-street, Boston, held the office of Alderman in that city during the years 1840 and 1841, under the administration of JONATHAN CHAPMAN, has been member of the Senate and House of Representatives, Engineer in the Boston Fire Department, and President of the Massachusetts Charitable Mechanics' Association. His age was about 71 years.
lead_paragraph: - On Tuesday afternoon, as the debate on the Betterment law was progressing in the Hall of Representatives at Boston, Mr. JAMES CLARK, who was sitting on one of the rear benches, listening to the remarks made by the different gentlemen, was observed to rise from his seat and to fall backwards. Those in the vicinity endeavored to assist him, but it was announced that be was dying, and the House immediately adjourned. Mr. CLARK lived but 45 minutes after he was attacked. The physicians, who were immediately summoned, judged that he had been seized with a fi[???] of apoplexy, though he was not predisposed to the disease. He was for many years of the firm of SCOTT & CLARK, pump and block makers, in Ann-street, Boston, held the office of Alderman in that city during the years 1840 and 1841, under the administration of JONATHAN CHAPMAN, has been member of the Senate and House of Representatives, Engineer in the Boston Fire Department, and President of the Massachusetts Charitable Mechanics' Association. His age was about 71 years.

abstract: The great Racket match between WM. DEVOY and LA MONTAINE -- both professional Racket players -- for $500 a side, came off yesterday in the court of the New-York Racket Club, No. 384 Bowery. LA MONTAINE has been the champion player for some time, but lately DEVOY has beaten him, giving the odds of two aces in a game of fifteen. This match was played at that odds on each game -- the one who should score three games in five to be declared the winner. The reputation of both the players for proficiency in the game, and the large stake, attracted quite a crowd of amateurs and others interested in the game, or having bets on the result. It is said that several thousand dollars were staked on the game, the odds being generally on DEVOY. For the benefit of the uninitiated, it may be stated that the principle of the game is simply the batting of a ball against a wall -- the man who bats it last, under certain specified conditions, counting a point.

abstract: JAMES, Earl of Southesk, a live lord from Scotland, recently came to this country on a visit, and on a Cunard steamer, and after a tour of pleasure, we believe, and of profit, we trust, reached Jersey City on the Erie Railroad, on his way home, at 12 1/2 P.M. yesterday. As soon as he had alighted from the cars he inquired among a crowd of bystanders at the depot whether the Asia had sailed. He received a response in the affirmative, and a person who -- the Earl says in an affidavit which he afterwards had occasion to make at the Mayor's office -- had the general appearance of a railroad employe, obligingly informed him that he would guide him to an office at which he could learn all that he wanted to know regarding the sailing of all steamers from Portland or from Boston. So they proceeded together to an office on Cedar-street, where his lordship was informed that the Canada, of the Cunard line, would sail from Boston on the 22d inst. The clerk who told him this advised him to take passage in a steamer from Portland, but this the nobleman declined to do. The clerk said he would give him a cabin in the Canada, and told another person in the office to go and reserve a cabin in the Canada by telegraph. Then he called the earl into an ante-room, and asked him to register his name. This done, he was required to pay to another clerk $275 for his own and his servant's passage. He did so, and presently the man who had been sent to telegraph to Boston, returned and reported that it was "all right." Then my lord was requested to pay $25 more; there had been a mistake in demanding only $275. The earl demurred; the price was greater than he had paid for a passage from England. That made no difference; it always cost more to go to England than to come from there -- a fact that the swindler in this instance would have realized had be been on British soil. Further, the clerk said there was an extra charge for securing the cabin, and something he said about paying for previsions; he might have charged several dollars more. Finally his lordship paid the extra charge and left the office without looking at the ticket, further than to ascertain that the signature was genuine. Not long after, in examining the ticket he perceived that the amount for which it was a receipt was only $225. Then the light broke upon him. He had been swindled out of $75. He found his way to the Mayor's office, made his affidavit, and an officer was dispatched to the ticket office, who arrested the proprietor, ISAAC SELOVER and brought him before Alderman PECK, the acting Mayor SELOVER stou[???]y denied the charge, but Alderman PECK decided to commit him and refused to take bail. Finally, when the swindler found that there was no other way of escaping punishment, he gave up the $75 and was permitted to depart "I wouldn't have paid it," he said, as he started to go, "only it is California steamer week, and I can't afford to lose my time!"

abstract: The Norristown (Penn.) Herald says: "A German peddler, named MOSES SOHLOSSTEIN, well known in this, place, and who has pursued his business in this region, was the victim recently of a gross outrage in Georgia. He was selling his wares in Merriweather, one of the western counties of the State, about sixteen miles from Greenville, the county seat. He was passing a blacksmith shop, where there was a crowd gathered, and saluted them politely, as traders generally do. But the "non-intercourse" fever forbade them to reciprocate the civility. They seized him and proceeded to beat him unmercifully. This assault was an outburst of chivalrous feeling, and then feigning a suspicion of his having "incendiary documents" in his possession, they followed and caught him again. With their knives they ripped open his pack, cutting his goods to pieces; they then stripped him, beat him outrageously, and left him insensible. When he returned to consciousness, he found that he was cut about the face and body, and that the thumb of his right hand was broken. He gathered together his ruined goods, and fortunately found a fearless and hospitable man who kept him ten days, when he was able to travel."

abstract: A special meeting of the American Geographical Society was held last night in the lecture room of the Historical Society.
lead_paragraph: A special meeting of the American Geographical Society was held last night in the lecture room of the Historical Society. The immediate purpose for which it was held was to commemorate the services to the cause of physical knowledge of CARL RITTER, of Berlin, whose labors entitle him to the distinction of being regarded as one of the greatest Geographers of the age. The attendance was not large. Rev. Dr. HAWKES, the President of the Society, occupied the chair. After the purely formal business of the evening had been disposed of, a series of resolutions was offered by Lieut. -VIELE on behalf of the Committee, to whom had been referred a resolution, the gist of which was a recommendation that the Society ask that the people of the United States give their aid to the scientific exploration proposed by their fellow-member, Dr. HAYES, having for its objects a continuation of the explorations of the late Dr. KANE, and a confirmation of the discovery of the open Polar Sea. The report was accepted and the appended resolution adopted unanimously.

abstract: Dr. Breda, of Natchitoches Parish, La., has devoted much time to experiment with grapes. The result, says the Natchitoches Union, is the complete success of his efforts in producing grapes of the most superior quality, and a demonstration of the fact that wine can be raised profitably, with comparatively little expense.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Breda, of Natchitoches Parish, La., has devoted much time to experiment with grapes. The result, says the Natchitoches Union, is the complete success of his efforts in producing grapes of the most superior quality, and a demonstration of the fact that wine can be raised profitably, with comparatively little expense. By grafting the best varieties from France upon the wild grape vines that grow so [???]riantly in the parish, he has now bearing plants that cannot be excelled in Europe. The Union predicts the raising of wine in North Louisiana, at no distant period, which will command the suffrages of amateurs.

abstract: The Wyandotte Constitution of Kansas had its fling from the Democratic side of the Senate yesterday, Mr. MASON taking occasion to deny that there were any evidences of its authenticity, or that it was properly before the Senate.
lead_paragraph: The Wyandotte Constitution of Kansas had its fling from the Democratic side of the Senate yesterday, Mr. MASON taking occasion to deny that there were any evidences of its authenticity, or that it was properly before the Senate. Then the concurrent resolution appropriating $3,000 for the expense of inaugurating a wretched statue of WASHINGTON in the wrong place, was debated. Mr. HALE made himself and his auditory merry over the pseudo works of art with, which the capital is disfigured, signalizing especially the spurious dog which guards one entrance of the Capitol, and PERSICO's "Columbus," likened by the facetious Senator to a dissipated player of nine-pins. The appropriation was passed. The bill of Mr. SLIDELL, prohibiting the issue of bank-notes in the District of Columbia, was discussed, but, without action, postponed to Monday. Previous to adjournment, Mr. BROWN gave notice of a bill to provide for the protection of slave property in Kansas. In the House, Mr. KEITT offered, but subsequently withdrew, a resolution providing for the adjournment of Congress on the 6th of June. Among a large number of bills and resolutions introduced and referred, the more important were those of Mr. TAYLOR, providing for the purchase of Cuba; of Mr. BRIGHAM, for the abolition of Congressional mileage; of Mr. SHERMAN, censuring the President and Secretary of the Navy for negotiating improper contracts, and reorganizing the Post-office Department; of Mr. HOWARD, granting pensions to the Soldiers of 1812; of Mr. VALLANDIGHAM, increasing the annual appropriation for arming the militia to $600,000. Mr. ANDERSON, of Missouri, after the States had all been called, obtained the floor for an able and vigorous speech in opposition to the Republican platform, which Mr. FENTON, of this State, replied to with equal force and eloquence. The election of Printer was deferred until to-day.

abstract: The Aldermen's Committee on Wharves, Pierz and Slips met at 2 P.M. yesterday, in Room No. 8 City Hall, to consider the properiety of directing that the Battery enlargement be completed.
lead_paragraph: The Aldermen's Committee on Wharves, Pierz and Slips met at 2 P.M. yesterday, in Room No. 8 City Hall, to consider the properiety of directing that the Battery enlargement be completed. Ex-Judge Bronson, Counsel to the Corporation, and Street-Commissioner Smith were present. The former said that, in his opinion, the contract for the enlargement of the Battery, originally entered into with Henry Conklin, had, by its terms, expired; that, even if it had not, it was [???]ull and void ab initio; and that the Common Council had a right to enter into a new contract for the completion of the work. A letter from the Commissioners of Pilots, calling attention to the inroads made into the channel about the Battery, at the junction of the East and North Rivers, by deposits from the extension, and the necessity of erecting a seawall, and a communication from Mayor Tlemaun in relation thereto, were before the Committee. Mr. Edward Ewen, Superintendent of Street Improvements, said that, according to the original bid, a parapet wall could be constructed about the Battery for $30,000. Alderman SMITH said that all that remained for the Committee was to report in favor of directing that the work be Completed, and the Committee adjourned.

abstract: Justice CONNOLLY issued a warrant a few days since for the arrest of David Marvin, formerly a member of the firm of D.  J.R. Marvin, merchants, lately of Troy, N.Y., who is charged with having made false representations to Messrs. Bowen, Holmes  Co. and defrauded them to the extent of $1,701,71.
lead_paragraph: Justice CONNOLLY issued a warrant a few days since for the arrest of David Marvin, formerly a member of the firm of D. J.R. Marvin, merchants, lately of Troy, N.Y., who is charged with having made false representations to Messrs. Bowen, Holmes Co. and defrauded them to the extent of $1,701,71. It is alleged that application was made by the accused last March to the complainants for the purchase of a bill of goods on 8 months' credit, and that they finally assented to his request, after he had given written guarantees of his responsibility. Subsequently the Troy merchants failed, and it is now charged that they were bankrupt when they obtained the goods from Bowen, Holmes & Co., who have been unable to get their money. It is also charged that these goods were sent back to this City and sold at auction for the personal benefit of the Messrs. Marvin, and that their creditors were defrauded of the proceeds. Officer Barron, of the Lower Police Court, yesterday brought Mr. Marvin down from Troy, and Justice CONNOLLY held him for examination.

abstract: -- The annual exhibition of the junior class at me Michigan University, which was to have taken place on Thursday evening last, was prevented by a serious accident resulting from another case of imperfect building. The exercises were to have taken place in the Union School Hall, in the City of Ann Arbor, and the room was already nearly filled when it was discovered that the floor was beginning to settle. A panic at once took possession of the audience, which was increased by the falling of one of the seven iron columns that supported the roof. This was a result of the settling of the floor, the column thereby loosened at the top. In falling it struck four persons, one of whom it is feared is ratally injured. Fortunately, here the damage ended, and the remainder of the crowd were permitted to escape. The names of the injured parties are as follows:

abstract: The circumstances attending the death of MARY STUART, an abondoned female, who died on Wednesday afternoon at a disceputable place, No. 41 1/8 Thomas-street, from the effects of a beating, received on Sunday evening, were investigated yesterday by Coroner SCHERMER.
lead_paragraph: The circumstances attending the death of MARY STUART, an abondoned female, who died on Wednesday afternoon at a disceputable place, No. 41 1/8 Thomas-street, from the effects of a beating, received on Sunday evening, were investigated yesterday by Coroner SCHERMER. It was shown that deceased had become involved in a quarrel with a young colored man named ENOS FOULKE, respecting a small amount of money. Finally FOULKE struck the woman on the head with his fists, knocking her down and rendering her insensible. She remained in an unconscious condition from that time until her death. FOULKE acknowledged to EPHRAIM HUSE, the proprietor of the house where the affray occurred, and also to DANIEL WILLIAMS, one of the inmates, that it was he who inflicted the blows, but, supposing the we man would recover, they failed to call the attention of the Police to the matter. Dr. GEORGE B. BOUTON testified that he had made a post-mortem examination of deceased, and found that death resulted from compression of the brain, which had been superinduced by violence. The jury agreed with the Doctor in his opinion, and charged that the blows had been inflicted by FOULKE. The prisoner stated that he was born in Philadelphia, and worked along shore. With reference to the charge, he said that he did not think that he had caused the woman's death. Coroner SCHIRMER committed him to prison to await the action of the Grand Jury, and detained HUSE and WILLIAMS as witnesses. Deceased was a Scotchwoman, about 33 years of age, and formerly gained a livelihood by peddling apples.

abstract: That enterprising journal, the Southern Confederacy, of Atlanta, Ga., has just run afoul of a snag, which has apparently knocked a hole through the bottom of this piratical craft, and has seriously damaged its cargo of "White lists" and "Black lists," even if it does not swamp it altogether.
lead_paragraph: That enterprising journal, the Southern Confederacy, of Atlanta, Ga., has just run afoul of a snag, which has apparently knocked a hole through the bottom of this piratical craft, and has seriously damaged its cargo of "White lists" and "Black lists," even if it does not swamp it altogether. The Pennsylvanian, whose pure Democracy and Southern sympathy are above all suspicion, in an article of yesterday upon the "Philadelphian Black list," after stating that its acquaintance with the "political character" of the mercantile houses set down in the list "enables us to speak with entire confidence and without the fear of contradiction," adds, "in accordance, therefore, with that knowledge, we are constrained to remark that JAMES PINCKNEY HAMBLETON, editor and proprietor of the Southern Confederacy, in reference to the Philadelphia houses, has departed from the truth so willfully and glaringly as to place himself in the category of venal libelers."

abstract: ITEMS. The Consolidated Ferry Company, between the Eastern District and New-York, have fixed upon three cents as the fare for foot passengers, unless the tickets are purchased by the hundred, when the price will be two cents....A man named BRANNI-...
lead_paragraph: ITEMS. The Consolidated Ferry Company, between the Eastern District and New-York, have fixed upon three cents as the fare for foot passengers, unless the tickets are purchased by the hundred, when the price will be two cents....A man named BRANNIGAN was arrested, yesterday, by Officer WADDY, of Fourth Precinct, for having a counterfeit $3 bill on Bank of Pemberton....Coroner MURPHY held an inquest, yesterday, on the body of MICHAEL CLARK, who was run over, on Wednesday, by a wagon and instantly killed. A verdict of accidental death was rendered....The City Railroad Company commenced, on Wednesday last, to sell twenty-five tickets for $1 on all of the routes under the control of this Company....A man named POWERS was on Thursday night, found by the Police of the Third Precinct, completely covered up in a snow drift. He was intoxicated, and had lain down to take a nap when the snow-storm came on and enshrouded him. He had $105 in his pockets.

abstract: The Southern mind, in a good many States, is just now agitated by the question, What had better be done with free negroes? Arkansas, with a magnificent disregard for vested rights, as well as for the claims of humanity, has solved the question by driving them out pell-mell.
lead_paragraph: The Southern mind, in a good many States, is just now agitated by the question, What had better be done with free negroes? Arkansas, with a magnificent disregard for vested rights, as well as for the claims of humanity, has solved the question by driving them out pell-mell. Tennessee was about to follow her example, when she was prevented by the energetic remonstrance of Judge CATRON, of the Supreme Court of the United States. Maryland is now laboring in the throes of anxious cogitation over the same vexed question. The Commission appointed by the House of Delegates to consider the condition of the free colored population in that State has just presented its report. It sets down the number of ownerless blacks at 90,000, and states that it is steadily on the increase; that their freedom confers no right on them, except that of not working if they do not like it, and charges them with preferring crowding into the cities, and picking up a precarious livelihood by small jobs, in preference to engaging in the hard but useful labor of the farms in the country. The report ends with the usual call for legislation, to make this black population more useful to the whites, and to prevent emancipation in future.

abstract: Our public servants at Albany are proposing to bring back the good old times that existed many generations ago, when it was a favorite measure of despots to seek to establish, by legislative or executive decrees, the rate of compensation that should be paid for a given quantity of merchandise or service.
lead_paragraph: Our public servants at Albany are proposing to bring back the good old times that existed many generations ago, when it was a favorite measure of despots to seek to establish, by legislative or executive decrees, the rate of compensation that should be paid for a given quantity of merchandise or service. Their experiments were most commonly made upon the currency. They created it. The life of the subject hung upon their will. Having the power, no process, apparently, could be easier or more simple than "to raise a revenue" by fixing the nominal value of the sixpences and shillings they uttered at twice their actual value. But no power could force the debased coin upon the public. As soon as the cheat was detected, it returned to plague the inventors, throwing the loss almost entirely upon their shoulders.

abstract: -- Thirteen columns of the Buffalo Republic are occupied with a report of the proceedings of a great charity festival given in that city on the 9th inst. abstract: On the 13th inst., DENIS TUBRIDY, an aged shoemaker, residing in Yorkville, fell over a stone wall on the west side of the track of the Harlem Railroad Company, between Eighty-sixth and Eighty-seventh streets, and the next morning was found dead, his body lying across the track.
lead_paragraph: On the 13th inst., DENIS TUBRIDY, an aged shoemaker, residing in Yorkville, fell over a stone wall on the west side of the track of the Harlem Railroad Company, between Eighty-sixth and Eighty-seventh streets, and the next morning was found dead, his body lying across the track. Coroner GAMBLE held an inquest, but the jury were unable to determine whether the deceased was killed by the fall or from having been run over by a passing train. The following verdict was given: "That the said DENIS TUBRIDY met with his death by falling over the stone wall on the west side of the Fourth-avenue, between Eighty-sixth and Eighty-seventh streets, upon the railroad track of the New-York and Harlem Railroad Co., on the evening of Monday, the 13th inst., between the hours of 4 and 7 o'clock; we further find that the wall which had been until within eight or ten days sufficiently high to prevent persons falling over upon the railroad track, not having been raised sufficiency high by the Railroad Company, was the immediate cause of the accident which befell the deceased, but whether the deceased was killed by the fall over the wall into the cut, or was killed by the train running over him, the jury are unable to determine. We further find that the New-York and Harlem Railroad Company have been guilty of gross neglect and culpable indifference in not building the wall on the west side of said avenue, after they had pulled the old wall down, of sufficient height as before, which would have, in the judgment of the Jury, prevented this sad accident, and that if the Company or its servants had performed their duty the same accident would not have occurred. We further find, and hereby certify that the condition of the walls between Seventy-ninth and Ninety-second streets have been for a long time, and now are, in a highly dangerous condition, including the bridges; and respectfully but earnestly suggest that the same be laid before the Grand Inquest of the County of New-York for indictment, or such other action as may suggest itself to that honorable body."

abstract: Our advices from Buenos Ayres reach to Dec. 23. The Indian marauders had been attacked on the  5th of December by Col. MACHADO, as they were driving off their booty.
lead_paragraph: Our advices from Buenos Ayres reach to Dec. 23. The Indian marauders had been attacked on the 5th of December by Col. MACHADO, as they were driving off their booty. The Argentine troops cut them to pieces in detail, killing 115, among whom were the Cacique and two Capitanejos, and rescuing from twenty-five to thirty thousand head of horned cattle, a considerable number of mares, and one captive who had been the wife of the Cacique. The Indians are believed to have numbered 400, many of whom escaped.

abstract: The Rocky Mountain News Extra, of Feb. 3, says:  On Monday, 30th ult., a portion of Denver City, on which there was but little improvement, was "jumped" by parties who immediately commenced  the erection of houses thereon.
lead_paragraph: The Rocky Mountain News Extra, of Feb. 3, says: On Monday, 30th ult., a portion of Denver City, on which there was but little improvement, was "jumped" by parties who immediately commenced the erection of houses thereon. The next morning a meeting of the "Claim Club" was called, and resolutions passed -- peaceful in character -- which which were published in our regular issue of Wednesday morning, Upon the adjournment of the meeting, the members of the Club present -- about eighty in number -- proceeded to the ground where the jumpers were at work, to warn them to desist. When within about one hundred yards of the building they were warned to halt, and rifles were immediately leveled upon the crowd by the four men at work on the building. A council was held, after which JOHN C. MOORE, Mayor of the city, advanced to hold a parley with the jumpers. He was peaceably received, and on his return reported that there were in the building some forty guns, heavily charged, and that the parties assured him that they would fight to the death rather than give up.

abstract: The case was resumed yesterday. Francis J. Beyer testified that he knew Williams; that he worked for him at his oyster saloon No. 74 Williamstreet; he paid him $9 the first week, and afterwards ...
lead_paragraph: The case was resumed yesterday. Francis J. Beyer testified that he knew Williams; that he worked for him at his oyster saloon No. 74 Williamstreet; he paid him $9 the first week, and afterwards he agreed to stop four weeks at $6 per week. Three or four weeks ago witness advertised for a partner, and defendant offered to buy him out, and after a week or so, defendant paid him a check on the Citizens' Bank for $460 payable to "John" or bearer and signed "James Simpson;" the date of the check was not remembered; the book-keeper got it certified; it was in part payment on the place; he made no other payment, and as they could not agree witness returned him the check, and they had no other business transactions.

abstract: SEMI-ANNUAL EXHIBITION OF COLUMBIA COLLEGE. The capacity of Hope Chapel was by no means sufficient to accommodate the numbers who flocked thither, yesterday morning, to attend the Semi-annual Exhibition of Columbia College;
lead_paragraph: SEMI-ANNUAL EXHIBITION OF COLUMBIA COLLEGE. The capacity of Hope Chapel was by no means sufficient to accommodate the numbers who flocked thither, yesterday morning, to attend the Semi-annual Exhibition of Columbia College; a great many were unable to obtain admission, and it was regretted that the exercises had not taken place in a larger hall. Declamations were delivered by ten students -- two from each of the four classes, and two representing respectively the Peithologian and Philolexian (literary) Societies. The orators were William C. Binns and Almar P. Webster, of the Freshman Class; Charles A. Spencer and Walter Cutting, of the Sophomore Class; Wm. H. Caswell and George Lansing, of the Junior Class; Edward L. Greenwood and Abraham Suydam, of the Senior Class; Langdon Greenwood, of the Peithologian Society, and T.H. Messenger, of the Philolexian Society. The Freshmen and Sophomores spoke selected pieces, and the orations of the Juniors and Seniors were original. That of Mr. CUTTING received the most applause, and to him the first prize was awarded. Messrs. SPENCER and TAYLOR received the prizes of the second best. President KING, in announcing the award, stated that the prizes were given for the best delivery, and the composition of the original orations were not taken into consideration. Why it was not, or why I should not be, he did not explain. He eulogized Mr TAYLOR's effort -- a poem called "The World's Hope' -- and said that gentleman would have received the first prize if the literary excellence of his production had been thrown into the balance. The President announced the names of the excelling five in each class They were as follows: Seniors, Wm. F. Whitehouse. J.H. Van Amoriage, Robert Goelet, Jr., Egerton L Winthrop and John W. Jenks. Juniors, Frederick C, Whitehouse, William A. Rice, Gratz Nathan, Wm H. Caswell and Elisha Horton, Jr. Sophomores, C. Sigourney Knox, David B. Oliphant, Charles K. Riley, J.N. Vanderpoel and Wm. A. Hegeman. Freshmen, Dan. Marvin, Jr., Henry E. La Combe, Francis L. Newcome, R.C. Hall, and Robert S. Tucker. After the benediction had been pronounced, and while the audience, three-fourths of which wore crinoline, was gradually dispersing, the students, who all the morning had been exceedingly quiet, made the hallway hideous with their cheers for him who had carried off the first prize, and with their groans for a policeman who endeavored to keep them quiet. Afterwards they gathered in the Chapel and vociferously called upon Mr. CUTTING to address them. He complied, thanking them for their expressions of gratification at the honor conferred on him, and concluded by advising them, for the credit of their Alma Mater, to disperse without making any more noise. They acted on the suggestion after a little delay, and thus ended the semi-annual racket match.

abstract: Mr. A.H. Ernst, a prominent Abolitionist, died at his residence in Cincinnati, on the 13th inst. He was born in Germany, but came to this country early in life, and settled in Cincinnati as a baker. By this trade lie amassed a handsome fortune, but was so unfortunate as to become embarrassed through the misfortunes in which members of his family were involved, and was obliged to make an assignment of his property, for the benefit of his creditors, but a few months before his death.

abstract: NEWS ITEMS. Two constables were arraigned in the Court of Sessions yesterday, for carousing with a prisoner on Thursday evening.
lead_paragraph: NEWS ITEMS. Two constables were arraigned in the Court of Sessions yesterday, for carousing with a prisoner on Thursday evening. The officers took the prisoner (LAMBERTSON) from the court-room in the afternoon, and did not reach the jail until 10 o'clock at night. Judge GARRISON reprimanded the officers, and stated that a repetition of the offence by any one would be severely punished....A sexton of the Church on the Heights was arrested Thursday night for shooting pigeons in violation of one of the city ordinances. He produced a permit from the Mayor, but this could not be recognized by the officer, and the accused was remanded for a hearing before Justice CORNWELL.... The Mercantile Union Association, organized three weeks ago, held heir first regular meeting last evening in the Polytechnic Institute. There are fifty members enrolled....A woman named MARY ANN SPENCE, residing on Myrtle-avenue, near Grand-street, was seriously burned yesterday, by the explosion of a fluid lamp.....The alarm of fire at 1 o'clock yesterday morning proceeding from the store of Mr. PRINCE, No. 183 Fulton-avenue, resulted in a loss of $50 The average number of inmates of the Kings County Lunatic Asylum is 300, or about 75 more than can well be accommodated....PATRICK ROURKE broke his leg yesterday, by a fall in a brewery on Wyckoff-street, E.D. He was taken to the City Hospital.

abstract: On Wednesday afternoon while the family of A.S. Solomons, Esq., residing at No. 157 Lexington  avenue, were at tea, a burglar obtained access to the house by means of a latch-key, and proceeding to the third story packed up a number of silk dresses and a ...
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday afternoon while the family of A.S. Solomons, Esq., residing at No. 157 Lexington avenue, were at tea, a burglar obtained access to the house by means of a latch-key, and proceeding to the third story packed up a number of silk dresses and a set of furs worth $500, then breaking open a desk secured $500 in coin and notes that it contained With this booty he was about to make off when his progress was arrested at the head of the first flight of stairs by the lady of the mansion, who demanded to know his business and what were the contents of the bundle that he had. The burglar, a stout negro, attempted to pass Mrs. Solomons, but she seized the bundle and struggled for its possession. The negro thereupon struck her several violent blows on the head and face, knocking her down. The noise, meantime, attracted the attention of the gentlemen of the family, at whose approach the burglar fled; escaping, however, with only about $25 of the money, the furs, dresses and remainder of the cash, having been scattered by the fugitive all the way from the place where the scuffle occurred to the front door. Mrs. S. was rendered nearly insensible by the blows which the ruffian dealt her; but by the courage which she displayed over $1,000 worth of property was saved from the thief.

abstract: It is quite unnecessary for the TIMES ever to proclaim its own victories in the way of enterprise. They are invariably followed by a yell of despair from the New-York Herald, so shrill and loud and dissonant as to compel the attention ...
lead_paragraph: It is quite unnecessary for the TIMES ever to proclaim its own victories in the way of enterprise. They are invariably followed by a yell of despair from the New-York Herald, so shrill and loud and dissonant as to compel the attention of everybody to the cause which provokes so portentous a clamor. Of late the occasions for these lamentations have occurred so frequently, that the outcries of our dilapidated contemporary have fairly run into one continuous incoherent shriek. In great things and in small he is so constantly outstripped, that he no sooner begins to subside from screams into sobs over one defeat than he is suddenly electrified into a fresh outburst over another, and accordingly gratifies his readers with a prolonged and heterogeneous ululation much more discordant and not at all more profitable than the baying of Irish wolves against the moon.

abstract: A meeting, called by some of our prominent citizens, was held last night in the City Assembly Rooms, for the purpose of giving expression to the sentiments of the people of America who sympathize with the cause of Italian Independence.
lead_paragraph: A meeting, called by some of our prominent citizens, was held last night in the City Assembly Rooms, for the purpose of giving expression to the sentiments of the people of America who sympathize with the cause of Italian Independence. It was so largely attended that many of the audience were obliged to take seats in the aisles, and others who were unable to avail themselves of that convenience, were obliged to content themselves with standing-room. Mr. JAMES W. BEEKMAN was chosen Chairman. Addresses were delivered by Rev. J.P. THOMPSON, Rev. HENRY WARD BEECHER and Rev. H.W. BELLOWS; by Hon. CHARLES KING, L.L.D., President of Columbia College; Mr. JOSEPH HOXIE and Prof. O.M. MITCHELL. With the exception of a momentary interruption caused by a gentleman who was presumed to be either drunk or crazy, the proceedings were marked by singular unanimity. The principles urged in the Napoleonic pamphlet of Le Pape et le Congres were enthusiastically indorsed, and the rights of the Italians to independence of the Roman See, unanimously asserted and ably vindicated.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. Great disappointment was experienced, last night, at the sudden announcement of a change of opera.
lead_paragraph: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. Great disappointment was experienced, last night, at the sudden announcement of a change of opera. Madame GAZZANIGA, it will be remembered, was to have made her appearance in the character of Saffo, -- a character peculiarly fitted for the display of her great dramatic and musical powers. BRIGNOLI was to have sung the tenor part, but this delicate tenor was, it seems, unwell at the critical moment, and, consequently, no "Saffo" could be given. Mme. GAZZANIGA, of course, refused to appear in any hastily substituted opera, and hence "Der Freischutz" enjoyed another performance, and a good one, under the direction of Mr. THEODOR THOMAS. The house would have been crowded; as it was there was quite a fashionable audience.

abstract: About 1 o'clock yesterday morning fire was discovered rising from the grocery and dry goods store of WM. EVANS, at the foot of Main-street, in Tarrytown.
lead_paragraph: About 1 o'clock yesterday morning fire was discovered rising from the grocery and dry goods store of WM. EVANS, at the foot of Main-street, in Tarrytown. Only three or four persons were near at the time, but in a few moments there were hundreds, which in a short time increased to thousands. There is no regularly organized fire company in Tarrytown, but everything that could be done under the circumstances, by the citizens, was accomplished. The flames first spread to the dwelling of Mr. EVANS, adjoining the store; from thence to the large dwelling owned by the same gentleman and occupied by Mr. PURDY; it then communicated to the large two-story dwelling occupied by Mr. MANNERLY; thence to a two-story house occupied by several small families. The fire then communicated to a one-story house on the opposite side of the street, and this, together with the sash and blind factory and the large two-story house adjoining, owned by Mr. JACOB STORMS, was presently wrapped in flames. No less than eight buildings were burning at the same time. The loss is variously estimated, but it will probably not exceed $20,000. Mr. EVANS' loss is from twelve to fourteen thousand dollars. There was a partial insurance up on the property. The origin of the fire is unknown.

abstract: The arrival of the Arabia and the Borussia, the former from Liverpool, and the latter from Southampton, on the 4th inst., supplies interesting intelligence from the Old World. In regard to the rumored acquisition of Savoy and Nice by France it would appear, notwithstanding the tranquillizing assurances of Lord JOHN RUSS$ELL, that the annexation is likely to be speedily effected.
lead_paragraph: The arrival of the Arabia and the Borussia, the former from Liverpool, and the latter from Southampton, on the 4th inst., supplies interesting intelligence from the Old World. In regard to the rumored acquisition of Savoy and Nice by France it would appear, notwithstanding the tranquillizing assurances of Lord JOHN RUSS$ELL, that the annexation is likely to be speedily effected. The French journals indeed already speak of it as un fait accompli. It is, of course, understood that Piedmont consents to this cession, because of the sacrifices of France in the late Italian campaign, and in view of the compensation anticipated in Central Italy. That the engagement under which the French army was to be placed upon a peace footing is not deceptive, we have evidence in the report of the French Minister of War announcing that the contingent of 1859 will be reduced from 140,000 to 100,000 men. Further details of the late actions in Morocco state that the battle of Jan. 23 was in reality drawn, both armies retaining their positions. In that of Feb. 1, the brother of the Emperor of Morocco commanded the Moors, who were mowed down fearfully by the Spanish artillery. It is now credibly reported that the regular army of the Emperor has not been in action, but has been held in reserve, upon the anticipation that the enemy might be drawn into the interior and then overwhelmed by an unexpected attack. KOSSUTH is said to have gone to Hungary. The Protestant deputation, to whom the Emperor had refused an interview, had published a memorandum indicative of irritated feeling and a hostile purpose. Discontent was so general and menacing that Government was rapidly massing troops on the frontier. In the Grand Duchy of Baden much excitement prevailed in antagonism to the recent concordat. Of the five Commissioners appointed by the Diet to examine the instrument, four are known and one is believed to be opposed to the treaty. The later advices we receive from Australia, India and Brazil are of merely commercial interest.

abstract: From a recent number of the Etoile Belge, a journal conducted with considerable talent, we extract the subjoined paragraph: "At the last Chantiliy Races, a lady well known in the fashionable circles at Paris,  inoculated with the English passion for betting on horses, lost 15,000f.
lead_paragraph: From a recent number of the Etoile Belge, a journal conducted with considerable talent, we extract the subjoined paragraph: "At the last Chantiliy Races, a lady well known in the fashionable circles at Paris, inoculated with the English passion for betting on horses, lost 15,000f. Her husband, ignorant that she had any stake on the race, entered the grand-stand in great glee, having won 20,000f. on Black Prince; observing his wife did not partake of his joy at this good fortune, he offered to share his gains with her, upon which she avowed her loss. Like a kind husband, he immediately paid it, saying, however, 'I must take a house for you, madam, in the country, there is no longer any question about that, and never let me hear of your be[???]ing again.' In England, women who possess an independent fortune bet like the men. The daughter of a great English poet, Ada. the sole fruit of his unfortunate marriage, fell a victim to her passion for betting. Having staked an amount of £80,000 on the Derby, she lost three-quarters of it (or 1,000,000f.), all her personal fortune. It was her ruin; her husband inexorable, allowed her a small pension, upon which she retired to an estate in Rutland-shire. Six months after this exile, the poor lady died of despair."

abstract: The first Chamber of the Diet, of the Grand Duchy of Baden has appointed a Commission to examine the Concordat, and the names of the members give a clue to the reception reserved for the Convention. With one exception, in which case the opinion to not known, the five members of the Commission are opposed to the Concordat. Two of them are Protestants.

abstract: JOHNSTON EWING, a young man employed in the hide-cleaning establishment of Mr. THOMAS SMULLEN, in Thirty-ninth-street, near the North River, on Thursday night, while grossly intoxicated, lay down near the furnace in the building. In the morning he was found quite dead, with marks of severe burns on his back, abdomen and thighs, and from the fact that his clothes were but slightly injured by the fire, it is inferred that he must have divested himself of them before he received his injuries, and afterwards have put them on again, the attack of delirium tremens, under which he was probably laboring, rendering him insensible to pain. Three persons who slept in the building heard him muttering to himself during the night. Coroner GAMBLE held an inquest, and a verdict of "Death from burns accidentally received" was rendered.
lead_paragraph: JOHNSTON EWING, a young man employed in the hide-cleaning establishment of Mr. THOMAS SMULLEN, in Thirty-ninth-street, near the North River, on Thursday night, while grossly intoxicated, lay down near the furnace in the building. Three persons who slept in the building heard him muttering to himself during the night. Coroner GAMBLE held an inquest, and a verdict of "Death from burns accidentally received" was rendered.

abstract: The Superintendent of this institution is necessitated by the deficiency of its funds, and by the large increase of lodgers since the setting in of Winter, to make an appeal for help to the benevolent public. Thinking that the design and workings of the institution are not sufficiently known, he places the following particulars before the reader:
lead_paragraph: The Superintendent of this institution is necessitated by the deficiency of its funds, and by the large increase of lodgers since the setting in of Winter, to make an appeal for help to the benevolent public. Thinking that the design and workings of the institution are not sufficiently known, he places the following particulars before the reader: Its objects are temporally to afford a partial home to otherwise homeless boys; to improve their minds, morals and manners, and so to elevate their tastes that they will aspire and seek worthy pursuits, and a better home -- in a word, to develop vagrant boys into useful and good men. Our attractions are, comfortable single beds, in a well ventilated apartment; a warm, supper; (free,) It the boy is in early, and in that case he may not afterwards leave without permission; a library, a melodeon, a savings bank, a school-room, (answering also for chapel and play-room,) bath and wash rooms, private lock-close's for each boy, in which property may be left. Every evening, besides a brief devotional exercise, there is interesting reading, designed to beget a taste for it.

abstract: Mr. George H. Hall, well known as one of the best colorists, if not the best, amongst our American artists, is about to spend two years in Spain, the land of color par excellence., traveling, sketching, and collecting reminiscences of all kinds for future use. Preparatory to his departure in the early part of Summer, he proposes selling the entire collection of pictures and sketches now in his studio at auction, at the end of the present month, and for the purpose of enabling the public to form an opinion of their merits before the sale, has placed them on exhibition at the Academy of Design, in Tenth-street, where they may now be seen by all comers. There are amongst them a large number of small sketches and cabinet pieces of rare beauty, that will well repay a visit even from the busiest passer.
lead_paragraph: Mr. George H. abstract: In the House of Commons, Feb. 2, Mr. DISRAELI drew attention to the peculiar character of recent transactions in the Duchy of Savoy, and asked whether Government would produce the correspondence which had taken place on the subject of the annexation of Savoy to France, between the British and French Governments.
lead_paragraph: In the House of Commons, Feb. 2, Mr. DISRAELI drew attention to the peculiar character of recent transactions in the Duchy of Savoy, and asked whether Government would produce the correspondence which had taken place on the subject of the annexation of Savoy to France, between the British and French Governments. Lord JOHN RUSSELL replied that after communicating with the English Ambassador at Paris, the Government had come to the conclusion that it would be inexpedient to produce the papers; but that a conversation had taken place between Lord COWLEY and Count WALEWSKI on the subject, in which the Count had stated that there was no intention on the part of the Emperor of the French to propose any such annexation, and a dispatch had been sent to Paris expressing the satisfaction with which the British Government had received that assurance.

abstract: -- At a recent meeting of the Royal Geographical Society, at which Sir R. MURCHISON presided, a communication from Mr. WHEELWRIGHT was read, for the construction of a railway across the Andes. That gentleman, who is well known for his successful endeavors to establish steam navigation along the western shores of South America, and for several railway projects in Chili, proposes to make a railway from Morro de Copiapo, about 27 degrees of south latitude, on the west coast of South America, to Rosario, on the Rio Plata, a distance of upwards of 1,000 miles, and to cross the Andes at a height of 16,000 feet above the level of the sea. The reading of extracts from other communications by Mr. WHEELWRIGHT prefaced his proposal, for the purpose of describing the other works he had planned and successfully prosecuted, and to show that the engineering difficulties of the proposed railway would, not be so great as those which had been overcome. The pass across the Andes which had been selected for the line, though at an elevation of 2,000 feet greater than some other passes, possesses the great advantage of being never blocked up with snow, and from that point eastwards there is a gradual slope that would present scarcely any difficulty. The descent on the westward of the mountains is, however, so precipitous that extremely severe gradients would in many parts be necessary, and Mr. WHEELWRIGHT spoke of a gradient from San Francisco of 450 feet in a mile. This portion of the railway they proposed to work by gravitation.
lead_paragraph: -- At a recent meeting of the Royal Geographical Society, at which Sir R. MURCHISON presided, a communication from Mr. WHEELWRIGHT was read, for the construction of a railway across the Andes. That gentleman, who is well known for his successful endeavors to establish steam navigation along the western shores of South America, and for several railway projects in Chili, proposes to make a railway from Morro de Copiapo, about 27 degrees of south latitude, on the west coast of South America, to Rosario, on the Rio Plata, a distance of upwards of 1,000 miles, and to cross the Andes at a height of 16,000 feet above the level of the sea. The reading of extracts from other communications by Mr. WHEELWRIGHT prefaced his proposal, for the purpose of describing the other works he had planned and successfully prosecuted, and to show that the engineering difficulties of the proposed railway would, not be so great as those which had been overcome. The pass across the Andes which had been selected for the line, though at an elevation of 2,000 feet greater than some other passes, possesses the great advantage of being never blocked up with snow, and from that point eastwards there is a gradual slope that would present scarcely any difficulty. The descent on the westward of the mountains is, however, so precipitous that extremely severe gradients would in many parts be necessary, and Mr. WHEELWRIGHT spoke of a gradient from San Francisco of 450 feet in a mile. This portion of the railway they proposed to work by gravitation.

abstract: The Academy of Music was filled to overflowing, like a generous wine-cup, Saturday evening, on the occasion of the grand concert of the new band of the famous Seventh Regiment. The rain, snow and hail commingled, of that stormy night, daunted not the fair, whom none but the brave deserve, from manifesting their ardent interest in the courted corps by their presence at the trumpeting forth of the new musical acquisition of the Guard.
lead_paragraph: The Academy of Music was filled to overflowing, like a generous wine-cup, Saturday evening, on the occasion of the grand concert of the new band of the famous Seventh Regiment. The rain, snow and hail commingled, of that stormy night, daunted not the fair, whom none but the brave deserve, from manifesting their ardent interest in the courted corps by their presence at the trumpeting forth of the new musical acquisition of the Guard. An acquisition indeed! Loud were the acclamations with which the new band was greeted, as, led by its chef, Mr. C.S. GRAFULLA, and habited in its elegant uniform, it was marshaled with military precision on to the stage. Then all was deep attention until the first piece -- a selection from "Attila" -- had been executed, and the applause that followed, compared with that which had preceded, was as thunder to the rolling of a drum. Everybody was satisfied; the thing was a success. All that the Band performed during the rest of the evening confirmed the verdict, and the drum corps, which came later on to the stage, led by Drum-Major DAVID GRAHAM, played to the accompaniment of plentiful praise. Mesdames COLSON and STRAKOSCH, and Messrs. STIGELLI and AMODIO, in solo and quartette, contributed vastly to the pleasure of the occasion.

abstract: To a stranger who has heard of New-York only as the abode of political and social corruption, the gratuitous salting of our streets by coach and car proprietors in this time of snows may appear a most surprising act of the purest disinterestedness. Such a stranger will no doubt be pained at our ingratitude, when we complain of these briny libations as an intolerable nuisance, making it cost a coat of varnish to ride through the town in a coach, and a suit of clothes to cross a street on foot; making the atmosphere of Broadway as cold and damp as that of a pork-packer's cellar, and planting the seeds of more colds, coughs and coffins than poverty and Winter themselves combined. Through this salting process Broadway, from a useful thoroughfare, is converted into a channel of mud, which divides eastern New-York from western even more effectually than the river separates both from Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: To a stranger who has heard of New-York only as the abode of political and social corruption, the gratuitous salting of our streets by coach and car proprietors in this time of snows may appear a most surprising act of the purest disinterestedness. Through this salting process Broadway, from a useful thoroughfare, is converted into a channel of mud, which divides eastern New-York from western even more effectually than the river separates both from Brooklyn.

abstract: Le Nord says that, on the 30th ultimo, couriers left London and Paris with identical instructions to the representatives of the two Powers at Turin, directing them to make known to the Sardinian Cabinet that the Italian annexation being, in the view of the two Governments, the only means of solving the question the Governments of France and England see no objection to the annexation becoming a fait accompli. The only difference between the two Governments relates to the mode of consulting the populations. France holds that it should be by universal suffrage, while England prefers the current elections. As the elections which have already been held have resulted in the call for annexation, there can be no doubt as to the wish of the country.
lead_paragraph: Le Nord says that, on the 30th ultimo, couriers left London and Paris with identical instructions to the representatives of the two Powers at Turin, directing them to make known to the Sardinian Cabinet that the Italian annexation being, in the view of the two Governments, the only means of solving the question the Governments of France and England see no objection to the annexation becoming a fait accompli. As the elections which have already been held have resulted in the call for annexation, there can be no doubt as to the wish of the country.

abstract: Almost from the first moment when he appears, amongst boys, amongst College students, amongst men, he is marked, and takes rank as a great Eng-...
lead_paragraph: Almost from the first moment when he appears, amongst boys, amongst College students, amongst men, he is marked, and takes rank as a great Englishman. All sorts of successess are easy to him; as a lad he goes down into the arena with others, and wins all the prizes to which he has a mind. A place in the Senate is straightway offered to the young man. He takes his seat there; he speaks, when so minded, without party anger or intrigue, but not without party faith and a sort off heroic enthusiasm for his cause. Still he is poet and philosopher even more than orator. That he may have leisure and means to pursue his darling studies, he absents himself for a while, and accepts a richly remunerated post in the East. As learned a man may live in a cottage or a College common-room; but it always seemed to me that ample means and recognized rank were MACAULAY's as of right. Years ago there was a wretched outcry raised because Mr. MACAULAY dated a letter from Windsor Castle, where he was staying. Immortal gods! Was this man not a guest for any palace in the world? or a fit companion for any man or woman in it? I dare say, after Austerlitz, the old K.K. court officials and footmen sneered at NAPOLHON for dating from Schonbrunn. But that miserable "Windsor Castle" outcry is an echo out of fast retreating-old-world remembrances. The place of such a natural chief was amongst the first of the land; and that country is best, according to our British notion, at least, where the man of eminence has the best chance of investing his genius and intellect.

abstract: Letters from Austria speak of increasing discontent in Hungary, and indicate that matters were daily getting more serious. It was reported that KOSSUTH had suddenly disappeared from among his friends in London, and an impression prevailed that he had gone to Hungary, with revolutionary designs.
lead_paragraph: Letters from Austria speak of increasing discontent in Hungary, and indicate that matters were daily getting more serious. It was reported that KOSSUTH had suddenly disappeared from among his friends in London, and an impression prevailed that he had gone to Hungary, with revolutionary designs. The Hungarian Protestant deputation, which went to Vienna for the purpose of demanding from the Emperor the restoration of all the rights and privileges of their Church, bad been refused an audience by the Emperor, and had quitted Vienna. They had published a memorandum, explaining the object of their mission.

abstract: STREET BEGGARS. -- Poets manage somehow or other to make a very picturesque character of the wayside mendicant; but even poetic inspiration would find it hard to discover the resemblance between the ideal and the real street vagabond of New-York. For our beggars, unfortunately for the similarity, have not long white hair and beards, nor do they bear about a harp. But young, stout, impudent, dirty and whining, a disgrace even to their own calling, they beset the benevolent on every hand. Every nation has its representatives among them except the Celestial realm. John Chinaman doesn't beg. He buys a small table, a box of cigars, a bunch of matches, and waits for a customer, with the philosophic patience of Confucius printed all over his face. Lately, however, a new candidate for mendicant honors has appeared on Broadway. On almost any pleasant afternoon, passers-by may see on the sidewalk an object which, upon examination, proves to be an abstract of a Chinaman, armless and legless, but what would be a Chinaman if filled out and finished. After the fashion of his race, his brow is in contact with the ground, and in his humility he doesn't look up even to thank the source whence pennies are showered into his cap beside him. You pity the poor creature, but then Chinamen are so ingenious, can so mimic any appearance, that you half fear he might, if he chose, stand up and look as nearly like a man as is possible for any one to look who was born in a country where the name of every river has an nkstg in it. It is generally safe, however, not to patronize beggars by the wayside. For the noble charities, public and private, of our City, are sufficient to relieve so nearly every case of honest want, that one is in danger of misapplying his benevolence if he withholds his support from them and distributes his alms at random.

abstract: This afternoon LEVI BARTLETT, Esq., of New-Hampshire, lectured on the cultivation of Winter wheat in the New-England States, but especially in the State of New-Hampshire. Prior to 1852, most persons, said he, would as soon have thought of growing oranges in that State as wheat. Few persons there had ever seen a wheat field. At that time one of his neighbors visiting New-York was so well pleased with the appearance of the wheat fields that he procured seed and determined to attempt its cultivation. His first crop produced abundantly, and this he disposed of to those of his neighbors who were willing to experiment in its cultivation. Some failed to get any favorable results, but those who cultivated thoroughly and sowed early got from 15 to 20 bushels to the acre. His own experiments for six years have given him an average of 15 bushels, and he had not attempted to grow large crops. His method was to turn over sod and sow it at once; top dress, at the time of sowing, with 150 pounds of guano, 15 bushels of ashes, and one bushel of salt, for each acre; soak the seed before sowing in weak brine for two hours, and roll in ashes; sow the latter part of August or first of September. Late sowing is useless, for the midge will destroy it, but we have no Hessian fly to injure it if early sown. Those varieties which ripen early are best. He had grown the Japan wheat for four years, and found it to succeed well. It ripens early though it is a red wheat, and does not make as fine flour as the white. He thought if Com. PERRY had brought forty bushels of it to this country, it would have been of more value than the entire expense of the Japan Expedition. Mr. BARTLETT closed by expressing the opinion that the day was not far distant when New-England would raise nearly all the wheat they would consume, and he urged that her people should take hold of the matter in earnest, and prosecute it thoroughly. They would certainly succeed, and instead of handing over a ten-dollar bill every time they wanted a barrel of flour, they would only have to measure up four bushels of Wheat of their own growing, and take it to the mill for grinding.

abstract: Mr. Adriah Sackett died at Providence, R. I., on the 15th inst. He was a native of Westfield, Mass, but removed to Providence when quite a lad, where he followed the trade of a jeweler. In 1848 and 1849 he was the Gubernatorial candidate of the Democratic Party in Rhode Island. For tea consecutive years he was a member of the State Central Committee, of which he was Chairman for the last five years of his life, and for ten years he acted as one of the State Prison inspectors.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Adriah Sackett died at Providence, R. I., on the 15th inst. He was a native of Westfield, Mass, but removed to Providence when quite a lad, where he followed the trade of a jeweler. It contains some very interesting papers on needle-work, and has a chapter on chess for the boys. The works is prettily illustrated and will prove an acceptable little work for the young folks. It is mailed for the very low price of seventy-five cents a year.

abstract: PRAYER FOR COLLEGES. The following arrangements were made at a meeting of pastors, held on Friday afternoon : 1. A Daily Union Prayer-meeting, from 4 to 5 o'clock P.M, commencing on Monday, the 20th inst., and continuing through the week.
lead_paragraph: PRAYER FOR COLLEGES. The following arrangements were made at a meeting of pastors, held on Friday afternoon : 1. A Daily Union Prayer-meeting, from 4 to 5 o'clock P.M, commencing on Monday, the 20th inst., and continuing through the week. To avoid confusion, this daily service will be held in the Lecture-room of the Presbyterian Church corner of South Third and Fifth streets, instead of being moved from day to day. 2. A public meeting on Thursday night, commencing at 7 1/2 o'clock, in the First Baptist Church, corner of Fifth and South Fifth streets, at which addresses will be delivered by gentlemen from abroad. Thursday is the day long observed by Christians, in great numbers, as a day of special prayer for Colleges, and the addresses will have reference to the object for which prayer is offered. As these services are meant for all the congregations, pastors are respectfully requested to give notice of them, and to attend themselves.

abstract: George W. Comstock, et al., vs. Andrew J. White and Andrew B. Moore. This is a long litigated suit, brought to restrain the defendants from making and selling the pills known as "Dr. Morse's Indian Root Pills;" and from using the trade-marks, labels, , heretofore used in selling these pills. The plaintiff claims to have bought out the exclusive right to manufacture and sell the pills in question.

abstract: On the arrival of the McLane Mexican treaty, certain persons claiming to speak for the Republican party at once denounced the measure in true partisan style, and the impression went abroad that as the Republicans had sufficient strength to defeat the treaty in the Senate, on a two-thirds vote, its non-ratification, as a matter of course, was considered certain.
lead_paragraph: On the arrival of the McLane Mexican treaty, certain persons claiming to speak for the Republican party at once denounced the measure in true partisan style, and the impression went abroad that as the Republicans had sufficient strength to defeat the treaty in the Senate, on a two-thirds vote, its non-ratification, as a matter of course, was considered certain. From all the information we can obtain on the subject, and from a consideration of the various elements of opposition to the treaty which appear to be stirring on every side, we are inclined, on the contrary, to believe that the ratification of this most important, treaty is rapidly becoming assured.

abstract: The statistics of crime are highly instructive, and, rightly interpreted, furnish a basis for wise reform in criminal jurisprudence and philanthropic effort. The facts of the Police Department given to the public last week, showing a remarkable diminution of arrests for crime during the quarter ending Feb. 1, deserve study in the light of a profounder philosophy than seems to have dawned on the official heads of that department.
lead_paragraph: The statistics of crime are highly instructive, and, rightly interpreted, furnish a basis for wise reform in criminal jurisprudence and philanthropic effort. abstract: On Friday the prosecution in the case of W.J. Lane, Jr., charged with defrauding the Fulton Bank, of this City, of $618 75, by means of a false entry on the "Foreign Register," rested their evidence, and on Saturday morning, the defence having no witnesses to examine, Mr. James T, Brady proceeded to sum up to the jury. He contended that though more than thirty indictments had been found against the prisoner, still no legal offence had been committed. The learned counsel spoke for a long time, and was followed by Mr. O'Conor for the prosecution. The Judge having charged the jury they retired at 2:15 o'clock, and after an absence of fifty minutes returned into Court with a verdict of guilty. Mr. Brady immediately notified the Court that he should move for a new trial, and Mr. Waterbury gave notice that on Thursday next he should move that sentence be pronounced on the prisoner.

abstract: On the 30th of last October John Brooks, alias W.H. Williams, and Geo. Coffin, alias Geo. Howard, visited Cold County, N.Y., and defrauded nearly all the saloon-keepers in the place with five dollar bills which purported to be issues of the Mechanics' Bank of New Haven; Conn. After having disposed of about one hundred dollars in these bills they went to the railroad depot, expecting to leave town by the next train, but some of their victims discovered the fraud which had been perpetrated upon them, and an alarm having been given by ringing the village bell, the people of the town rushed en masse to the depot, and after a severe struggle succeeded in arresting the culprits. After a summary trial and conviction they were committed to the County Jail at Carmel, where they remained just nine days, when they effected their escape. Brooks was rearrested two days subsequent, charged with having passed more counterfeit money at Bridgeport, Conn., but his friends succeeded in effecting his release. All trace was lost of these enterprising individuals until a fortnight ago, when Sergeant Dickson and Detective Farley observed Brooks in this City and traced him to a house in Delancey-street. On Saturday night they effected his arrest. Information which they received led the officers to suspect that Coffin was frequenting the house No. 102 Cannon-street. On inquiring for him, his wife, who lived there, told them that he would be at home in a few days. During the temporary absence of Sergeant Dickson, about five o'clock yesterday morning, Coffin entered the house, and Detective Farley, who was on watch, followed him, and ordered him to surrender. In reply, Coffin drew a dirk-knife and threatened to stab the officer if he did not withdraw. Although Detective Farley was armed and could have maimed the prisoner with ease, he decided to await the return of Sergeant Dickson, knowing that Coffin could not effect his escape in any other way than by the front door. In about half an hour Dickson made his appearance, and the two officers at once stepped up and attempted to arrest him. Rendered desperate by the apparent impossibility of his escape, Coffin struck at Detective Farley with his knife, and in warding off the blow, the pistol which the officer held in his hand exploded, the ball wounding Coffin over the right temple. He was then overpowered and taken to Police headquarters, where his wound was dressed. He will probably lose his right eye. The likenesses of both these desperadoes will be added to the Rogue's Gallery, and the prisoners will be immediately removed to Carmel.
