abstract: the Melbourne Argus, of Dec. 19, in its commercial report, says that the condition of the Australian market has not been so bad since the crisis of 1855. The money market has been very generally affected by the numerous failures, assignments and private arrangements which have occurred during the month. Coin and bullion have been decreasing in the Bank coffers, and the managers have felt themselves compelled from time to time to draw in the limits of the accommodation to their customers. The month has been one of almost daily suspensions, arrangements and assignments. Public confidence is shaken. Money has been throughout increasing in tightness, and the crisis is aggravated by the large amount of capital locked up in unsalable goods. The bonded stock of brandy alone cannot be valued at less than Â£200,00 while at the same time the imports continue beyond our powers of consumption. The Argus adds: "Our imports are still in excess, week by week, of our experts, the balance in value for the year being a million and a half starling in favor of the former. In the face of this the advices received by the last mail speak of still increasing shipments from all British ports and from America,."

abstract: Upwards of 500,000 workers are now employed in our cotton factories, and it has been estimated that at least 4,000,000 persons in this country are dependent upon the cotton trade for subsistence. A century ago Lancashire contained a population of only 300,000 person; it now numbers 2,300,000. In the same period of time this enormous increase exceeds that on any other equal surface of the globe, and is entirely owing to the development of the cotton trade. In 1856 there were in the United Kingdom 2,210 factories, running 28,000,000 spindles and 293,000 looms, by 97,000 horse power. Since that period a considerble number of new mills have been erected and expensive additions have been made to the spinning and weaving machinery of these previously in existence. The amount of actual capital invested in the cotton trade of this kingdom is estimated to be between £60,000,000 and £70,000,000 sterling. The quantity of cotton imported into this country in 1859 was 1,181 3/4 millions pounds' weight the value of which at [???] per [???] is equal to £30 000,000 sterling. Out of 2,829,110 bales of cotton imported into Great Britain, America has supplied us with 2,086,341, that is 5 7[???] of the whole. In other words, out of every 7 [???]s. imported from all countries into Great Britain, America has supplied 5 lhs., India has sent us about 600,000 bales. Egypt about 100 000, South America, 124,000; and other countries between 8,000 and 9,000 bales. In 1859 the total value of The exports from Great Britain amounted to £130,513,185, of which £47,920,720 consisted of cotton goods and yams. Thus, more than one-third, or £1 out of every £3 of our entire exports, consists of cotton. Add to this the proportion of cotton which forms part of 12 millions more exported in the shape of mixed woolens, haberdashery, millinery, silks, apparel, and slops. Great Britain alone consumes annually 24 millions' worth of cotton goods. Two conclusions therefore, may safely be drawn from the facts and figures now cited -- first, that the interests of every c[???]ion-worker are bound up with a gigantic trade which keeps in motion an enormous mass of capital, and this capital, machinery and labor depend for five-sevenths of its employment upon the slave States of America for prosperity and continuance; secondly, that if a war should at any time breakout between England and America, a general insurrection take place among the slaves, disease sweep off those slaves by death, or the cotton crop fall short in quantity, whether from severe frosts, disease of the plant, or other possible causes -- our mills would be stopped for want of cotton, employers would be ruined, and famine would stalk abroad among the hundreds and thousands of workpeople who are at present fortunately well employed. Calculate the consequences for yourself Imagine a dearth of cotton, and you may picture the horrors of such a calamity from the scenes you may possibly have witnessed when the mills have only run on "short time." Count up all the trades that are kept going out of the wages of the working classes, independent of builders, mechanics, engineers, colliers, &c., employed by the mill[???]where. Railways would cease to pay, and our strips would lie rotting in their ports, should a scarcity of the raw material for manufacture overtake us.
lead_paragraph: Upwards of 500,000 workers are now employed in our cotton factories, and it has been estimated that at least 4,000,000 persons in this country are dependent upon the cotton trade for subsistence. A century ago Lancashire contained a population of only 300,000 person; it now numbers 2,300,000. In the same period of time this enormous increase exceeds that on any other equal surface of the globe, and is entirely owing to the development of the cotton trade. In 1856 there were in the United Kingdom 2,210 factories, running 28,000,000 spindles and 293,000 looms, by 97,000 horse power. Since that period a considerble number of new mills have been erected and expensive additions have been made to the spinning and weaving machinery of these previously in existence. The amount of actual capital invested in the cotton trade of this kingdom is estimated to be between £60,000,000 and £70,000,000 sterling. The quantity of cotton imported into this country in 1859 was 1,181 3/4 millions pounds' weight the value of which at [???] per [???] is equal to £30 000,000 sterling. Out of 2,829,110 bales of cotton imported into Great Britain, America has supplied us with 2,086,341, that is 5 7[???] of the whole. In other words, out of every 7 [???]s. imported from all countries into Great Britain, America has supplied 5 lhs., India has sent us about 600,000 bales. Egypt about 100 000, South America, 124,000; and other countries between 8,000 and 9,000 bales. In 1859 the total value of The exports from Great Britain amounted to £130,513,185, of which £47,920,720 consisted of cotton goods and yams. Thus, more than one-third, or £1 out of every £3 of our entire exports, consists of cotton. Add to this the proportion of cotton which forms part of 12 millions more exported in the shape of mixed woolens, haberdashery, millinery, silks, apparel, and slops. Great Britain alone consumes annually 24 millions' worth of cotton goods. Two conclusions therefore, may safely be drawn from the facts and figures now cited -- first, that the interests of every c[???]ion-worker are bound up with a gigantic trade which keeps in motion an enormous mass of capital, and this capital, machinery and labor depend for five-sevenths of its employment upon the slave States of America for prosperity and continuance; secondly, that if a war should at any time breakout between England and America, a general insurrection take place among the slaves, disease sweep off those slaves by death, or the cotton crop fall short in quantity, whether from severe frosts, disease of the plant, or other possible causes -- our mills would be stopped for want of cotton, employers would be ruined, and famine would stalk abroad among the hundreds and thousands of workpeople who are at present fortunately well employed. Calculate the consequences for yourself Imagine a dearth of cotton, and you may picture the horrors of such a calamity from the scenes you may possibly have witnessed when the mills have only run on "short time." Count up all the trades that are kept going out of the wages of the working classes, independent of builders, mechanics, engineers, colliers, &c., employed by the mill[???]where. Railways would cease to pay, and our strips would lie rotting in their ports, should a scarcity of the raw material for manufacture overtake us.

abstract: Lord Ward, upon whom Her Majesty has signified her intertion to bestow a mark of the royal favor, by advancing him to an Earl's coronet, as Earl Dudley, of Dudley Castle, is well known in the midland counties as one of the largest land-owners in Staffordshire and Worcestershire, and as one of the most deservedly popular and influential landlords in the kingdom.
lead_paragraph: Lord Ward, upon whom Her Majesty has signified her intertion to bestow a mark of the royal favor, by advancing him to an Earl's coronet, as Earl Dudley, of Dudley Castle, is well known in the midland counties as one of the largest land-owners in Staffordshire and Worcestershire, and as one of the most deservedly popular and influential landlords in the kingdom. Fabulous stories are told of his wealth which is largely derided from extensive coal mines on his Staffordshire estates: and he has lately become an extensive land-owner in Scotland, having purchased a considerable portion of what once was the princely inheritance of the Ma[???]donells of Glengarry. His lordship is the elder of the two sons of the late Rev. William Humble Ward, who late in life succeeded to the barony as tenth Lord Ward, and died shortly afterwards, in 1835. He was born in 1817, so that he has not yet completed the 43rd year of his age.

abstract: A Madrid telegram of the 2d inst. says:  Yesterday considerable Moorish forces attacked the right wing of the Spanish encampment, but were repulsed.
lead_paragraph: A Madrid telegram of the 2d inst. says: Yesterday considerable Moorish forces attacked the right wing of the Spanish encampment, but were repulsed. The Spanish then made an attack on the Moorish lines, threw the Moors into disorder, and took their positions, which they maintained until the end of the fight. The Spanish artillery caused enormous losses to the enemy, estimated to amount to 2,000. The Spanish lost 200. The victory was complete. The brother of the Emperor commanded the Moors.

abstract: The United States vs. Three cases marked A.A.S., No. 6, and one other case, and one barrel containing cigars. -- This was an action to forfeit the goods for an alleged fraudulent undervaluation. The goods were imported from Havana by the bark Amanda in November, 1858, and on appraisal, their value was advanced more than 10 per cent. of the value specified in the invoice. Testimony was offered by the Government and by the claimant, Mr. Samanos, of the market value of the cigars at Havana, which was quite conflicting. The different cases were advanced different rates. There was no evidence of seizure of the goods, but the claimant admitted the seizure of one case, No. 6, and one barrel. The jury found a verdict for the United States as to the one case, No. 6, and in favor of the claimants as to the rest of the goods.

abstract: The House of Representatives should wait to see whether the franking privilege will be abolished or not, before restoring the desks which were discarded last session. When members are deprived of the right of sending political wisdom by the hundred weight gratis through the Post-office, they will probably be able to write their correspondence in their rooms, and be able to listen to what is going on while they sit in the House.
lead_paragraph: The House of Representatives should wait to see whether the franking privilege will be abolished or not, before restoring the desks which were discarded last session. When members are deprived of the right of sending political wisdom by the hundred weight gratis through the Post-office, they will probably be able to write their correspondence in their rooms, and be able to listen to what is going on while they sit in the House. The franking privilege may have made desks a necessity; but their presence unquestionably leads to a terrible waste of time. They were the main promoters and supporters of that system of essay-reading which has gradually taken the place of debating in both Houses of Congress. How much they have had to do with the present lamentable condition of parliamentary oratory in Washington, is partially shown in the wide difference which everybody recognizes between the style of public speaking at an ordinary public meeting for business, and that which prevails at the Capitol. When men get up to address audiences at Faneuil Hall or the Cooper Institute, they have either to argue well, or joke well, or be very pathetic, or very sublime. If they are simply long-winded, and insist upon repeating what everybody knows without either wit, or humor, or logic, one of two things is sure to happen -- the audience will stamp them down, or the getters up of public meetings will never ask them to speak again. For the sake of his present comfort, as well as his future reputation, the orator who addresses an ordinary popular assemblage is compelled to employ all his powers in keeping up the attention of those who are present. They are there to be either amused, or convinced, or excited, and while they are perfectiy ready to accept whatever boon he pleases to confer upon them, they insist upon his either amusing, exciting or convincing them. The public meeting is, in short, a barometer by which the extent of every "spouter's" powers may be pretty accurately ascertained.

abstract: The First Baplist Church in Brooklyn vs. The Brooklyn Fire Insurance Company. This is a suit on an alleged verbal agreement to keep the plaintiffs insured till either party should give notice to the other to discontinue the insurance. The cause was first tried in January 1852, when a verdict was rendered for the plaintiffs.
lead_paragraph: The First Baplist Church in Brooklyn vs. The Brooklyn Fire Insurance Company. This is a suit on an alleged verbal agreement to keep the plaintiffs insured till either party should give notice to the other to discontinue the insurance. The cause was first tried in January 1852, when a verdict was rendered for the plaintiffs. This was sustained by the General Term, but the Court of Appeals held that such an agreement was void, and sent the case back. On the second trial the plaintiffs were nonsuited on this ground, and the case was again appealed to the Court of last resort, who reversed their previous decision, and held that such an agreement was valid. The case of course was ordered to be tried again, and came on to be tried on Monday last, before Justly ALLE[???], of Oswego.

abstract: The Modena Official Gazette continues to publish letters and documents found in the archives of the Ex-Duke. The greater portion of these papers refer to questions purely Italian.
lead_paragraph: The Modena Official Gazette continues to publish letters and documents found in the archives of the Ex-Duke. The greater portion of these papers refer to questions purely Italian. Others concern questions pending at the time they were written. Some are anterior to the revolution of 1848, and relate specially to the BONAPARTE family, the majority of the members of which were then in Italy. Among these last is a secret letter, written by Prince METTERNICH to the Austrian Minister at Florence, that acquaints us with the measures of safety adopted by the Congress of Vienna against the BONAPARTE family -- measures that placed them, to speak properly, under the surveillance of the higher police of the Holy Alliance. Here is the text:

abstract: The Special Committee on the contested seat in the Board of Councilmen met again yesterday afternoon. Mr. BAKER, whose seat is contested by Mr. LENT, was not present, although he was in the City and had been subpoenaed. His counsel informed the Clerk of the Committee that he (counsel) had advised Mr. BAKER not to attend the Committee's meeting. The records of the Court of Common Pleas were produced, in which Mr. BAKER was found registered as having taken out his naturalization papers on the 20th of December, some time after the Charter Election at which he was chosen Councilman. In order to give Mr. BAKER another chance to be heard, the Committee adjourned to Thursday next.
lead_paragraph: The Special Committee on the contested seat in the Board of Councilmen met again yesterday afternoon. abstract: Our legislators at Albany find themselves in a very common dilemma--the necessity of raising a revenue, the ordinary sources of which have failed.
lead_paragraph: Our legislators at Albany find themselves in a very common dilemma--the necessity of raising a revenue, the ordinary sources of which have failed. Many years ago it was decreed by the Constitution of the State that its canals should pay, annually, a certain sum to this object, another sum to that, and so on, till the amount reached some two or three millions. This enactment was made at the very moment that a vast step had been taken in the science of locomotion, but one of which our people, at the time, were unconscious. Its importance is now fully revealed. The canal is no longer the sole, nor is it the most convenient or economical means of moving persons, or many kinds of property. The railroad upon the very route of the Erie canal has taken from it a very large traffic. Upon numerous other routes between the interior and tide water, impracticable for canals, have railroads been constructed, all drawing off a portion of the traffic once enjoyed by our great water line. The result is a somewhat diminished tonnage, and a greatly diminished revenue. The canal can no longer meet the charges arbitrarily placed upon it. The State is called upon to supply the deficiency.

abstract: A CORRECTION. -- About a month ago we published, with comments of our own, an account which appeared in a Mississippi newspaper of the killing at Columbus, in that State, of a certain Dr. SHEPHERD by one Mr. JAMES BLAIR. According to that account Mr. BLAIR had drawn upon himself the contemptuous indignation of Dr. SHEPHERD by voluntarily invading the privacy and ransacking the goods of a Northern traveler, named JOHNSON, then sojourning in Columbus, and we dealt with the case as an illustration of the outrages and indecencies of conduct inseparable from such a state of panic as was aroused throughout the United States by the affair at Harper's Ferry. In so doing we stigmatized the part played by Mr. BLAIR in the severest terms. We are now assured, on what we regard as good authority, that Mr. BLAIR's original interference with the property of JOHNSON resulted from the application of a Justice of the Peace, and that his subsequent investigations were in company with and under the countenance of the Mayor and the District-Attorney. The original version of this story, therefore, while faithful enough to the general features of the case, did decided injustice to the personal motives and behavior of BLAIR, and the collision between himself and SHEPHERD, which resulted in the death of the latter, appears to have been simply one of those savage personal affrays which Southern men have not yet learned to consider inconsistent with civilization, justice, order and Christianity.

abstract: COMMON COUNCIL. A regular meeting of this body was held last evening. A resolution remonstrating against a bill now before the Legislature empowering the city to advance funds to pay a tax imposed on a portion of South Brooklyn for closing the tunnel on Atlantic-street, was adopted. The matter of appropriating $25,000 to rebuild Public School No. 13, was referred to the Finance Committee with power. The presentment of the Grand Jury calling...
lead_paragraph: COMMON COUNCIL. A regular meeting of this body was held last evening. A resolution remonstrating against a bill now before the Legislature empowering the city to advance funds to pay a tax imposed on a portion of South Brooklyn for closing the tunnel on Atlantic-street, was adopted. The matter of appropriating $25,000 to rebuild Public School No. 13, was referred to the Finance Committee with power. The presentment of the Grand Jury calling the attention of the Board to the negligence in taking care of the city property, was presented and referred to the Committee on Lands and Places. A resolution was adopted asking that the bill now before the Legislature, relative to the East River Ferries, be so amended that no Ferry Company can charge more than one cent fare for foot passengers, was adopted. The annual statement of the Comptroller was submitted:

abstract: Another Union meeting takes place this evening at the Cooper Institute, and we are requested to state that the speakers announced have already arrived in the City, and will positively be in attendance. We are further requested to say that Lieutenant-General SCOTT has promised to attend, -- that J.W. GERARD, Esq., will preside, and Dodworth's Band will furnish the music. We understand that one of the speakers -- a distinguished gentleman from a Southern State -- has never before been in the City of New-York. We trust he will have an opportunity to meet this evening a large number of those Northern men whom he has been taught to regard as Abolitionists and Disunionists; he may be convinced that a very great error as to their character and purposes prevails in the southern section of the Union.

abstract: THE SHOEMAKERS' STRIKE IN MASSACHUSETTS. -- It is generally believed, by those most familiar with the boot and shoe trade, that the strike of the journeymen shoemakers will inure principally to the benefit of the manufacturers. For some time past there has been an over-supply of boots and shoes, and manufacturers have been repeatedly urged to reduce their production. But there could be no combined movement for this purpose, and no individual manufacturer was willing to curtail his business one quarter or one-third for the benefit of his neighbors. So the supply has exceeded the demand, with a prospect of the continuance of the same depressing feature in the trade during the coming season. -- Boston Journal.

abstract: Our neighbor, the Herald, actually succeeded in getting hold of a treaty yesterday! We mention the fact to explain in advance the hundred guns which will probably be fired in the Park to-day in honor of the event To be sure, the treaty is over a year old -- being in fact nothing more serious than the famous Bowlin Convention with Paraguay, of which we published the outline sometime in 1858 But this is a matter of trifling consequence, -- it is a treaty, nevertheless, and helps so far to redeem the Herald's reputation for enterprise.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, the House resolution appropriating ten thousand dollars for the inauguration of WASHINGTON'S statue was passed. Mr. BROWN'S resolution was then taken up, and Hon.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, the House resolution appropriating ten thousand dollars for the inauguration of WASHINGTON'S statue was passed. Mr. BROWN'S resolution was then taken up, and Hon. DANIEL CLARK, of New-Hampshire, spoke at some length in opposition. Mr. CLARK recounted the annals of Pro-Slavery agitation since 1850, showing that the institution during the past ten years had become daring and aggressive, and prophesying its early extension over the soil of the Free States. Mr. TOOMBS, of Georgia, took occasion from a remark of the Senator to deny that he had ever engaged to call the roll of his slaves in the shadow of Bunker Hill. In conclusion, Mr. CLARK repudiated the idea of the Senator from Mississippi, that Slavery was the keystone of the Federal arch. He pronounced it rather a cobble stone, adding nothing to the strength of the structure, which indeed would be stauncher for its absence. A message from the House announced the death of Hon. WILLIAM O. GOODE, the predecessor of Hon. ROGER A. PRYOR. Messrs. HUNTER and CLAY uttered brief panegyrics upon the deceased, and the Senate adjourned. The Speaker of the House of Representatives announced the special Committee upon the Senate's bill abolishing the franking privilege. It consists of Messrs. Vallandigham, Kellogg, Burnett, Adams of Kentucky, and Stokes. Mr. LOVEJOY, of Illinois, moved a Committee of Inquiry as to the alleged violations of that article of the Constitution which, guarantees the citizens of one State equal rights in another. He was unable to procure a vote on his resolution. Various bills for the support of Executive bureaus were reported from the Committee of Ways and Means. The death of Mr. GOODE, member of the House from Virginia, was announced by Hon. ROGER A. PRYOR, his successor, and after fitting eulogies, the House adjourned.

abstract: A piece of legal intelligence appeared in our columns yesterday which is very much too rich and racy to be allowed to lie buried in the learned obscurity of a law report.
lead_paragraph: A piece of legal intelligence appeared in our columns yesterday which is very much too rich and racy to be allowed to lie buried in the learned obscurity of a law report. It is our agreeable duty to drag it into light for the entertainment, if not for the edification, of the public. It is but justice to ourselves to add, however, that we enter upon our task with that unfeigned diffidence which ought to characterize the ordinary lay mind upon such an occasion. For the purpose of appeasing Judge HILTON, Mr. ASHMEAD, and other priests of the forensic sanctuary, we make a preliminary admission of our unfitness for the delicate undertaking which lies before us. Nothing but the deplorable necessities of our position could induce us to meddle with it. In short -- for concealment is no longer possible -- we are about to present to the admiring gaze of our numerous readers one of the many beauties of our Judicial system, as by law established, in the hope that they may find as much comfort in the contemplation of it as we do ourselves.
headline: {'main': 'Beauties of Our Judicial System.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Beauties of Our Judicial System.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: At the meeting of the Board of Councilmen last evening, the following resolutions were referred to the Committee on Streets: To lay Belgian pavement in Broadway, between Seventeenth and Forty-second-street; in Liberty-street, from Broadway to West-street; in Maiden-lane and in Dey and Cortlandt-streets, from Broadway to West-street, the expense in this instance to be divided equally between the City and the property-owners who would be benefited. A resolution to have a sewer built in Greenwich-street, between Jay and Hudson; a petition to pave Duane-street, between City-hall-place and Broadway, and Elm, adjoining Duane-street, graded, and to have the curb and gutter-stones set; and to have College-place widened on the westerly side, from Chambers-street to Barclay, and extended to Fulton-street; and authorizing the Street Commissioner to advertise for proposals to build steam fire-engines, to be used in the City, were also referred.
lead_paragraph: At the meeting of the Board of Councilmen last evening, the following resolutions were referred to the Committee on Streets: To lay Belgian pavement in Broadway, between Seventeenth and Forty-second-street; in Liberty-street, from Broadway to West-street; in Maiden-lane and in Dey and Cortlandt-streets, from Broadway to West-street, the expense in this instance to be divided equally between the City and the property-owners who would be benefited. A resolution to have a sewer built in Greenwich-street, between Jay and Hudson; a petition to pave Duane-street, between City-hall-place and Broadway, and Elm, adjoining Duane-street, graded, and to have the curb and gutter-stones set; and to have College-place widened on the westerly side, from Chambers-street to Barclay, and extended to Fulton-street; and authorizing the Street Commissioner to advertise for proposals to build steam fire-engines, to be used in the City, were also referred.

abstract: Though Free Trade has only met with official sanction in France within the last two months, she has for nearly twenty years been the scene of labors in the cause, which, if not so successful, have been no less devoted and hardly less skillful than those of COBDEN and the League in England.
lead_paragraph: Though Free Trade has only met with official sanction in France within the last two months, she has for nearly twenty years been the scene of labors in the cause, which, if not so successful, have been no less devoted and hardly less skillful than those of COBDEN and the League in England. The tardy concession which has just rewarded their efforts, is due in much greater degree to the weight of centralization with which they have had to contend, and the consequent immensity of the sphere which the Government is expected to fill in every Frenchman's eyes, than to any lack of zeal or logical power on their part. They have had not simply to wage war against economic fallacies, but against political heresies of the worst kind. All the best traditions of English politics, all the soundest and most valuable principles of the English law, backed up the Manchester men in their struggles which brought the triumph of 1847, while their French sympathizers had to assail almost all that was most deeply rooted in French notions of government and political economy. The direct interference of the Government in England for the encouragement of either trade or commerce, was clearly a flagrant exception to the general theory of individualism and decentralization on which the whole fabric of society is based; in France, on the contrary, it was the most natural thing in the world -- a thing which the masses believed to be absolutely essential to the national prosperity.

abstract: THE CELEBRATION OF WASHINGTON'S BIRTH DAY. The preparations for the celebration of the Anniversary of WASHINGTON'S birthday, which recurs to-morrow, are not as extensive as they have been for many years past.
lead_paragraph: THE CELEBRATION OF WASHINGTON'S BIRTH DAY. The preparations for the celebration of the Anniversary of WASHINGTON'S birthday, which recurs to-morrow, are not as extensive as they have been for many years past. The City authorities have made no preparations whatever for the occasion. A resolution adopted by the Board of Councilmen was amended in the Board of Aldermen, to appropriate $1,000 for the purpose of celebrating the event, but since the resolution as amended has not been acted upon by the Councilmen, there is no appropriation at all. It is expected that some of the societies of the Order of United Americans will hold meetings on that day. The only civic society which has announced an intention to parade is the American Protestant Association -- they will be reviewed by the City authorities, in front of the City Hall, about mid-day. In the way of military display, four regiments promise to turn out: the Eighth, Col. LYONS; the Eleventh, Col. BOSTWICK; the Twelfth, Col. BUTTERFIELD, (first parade with new uniform.) and the Seventy-first, Col. VOSBURG. The Veterans of the War of 1812 will also parade and enjoy a social repast during the afternoon. The Highwood Guard, Capt. NEWKIRK, of Hoboken, N.J., will parade in this City during the forenoon, and in Jersey City later in the day. The Aurora Guard gives a ball at the Third-avenue Railroad Assembly Rooms; The Washington Association has a reunion at the Apollo Rooms, and Company D., Fifth Regiment, (late Washington Rifles,) gives a ball at the Union Assembly Rooms. There has been no preparation on the part of the Fire Department to turn out. It is understood, however, however, that there will be Fire Companies here from Brooklyn, Newark and Jersey City, and that some of our firemen will take part with the strangers in the fun of throwing the Croton as high as possible up the liberty pole on Laird's-square, corner of Franklin-street and West Broadway. Flags will be raised on the public buildings and shipping, and WASHINGTON's Farewell Address will be read in some of the public schools.

abstract: WINTER GARDEN. Two of the public's best appreciated servants Mrs. JOHN WOOD and Mr. JOSEPH JEFFERSON returned to their legitimate quarters at this popular establishment last evening, and, by the force of fun, dispelled the vapors of a chill and particularly cheerless night.
lead_paragraph: WINTER GARDEN. Two of the public's best appreciated servants Mrs. JOHN WOOD and Mr. JOSEPH JEFFERSON returned to their legitimate quarters at this popular establishment last evening, and, by the force of fun, dispelled the vapors of a chill and particularly cheerless night. It is so long since we have had anything in the shape of downright merriment at a New-York theatre, that the advent of these artists is certainly a circumstance to be rejoiced at. From the time that Mrs. WOOD withdrew from the Winter Garden, the sensation drama, in one shape or other, has had full possession of its respectable stage. Even Mr. JE FERSON, who is by no means of a saturnine and moody disposition, has been compelled, by adverse circumstances, to abstain from making in decorous appeals to the risibility of the audience. It is something that now, under brighter auspices, and in view of a notable reaction in public taste, Mr. STUART has determined to give us a feast of a light and wholesome character, and something more that this feast is presided over by such spirits as Mrs. JOHN WOOD and Mr. JEFFERSON. Two such mirth provokers cannot be found elsewhere. Their efforts last night -- albeit the programme was not attractive for its novelty -- kept the house in a roar. Mrs. JOHN WOOD has lost none of that vehement jollity which has always been the characteristic of her playing, and which never fails to delight an audience. Mr. JEFFERSON is, as heretofore, irreproachable and inimitable, always doing enough, but never exceeding the bounds of good taste. The prominent members of the very efficient company assist Mrs. WOOD in the most desirable way.

abstract: Yesterday morning, between one and two o'clock, a fire broke out in the attic of the house No, 81 Vandam-street, occupied as a bakery and dwelling by WILLIAM NUGENT. The furniture suffered injury to the extent of $100, and the building, owned by Mrs. SPIER, was damaged to the amount of $200; no insurance. Officers PRICE and UNDERHILL, of the Eighth Precinct Police, saved two bakers named KERR and SMITH from suffocation. The fire originated, it is presumed, in the upsetting of a candle in the room occupied by KERR and SMITH.

abstract: The discussion of the part played by mining and minerals in the industry and commerce of the world, which is likely to follow the ratification of the McLane Treaty with Mexico, and the consequent restoration to the supply of the world's wealth of the long-dormant metallic treasures of Western and Central Mexico, may, it is to be hoped, give a fresh and salutary prominence in the public attention of this country to the mineral resources of our own territory. Of all the magnificent materials of human welfare and national progress which Providence has so lavishly bestowed upon the United States, no one has been so strangely neglected by our astute people, as that which lies, so to speak, directly at our feet in almost every section of our common country. We have been driven by the pressure of absolute necessity to make some use of our superb coal-beds; we have made more or less intelligent attempts to put our vast iron mines to profit, and we have rather speculatively played with than practically worked our unrivaled deposits and veins of copper and lead. But nothing can be more just than the strictures addressed by Gov. WRIGHT, our Minister at Berlin, to his fellow-citizens of Indiana and the West, about a year ago, upon the slight and superficial way in which all these industries, and others kindred with them, have been prosecuted in America. Fresh from a visit to the silver mines of the Hartz District, the Governor dilates with great earnestness and good sense upon what he calls our careless and improvident "scratching of the soil," after a few crops of cereals, even where all the indications of mineralogical science give assurance of far more lasting and remunerative resources slumbering but a few feet below the surface of the earth, and asking only the Aladdin's Lamp of wisely directed capital to evoke them into service, the cultivator shifts to other fields, and the treasure is undisturbed.

abstract: A fight occurred in Water-street, on the 9th of last month, between Pedro Ari, a Spaniard, and Thomas Keegan, an Irishman, in the course of which the latter stabbed his antagonist in the abdomen and rendered him helpless. Keegan eluded the Police at the time, and subsequently departed for Savannah, Ga., where it is now ascertained that he is in custody of the criminal authorities. Ever since the affray Ari has been under treatment at the New-York Hospital, and his physicians believe his recovery to be doubtful. Yesterday afternoon the injured man was conveyed to Court, and made a complaint against Keegan, upon which the Grand Jury will probably food an indictment, when an officer will be dispatched to Georgia, with a requisition from the Governor of this State for the return of the accused.

abstract: OF JERSEY CITY. The bill recently introduced into the Legislature of New-Jersey, contemplating the sale of all the land lying under water in front of Jersey City, beyond a certain base line, for the benefit of the State, has aroused a deep feeling of opposition to that measure in the people of Jersey City, who met last evening at Commercial Hall for the purpose of protesting against the bill.
lead_paragraph: OF JERSEY CITY. The bill recently introduced into the Legislature of New-Jersey, contemplating the sale of all the land lying under water in front of Jersey City, beyond a certain base line, for the benefit of the State, has aroused a deep feeling of opposition to that measure in the people of Jersey City, who met last evening at Commercial Hall for the purpose of protesting against the bill. The meeting, though not large, comprised many large property owners, and some of the most influential public men. A series of resolutions and the form of a memorial were adopted, after some remarks expressive of the views of the meeting. They declared that the bill contemplating the appointment of three Commissioners to dispose at public auction of the lands lying under water within the limits of a base line drawn between Vandervorst-street and Constable's Hook, would be doing great injury to the rights of many citizens as riparian owners; would destroy the fisheries, and seriously affect the interests of navigation, and that they accordingly remonstrate against its passage. They declare that the assumption that the State is the owner of all lands lying under water within the ebb and flow of the tide is erroneous, as shown by the uniform legislation of the State. That the grants to individuals of the right to erect wharves and piers does not confer a grant to the land, but is only leave to extend the structure into the navigable waters belonging to the public; that the State is merely the guardian for the whole community, and must act solely as a trustee of the common property, and that it is in this character only that she can confer grants. The attempt to lay upon Hudson County alone this burden of paying the debt of the State, was denounced as ah odious species of special legislation, which should be opposed to the utmost. Messrs. STOUGHTONBERG, Judge MARSH, E.B. "WAKEMAN and Hon. E.R.V. "WRIGHT addressed the meeting at length in support of the resolutions, and a Committee of thirty persons was appointed to go to Trenton and represent these views to the Legislature. The meeting then adjourned.

abstract: The following letter from Judge CONWAY, of Kansas, in vindication of the memory of JOHN BROWN, appears in the Boston Journal:  SIR: I am very much surprised to find, in a late number of your paper, a letter from your excellent correspondent, A.D. RICHARDSON, Esq., in which my name is used to corroborate a most atrocious slander upon the memory of Old JOHN BROWN, of Osawatomie. Mr. RICHARDSON does not himself indorse this...
lead_paragraph: The following letter from Judge CONWAY, of Kansas, in vindication of the memory of JOHN BROWN, appears in the Boston Journal: SIR: I am very much surprised to find, in a late number of your paper, a letter from your excellent correspondent, A.D. RICHARDSON, Esq., in which my name is used to corroborate a most atrocious slander upon the memory of Old JOHN BROWN, of Osawatomie. Mr. RICHARDSON does not himself indorse this wicked calumny, but refers to a conversation he had with me, in which he says that I informed him that BROWN admitted to me that he was engaged in the killing of DOYLE and others, on Potawatamie bank, in 1856. He also cites a conversation with Capt. WALKER, to the same effect. This, Sir, is a mistake, so far as it relates to me, which I cannot see how a gentleman of Mr. RICHARDSON's intelligence could contrive to fall into. Mr. RICHARDSON must, therefore, pardon the directness of my answer, when I assure him emphatically that I never cold him any such thing. Capt. WALKER will also pardon me, when I say to him, most courteously, that I do not believe that BROWN ever told him any such thing. It is, indeed, a wonderful circumstance, taken from any point of view, how many persons have recently sprung up to whom JOHN BROWN long since confided a dreadful secret -- a secret which, if exposed, would have cost him hi[???] life, and which, not being exposed, made any one in it liable to the penalties of a capital offence. And still more wonderful, that those persons are of a class with which BROWN never had any sympathy, and toward which he always maintained a profound aversion!

abstract: It was expected that Hon. HUMPHREY MARSHALL of Kentucky, Hon. THOMAS A.R. NELSON of Tennessee, Hon. J. MORRISON HARRIS of Maryland, and Hon. GEORGE BRIGGS of New-York, would ar-...
lead_paragraph: It was expected that Hon. HUMPHREY MARSHALL of Kentucky, Hon. THOMAS A.R. NELSON of Tennessee, Hon. J. MORRISON HARRIS of Maryland, and Hon. GEORGE BRIGGS of New-York, would arrive in this City last evening, for the purpose of being present at the Union meeting to-night, and consequently the Young Me[???]s Nation Union Club, and other friends of the Union movement arranged to give them a serenade. A short time before the time for the serenade, dispatches were received, stating that all of them, excepting Mr. BRIGGS, had been detained in Philadelphia, and, as a consequence, the serenade was confined to Mr. BRIGGS. But little notice of the intended demonstration had been given, and it was not until 11 o'clock that the services of DODWORTH's Band could be had. At that time, however, there was quite a large gathering in front of the St. Nicholas, and after the first piece had been played, CHESTER DRIGGS, Esq., advanced to the balcony and introduced Hon. GEORGE BRIGGS.

abstract: The notorious confidence-man, Thomas Thompson Ellis, styling himself a " dental physician," whose adventures have been the theme of the newspapers of Canada and the Eastern States, including New-York, for three year past, came to trial yesterday before Recorder BARNARD.
lead_paragraph: The notorious confidence-man, Thomas Thompson Ellis, styling himself a " dental physician," whose adventures have been the theme of the newspapers of Canada and the Eastern States, including New-York, for three year past, came to trial yesterday before Recorder BARNARD. Though often taken before Police magistrates, and committed to the Tombs for examination, he has hitherto, by finesse and address, managed to evade a direct criminal trial. But yesterday, notwithstanding further efforts of his counsel for postponement (and it may here be said, that Ex-Recorder Smith, Ex-Judge Dean and Mr. H.L. Clinton, having been applied to to defend him, refused to do so,) he was confronted with a jury. The special charge, out of many, which was tried, was one of grand larceny, the indictment charging him with obtaining a diamond ring, valued at nearly $200, by fraud, from a patient of his, named Mary Roberts, a lady residing in Broome-street -- the Doctor's office being in Bleecker-street. The lady, it appeared, had been Ellis' patient for some time, and had been cajoled by him into lending him on sundry occasions, sums which in the aggregate amounted to $1,100. In acknowledgment thereof, he had given her notes of hand -- one for $500 on a worthless Pennsylvania Coal Company -- and others, all of which he subsequently obtained from her and destroyed. On Feb. 25, 1858, he "admired" a diamond ring on her finger, asked to look at it, and, permission being granted, put it in his pocket, and never thereafter did Miss Roberts lay eyes on it. And that was the specific charge against him yesterday. Miss Roberts testified clearly to this fact, and bore from the counsel who were not ashamed to defend the "Doctor," as those before named had been, a very rigid cross-examination with considerable equanimity.

abstract: Our readers will remember that we some time since called public attention to the really atrocious recklessness with which the lives of passengers and the property confided to their care are habitually treated on the line of railway travel between Baltimore and Philadelphia.
lead_paragraph: Our readers will remember that we some time since called public attention to the really atrocious recklessness with which the lives of passengers and the property confided to their care are habitually treated on the line of railway travel between Baltimore and Philadelphia. Our remarks were then called forth by an accident which had just occurred at Havre de Grace, to the express car of the mail train for the South -- driven on board of the ferry-boat, with the mail and sleeping-cars attached, to take its chance of coming to a halt before plunging over the bows of the boat into the deep water of the river.

abstract: It does not become us to speak, or to assume to speak, for the Republican Party of the United States. We can, however, and always do, speak very plainly for ourselves; and thirty-two years' experience has enabled us to judge somewhat of the feelings and wishes of those with whom we act. We proclaim, then, as our belief, that at this day nine-tenths of all the opposition to the Democracy in the Free States ...
lead_paragraph: It does not become us to speak, or to assume to speak, for the Republican Party of the United States. We can, however, and always do, speak very plainly for ourselves; and thirty-two years' experience has enabled us to judge somewhat of the feelings and wishes of those with whom we act. We proclaim, then, as our belief, that at this day nine-tenths of all the opposition to the Democracy in the Free States are solidly banded together under the Republican organization. And yet those nine-tenths are perfectly satisfied that a union of all the elements of opposition to the Democracy is desirable; and to produce such a union they are willing to make any reasonable concession. We do not doubt for a moment that if the one-tenth to whom we allude should say to the Republican Party in convention, "Be generous -- act with magnanimity, and give us the Vice-President," the response would be favorable; and that Mr. BATES, Mr. BELL, Mr. CRITTENDEN, or any man of that class, could be placed upon the Republican ticket for Vice-President. There are no better men than they in the whole United States -- none for whom we entertain greater respect; and individually, we should rejoice in the nomination of one of them for Vice-President, and believe that the Republican Party would approve of the act. But when the one-tenth of the Opposition, say to us, as they do, "You must take one of our men as your nominee for the Presidency or we will not act in concert with you;" our reply is -- Never. Much as we desire Union, we cannot and will not recognize the right of one-tenth to dictate to the nine-tenths; and such we believe is the almost unanimous feeling of the people who compose the Republican Party. We believe this feeling is so general, that the nomination by the Chicago Convention of any man for the Presidency who acted against us in 1856, would inevitably insure the defeat of the Republican Party; and we believe, too, that the nomination of any other person than WILLIAM H. SEWARD, would endanger a similar result. This, also, is the conviction of the Democracy; and to produce such a result, is now admitted to be the only game left them to play with any chance of their success. We have no faith in their political honesty, and still less in their political principles; but we know them to be cunning and wise in all that concerns the action of the masses, and when they arrive at the conclusion that the Republican Party can only be defeated by defeating the nomination of WILLIAM H. SEWARD, and find that decision is in accordance with our own judgment, there exists no longer a doubt in our mind, that if SEWARD be not nominated, the Democratic Party will have a reasonable hope of success.

abstract: On Saturday, 18th inst., says the Montreal Herald, the annual races of the Montreal Snow-shoe Club came off at the Mile-End. A large number of ladies and gentlemen attended. A little after 1 o'clock, Gen Sir W.F. WILLIAMS, with another officer, mounted the Judges' balcony, and in spite of the cold the General remained presiding over the sport till it was concluded. Four Indians and a white man entered for the four-mile race -- Takarahonte, Joseph, Charlie Darbie, Pierre Asahatakaure, and Frederick Castle. When the start was given, they moved off in an easy, careless manner, the Indians stealing to the front, and the white man consequently falling back. The time of this race was, 7 min, 40sec., four-mile heat. Mr. F. CASTLE broke down at the end of the second mile, leaving the contest to the Indians. After a stiff fight TAKARAHONTE, who had been second for a good part of the time, came in first, loudly cheered.

abstract: HUNTINGTON, Feb. 20. -- The schr. Hardscrabble, from Rockland, Me., lost anchors off Chatham, Mass., in the gale of the 9th, and blew off to sea, where she lost boat and rudder, and although far at sea when the gale abated, they worked her into and nearly through Long Island Sound, finally going ashore on Floyd's Neck, near Huntington. The snow storm of Saturday (18th) night drove her high upon the shore, and made her leak so that it was difficult to keep the water from reaching the lime, but by bailing and pumping the crew succeeded in doing so, and, yesterday, at low water, threw most of their lime overboard, which was saved by persons on shore. To-day she will be provided with an anchor and temporary rudder, and will probably float off the shore to-night. Without a boat at this season of the year, and loaded as they were with lime, the crew would have all perished had they have struck a rock any distance from shore.
lead_paragraph: HUNTINGTON, Feb. 20. -- The schr. Hardscrabble, from Rockland, Me., lost anchors off Chatham, Mass., in the gale of the 9th, and blew off to sea, where she lost boat and rudder, and although far at sea when the gale abated, they worked her into and nearly through Long Island Sound, finally going ashore on Floyd's Neck, near Huntington. The snow storm of Saturday (18th) night drove her high upon the shore, and made her leak so that it was difficult to keep the water from reaching the lime, but by bailing and pumping the crew succeeded in doing so, and, yesterday, at low water, threw most of their lime overboard, which was saved by persons on shore. To-day she will be provided with an anchor and temporary rudder, and will probably float off the shore to-night. Without a boat at this season of the year, and loaded as they were with lime, the crew would have all perished had they have struck a rock any distance from shore.

abstract: THE STREETS YESTERDAY. -- The combined powers of the salt and sun have been at work upon the snow since it fell; and, yesterday, they had reduced it to that condition which cannot be described appropriately by any other word than "slush." Whereever there was inclination enough, the water ran in mimic brooks. Thanks to the Croton Board, it could not find an outlet in the sewers in very many places, so it kent on its course until here and there veritable ponus were formed. At the junction of Canal-street and Broadway, for instance, it was unsafe for any pedestrian who was not provided with a life-preserver -- in the shape of India Rubber boots -- to attempt a passage. There were a few ladies in Broadway, whom the imperative necessities of their wardrobes, compelled to attempt shopping expeditions. Some of them felt obliged to cross Canal-street, and they would walk up to the edge of the pavement, look into the waste of waters before them with a melancholy gaze, turn and stalk slowly ana meditatively along for a short distance, like cranes on the banks of a country pond, and then beat a retreat altogether, or make a despairing dive for the opposite shore -- curb stone we should say. The same scenes were repeated in the vicinity of St. Paul's Church and the Museum. The polite Policemen here had their hands full, and sometimes their arms, for they were occasionally under the necessity of transporting animated bundles of dry goods from one side to the other of Broadway. During the early part of the day there was a full force of officers in attendance, but as the waters rose higher, in the afternoon, only a single one, and he at least six feet in height, maintained his position. The frightful condition of affairs at length awakened the attention of the authorities. Yesterday the City Inspector's entire force was called together and ordered to be ready for duty on Broadway at an early hour in the evening. Soon after dark several hundred carts and men appeared in the street, and the work of removing the snow and slush was commenced. At midnight the condition of the street had been very much improved, and it was thought that by daylight it would be passable. Other thoroughfares will be cleaned as soon as possible.

abstract: -- The Baltimore Patriot, of the 20th, says: "Yesterday morning, about 9 1/2 o'clock, smoke was discovered issuing from the door and windows of the warehouse No. 305 West Baltimore-street, occupied by Messrs. FRA K F. HORNER & BRO., wholesale dealers in foreign fan y goods. Messrs. HORNER & BRO. have insurance on their stock to the amount of $50,000, $20,000 of which is in offices in this city, and $35,000 in foreign offices. In this city the insurances are $10,000 in the Firemen's Office, $5,000 in the Baltimore Fire Insurance Company, and $5,000 in the American Fire Insurance Company. The foreign offices are mostly located in New-York City. Mr. Wm. T. HOOPER is the agent. The warehouse belongs to Mr. GRANGER, and the damage thereto, about between $600 and $700, is insured in the Equitable office of this city. A good part of the stock injured and destroyed was not unpacked from the cases in which they were received from New-York only a few days since."

lead_paragraph: The political aspect of the country fills the public mind with painful apprehension. The people are everywhere disturbed with fear of some disastrous crisis. Many are alarmed for the safety of the Union. All are conscious that the sentiment of fraternity which once linked the States together, even more firmly than the compact of the Constitution itself, has been rudely shaken, and that discord has crept into the relationship of communities which should have found, both in the interests of the present and in the memories of the past the strongest motives for mutual regard and confidence.

abstract: The Tribune has rather startled its Republican brethren by openly advocating the nomination of EDWARD BATES for the Presidency. It has not been thought impossible, for some months, by very many sagacious members of the Republican Party, that a contingency might arise which should render this nomination expedient:--but they have been hoping that the ...
lead_paragraph: The Tribune has rather startled its Republican brethren by openly advocating the nomination of EDWARD BATES for the Presidency. It has not been thought impossible, for some months, by very many sagacious members of the Republican Party, that a contingency might arise which should render this nomination expedient:--but they have been hoping that the necessity might be averted and that the canvass would assume so open and direct a shape as to make the contest purely one of principle, -- each side nominating its representative men, and aiming at a result which should decide something, instead of evading the issue and leaving the real points of difference to be contested hereafter. The Tribune, however, begins by inviting the contingency. It assumes, as already settled, that the Democrats will nominate DOUGLAS, and thus ovade the issue which the selection of WISE, STEPHENS, or any distinctively Southern man would raise; and upon this assumption it proceeds to show that the Republicans cannot hope for success unless they secure the support of other parties. The Courier and Enquirer resents this policy with great show of indignation, and announces its determination to bolt the nomination of any man who did not act, heartily and zealously, with the Republican Party in 1856. The only thing which gives this pronunciamiento any importance, is the fact that the Courier and Enquirer is the special organ of the State Administration, -- having been adopted as such, through the Bank Department, within a week after Gov. MORGAN's administration.

abstract: These are very uncommon poems; full of delicacy without weakness, and power without coarseness. We do not find in them any trace of the ravings peculiar to the school that names itself "passionate;" yet the very cadence of the lines reveals a truly passionate nature in the writer. The pieces are mostly of the occasional class, and we do not, therefore, get much beyond the emotional element.

abstract: Our readers doubtless recollect the exclusion some weeks since of a negro servant from Rev. Dr. CHEEVER's Church, and the discussion which ensued thereupon. It was stated at the time that the servant belonged to a "distinguished foreigner," whose name, however, was not given to the public. In the London Anti-Slavery Reporter for Feb. 1, we find a letter from the gentleman himself, narrating the circumstances of the case. He is spoken of by the Reporter as "the Landdrost, J.J. RUCHUSSEN," -- but from what region of the world he comes, it does not inform us. His letter is temperate and sensible. The circumstances of the case are precisely as they have been already stated. The Landdrost says that he "dare not condemn Dr. C. in the matter, as he does not know his opinion of it." Before this time he has probably seen the action of the Church on the subject, in which Dr. C. washed his hands of all responsibility, and expressed his regret at the occurrence. It evidently made some impression abroad, however as the Reporter expressed the opinion that no more money should be collected in Great Britain for the support of the Church on Union-square until this matter should be cleared up.
lead_paragraph: Our readers doubtless recollect the exclusion some weeks since of a negro servant from Rev. Dr. CHEEVER's Church, and the discussion which ensued thereupon. It was stated at the time that the servant belonged to a "distinguished foreigner," whose name, however, was not given to the public. In the London Anti-Slavery Reporter for Feb. 1, we find a letter from the gentleman himself, narrating the circumstances of the case. He is spoken of by the Reporter as "the Landdrost, J.J. RUCHUSSEN," -- but from what region of the world he comes, it does not inform us. His letter is temperate and sensible. The circumstances of the case are precisely as they have been already stated. The Landdrost says that he "dare not condemn Dr. C. in the matter, as he does not know his opinion of it." Before this time he has probably seen the action of the Church on the subject, in which Dr. C. washed his hands of all responsibility, and expressed his regret at the occurrence. It evidently made some impression abroad, however as the Reporter expressed the opinion that no more money should be collected in Great Britain for the support of the Church on Union-square until this matter should be cleared up.

abstract: Quite a sharp--not to say bitter--controversy seems to be raging between the Tribune and the Buffalo Commercial Advertiser, on a point of some political and professional interest. It seems that Mr. WENDELL, one of the Printers to Congress under this Administration, employed a Mr. JEWETT, a proprietor of the Buffalo Commercial, to do part of the work ...
lead_paragraph: Quite a sharp--not to say bitter--controversy seems to be raging between the Tribune and the Buffalo Commercial Advertiser, on a point of some political and professional interest. It seems that Mr. WENDELL, one of the Printers to Congress under this Administration, employed a Mr. JEWETT, a proprietor of the Buffalo Commercial, to do part of the work under his contract. The Tribune charges that this was in payment for services rendered by the Commercial in sustaining the Fillmore movement in 1856, and thus aiding Mr. BUCHANAN's election. This imputation is somewhat tartly repelled by the Commercial, that paper declaring that it secured the work merely because it was the lowest bidder, and without any reference whatever to political considerations. The Tribune scouts all this as sheer evasion.

abstract: The administration of justice in this City is almost as entertaining, though by no means so prompt and satisfactory, as in the judicial annals of Oriental life, preserved in that most veracious collection of histories, the "Arabian Nights' Tales." The stolid flow of litigation, drifting sluggishly on from precedent to precedent, is constantly refreshed and diversified ...
lead_paragraph: The administration of justice in this City is almost as entertaining, though by no means so prompt and satisfactory, as in the judicial annals of Oriental life, preserved in that most veracious collection of histories, the "Arabian Nights' Tales." The stolid flow of litigation, drifting sluggishly on from precedent to precedent, is constantly refreshed and diversified by little eddies and jets of individual originality, often quite worthy of the Cadi who sentenced Bedreddin to death for making creamtarts without red pepper; and, however suitors may moan and lament over the rough course of true law in New-York, the public may fairly take to itself such small comfort for its great expenses in maintaining our judicial system as it can find in the quirks and quiddities of our Daniels voted to the judgment seat. We cannot, therefore, suffer our readers to lose the benefit of one of the most singular exhibitions ever made "on this or any other Bench," Dogberry's and Sir Peter Laurie's inclusive. This striking spectacle was yesterday witnessed in the Court of General Sessions, and before Mr. Recorder BARNARD.

abstract: Lieut. Calvin F. Thomas, United States Navy, died at Buffalo, Feb. 18. His first service was on the African Coast, whence he returned as Sailing Master of a prize, a captured slaver, which was sent to Boston. He then rejoined the Naval Academy for a time, and after a year of service on the Coast Survey was examined and appointed a Passed Midshipman. Immediately thereafter he was appointed to the Arctic, and was one of her officers in the celebrated sounding expedition made preliminary to the laying of the Atlantic Telegraph Cable.
lead_paragraph: Lieut. Calvin F. Thomas, United States Navy, died at Buffalo, Feb. 18. abstract: -- According to the report of Adjt.-Gen. STONE, of Massachusetts, the number of enrolled militia in that State is 152,112. Active militia, 5,739. The active, or volunteer troops are organized into three divisions, which are subdivided into six brigades, nine regiments, seven battalions, and eighty-seven companies. In the first brigade there are seven companies of Infantry, two of light dragoons and one of light artillery. In the second brigade, fifteen infantry, one light dragoons. Third brigade, fourteen infantry, two riflemen, one light dragoons. Fourth brigade, fifteen infantry, three riflemen, one (section) light artillery. Fifth brigade, eight infantry, two riflemen. Sixth brigade, ten infantry, one cavalry. During the year 200 officers have been commissioned and 215 discharged, Vacancies at the close of year, 30.

abstract: THE CASE OF ELLA BURNS -- THE CHILD REMANDED TO MRS. BURNS. -- The Philadelphia North American of yesterday says: "Our Supreme Court, sitting in banco, yesterday decided (by a majority of three Judges to one) that EVA BELL WHITTEN, commonly known as 'ELLA BURNS,' be remanded to the care of Mrs. BURNS, to whom she was apprenticed by her father at the age of two years and eight months, and by whom she has been treated with maternal solicitude and affection. In other words, the Supreme Court of Pennsylvania declines interfering with the deliberate decision of a Judge of the Supreme Court of New-York. That decision gave the child to the care of Mrs. BURNS, under the guardianship of Mr. THAYER, one of the most reputable citizens of New-York; and Judge DAVIES, who heard and decided the case in New-York, consented, on application from Mr. THAYER, that the child should be permitted to visit Pennsylvania, and to read there, in public, or in private families, under restrictions which have not been violated. While Judge READ was speaking, the ladies who had charge of little ELLA were over-whelmed with dismay at the possibility of the Court taking her from their custody; but when the other Judges commenced, with an opposite view of the case, their feelings found vent in tears, in which the little child, from sympathy, freely joined. When the final order of the Court was made, little ELLA was seized by her friends and covered with kisses, and the parties left the Court in a high state of excitement. The father of ELLA was not present."

abstract: -- Why cannot our City Government make some provision for clearing away the crossings, at least of the principal streets? With the present accumulation of snow and mud, it is almost impossible to cross Broadway, or to reach the sidewalk from an omnibus. The public are entirely dependent on the voluntary efforts of the ragged boys and girls, who supply the place of a street department very well at a few of the principal thoroughfares. But the matter ought not to be left wholly in their hands.

abstract: The weekly report from the institutions, made to the Board of Governors yesterday, stated that the number of inmates on Feb. 18 was 8,327 -- a decrease of 57, as compared with the number reported the week before. The time for the meeting of the Board is 4 o'clock. At that hour there was a quorum of members in the building, but it was not until 20 minutes of 5 that a sufficient number to do business was present in the meeting-room. After the President, B.F. PINCKNEY, and Governors BRUENINGHAUSEN and SMITH had waited nearly half an hour, the other members were sent for, but it was not until the President threatened to adjourn the Board for want of a quorum that they were brought in. Such delay is frequent in the Board, and often causes trouble. The President announced his intention to enforce a more prompt attendance.

Strong interests are enlisted in the support of each; whether both are to be passed or not remains to be seen.

abstract: -The New-Orleans Picayune notices the fact that the last annual report of the Louisiana institution for the deaf and dumb was printed by the inmates of the institution, from the setting of the type to the press-work. By an act of the Legislature, approved last March, the Board of Administrators were authorized to introduce printing for the purpose of instructing the pupils. This was done; and the Board say that the mute boys engaged in setting type and in press-work, have learned with two-fold the rapidity of speaking persons under similar circumstances; they are passionately fond of the occupation, and prefer engaging in it to any of their other recreations. Their teachers find that it furnishes an important auxiliary to the department of instruction; a good scholar and a good printer can be made of a mute sooner than it would be possible to render him either, alone.

lead_paragraph: The Seventh Regiment, National Guard, Col. MARSHALL LEFFERTS commanding, left this City yesterday afternoon, to assist in the celebration of this semi-national holiday at Washington. In compliance with a general order, the Regiment assembled at Lafayette Hall at 3 o'clock P.M., dressed in a full Winter uniform of gray, with knapsacks. About 3 o'clock the order to march was given, and the companies fell into line and proceeded down Broadway, marching in flank upon the sidewalk, two or three abreast, in the following order, the accumulated mud and snow rendering it impossible for them to take the centre of the street: National Guard Troop, Capt. Perley; Band of forty pieces; Field and Staff Officers; Company Three, Capt. Price; Seventh, Capt. Munroe; First, Capt. Bensel; Second, Capt. Shaler; Fourth, Capt. Reblet; Eighth, Lieut. Smith commanding; Fifth, Capt. Speight; and Sixth, Capt. Nevers. By companies they stood as follows:

abstract: The Jail at Waverly, Tenn., was attacked by a mob of desperate characters on Friday night, Feb. 10, and six prisoners were set at liberty. The Nashville Union gives the following particulars: "On Friday-night, the 10th inst., a party of desperadoes, consisting of about thirty men, armed with double-barreled shot-guns, &c., attacked Mr. MCGRE, the jailor at Waverly, as he was going to the jail about 7 o'clock in the evening, confined and gagged him; took the key of the outside door from him, and then carried him to a secure place, and while a part kept watch over him, the others went to work and cut away the inside door, which, being iron, occupied four or five hours. They then released six prisoners confined in the jail, three of whom were sent from Dickson County for safe-keeping. The three from Humphreys County were: D.L. CROCKETT, confined under charges of murder and theft; ISHAM BETHEL, for passing counterfeit money, and -- -- MCKIMMONS, for stealing. The mob then started off with the prisoners and the jailor, and having carried the latter about five miles, released him. The jailor returned to Waverly about 3 o'clock Saturday morning.
lead_paragraph: The Jail at Waverly, Tenn., was attacked by a mob of desperate characters on Friday night, Feb. 10, and six prisoners were set at liberty. abstract: We publish, to-day, a careful and accurate sketch of the origin and history of the disease which has made its appearance among us within the last few years, under the perfectly unintelligible and formidable name of Diphtheria, This sketch has been prepared for us by an accomplished surgeon of this City, connected with one of our largest public hospitals, ...
lead_paragraph: We publish, to-day, a careful and accurate sketch of the origin and history of the disease which has made its appearance among us within the last few years, under the perfectly unintelligible and formidable name of Diphtheria, This sketch has been prepared for us by an accomplished surgeon of this City, connected with one of our largest public hospitals, and we trust may produce some salutary effect upon the excited and terrified public mind. It will be seen that this novel adversary, who is commonly supposed to be going about seeking whom he may devour, is simply an old foe with a new face, from whom we have nothing really strange and exceptional in the way of devastation to expect. It is quite true that the practice of salting the snow in our thoroughfares has already done not a little to deteriorate the average health as well as the average comfort of our population. But this, as will be seen, is to be attributed simply to the fact that by dissolving marine or muriatic acid saturated with mineral alkali, otherwise known as muriate of soda, otherwise again known as "common salt," in water, or ice, or snow, you expand the liquid, augment its capacity for heat, and consequently depress its temperature. Any industrious housekeeper, who has accelerated the process of freezing "iced-cream" by putting rock-salt into her "freezer," will readily appreciate this fact, even if she fails to comprehend its philosophical explanation. The process of strewing our snow-covered streets with salt, accordingly, subjects every man, woman, or child, whose feet may be immersed in the solution thus produced, (and now vulgarly known as "Broadway at the crossings,") to the immediate subtraction from his, her, or its body, of a certain measure of caloric essential to the due fulfillment of the vital functions. In other words, so long, as we submit to the despotism of our Omnibus Companies and owners, we may expect to have chills, rheumatism, and colds in the head.

lead_paragraph: After Mr. ALLEN came SANFORD HOWARD, Esq., of the Boston Cultivator, on the subject of horses. The horse, said Mr. HOWARD, is a native of the Eastern Continent, and is still found wild in portions of Asia. In different countries we always find breeds with certain peculiarities, which adapt them to the soil and climate. The horse was early brought wild into this country, and from those thus introduced sprang the wild horses found on the plains ot Mexico. Tne Arabian horse is placed at the head of his species, though how long he has possessed this leadership is unknown. Job's sublime description of the war-horse could hardly apply to any other than the Arabian, and the sculptures obtained by Mr. LAYARD from the ruins of Nineveh reveal the fact that the horses of that day varied little from the present Arabian steed. They stand unrivaled for carrying great weights long distances. It is doubtful if any of the best type of these horses until quite recently have found their way to this country. The English race-horse stands at the head of all horses for speed. He is of modern origin. The term thorough-bred, which is applied to him, indicates that he is of pure blood, but this is not true; he being derived from a mixture of the Egyptian, Syrian, Turkish, Arabian and Grecian breeds. The roadster requires a different conformation from the racer. The latter requires to be nearly of the model of the hare; but this outline would ill become the roadster. The racer should have a long back; the roadster a short one. The racer requires a long pastern; the roadster a short one. So again the roadster requires the oblique shoulders, while many of our best racers have upright ones. The best illustration of the roadster we have in New-England is the Morgan horse. The coach horse belongs to a still different class. They should have fine hair, elegant outline, and showy. In England the Cleveland bay is the most popular, and they have lately been introduced into Virginia. Omnibus horses are much required in all our large cities. The Norman horse is the best breed of this variety I have seen They have great strength, are hardy and can travel with a heavy load from eight to ten miles an hour. Their height is about 15 hands, and their weight about 1,200 pounds. They are well adapted to farm labor. Draft horses are only suitable for heavy work, and the only gait required for them is the walk. They should have an upright shoulder, or nearly so, this being more favorable for power than the oblique. The leading breeds are the large English draft horse (weighing sometimes 2,400 pounds), the Suffolk, and the Clydesdale.

abstract: -- City Court Calendar for this day, Nos. 40, 34, 35, 37 1/2, 50, 51, 52, 57, 58, 59, 60, 63, 65, 66, 18, 22, 26, 32, 5. In the Court of Sessions, a Jury was obtained, after an effort of three days, in the case of LAMBERTSON. The case will be proceeded with to-day. The injunction obtained by IRA BUCKMAN, restraining the Common Council from acting upon the Mayor's veto in the Grand-street Railroad Grant, was dissolved yesterday by Judge SCRUGHAM, and immediately after one was obtained from the City Court to the same effect as the first. A special meeting of the Common Council had been called for this evening, in anticipation of the dissolution of the injunction, to act on the matter, but the new injunction will prevent any definite action to-night.

abstract: Mary Burke, on the 22d January, stole a watch from Richard Palmer, valued at $150. About midnight -- shortly before or a little after -- the twain were riding in a Third-avenue car, and made a mutual acquaintance. On leaving the car, they had a slight farewell passage of affection, at the corner of the street, during which Palmer missed his watch. An arrest followed, and yesterday the jury convicted Mary Burke. The Recorder sentenced her to three years and two months in the State prison.
lead_paragraph: Mary Burke, on the 22d January, stole a watch from Richard Palmer, valued at $150. abstract: The great Union Mass Meeting assigned for the eve of WASHINGTON'S birthday came off last evening at the Cooper Institute, and was made the occasion of inaugurating, in this City, the new party on the platform of the Union, the Constitution and the enforcement of the laws." Mr. JAMES W. GERARD presided and addressed ...
lead_paragraph: The great Union Mass Meeting assigned for the eve of WASHINGTON'S birthday came off last evening at the Cooper Institute, and was made the occasion of inaugurating, in this City, the new party on the platform of the Union, the Constitution and the enforcement of the laws." Mr. JAMES W. GERARD presided and addressed the meeting at considerable length, defining his position in the present movement. He was followed by Hon. J. MORRISON HARRIS, of Maryland, in a speech of some length, appealing to the conservative men of the North to maintain the rights of the South. Hon. GEORGE BRIGGS gave a history of the late contest for Speaker of the House of Representatives, and defended his own action. Mr. THEODORE E. TOMLINSON made an impassioned and patriotic address, in which he expressed his willingness to vote for Gen. SCOTT for President. Gen. SCOTT, was present, and was frequently and enthusiastically cheered. The room was about filled, and the proceedings were characterized by great unanimity.

abstract: Mo. -- Some boys and men having become exasperated for some reason at the keeper of a disreputable house in Belleville, Mo., attempted to repress the nuisance on the 15th inst. by storming the building. The wife of the keeper of the establishment, whose name was JEROT, thought to drive the mob away by injuring some of those who composed it, and, seizing a double-barreled gun, ran to the door and discharged it at a gentleman by the name of KARR, who happened to be passing, but who had no connection whatever with the affray. She missed him, and her husband seized the weapon and fired the other barrel. The ball this time entered Mr. KARR's nostril, and lodged in the back of his head, inflicting a wound from which there seemed to be no possibility of recovery. JBROT immediately fled to St. Louis, where officers were searching for him.
