abstract: There is another project on foot at Albany for providing, compensation for the Aldermen and Common Councilmen of this City, in the shape of a yearly salary. It seems, at first sight, rather unfair for the City to accept the services of these eminent men without remunerating them in the usual manner. But the fact is that the question is entirely one of expediency, and ...
lead_paragraph: There is another project on foot at Albany for providing, compensation for the Aldermen and Common Councilmen of this City, in the shape of a yearly salary. It seems, at first sight, rather unfair for the City to accept the services of these eminent men without remunerating them in the usual manner. But the fact is that the question is entirely one of expediency, and justice is in no way mixed up in it. The two branches of the Common Council were established, not in order to provide a certain number of citizens with salaries, but to provide the City with a government. Nobody pretends, or has ever pretended, that one of the objects of the Charter is to secure forty-three gentlemen, to be designated by the electors, in the enjoyment of comfortable incomes. Its sole object is to provide a legislative body for the government of the municipality. This conceded, the question at once presents itself: Do we get a better government by not paying the Aldermen and Common Councilmen, than by paying them? If this can be answered truly in the affirmative, and we believe it can, it disposes completely of the matter in controversy. If the objects of the Charter are best carried out by withholding salaries, the salaries ought to be withheld; if not, not. The personal needs of the legislators have nothing to do with it. That the Boards which have been elected under the present Charter contrast very favorably with their predecessors under the old one, we think is tolerably well established. The government of the City is still bad, but it might be and has been worse, and the sovereign people has not, in the later manifestations of its will, dealt so hardly with us as on many former occasions; and the reason is obvious. In a City like this, a man who can do the duties of an Alderman, and earn his bread as well, is pretty sure to be an honester, more respectable and better-behaved man than an Alderman by profession. In other words, in the existing condition of ward politics, a person who has no ostensible means of support, and looks to being elected a municipal legislator for board and lodging, is pretty sure to be a worthless adventurer, and having no affairs of his own, is the last person in the world to be charged with the management of the affairs of other people. We do not assert or insinuate that penniless people are unfit for office, but we know as a matter of fact that penniless people in New-York, who take to ward politics for a livelihood, are, in nine cases out of ten, incorrigible scamps.

abstract: In the evening, an animated sheep discussion was had. Mr. GOULD, on the relative value of Spanish and French Merinoes, quoted Mr. SANFORD, of Vermont, (good authority,) as recommending the French variety to pioneer with at the West. Western farmers are captivated with their fine form and purchase them. Afterwards they are the more easily induced to take hold of the Spanish, and to like them.

abstract: After a session of three whole days and nearly three whole nights, the grand Democratic Convention adjourned at a late hour on Saturday night. A graphic account of the proceedings, by our regular reporter, will be found in another column; and yet no account, however graphic, can do justice to such an infernal pow-wow. We have never seen--not even at the famous Petersburgh Convention--such disorder, such tumult, such wild and frantic uproar.
lead_paragraph: From the Richmond Whig, Feb. 20.

abstract: I have just returned from Annapolis, our State capital, where official duties and professional services have required my attention for some days past. The crowd of lobbyers has been and is enormous. Never before in the history of our State has there been so much excitement or so large a representation of "outsiders" at the ancient city. Every hotel and boarding-house is filled to overflowing.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE, Saturday, Feb. 18,1800 -- P.M.

abstract: ACCIDENT ON THE BOSTON & WORCESTER RAILROAD -- The mail train for New-York over the Boston & Worcester Railroad, which left this city at 6 1/2 o'clock Sunday evening, met with an accident, which detained the passengers and mails all night. The train, consisting of the locomotives Yankee, Neptune and Vesuvius, one heavy baggage and mail car, and one passenger car, in which were 47 passengers, with a snow-plow in advance, was running at the rate of about 15 miles an hour, and had Proceeded to within a third of a mile of the Cordaville station, in Southboro[???], when suddenly the Neptune became disabled from the breaking of some portion of the machinery, and immediately broke down. The Vesuvius drove over the Neptuns, demolishing its own and the tenders of the two forward engines, and was itself so badly damaged as to be unserviceable. The forward platforms of the baggage and passenger cars were torn up, and one seat broken, but with this exception, the cars were not materially damaged. The passengers, among whom was Mrs. JOHN WOOD, the actress, escaped injury. The only person harmed by the accident was a fireman named DAVIS, who received a Severe Wound in his wrist ï¿½- Boston Journal, 20th.
lead_paragraph: ACCIDENT ON THE BOSTON & WORCESTER RAILROAD -- The mail train for New-York over the Boston & Worcester Railroad, which left this city at 6 1/2 o'clock Sunday evening, met with an accident, which detained the passengers and mails all night. abstract: We prepared for the rougher travel on foot through the mountain forests to Tahawus, ten miles distant. Here the expectant tourist in this region may be instructed in regard to such prepation. Every arrangement should be as simple as possible. A man needs only a stout flannel hunting shirt, coarse and trustworthy trousers, woolen stockings, large heavy boots well saturated ...
lead_paragraph: We prepared for the rougher travel on foot through the mountain forests to Tahawus, ten miles distant. Here the expectant tourist in this region may be instructed in regard to such prepation. Every arrangement should be as simple as possible. A man needs only a stout flannel hunting shirt, coarse and trustworthy trousers, woolen stockings, large heavy boots well saturated with a composition of beeswax and canow, a sort felt hat, and strong buckskin gloves. A woman needs a stout flannel dress, over shortened crinoline, of short dimensions, with loops and buttons to adjust its length; a hood and cape of the same materials, made so as to envelop the head and bust, and leave the arms free; woolen stockings, stout calfskin boots that cover the legs to the knee, well saturated with beeswax and tallow, and an India-rubber satchel for necessary toilet materials. Provisions, also, should be simple. The hunters live chiefly on bread or crackers, and maple sugar. The usual preparation is a sufficient stock of Boston crackers, pilot bread, or common loaf bread; butter, tea or coffee, pepper and salt, an ample quantity of maple sugar, and some salted pork, to use in frying or boiling fish, birds and game. The utensils for cooking are a short-handled frying-pan, a broad and shallow tin pan, tin tea or coffee-pot, tin plates and cups, knives, forks and spoons. These, with shawls or overcoats, and India rubber capes to keep off the rain, the guides will carry, with gun, axe and fishing-tackle. Sportsmen who expect to camp out some time, should take with them a light tent. The guides, will fish, hunt, work, build camps, and do all other necessary service, for two dollars a day and food. It is proper here to remark that the tourist should never enter this wilderness earlier than the middle of August. Then the flies and mosquitos, the intolerable pests of the forests, are rapidly disappearing, and fine weather may be expected. The sportsman must go in June or July for trout, and in October for deer. -- Art Journal.

abstract: Madame eats little, but she is a dencate feeder, and she and I perfectly agree on one point -- we both love a change dearly. The same dish never appears twice in the same week, except by particular desire. Women are very observing. Madame probably saw, from my habits of life, that my finances were not very flourishing; and when she gave me my bill at the end of the month I was almost ashamed to pay it. There were several things to be learned in the kitchen. I saw how Blot made a potage au gras and a maigre, a puree of vegetables, a vol au vent, and, above all, a salad. I also learned how, with a handful of coals or charcoal, and a fourneau or range 40 inches long and 34 wide, a dinner could be served hot and fresh for a party of eight. The fuel consumed in this kitchen in a year would not keep going the kitchen of a hotel of the same size in England for one week. -- Once a Week.
lead_paragraph: Madame eats little, but she is a dencate feeder, and she and I perfectly agree on one point -- we both love a change dearly. abstract: The shoemakers of Lynn met again at Liberty Hall, on Saturday evening, to hear the report of the committee to visit the manufacturers. The large hall was densely crowded. The report was of a favorable character, with two exceptions. J.W. Neale and Isaac Newhall refuse to make any compromise whatever. Mr. Newhall stated that if it was for his interest to hire "jours" cheap, he should do so in ...
lead_paragraph: The shoemakers of Lynn met again at Liberty Hall, on Saturday evening, to hear the report of the committee to visit the manufacturers. The large hall was densely crowded. The report was of a favorable character, with two exceptions. J.W. Neale and Isaac Newhall refuse to make any compromise whatever. Mr. Newhall stated that if it was for his interest to hire "jours" cheap, he should do so inspite of outside influences. Three groans were then given for Mr. Newhall, and three cheers were given for the rest of the manufacturers who were willing to cooperate with them in the movement. It was stated by the committee that some of the manufacturers would pay as high as $300 to help carry the strike to a successful issue. This announcement was followed by three hearty cheers.

abstract: The first substantial victory for Judge DOUGLAS in the South has been achieved. Returns have been received in New-Orleans from the First, Second and part of the Third districts, showing that more than two-thirds of the delegates elected to the State Convention, which is to meet on the 5th March, are in favor of STEPHEN A. DOUGLAS, and will elect delegates to the Charleston Convention instructed to vote for him.

abstract: The servants of the hall, headed by the steward, or maitre d'hotel, with his rod of office brought the dishes to the table in formal procession. Their approach and arrival were usually announced by the sounding of trumpets and music. Those who served at the table itself, whose business was chiefly to carve, and present the wine, were of still higher rank--never less than esquires ...
lead_paragraph: The servants of the hall, headed by the steward, or maitre d'hotel, with his rod of office brought the dishes to the table in formal procession. Their approach and arrival were usually announced by the sounding of trumpets and music. Those who served at the table itself, whose business was chiefly to carve, and present the wine, were of still higher rank--never less than esquires -- and often, in the halls of princes and great chiefs, noble barons. The meal itself was conducted with the same degree of ceremony, of which a vivid picture may be drawn from the work called the Menagier de Paris" composed about the year 1,393. When it was announced that the dinner was ready, the guests advanced to the hall, led ceremoniously by two maitres d' hotel, who showed them their places, and served them with water to wash their hands before they began.They found the tables spread with fine tablecloths, and covered with a profusion of richly-ornamented plate, consisting of salt-cellars, goblets, pots or cups for drinking, spoons, &c. At the high table the meats were eaten from slices of bread, called trenchers, (tranchoirs,) which, after the meats were eaten, were thrown into vessels called couloures. In a conspicuous part of the hall stood the dresser, or cupboard, which was covered with vessels of plate, which two esquires carried thence to the table to replace those which were emptied. Two other esquires were occupied in bringing wine to the dresser, from whence it was served to the guests at the tables. The dishes, forming a number of courses, varying according to the occasion, were brought in by valets, led by two esquires. Anassecur, or placer, took the dishes from the hands of the valets, and arranged them in their places on the table. After these courses, fresh table-cloths were laid, and the entremets were brought, consisting of sweets, jellies, &c, many of them molded into elegant or fantastic forms; and, in the middle of the table, raised above the rest, were placed a swan, peacocks, or pheasants, dressed up in their feathers, with their beaks and feet gilt. In less sumptuous entertainments the expensive course of entremets was usually omitted. Last of all came the dessert, consisting of cheese, confectioneries, fruit, &c, concluded by what was called the issue, (departure from table,) consisting of a draught of hypocras, and the bonte-hors, (turn out,) wine and spices served round, which terminated the repast. The guests then washed their hands and repaired into another room, where they were served with wine and sweetmeats, and after a short time they separated. The dinner served slowly and ceremoniously, must have occupied a considerable length of time. After the guests had left the hall, the servers and attendants took their places at the tables. -- Art Journal.

abstract: The Leavenworth (K.T.) Times, of the 16th inst., says that the telegraph wires have been cut of late so as to prevent communication between that place and Kansas City. For some days the operators were unble to detect where the break was, but finally the operators from Kansas City took their instruments out on the line, and, by testing in several places, found that about four miles from town the wire was taken off from the poles, and a leather string wound around it for some distance, and the wire cut in two with a file and placed upon the poles. As several horses were stolen on the night that communication was interrupted, it is supposed that the thieves out the wire to avoid arrest.

abstract: The Five Points and the streets adjacent have been, for half a century, the reproach and opprobrium of New-York. St. Giles, London, in its worst estate, was never a more complete cage of unclean birds than this festering plague-spot of our goodly City. Here murder and lust, drunkenness and theft, the most abject poverty and the most beastly sensuallty, joined hands.
lead_paragraph: The Five Points and the streets adjacent have been, for half a century, the reproach and opprobrium of New-York. St. Giles, London, in its worst estate, was never a more complete cage of unclean birds than this festering plague-spot of our goodly City. Here murder and lust, drunkenness and theft, the most abject poverty and the most beastly sensuallty, joined hands. This side the infernal pit, it was impossible to conceive of lower, deeper, fouler degradation. Pious and virtuous citizens deemed all effort to reform the denizens of the place hopeless, and if respectable people visited it, they did so only under the protection of a policeman, and even then, as they conceived, perilled their lives in the act. Its inhabitants were the pariahs of our social system; outcasts, to whom there remained no hope of return to their lost heritage of humanity; human swine, left to wallow in their own filthiness and degradation; fallen spirits, for whom was reserved only the blackness of despair.

abstract: The sun was created with me, with you; and by and by, when we had got over the morning of infancy, we sat on a wall, in a field, on a hill, at our own little bedroom window, and our childish eyes being by that time opened, we saw the sun go down for the first time. Nor are these pleasures and advantages confined to the external world, to the sensations it inspires, or the influence it exerts upon us. No human passion, no emotion, the fiercest or the tenderest, comes to us at secondhand. The experience and observation of a thousand years, all the metaphysical and poetical, and dramatic books that ever were written, cannot add a jot to the duration or intensity of any emotion of ours. They may exercise it, but they cannot form it, nor instruct it; nor, were they fifty times as many and as profound, could they dwarf it. It lies in our hearts in original creation, complete, alone; like my life and yours. -- Cornhill Magazine.
lead_paragraph: The sun was created with me, with you; and by and by, when we had got over the morning of infancy, we sat on a wall, in a field, on a hill, at our own little bedroom window, and our childish eyes being by that time opened, we saw the sun go down for the first time. Nor are these pleasures and advantages confined to the external world, to the sensations it inspires, or the influence it exerts upon us. No human passion, no emotion, the fiercest or the tenderest, comes to us at secondhand. The experience and observation of a thousand years, all the metaphysical and poetical, and dramatic books that ever were written, cannot add a jot to the duration or intensity of any emotion of ours. They may exercise it, but they cannot form it, nor instruct it; nor, were they fifty times as many and as profound, could they dwarf it. It lies in our hearts in original creation, complete, alone; like my life and yours. -- Cornhill Magazine.

abstract: The Chicago Journal reports a fatal affray which occurred in that city, Feb. 15, resulting in the death of a well-known citizen, HENRY MCAULEY, Esq. On Monday night Mr. F.P. SHESKIN, a tin roof manufacturer on Lake-street, was at a ball given at Metropolitan Hall, for the benefit of the Catholic Asylum. At a very late hour Mr. MCAULEY entered the hall, and shortly after accosted Mr. SHESKIN, and made some insulting remarks in regard to a lady with whom that gentleman was dancing. Mr. SHESKIN repulsed him, and the managers of the ball perceiving that Mr. MCAULEY was very much intoxicated, expelled him from the hall. On the succeeding night (Tuesday) Mr. SHESKIN was in the St. Charles saloon, kept by Mr. M. CONLEY, on South Clark-street, when Mr. MCAULEY entered. Immediately on seeing him, Mr. SHESKIN exclaimed: "Here you are! you are the man I was looking for!" or words to that effect, at the same striking him a blow in the forehead, directly between the eyes and at the top of the nose. MCAULEY fell to the floor, but got up and went out of the saloon. In a few moments he returned, and as he came in SHESKIN gave him another blow, which again prostrated him. He died on the following day. Mr. MCAULEY was an old resident of Chicago and very wealthy.
lead_paragraph: The Chicago Journal reports a fatal affray which occurred in that city, Feb. 15, resulting in the death of a well-known citizen, HENRY MCAULEY, Esq. On Monday night Mr. F.P. abstract: The citizens of Brooklyn were aroused to the exhibition of an unusual degree of patriotism yesterday. Many private buildings and all the public institutions displayed the National ensign, and salutes were fired in each District. Mayor POWELL reviewed the Ringgold Horse Guards, which paraded in a new uniform and the different Lodges of the American Protestant Association, together with the other civic societies, marched in procession through the principal streets. In the evening the annual distribution of premiums to the pupils of Brooklyn Institute took place, and balls and concerts were given in various parts of the city.

abstract: -- The annual report of the Superintendent of the Canal around the Falls of St. Mary's shows that the receipts of the Canal for the past season were $11,602 29 beyond its expenses, showing an increase of more than fifty per cent. over that of last year, and the net proceeds to be more than four hundred per cent., and also a gain in its business of four hundred per cent. over the first year. The average number of vessels passing throug the Canal was seven per day, and the aggregate tonnage 352,642. The Superintendent estimates, not without reason, that the tonnage will be twice as large next season, leaving no room to doubt that the Canal bonds will be paid at maturity, from the receipts at the Canal.

abstract: THE GEORGETOWN WATER WORKS. -- Capt. MEIGS has presented his final report to the Water Board of Georgetown, (D.C.) There have been laid by the Board 45,254 1/2 feet of pipe; 93 1/2 per cent. of which is four-inch, the rest six-inch pipe. There are 79 fire-plugs, and there will be 105 free public hydrants -- one fire-plug to 86 and one public hydrant to 117 persons in the city. The cost has been thus far $30,602. There remains to be paid for setting up the hydrants, completing the repairs of the streets, and for stationery and other small charges, $3,334 65; making the total cost of the completed work $33,936 65, which makes the arrearages per foot for the pipes laid 82 1/4 cents, and per mile $4,345 -- including all fireplugs, hydrants, and contingencies of every kind.
lead_paragraph: THE GEORGETOWN WATER WORKS. -- Capt. MEIGS has presented his final report to the Water Board of Georgetown, (D.C.) abstract: We have been publishing, for the last three or four weeks, a series of letters from our Special Correspondent in the island of Jamaica, which are well worthy of the diligent perusal of everybody who wishes for valuable information upon the most vexed, and, we may add, one of the most important, questions of the day--the effect of emancipation from Slavery upon the negro race.
lead_paragraph: We have been publishing, for the last three or four weeks, a series of letters from our Special Correspondent in the island of Jamaica, which are well worthy of the diligent perusal of everybody who wishes for valuable information upon the most vexed, and, we may add, one of the most important, questions of the day--the effect of emancipation from Slavery upon the negro race. There is no subject which possesses more momentous interest for the people of these States than this, and there is none which, to be discussed profitably, has more need to be discussed with candor and impartiality. What its fate has been, however, in our hands, everybody knows. It has had the misfortune to have a most important bearing upon one of the most exciting political controversies by which any country was ever agitated, and consequently so far from receiving the calm investigation due to the working of a great experiment in social and ethnological science, it has been treated precisely as an irate attorney treats a piece of adverse testimony, the effect of which on the jury he wishes to destroy. There is a large party amongst us who are -- and naturally, perhaps -- opposed to the emancipation of negro slaves, and they endeavor to help their cause by the constant iteration of the assertion that negroes are not fit for freedom. Before there were any free negro communities in existence, this proposition of course belonged to the same category with the theses of the old schoolmen. It might be true, and it might not; but whether it was or not, it was impossible to prove. It was of course most fallacious to argue from the past condition of a race as to what it could possibly achieve in the future, but as the conflict was one in which it was never intended that either science or logic should play a very leading part, this was not a matter of much moment.

abstract: The One Hundred and Twenty-eighth AnniverSary of the birth of WASHINGTON was perhaps in many respects much less respectable than any of the one hundred and twenty-seven which preceded it.
lead_paragraph: The One Hundred and Twenty-eighth AnniverSary of the birth of WASHINGTON was perhaps in many respects much less respectable than any of the one hundred and twenty-seven which preceded it. At daybreak the rain, provoked by a boisterous south-east wind, began to fall in torrents, visiting with impartial bounty nearly every point from which information reaches us, on the Atlantic seaboard. Of course, to so general and persistent a "quencher" no enthusiasm could be proof, and where the programme of observance was not wholly abandoned, the proceedings were of the most imperfect and disheartening character. To the actual state of the weather in this City, was added the unspeakable condition of the streets, the legacy of the last snow storm. Something had been done to purge the portion of Broadway ordinarily used as the processional and military line of march. The remainder, and all the lateral streets, were little better than a representation of the Dismal Swamp, with its canal capitally reproduced in duplicate. Yet we had our parades and processions. The Eleventh, Seventy-first, Sixty-ninth, Eighth and Twelfth Regiments turned out over fifteen hundred men, and the American Protestant Association about five hundred more. The Veterans of 1812 fired a national salute on the Battery at noon. Numbers of the firemen collected at Laird's square, in West Broadway, and tried their engines. In the evening there were lectures, soirees, reunions, and other ceremonies appropriate to the occasion. At Philadelphia the military, quite as enterprising as our own, united in the consecration of a monument at Roxbury, in honor of Revolutionary martyrs. At Baltimore the parade, though seriously diluted, was not foregone. At Boston the State fired its salute, to which the departing steamship Canada responded in lavish courtesy, adding a profuse display of flag and streamer from every available mast and pole. A similar compliment was paid by the Arabia, at her dock in Jersey City. These celebrations of the day were insignificant when compared with that which was in progress at Washington. In response to the invitation of the joint Congressional Committee having charge the arrangements for the inauguration of MILL's Equestrian Statue, companies of military from Baltimore, with our own Seventh Regiment, and civilians innumerable, sacrificed the claims of private business to those of patriotism, and took up their journey to the Capital. The storm which paid us such an untimely visit fortunately broke away in Washington before the day was over. The procession, in which were the President, Vice-President, and other high dignitaries, moved about 3 1/2 o'clock, and marched past the Presidential mansion through Pennsylvania-avenue to the circle inclosing the statue. When those who were entitled to the honor had taken seats upon the platform, Rev. Dr. NADAL offered an appropriate prayer, and after the delivery of an oration by Hon. THOMAS S. BOCOCK, of Virginia, the statue was unveiled by President BUCHANAN amid the plaudits of the multitude. The ceremonies over, the troops were reviewed by the President and the celebration was concluded.

abstract: Tha rain, as if in disgust at the dirty face which the City has lately worn, has condescended at Length to join the authorities in cleaning the streets.
lead_paragraph: Tha rain, as if in disgust at the dirty face which the City has lately worn, has condescended at Length to join the authorities in cleaning the streets. It is true, the authorities had a little the start in point of time; but they were so unaccustomed to any action for public relief, that the rain steadily gained on them, and at last came out many lengths ahead. The purification by the falling element was inaugrated yesterday noon, by firing cannons, and a display of flags from the City Hall, on the steps of which a dense throng had assembled for the purpose of witnessing the strange phenomenon of a public washing of New-York. When the rain had fairly begun its work, the crowd dispersed, as if satisfied with the display. The The evacuation of the mud from the City was hardly less grateful to the people than the departure of the National enemy, years ago, at the approach of that great man, in whose honor yesterday was kept. But the departure of this accumulation of snow and dirt excited serious apprehensions among the residents of the streets running down to the rivers. As the waters carried down the filth, the sidewalks were inundated, and some basements were injured. A volunteer corps of men, women and children, armed with shovels and brooms, stood at their doors, and with strenuous efforts drove the rushing filth from their threatened abodes. The wharves were flooded, and many cartloads of dirt were deposited upon the piers. But it was a great day for those chivalric gentlemen -- the Police. They were in their glory. In the time-tested fact that women will go out when it rains, if only to show their nicely made, pretty little water-proof boots, our gallant policemen found their principal exercise and greatest joy. The women did go out, even when the waters were highest in the streets, and as dirty as the highly-flavored Thames. In doing so, peradventure, they must go over the crossings, and what policeman with the heart of a HOWARD and the pluck of a HEENAN, (which every policeman has,) could remain quiescent when those highly-polished, distracting little boots were in danger of being soiled. To their everlasting credit be it said, they did not; but dashing through the slimy deeps, they seized the fair owners of these boots and bore them both to a place of safety, gallantly and triumphantly. But policemen are only human, after all, and have many of the failings that flesh is heir to -- one of the most prevalent being a partiality for the beautiful. The poet, singing of an important personage, exclaims:

abstract: WINTER GARDEN.--An old but a very agreeable comedietta called the "Governor's Wife" was produced here last night. It is a souvenir of the times
lead_paragraph: WINTER GARDEN.--An old but a very agreeable comedietta called the "Governor's Wife" was produced here last night. It is a souvenir of the times when marriageable women were shipped to any place that bore the general name of India, in the firm faith that they would there marry some one from the Governor downwards. The play is a peculiarly comic one, from the complications which arise between the right Governor and the right lady -- both for the matrimonial moment being impostors. Mrs. WOOD as Letty Briggs is especially jubilant and extatic. Mr. JEFFERSON as the mock Governor is confusedly great. The other parts, being amply filled, contribute to the comical perplexity of the dramatist's scheme, and involve a plot thoroughly farcical. A large audience applauded vociferously; the piece will undoubtedly enjoy a run.

abstract: -- According to the representations of our Correspondent, the incipient State of Kansas is doing a very heavy business in the matter of granting divorces. Every little favor asked for in this matter seems to be very promptly granted -- and oftentimes without taking the trouble of hearing any evidence, or learning anything more about the case than the applicant chooses to tell. Naturally enough men emigrate thither from every section of the country, for the purpose of securing a deliverance which the more rigid laws of their own States would not concede.

abstract: The Seventh Regiment of New-York, Col. LEFFERTS, reached this city last evening, on the way to Washington, to take part in the inauguration, to-day, of MILLS' statue of WASHINGTON. The Regiment was invited by the Congressional Committee to be present, and got ready on very short notice. The men were equipped in the uniform coat and cap, with overcoat, gray pants, and cross-belts and fatigue cap; the officers also wore the fatigue coat. It was estimated that the Regiment, which is one of the largest and best disciplined in New-York, numbered from six to seven hundred men. The regiment arrived at Camden about half-past 9 o'clock, and were taken on board the ferry boat direct to Washington-street wharf, where they took the cars for Baltimore, leavng the depot at 11 1/4 o'clock. -- Philadelphia Ledger 22d.

abstract: The basement door of Mr. Robinson Butler's dwelling-house, No. 57 King-street, was opened by burglars on Monday night, who ransacked the house, carrying off several articles of clothing. The next day Mr. Butler observed that Francis Manning, a young man residing in the neighborhood, was wearing one of the stolen garments -- a coat. He therefore had him arrested on suspicion of having committed the burglary. Justice QUACKENBUSH fixed his bail at $1,000, and, failing to procure a bondsman, he was committed for trial on the charge. The prisoner says that he took the property from a boy, who broke open the door and procured it.

abstract: The Order of United Americans celebrated the day by an oration and other appropriate exercises at the Cooper Institute. Notwithstanding the rain, the large hall on the ground floor of the Institute was completely filled with an audience composed in great part of ladies.
lead_paragraph: The Order of United Americans celebrated the day by an oration and other appropriate exercises at the Cooper Institute. Notwithstanding the rain, the large hall on the ground floor of the Institute was completely filled with an audience composed in great part of ladies. The room was tastefully decorated with national flags and with banners of the order. The First and second companies of the continental Guard graced the occasion with their presence, and on the platform were seated the Veteran Corps of 1812, together with a large number of invited guests. Among the latter we noticed Hon. GEORGE BRIGGS and Hon. W. RIVES, of Maryland.

abstract: -- The late Legislature of Mississippi raised the taxes to 75 cents on each negro, instead of 40, as heretofore; and to 20 cents on each $100 of land, instead of 16 cents -- thus nearly doubling the tax on slaves, and increasing that on lands 25 per cent. As there are about 400,000 slaves in the State, it will increase the taxes on that property alone about $150,000, and on lands about $60,000 per year; so that, after this year, the gross revenue will be about $210,000 more than it has been past years from these two items.
lead_paragraph: -- The late Legislature of Mississippi raised the taxes to 75 cents on each negro, instead of 40, as heretofore; and to 20 cents on each $100 of land, instead of 16 cents -- thus nearly doubling the tax on slaves, and increasing that on lands 25 per cent. abstract: As the programme prepared at Villafranca appeared for the moment to be inconsistent with the policy and known opinions of CAVOUR, he yielded to the political necessity of the hour, and resigned his place as Prime Minister to the King of Sardinia.
lead_paragraph: As the programme prepared at Villafranca appeared for the moment to be inconsistent with the policy and known opinions of CAVOUR, he yielded to the political necessity of the hour, and resigned his place as Prime Minister to the King of Sardinia. Now, when the purposes of the Emperor NAPOLEON, begin to be more correctly understood, and are seen to be substantially in agreement with the policy of the Sardinian Ministry before the war, nothing is more natural than the return of Count CAVOUR to his appropriate and important position. The regeneration of Italy had, in a good degree, its beginning with him, and has made progress chiefly through the counsel and influence of this great statesman. His return to power, therefore, gives great satisfaction to all friends of Italian independence.

abstract: At the imminent risk of diphtheria, and the concomitant evils of rheumatism, chills, colds in the Dead, and other bodily evils, the patriotic population . pf New-York honored the natal day of the Father of his Country yesterday.
lead_paragraph: At the imminent risk of diphtheria, and the concomitant evils of rheumatism, chills, colds in the Dead, and other bodily evils, the patriotic population . pf New-York honored the natal day of the Father of his Country yesterday. As the terrors of coup de soliel can never interfere with the celebration of our National birthday, so the horrors of a February thaw could not effect an estoppel of Metropolitan patriotism. Happily our population is amphibious, and neither the opening of the flood-gates of the heavens not the closing of the flood-gates of the sewers could prevent the street demonstrations in honor of the day; and although our forefathers waded in blood to achieve our liberties, their descendants walked in a saline mixture almost as terrible to commemorate them, evincing a fortitude which could hardly be displayed in a better cause.

abstract: The number of candidates for the Presidency, especially on the Republican side, seems to be rapidly increasing.
lead_paragraph: The number of candidates for the Presidency, especially on the Republican side, seems to be rapidly increasing. An appeal has been issued by a Committee appointed for that purpose in New-Jersey, nominating WM. L. DAYTON, and setting forth at length the manifold reasons which commend him to the support of the Republican Party. He was their candidate for Vice-President in 1856, it will be remembered, but failed to carry his own State. His identification with the old Whig Party, and with the scheme of protective tariffs, is cited by these gentlemen as reasons for his nomination. The People's Party in Pennsylvania, meantime -- which is invited by the Republicans call to send delegates to Chicago -- pronounces in favor of Senator CAMERON, and will doubtless urge him upon the National Convention. We doubt, however, whether this movement aims at anything more than to promote the chances of his nomination for the Vice-Presidency, and it is possibly intended mainly to prevent the party in Pennsylvania from being committed to any of the other candidates already in the field. The Chicago Press and Tribune nominates ABE. LINCOLN, who was Judge DOUGLAS' unsuccessful competitor for the Senate in the last canvass, -- and the Missouri Democrat, the Republican organ of Missouri, presses the nomination of Judge BATES.
headline: {'main': 'Presidential Candidates.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Presidential Candidates.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: A correspondent thinks that the President of the Sixth-avenue Railroad Company should be held legally responsible for loss of time and other injuries that may arise from displaying on their cars the words "Ball up," in order to induce skaters to go to the Central Park only to find the ball down. Very well--let him try.
lead_paragraph: A correspondent thinks that the President of the Sixth-avenue Railroad Company should be held legally responsible for loss of time and other injuries that may arise from displaying on their cars the words "Ball up," in order to induce skaters to go to the Central Park only to find the ball down. Very well--let him try. It would be amusing, at all events, to see an attempt made to hold anybody connected with a wealthy corporation responsible for such peccadilloes as breach of faith and false pretences. The thing is quite unheard of in this community. It is not possible to enforce against such parties the fulfillment of even their ordinary obligations. Any community which will tolerate the treatment received every day at the hands of our City Railroads, would be greatly amused at the idea of complaining of such little misrepresentations as our correspondent speaks of.

abstract: "Down town " is a phrase definite of a locality which no one associates with any idea but that of wharves, drays, and great warehouses. Being "down town" is only a sort of negative condition, an absence from up town.
lead_paragraph: "Down town " is a phrase definite of a locality which no one associates with any idea but that of wharves, drays, and great warehouses. Being "down town" is only a sort of negative condition, an absence from up town. Conventional gossip never runs below the numbered streets for a topic. Exclamations of surprise are constantly uttered at the rapidity with which up town is getting up-er; and dismal forebodings are indulged in, of a time to come, when the dwellers in mansions about Madison-square can only retain their quarters at the cost of falling to the level of the vulgar hoi polloi, and when the Central Park will become central, at least to the elite of the town. Young New-York is very fast, and always outward bound. It has imported for its own worship the Roman Terminus, and placed that divinity with his face toward Harlem, trusting to its irreversibility to reach the island's North pole.
headline: {'main': 'A Home Down Town.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'A Home Down Town.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: BENEFIT FOR THE NEWSBOYS' LODGING-HOUSE --An amateur performance came off last night at the little French Theatre in Broadway, under the auspices of Messrs.
lead_paragraph: BENEFIT FOR THE NEWSBOYS' LODGING-HOUSE --An amateur performance came off last night at the little French Theatre in Broadway, under the auspices of Messrs. CLARK & FANNING, of the Mount Washington Institute, for the benefit of the Newsboys' Lodging-house, the actors being wholly of domestic material, furnished from the ranks of the students themselves. The house was well filled by the friends of the Institution, and by the pupils, as well as by a large number of ladies and gentlemen, who testified their approval by their presence. The programme of the evening consisted of declamations by the young and old students of the school, interspersed with music by the orchestra band; and of a play from SHAKESPEARE -- "The Merchant of Venice" -- with an afterpiece, which unfortunately prolonged the exercises to the point of weariness. Prof. HEGEMAN, under whose direction the rehearsal had been conducted, took the character of Shylock, in which he showed himself fully at home, frequently bringing down the house with applause. The various parts were also well sustained by the students, exhibiting a good degree of talent, and no little labor in their preparation. The efforts of Gratiano to keep his mustache in place furnished much amusement to the boys, and when he tossed it behind the scenes in disgust, the gravity of the parents gave way, and they joined the boys in a hearty laugh. About one hundred and twenty-five dollars were realized for the newsboys. It was handed to Mr. BRACE at the close, and that gentleman made a handsome acknowledgement for the same. The audience dispersed, well pleased, as were, no doubt, the scholars, with their first performances on the stage.

abstract: The burin is traveling fast after the pencil on this side of the water, and it is beginning to be reasonable to hope that at no very distant day American engravers may be able to do that justice to American painters and sculptors which CHURCH, and LEUTZE, and POWERS and CRAWFORE have been obliged to cross the ocean to find.
lead_paragraph: The burin is traveling fast after the pencil on this side of the water, and it is beginning to be reasonable to hope that at no very distant day American engravers may be able to do that justice to American painters and sculptors which CHURCH, and LEUTZE, and POWERS and CRAWFORE have been obliged to cross the ocean to find. The engraver's work, is, perhaps, less peculiarly adapted to the restless American organization, impatient of processes, and bent upon immediate results, than any other of the fine arts; but the strong feeling for color and chiaroscuro which seems to be the constant concomitant of any decided artistic ability in America, promises to bear such excellent fruits when properly applied in this direction, that we watch the gradual progress of our engravers with no slight or secondary interest. A not uncommon, but a very superficial notion, which one stumbles upon constantly in the current art-criticism of the day, threatens the engraver with the doom dealt out to the wicked overseer in the sensational drama of the "Octoroon." He is to be slain by means of the photograph. Nothing could be less reasonable than this impression, at least in the present stage of practica-photography. The photograph applied to a great picture does not reproduce, but simply represents it, limning through a medium of perspective which the painter never took into the account the precise mechanical and material facts of his work; through which, under the conditions prepared and considered by himself, he meant its strictly pictorial and intellectual effect to be reached. A moment's reflection will satisfy any one that whatever interesting tests may in this way be applied to a painter's manner of handling, to the accuracy of his design, to his power over atmospheric perspective, no properly artistic and picturesque reproduction of his thoughts can be so achieved as adequately to interpret that thought through a perfectly satisfactory, because perfectly independent and well-calculated form of expression. The engraver supplies precisely this form of expression which, so far as yet appears, we may never expect to see supplied by any strictly mechanical contrivance whatever, uninformed by that mysterious, but hitherto indispensable element of artistic success, the artistic human mind. The relation which the engraver bears to his original was not inaptly likened by ALLAN CUNNINHGHAM to that which the translator holds to his author. It may more fitly still be compared to that which exists between the composer who writes for a full orchestra and the artist who rearranges his composition for a single instrument. What GOODALL, WILSON, PYE, have done for the landscapes of TURNER, STANFIELD, and CONSTABLE, differs not essentially from the services rendered by LISTZ and THALBERG to BEETHOVEN and MEYERBEER and ROSSINI. And this consideration may lead some of our readers to the thought that, until we have really begun to possess with perfect confidence our own Stanfields and Constables and Turners, we need not look for our Wilsons and Pyes and Goodalls, and the rest.

abstract: The vigorous measures taken by the French Government to protect that portion of the population of the Turkish Empire which professes the Roman Catholic faith, have not been without their natural effect in strengthening the hands of the numbers of priests and monks scattered through the East.
lead_paragraph: The vigorous measures taken by the French Government to protect that portion of the population of the Turkish Empire which professes the Roman Catholic faith, have not been without their natural effect in strengthening the hands of the numbers of priests and monks scattered through the East. Moral suasion and even the largest concessions possible granted to the members of the Greek, Armenian and other Oriental Christian Churches, both in respect to doctrine and practice, have been hitherto strikingly unsuccessful. The "United" Churches, constituted by the few thus detached from the national organizations, are repudiated by the masses, who will hear nothing of the supremacy of the Pope. But a new energy has been imparted to proselytism by the successes of LOUIS NAPOLEON, and in particular by the issue of the Crimean War. A recent incident, throwing light upon this movement, will be of interest to all who feel desirous of tracing the influence of European politics on the nationalities of the East. At Athens, the intelligence seems to have produced the greatest consternation and disgust. For a long time the island of Crete has been doomed to feel with peculiar force the evils of the Turkish rule. With all the advantages of a most fertile soil and a delightful climate, the population has been reduced to a mere fraction of that which could easily be sustained, and, indeed, of that which the island did once sustain. Nor need we wonder at this, for abuses of power exhibited towards the Christians here pass unnoticed, which would call forth the indignant protests of the representatives of the Great Powers if committed anywhere in the vicinity of Constantinople or Smyrna.

abstract: Following Mr. GOLD came Prof. SILLIMAN on "Meteorology." As I have given no report of this gentleman's first lecture, I will briefly allude to it here. His subject related chiefly to temperature, and his time was mostly occupied in showing us on what its condition depends, and in describing the two instruments, the thermometer and the hygrometer.
lead_paragraph: Following Mr. GOLD came Prof. SILLIMAN on "Meteorology." As I have given no report of this gentleman's first lecture, I will briefly allude to it here. His subject related chiefly to temperature, and his time was mostly occupied in showing us on what its condition depends, and in describing the two instruments, the thermometer and the hygrometer. The temperature of the earth varies on different portions of its surface, but we can pass through all these gradations of climate which occur between the equator and the poles by simply going up the sides of a high mountain. This is beautifully illustrated in Mr. PRESCOTT's description of the journey from the Gulfto the Valley of Mexico. At the equator we should have to go higher of course to accomplish this than further North. The limit of perpetual snow is quite low down, in regions even inhabitable by men. Capt. EICHWALD, of the Russian Topographical Engineers, describing to Prof. BUSH, of Yale College, the digging for gold in Siberia, spoke of penetrating the earth to the depth of 200 feet, and being still in ice. And yet this is in a region where barley grows.

abstract: -- The Daily News thinks it very hard that Mayor WOOD should not be allowed to advertise the proceedings of the Common Council at his own discretion, without authority of law or anything else. As the Mayor is understood to be substantially the owner of the News, and would therefore by such advertising only be "transferring" money from the City treasury to his own pocket, it is not at all strange that the News should hold this opinion.

abstract: The Boston Journal, Feb. 21, says: "In Revolutionary times a wooden structure, used for a display of beacon lights, stood upon the summit of Beacon Hill. Subsequently this was replaced by a brick monument. In 1804, when the elevation in the rear of the State House was levelled, this monument was pulled down. Several slate tablets, with inscriptions, were inserted in the base of the monument, upon the demolition of which these were removed to the State House and set into the walls of a dark recess on the east side of Doric Hall. The present Legislature having ordered their removal to a more conspicuous position, the tablets were to-day taken from the dark recess, and inserted in the east wall of Doric Hall, where they are sure to meet the eyes of nearly all visitors to the State House."

abstract: -- The approaching election for Mayor of Chicago has excited an unusual degree of attention, not only in that immediate locality, but throughout the State. "Long JOHN WENTWORTH," who used to be a furious Democrat, joined the Republicans a few years since and was elected Mayor of the City. His administration, however, was not particularly creditable either to the city or the party, nor has he ever been distinguished for an entire and unqualified adhesion to the Republican organization. He has threatened to "bolt" once or twice unless the nominations were made to suit him, and his general walk and conversation have indicated a purpose to please himself, without much regard to the wishes of the party. There has been a very resolute purpose, therefore, on the part of the Republicans of Chicago, this Winter, not to permit him to be their candidate, while his own determination has been equally resolute the other way. All the leading men of the party, its regular committees and its prominent presses, have openly resisted his nomination.

abstract: A SUMMER DAY.--Everybody of classical reading knows that the job of expressing the sun around the earth once in twenty-four hours, was let out by the mythologists who had charge of the matter, to a very gentlemanly person by the name of Apollo. He has generally discharged his duty to the public with exemplary fidelity.
lead_paragraph: A SUMMER DAY.--Everybody of classical reading knows that the job of expressing the sun around the earth once in twenty-four hours, was let out by the mythologists who had charge of the matter, to a very gentlemanly person by the name of Apollo. He has generally discharged his duty to the public with exemplary fidelity. Occasionally, however, the packages in his express chariot get sadly mixed, and he makes a mistake and delivers to us the wrong day. Yesterday one of these irregularities occurred. Whether or not the solar charioteer had imbibed too freely on the previous day, in honor of our illustrious pater patrioe, does not transpire. It is only known that for some cause or other, the inhabitants of this town, on opening the Municipal door to receive the usual auroral package, yesterday morning, found instead of a Winter day which was due, a bundle of beautiful, bright shining hours, that would reflect credit on an attempt of the riper end of April, or even of early May. Though the package was doubtless intended for a different destination, and only left with us by mistake, the temptation to appropriate its genial warmth was too strong to be resisted by even the proverbially tender conscience of honest New-York. Though all is not gold that gilters, yet yesterday was a golden day; one which reflected honor on Summer itself. No seasoning or flavor of spice was omitted to make its character complete. In the afternoon the usual shower of a Summer day came to perfect the illusion, and deceive terrestrials into the belief that the earth had really been hurried along already into the sweet vernal influences of the Pleiads. At sunset the clouds cleared away, and let in the last golden rays which blended the day into night. Such slips on the part of Phoebus as we have here recorded, may easily be forgiven; and we are not sure that an occasional repetition of the weakness may not even redound to his sublunary popularity.

abstract: Baker  Vail vs. Horatio N. Curtis and John H Vandoler.--This was an action against the defendants as bail, commenced on the 12th day of November last.
lead_paragraph: Baker & Vail vs. Horatio N. Curtis and John H Vandoler.--This was an action against the defendants as bail, commenced on the 12th day of November last. Defendant Curtis then answered on the merits, but omitted to apply for extension of time in which to surrender his principal, until after the twenty days allowed for that purpose by section 191 of the code had expired. On the 7th of January, 1860, he surrendered his principal to the Sheriff, and on such surrender moved to be exonerated from liability on his bail-bond upon payment of the costs of the action, on such terms as might be deemed just. The defendant also showed to the Court his diligence in arresting his principal, whom he had brought from St. Louis, and of whom he had been in constant pursuit since this suit was begun.

abstract: On the 30th ult., Patrick Conlan, a laborer, residing in Fiftieth-street between Fifth and Sixth avenues, was apprehended on the complaint of his wife Catharine, charging him with having beaten her in a brutal manner, and afterwards with having dragged her over the rocks in front of their shanty.
lead_paragraph: On the 30th ult., Patrick Conlan, a laborer, residing in Fiftieth-street between Fifth and Sixth avenues, was apprehended on the complaint of his wife Catharine, charging him with having beaten her in a brutal manner, and afterwards with having dragged her over the rocks in front of their shanty. Justice CONNOLLY [???] the bail of the accused at $300, and John McGuinness, of Forty-fifth-street and Eleventh-avenue, became his surety to appear for trial yesterday at the Court of Special Sessions. The case was accordingly called, but it appeared that Mrs. Conlan had died on the 10th inst, and, of course, as there was no complaint ant, it could not be brought to trial. McGuinness, however, said that he desired to be released from his bond, as the neighbors of the late Mrs. Conlan persisted in asserting that her death had been caused by her husband's brutality, notwithstanding the fact that an investigation into the circumstances of her decease by Coroner SCHIRMER, had resulted in a verdict that it was caused by disease of the heart. Under these circumstances the prisoner was committed to prison to await the result of an investigation which it is said Justice CONNOLLY will make into the case. The accused and his alleged victim are said to have been of intemperate habits.

abstract: A languid day, yesterday, in the United States Senate. Various bills were reported, and several introduced, before Mr. CHANDLER made an ineffectual effort to call up the President's veto of the St. Clair Flats Appropriation bill. The bill...
lead_paragraph: A languid day, yesterday, in the United States Senate. Various bills were reported, and several introduced, before Mr. CHANDLER made an ineffectual effort to call up the President's veto of the St. Clair Flats Appropriation bill. The bill providing for the sale of arms to the States was discussed, the clause requiring the Superintendents of the National Armories to be officers of the Army meeting with opposition from Messrs. HALE, PUGH, and others. The subject was, after hasty treatment, laid aside, and the bill to prevent the issue of bank bills in the District of Columbia taken up. A clause prohibiting the circulation of any paper money in the District was finally passed by a large vote. The House renewed its effort to elect a Printer. Two ballots gave assurance that Mr. DEFREES, the Republican candidate, could not be chosen; and the name of Mr. SAMUEL BOWLES, of the Springfield Republican, was substituted. Mr. BOWLES proved even less acceptable than Mr. DEFREES; and on the fourth ballot Mr. EDWARD BALL, of Ohio, who took his place, came within one vote of election. Without another attempt, the House adjourned.

abstract: The first lecture of the afternoon was on the different breeds of sheep, and was given by Mr. T.S. GOLD --I will kiss the book that I wrote that name just so last week, though the compositor made it read "GOULD."
lead_paragraph: The first lecture of the afternoon was on the different breeds of sheep, and was given by Mr. T.S. GOLD --I will kiss the book that I wrote that name just so last week, though the compositor made it read "GOULD." He had on the stage, for the purpose of illustrating his subject, a fine Spanish Merino from the flock of ALONZO WHITNEY, of Torrington, Conn.; also a splendid specimen of the Cotswold, imported by Mr. T. HITCHCOCK, of New Preston, Conn., from the flock of Mr. FLETCHER, of Shipton Sollers, Eng. It was his intention to show us, also, a sample of the middle wools, by exhibiting a South Down, but he failed to procure a specimen. The first part of the lecture was occupied with a description of the two different kinds of manufacture of wool -- one, the combing process, in which the long wools are used, and called combing because the wool is drawn between fine steel teeth. Of this worsted goods are made; also, blankets and mats. It is opposed to the other, or carding process, in that the fibre is required to lie as nearly as possible in parallel lines, and kept at its full length; whereas, in carding, the fibre is torn apart, and reliance placed upon the felting qualities of the wool to keep it together. These felting qualities were explained to depend upon the serrated side of the fibre of wool, as shown by the microscope. The finer the wool the greater the number of serrations, amounting sometimes to as many as 2,720 in the space of an inch. These, by their interlocking, hold the wool so firmly together that a good fabric may even be made by the process of felting alone. It is this property which causes fine wool fabrics to shrink or full more than coarse. Wool is capable, said the lecturer, of great extension -- a single fleece of coarse wool, of seven pounds weight, being capable of being spun out to a length of 155 miles.

abstract: MICHAEL TURNER, a laborer, while engaged at work upon the new Reservoir in process of construction at the Central Park, was instantly killed on Wednesday by the fall of a derrick used for hoisting tone. MICHAEL COLLINS, JOHN DULEN and CHARLES TOWNLY, three other laborers were also slightly injured at the same time. Deceased was an unmarried man. His remains were removed to his late residence in Ninetieth-street, between Fourth and Fifth avenues, where an inquest was held upon them by Coroner GAMBLE.

abstract: McDonald had a friend -- a faithful friend -- named Patrick Madden, sometimes known as Patrick Meade. No sooner did Madden, alias Meade, know that McDonald was confined, on suspicion of being engaged in the aforesaid burglary, in the Seventh Precinct Station-house, Gouverneur-street, than he undertook to liberate him. Madden, alias Meade, went promptly to the Station-house, and under cover of the sable pall of night, filed away one of the iron bars, which externally guard the window of the cell in which McDonald was placed. He was overheard, caught and arrested. The Grand Jury, that such a Damon should not be separated from such a Pythias, indicted him for burglary. Yesterday he pleaded guilty to an attempt at burglary, and received a sentence of two years and four months in the State Prison. United when at liberty, they share their incarceration under the same roof.

abstract: The budget which has just been introduced into the British House of Commons by Mr. GLADSTONE, the Chancellor of the Exchequer, is in all respects the most important which has been framed since that famous one of 1847, which sealed the doom of the Corn Laws.
lead_paragraph: The budget which has just been introduced into the British House of Commons by Mr. GLADSTONE, the Chancellor of the Exchequer, is in all respects the most important which has been framed since that famous one of 1847, which sealed the doom of the Corn Laws. Sir ROBERT PEEL's master stroke conferred upon the laboring classes the inestimable boon of cheap bread. It threw open to the busy denizens of the great manufacturing towns, which have sprung into existence since the battle of Waterloo, the corn markets of the entire world. The millions of operatives who had for thirty years -- in spite of the great rapidity of their increase, and in spite of the immensity of their contributions to the national wealth, and in spite, too, of the chronic misery of their condition -- been compelled to purchase the bread they ate of English landholders at their own price, suddenly found the first necessary of life as cheap as the competition of the whole globe could make it. Better still, the market for the sale of their handiwork was extended in the same ratio with that in which they purchased their wheat. As loaves became cheaper, calicoes became in greater demand.
headline: {'main': "Gladstone's Budget and the British Poor.", 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': "Gladstone's Budget and the British Poor.", 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Several of the ostentations sympathisers with JOHN BROWN, who have been summoned to Washington as witnesses before the Senate Committee, seem resolved to bring themselves conspicuously into public notice at all events.
lead_paragraph: Several of the ostentations sympathisers with JOHN BROWN, who have been summoned to Washington as witnesses before the Senate Committee, seem resolved to bring themselves conspicuously into public notice at all events. Mr. THADDEUS HYATT, of our City, is especially pertinacious and diligent in this endeavor. He began by refusing peremptorily to obey the summons, and boldly confronting the power of the Government. After a little reflection, he graciously consented to go to Washington and appear before the Committee, but resolved when there not to open his mouth. On reaching Washington he solicited a delay of ten days, in order to consider whether he would answer the questions of the Committee or not. When this was refused he wrote a very long letter to Senator MASON, the Chairman of the Committee, remonstrating vehemently against the rejection of his reasonable and respectful request, and treating the Senator to a very transcendental disquisition upon the general powers of Government and the great dangers Mr. MASON runs of engendering "the fierce brood that incubates where hate, within the shadows of tyranny, sits moodily fostering despair!" Here are a few sentences from this impressive epistle:

abstract: A mass meeting of such members of the National Guard as were unable to accompany the Regiment to Washington was held, last evening, in the drill room of the Eighth Company.
lead_paragraph: A mass meeting of such members of the National Guard as were unable to accompany the Regiment to Washington was held, last evening, in the drill room of the Eighth Company. Ex-Col. DURYEA was unanimously requested to preside. Upon taking a count of those willing to join the escort, eighty members expressed their willingness to turn out, and enough more will go to swell the number to one hundred.

abstract: Mrs. MARY MAEDER, a German woman, residing at No. 22 Clinton-street, died on Wednesday night in consequence of severe burns, received a week ago. Her sister was filling a lamp, when a child jostled against her, and caused her to spill the fluid on the table. It instantly caught fire, and Mrs. MAEDER sought to extinguish the flames with her apron, but instead of accomplishing her intention, the whole of her clothing was instantly in a blaze. Deceased was 29 years of age. Coroner JACKMAN held an inquest upon the body.

abstract: -- The people of Kansas are probably anxious for immediate admission into the Union. They say they are, and we are bound to believe them. But they are evidently not inclined to make any political sacrifices for the accomplishment of that object, nor to waive any of their local rights in order to secure it. They have already passed a bill for the prohibition of Slavery, which Gov. MEDARY has permitted to become a law, and are busily engaged upon a Personal Liberty bill, the object of which, according to our correspondent, is to prevent the recovery of fugitive slaves.

abstract: Several interesting criminal cases came up for trial before the Richmond County Court of Sessions, which adjourned on Wednesday last at Richmond, Staten Island.
lead_paragraph: Several interesting criminal cases came up for trial before the Richmond County Court of Sessions, which adjourned on Wednesday last at Richmond, Staten Island. Among others, that of Mrs. Decker, which, during the last three years, has been postponed from time to time, was again called for trial. Upon the present occasion, after much difficulty, the prosecution bad succeeded in securing the presence of all the principal witnesses in the case, to the number of some fifteen, and the District-Attorney announced his readiness to proceed with the same. Mr. White, counsel for Mrs. Decker -- who failed to appear -- moved to quash the indictment upon grounds which he was about to state, when the District-Attorney urged that no motion can he sustained to quash any indictment for felony in case the prisoner is not present in person. Objection sustained by the Court, and motion to quash denied.

abstract: Next in order came another admirable lecture by Mr. FLINT on the Dairy. Milk, said he, as the first product of the cow, is composed of an oily substance, which gives it its richness, of a cheesy substance to which it owes its strength, and of a serous or watery substance which makes it refreshing as a beverage, with a small per centage of sugar of milk, to which it owes its sweetness, and a slight proportion of alkaline substances, to which it owes its medicinal properties. Under the microscope, milk appears to be filled with myriads of little round globules, of various sizes, which seem to float in the watery substance, and which rise to the surface on account of their greater lightness, as compared with the surrounding matter, and form a semi-liquid coating, known as cream. The largest particles rise first, and bring up a smaller proportional quantity of cheesy matter than the smaller particles which rise slower. These globules are the butter particles, surrounded by a cheesy film, and the object of churning is to break this coating and to disengage the butter particles from it. The different constituents of milk, therefore, separate on account of their difference in specific gravity.
lead_paragraph: Next in order came another admirable lecture by Mr. FLINT on the Dairy. Under the microscope, milk appears to be filled with myriads of little round globules, of various sizes, which seem to float in the watery substance, and which rise to the surface on account of their greater lightness, as compared with the surrounding matter, and form a semi-liquid coating, known as cream. The largest particles rise first, and bring up a smaller proportional quantity of cheesy matter than the smaller particles which rise slower. These globules are the butter particles, surrounded by a cheesy film, and the object of churning is to break this coating and to disengage the butter particles from it. The different constituents of milk, therefore, separate on account of their difference in specific gravity.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- Madame GAZZANIGA will make her farewell appearance to-night in PACINI's famous opera of "Saffo." Mr. BRIGNOLI's indisposition having come to an end, the performance is announced positively. All the admirers of the prima donna will rally to her support on this interesting occasion. We have had many good singers, but never one who could rival Mme. GAZZANIGA as a grand lyric tragedienne.

abstract: Every nation and every race of men seems to have its special incapacity as well as its special talent; and there can be little doubt,
lead_paragraph: we think, that we of the United States and of the British blood inherit, with many ancestral virtues, the British inability of parade. The individual successes of a DUGNUAY-TROUIN, a TOURVILLE, a JEAN BART, a SURCOUF, have not abated the world's general belief that a Frenchman at sea is like a cat in walnut shells. Lord WESTMORELAND relates that the only clever cook he ever met in Germany was a Parisian, who had lived twenty years in Dresden without learning the language, "because he could see no use in talking to people who had no notion of a cuisine." No man in his senses would ever think of employing a Turk to manage a steamer, unless on the Mississippi, where fatalism might well supply the place of skill, and a Moslem engineer heap up his fires with a more placid indifference to results than any Anglo-Saxon can possibly acquire. But neither a Frenchman in a gale off Cape Hatteras, nor a German in the kitchen of the Tuileries, nor a Turk in the engine-room of a Cunarder could make a more lamentable figure than is cut by your average English and American committees when they undertake to get up a magnificent celebration. It is a curious thing that this should be so, and the psychologists, if they have quite disposed of spiritualism and the doctrine of affinities, may amuse themselves with taking up this question. But so it is, and the attempt of Congress to inaugurate the statue of WASHINGTON at the Federal Capital on the day before yesterday was hardly a more conspicuous and melancholy illustration of the painful truth than was the gorgeous ceremonial of the burial of WELLINGTON in London eight years ago. Somehow or other they "manage these things better in France." The welcome of the ashes of the First NAPOLEON to Paris, under LOUIS PHILIPPE, the festival of Liberty under the Republic of February, the return of the armies of the Crimea and of Italy under the reigning Emperor, were perfect pageants, each in its way. The right people somehow find themselves in the right places; the feux-de-joie go off at the right moment; the speeches, if there are any speeches, flash up as appropriately, and explode in splendor as satisfactorily as the rockets. With us and our cousins, on the contrary, something is always getting out of order. Somebody is always particularly snubbed who ought to have been particularly honored. Somebody else, who promised to be present, and whose presence was essential, sends a letter of mingled lamentation and enthusiasm at the eleventh' hour, or comes and says some thing which makes everybody wish he had stayed at home; processions are sure to tie themselves up into a series of perplexing and provoking snarls; fireworks miss fire, or go off all at once in a premature Vesuvius of chaotic eruption. The British Parliament vote four hundred thousand dollars to bury England's greatest soldier as becomes her greatness and his own; the sincere sorrow of a mighty nation struggles to express itself in all imaginable solemnities of pomp and stately obsequies; London for a day suspends her busy breath to do him honor. But the Queen makes up her mind that it will not do for her to appear in the procession; a quarrel of precedence throws a whole string of distinguished carriages into confusion; and a stupid beadle keeps a circle of England's noblest and gravest dignitaries standing in a draught which sends them home weeping in no figurative sense, with genuine colds in the head.

abstract: A special meeting of the Brooklyn Common Council was held yesterday. The resolution giving the right to construct a horse railroad over Grand-street (Eastern District) to the New-York and Flushing Railroad Company, adopted several weeks ago, and subsequently vetoed by the Mayor on the ground that the action of this Board was illegal, was called up and adopted over the Mayor's veto. At the request of the Mayor, the action of the Board giving the Jamaica and Long Island Railroad Company permission to run horse cars over Fifth and Flatbush avenues, was reconsidered and referred back to the Railroad Committee. The Mayor has several amendments to suggest, which the Committee will take under consideration.
lead_paragraph: A special meeting of the Brooklyn Common Council was held yesterday. The Mayor has several amendments to suggest, which the Committee will take under consideration.

abstract: James E. Covley vs. Francis J. Huntington. -- This action has been some time pending, and was in December, 1858, referred to Hon. Wm. Kent, Referee. When the cause came before him an application was made by the plaintiff's counsel, John T. Doyle, Esq., for a postponement on account of the plaintiff's absence in Europe; the plaintiff, being, it was alleged, a necessary witness on his own behalf, and having certain papers essential to his case in his keeping. The Referee accordingly adjourned the cause to Feb. 1, 1860. At that date the plaintiff's counsel made a motion for a further postponement on the same grounds as before, plaintiff not having yet returned from Europe.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--Mme. GAZZANIGA made her farewell appearance in grand opera last night, playing Saffo, (in the work of that name,) a part which she has made exclusively her own.
lead_paragraph: ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--Mme. GAZZANIGA made her farewell appearance in grand opera last night, playing Saffo, (in the work of that name,) a part which she has made exclusively her own. The career of this truly great artiste since her arrival in America has been one round of unvarying successes. Unlike most popular favorites, her position was at first disputed, both by the Press and the public. It was objected that she could not sing, in the technical sense of the term, but admitted on all hands that she had moments of true inspiration. We are disposed to regard this estimate of Mme. GAZZANIGA's powers as the real secret of her continued popularity. There was nothing extravagant about it, and the lady not being burdened with a fictitious reputation, like so many of our prima donnas, was always capable of a higher flight. There cannot be a doubt that, as a sensational singer of the true Italian dramatic school, she has had no superior here. With a presence singularly pleasing, and a voice which, if not thoroughly fresh, has certainly vastly improved during her stay on our shores, Mme. GAZZANIGA has given to certain characters an impress of individuality which will not speedily be forgotton. Of the truly grand lyric artists who have purpose in what they do, she is the last. For the moment, at least, we must depend on singers merely, and gather our pleasures from the wonderful rather than the sublime. After a brief adieu to-morrow, at the matinee, Mme. GAZZANIGA proceeds on a concert tour, and subsequently will play an engagement in New-Orleans. It is hard to lose an artiste on whom we could always depend for a moment of exquisite pleasure, but the fiat has gone forth, and the magnates of the Academy are inexorable.

abstract: FEMALE MAIL ROBBERS. -- A St. John's, N.F. correspondent of the Boston Journal furnishes, the particulars of a remarkable Systametic mail robbery, which has just been brought to light in that city. It appears that money letters have often disappeared of late, among others a letter mailed by an editor from St. John's to Conception Bay. The editor finding that the Post office authorities would not properly investigate the matter, appealed to the Governor, who immediately ordered an inquiry, which has resulted in some extraordinary developments. It seems that Mrs. and MISS SHEA, (wife and daughter of the chief Clerk in the Post office -- the Postmaster-General being absent in England, the Chief Clerk had charge of the office,) and two servant girls who lived with them, made a practise of openning the letters whether they wanted money, and appropriating the contents. If they found bills of exchange or foreign notes they destroyed them. In one case, a widow women, named WOODS, met with a serious less. Some of her friends in England sent her a Â£50 Bank of England note. Mrs. SHEA, not being able to pass it bu[???]t it. Numerous other cases have come to light. The discovery created great exe[???]ement, the parties implicated being related to some of the high Government officials. The four females are imprisoned in the Perit[???]tiary a waiting their trail.

abstract: RAPID INCREASE OF THE CELTIC RACE. -- In this city, we believe, a majority of the children born are of foreign parentage, chiefly Irish, and the same is probably the case in many of the large places in this and other New-England States. In the town of Newton, which has a population of about 8,000, some 1,200 are Irish, and the total number of births during the year 1859 was 210, of which 100 were from Irish parents, 14 of other foreign parents, and only 92 of American parents. -- Boston Traveller.
