abstract: The examination of the Norwalk Bank case was concluded yesterday. The points relied on by the counsel for the defence were the following:
lead_paragraph: The examination of the Norwalk Bank case was concluded yesterday. The points relied on by the counsel for the defence were the following: The identity in this case was most doubtful, inasmuch as the same witnesses, before another court, had identified another person, who had been examined and held to bail. The present Commissioner had no jurisdiction. There was no evidence of criminality in the facts that the defendant had offered to lend money, or to buy persons out, or had deposited money in Bank under other names; which might have been done to prevent his wife from reaching it by an action for separate maintenance. If James S. Williams had committed the forgery at Adams' Express Office, it was not evidence that he had purloined the letter from the Post-office. One Commissioner could not review the proceedings of another Commissioner, both having coordinate jurisdiction, and two persons could not be held at the same time for trial on the same charge. There was not proof that the accused unlawfully took the letter in question, or any other. Guilt could not be inferred from subsequent criminal acts, and the presumptions of law in favor of innocence must be rebutted by direct proofs of guilt.

abstract: We observe that Mr. COBB, of Alabama, has given notice in the house of Representatives of the United States of a bill intended to repeal the act creating the Court of Claims; and that Judge IVERSON, of Georgia, has introduced a bill in the Senate with the view of amending the organization of that tribunal.
lead_paragraph: We observe that Mr. COBB, of Alabama, has given notice in the house of Representatives of the United States of a bill intended to repeal the act creating the Court of Claims; and that Judge IVERSON, of Georgia, has introduced a bill in the Senate with the view of amending the organization of that tribunal. Before devoting much time to its improvement, or the entertainment of propositions for its destruction, we think it would be well for Congress to attend to the bills now on its table, reported with the view of giving effect to the judgments of the Court rendered during the last four years. Already two of the three Judges who originally composed the tribunal have been removed from their labors by death; and we regret to say that they died with the painful and mortifying conviction that their honest and well-considered judgments were treated by the legislative body with marked and unmerited contempt. Cases reported to Congress as long ago as May, 1856, are as yet unacted upon; and we wish we could say that it is probable they will be considered in four or forty years to come. Men who have the reputation of honesty in their personal affairs, think nothing of hindering, delaying and defrauding public creditors. Men who sometimes pay their own debts, make it an article of their religion never to connive at the payment of a debt of the United States. Until some reform is effected in the legislative branch in this regard, it matters little whether the Court of Claims is abolished or reorganized: -- in either case the public creditor will continue to be delayed by fraud and defrauded by delay.

abstract: The English Government has offered to Hanover a delay of three months from the 16th instant, for regulating by General Conferences with all parties interested, the redemption of the State dues. Hanover has refused to settle the question by General Conferences, and has proposed a special agreement with England. She insists that the indemnity for these tolls shall be fixed at one-fourth of the receipts capitalized.

abstract: Coroner JACKMAN was notified yesterday to take the ante-mortem deposition of JOHN DUNN, a young man 20 years of age, who is alleged to have been so badly beaten about the head on the night of the 10th inst. that his life is despaired of. The father of the young man is a plasterer by occupation, and also proprietor of a small grocery store at No. 235 East Twentieth-street, of which his son has taken charge. Some time ago some of the elder DUNN's tools were stolen from his store, and they are alleged to have been found in the possession of one J. MULNAHAN. Since this occurrence there has been unpleasant feeling between the parties, and it is charged that MULNAHAN, with a party of his friends, entered the grocery of Mr. DUNN, during his absence, and inflicted the injuries upon his son. The names of the suspected parties are all known, but as the Coroner intends making a further investigation of the matter it is not expedient to give them to the public at present.

lead_paragraph: It was extensively rumored that at the meeting of the Police Commissioners yesterday, General Superintendent PILSBURY would send in his resignation. The expected event, however, did not take place, although in certain contingencies the rumor would have proven to be well founded, as a written resignation was in the hands of one of the Commissioners, to be presented in case certain action was taken by the Board.

abstract: NEW-YORK HOTEL LIFE.--A Western editor, whose occasions brought him to the Metropolis of the hemishere in which he exists, returns home to descant in long leaders upon the miseries and mysteries of modern hotels, and to eulogize the inn of other days.
lead_paragraph: NEW-YORK HOTEL LIFE.--A Western editor, whose occasions brought him to the Metropolis of the hemishere in which he exists, returns home to descant in long leaders upon the miseries and mysteries of modern hotels, and to eulogize the inn of other days. It is simple justice to concede to him that the old-fashioned tavern, a place where might be had "entertainment for both man and beast," bears quite as little resemblance to its offspring, the modern hotel, as the honest, pains-taking, gain-getting man of business who occasionally spent the night and ate his Breakfast at the former, does to his thriftless son who wastes his inherited wealth in the latter. Good fare, at comfortable bed, and a roaring bar-room fire were the perfection of tavern excellencies once. How different the metropolitan hotel of to-day. Heat from furnace, light from gas, waiters at the touch of bell-spring, reading-room, smoking-room, hot water or cold, [???]owing as readily at the touch of every guest, as from the ancient rock at the stroke of the prophet's wand, past-office, telegraph, a rattling gong, and two dollars and a half a day, are the inevitable concomitants of hotel-life, as it is now. Nor does there seem to be any limit to the adoption of new expedients for relieving guests from the necessity of the slightest physical exertion for the accomplishment of their wants. The latest illustration of this accommodating tendency of hotel-keepers is the introduction of an elevator to take gouty gentlemen and languid females from the dinner-table to their rooms above, without the intervention of stairs. The human package of dinner or ennui, entering an apartment not unlike a cushioned church-pew, finds itself in a few seconds carried to the top of the house by the revolution of a giant screw, to which the car is attached, as smoothly and quietly as many a church-goer hopes that he is gliding up, by the exertion of the priest, to whom as supporting column his faith is hung. We shall next expect to hear of some mechanical contrivance for putting lazy folks to bed, and a crank mill through which they will be run in the morning, to come out washed, cravated, brushed and combed, ready for the breakfast table, or rather, more probably the breakfast-stuffing machine, which will have taken its place.

abstract: During the last few weeks, and even months, the weather on the Atlantic has been more continually harassing and fearful in its character than has been ever known by the oldest seaman in connection with Liverpool. Some of the escapes from shipwreck and utter destruction have been truly marvellous, and none more so than that of the Guy Mannering, an American liner, which yesterday returned to Liverpool, after thirty-two days' vain effort to reach New-York. Though she sailed on the 6th of January last, on her twenty-fourth day out she had only reached 26 1/2° W. lon., and 48° N. lat. Captain DOLLARD, the commander, never during his whole lite experienced a more fearful combination of wind and sea. For eighteen successive days there were incessant gales from the S.S.W. to the N.N.W. which blew away almost all the sails, broke the rudder at the trunk, and opened great leaks in the vessel's hull. The skylights and all loose articles were washed away, and the cabins filled with water. To add to these diasters, a boat was washed by the sea upon one of the men, killing him upon the spot, while another of the crew fell from the maintopsail-yard, nearly 100 feet, and though, miraculous to relate, still alive, he is not expected to survive. Nine of the crew of 24 were so disabled that they had to lay up in the forecastle, and of those who remained to work the ship, not one is free from injury or disease, the results of working incessantly in salt water. Capt. DOLLARD, throughout, not only maintained his calmness and courage, but manifested a degree of skillful resource which shows him to be an accomplished seaman. He brought his vessel to port again without the aid of a steam-tug, and with the rudder worked from the sides of the ship by means of chains and tackle. -- Manchester Guardian.

abstract: The Bologna currespondent of the Daily News, writing on the 1st instant, gives the following account of his visit to Palazzo del Governo, the prison in which Father FELLETTI is confined, charged with the abduction of the child MORTARA.
lead_paragraph: The Bologna currespondent of the Daily News, writing on the 1st instant, gives the following account of his visit to Palazzo del Governo, the prison in which Father FELLETTI is confined, charged with the abduction of the child MORTARA. The room which he now occupies is called the Torrione, because it forms part of a massive tower on the northern side of the ancient building. It was about a quarter to ten when the turnkeys ushered me into the Torrione. The prisoner was then sitting at a wooden desk, which he had turned into a small altar for his private devotions. On entering I was struck with the cleanliness and monastic order which were discernible within. It was a lofty, vaultea room, twelve feet long by ten feet wide. The walls were cleanly white washed, and at the southern and northern sides two large windows protected by an [???] rail insured a copious and wholesome ventilation. The pavement had been expressly covered with matting, and a large stove had been placed in a corner of the room to warm it. The clean iron bedstead stood at the right-hand side of the door, and opposite it there was a large oak table, upon which bottles of wine had been placed in an orderly row by the prisoner, together with an abundant supply of dishes, forks, knifes and spoons. This was the batterie de cuisine of Father FELLETTI. A glance at the labels on the bottles inspired me with respect for the Father's judgment, and the resources of his extempore cellar. The wine of Monte Pulciano, the Alcatico of Florence and the famous Vino Santo were all included in the collection. An abundant store of sweet Bolognese cakes, called biscottmi, was heaped up at the side of the bottle; and from what the turnkeys told me Father FELLETTI has a proper appreciation of these delicacies, which are regularly sent to him by the pious ladies who used to confess to him when he was free. On my entering into the comfortable room Father FELLETTI rose from his arm-chair, bidding me good morning, with the usual monastic formula, "God be praised." He was dressed in the white loose woolen robes of his order, with a long black narrow s[???]plice, which descended from the shoulders nearly to the extreme edge on it. His head was covered with a white hood, which he had drawn up to protect it. Although the prisoner is not yet 62 years of age, he looked a great deal older, and being short and thin the large to[???]s of his [???] [???] closely about his [???]. Having read so much about the hence characters of ancient and modern inquisitions of the Holy Office, I must say I rather expected to find Father FELLETTI of a somewhat austere countenance. On the contrary, the expression of his pale face is decidedly prepossessing. His spacious forehead and the well marked lines of his mouth be[???]okened, however, a certain amount of character and determination, which now and then became more apparent from the rapid movements of his eyes. On the whole, he gave me the impression of a good pious man, [???]o belongs. I had afterwards an opportunity of ascending that such is the reputation he has long enjoyed at Bologna, where he discharged the rather [???] duties of holy inquisitor for 26 years, without weighing too heavily upon the population which fell within his jurisdiction. If in the Mortara affair he acted with inhumanity and harshness, it was because orders were sent from Rome to this effect, and because he had a blind and unreasoning [???] that he was doing what his religion enjoined. Before leaving the [???]orrtoue, I asked Father FELLETTI whether he was humanely treated in his prison. Not knowing who I was and for what reason I had been allowed to visit him, he did not give any positive answer to my question. Lifting up both his eyes and his shoulders, he only made a gestate which meant that he was resigned to his fate. The turnkey, who had caught sight of it, urged him to answer, but no answer was given. I was then informed by this man that the convent provided for the daily wants of the prisoner, whose dinner consisted of a good wine. After this declaration, Father FELLETTI was at last induced to speak, and told me that he had nothing to co aplain [???] except the noise of the street, which prevented his sleeping. To this matter the Government will attend for I hear that the prisoner will be removed to a quarter prison either to morrow or the day after."

abstract: Dr. THOMAS T. ELLIS, the confidence operator, whose conviction and sentence to Sing Sing for three years and six months, on Monday, in the Court of General Sessions, was reported in the TIMES of the following day, was taken to Sing Sing yesterday morning to serve out his term of ...
lead_paragraph: Dr. THOMAS T. ELLIS, the confidence operator, whose conviction and sentence to Sing Sing for three years and six months, on Monday, in the Court of General Sessions, was reported in the TIMES of the following day, was taken to Sing Sing yesterday morning to serve out his term of imprisonment. No common criminal is Dr. ELLIS. Enjoying splendid opportunities to achieve high social and literary distinction, he has suck to the deeper depths of infamy. He had fine talents and perverted them, and the noble endowments of his intellect and person he turned to ignoble use. Having been tried only on one indictment whereas a dozen are hanging over his head, a fractional part only of his life has been developed before the Counts. In view of this fact, and the singularly marked character of his career, we give below a somewhat extended record of his life. Many of the facts were gathered from his own lips, and their accuracy, as well as that of the other statements given, is well attested. A wasted life the story shows, and rightly read, there is a moral in it of some importance.

abstract: LADIES' BIBLE UNION. -- The Anniversary of the Ladies' Bible Union was held last evening at the Broome-street Baptist Church. The introductory exercises were of the usual character. The annual Report showed that $694 74 had been received and expended in the work of translating the Scriptures. Rev. FRANK REMINGTON delivered the address. Subject -- "A pure Bible the only true platform of Christian Union." Dr. SHEPHERD and Rev. M. BUCKBEE also made brief addresses. In consequence of the storm the attendance was quite limited.

abstract: Stone pavements are generally supposed to be much cheaper than iron:--yet we are quite inclined to believe that the aggregate expense of keeping Broadway well paved with stone for a hundred years, would be a million dollars more than the cost of paving it with iron during the same period.
lead_paragraph: Stone pavements are generally supposed to be much cheaper than iron:--yet we are quite inclined to believe that the aggregate expense of keeping Broadway well paved with stone for a hundred years, would be a million dollars more than the cost of paving it with iron during the same period. If our City rulers can be induced to study the question with some care, in the light of engineering science and facts, they will probably come to the same conclusion: -- they cannot fail, at all events, to see that the cost of our pavements, and the cost to those who use them, may both be materially reduced.

abstract: AT WESTBORO', MASS. -- On Tuesday, Feb. 21, the steam-power works at Westboro', Mass., were totally destroyed by fire. The building, which was of wood, was about 125 feet long by 40 wide, and was three stories in height. It was owned by OTIS F. VINTON, Esq., and was occupied in part by him for the manufacture of wagons and sleighs. The other occupants were PRESCOTT SIBLEY, manufacturer of boxes; A.M. HOWE, manufacturer of cutters, and D.R. STETSON, nail manufacturer. Mr. VINTON was insured, and Mr. HOWE partially so, but Messrs. SIBLEY and STETSON lost everything. The total loss is estimated at $10,000, about three-fourths of which is covered by insurance. Several other buildings in close proximity, among which was the "Nursery," a building occupied by about 250 of the State Reform School boys, were saved only by great exertions.

abstract: A few weeks since I gave the readers of the NEW-YORK TIMES some recollections of the late MIKE WALSH, whom I had known personally and politically for several years; and I promised to follow them with a similar sketch of his old crony and co-subteranen, D.C. BRODERICK. An accident  which disable me for a time has hitherto prevented ...
lead_paragraph: A few weeks since I gave the readers of the NEW-YORK TIMES some recollections of the late MIKE WALSH, whom I had known personally and politically for several years; and I promised to follow them with a similar sketch of his old crony and co-subteranen, D.C. BRODERICK. An accident which disable me for a time has hitherto prevented the fulfillment of this purpose. The formal announcement which was made last week in the Sen-of his death, and the accompanying complimentary notices of him, have brought his name and fate once more to public recollection; and I seize this occasion to present some incidents in his history as a New-Yorker, hitherto unpublished, before he shall have passed into the oblivion, or at least general indifference, to which all such persons tend in spite of their greatest successes and their highest triumphs.

abstract: There is actually a possibility that we may have clean streets for the whole of the coming year! The news is too good to be true, and we shrink from announcing it as anything that is likely actually to happen; but the bare chance of such an experience is enough to bewilder imaginations so long accustomed to the mud and filth with which our citizens have become familiar.

lead_paragraph: The NEW-YORK TIMES is the youngest of the daily newspapers of the City of New-York. The first number was issued on the 18th of September, 1801,-- so that it has only just completed the eighth year of its publication. But it has already become one of the most widely known and most firmly established daily journals of the United States. Its circulation is quite as large as that of any other daily of its class in the City of New-York, -- and in reputation for enterprise, energy, and reliability, it may fairly challenge comparison with any other newspaper in the country.

abstract: Whatever doubts may have lingered in the minds of rational Roman Catholics as to the real origin of the troubles which are now gathering so ominously about the throne of St. Peter, must be finally removed, we think, by the letter of Pope PIUS IX. to NAPOLEON III., which we publish to-day from our European files.
lead_paragraph: Whatever doubts may have lingered in the minds of rational Roman Catholics as to the real origin of the troubles which are now gathering so ominously about the throne of St. Peter, must be finally removed, we think, by the letter of Pope PIUS IX. to NAPOLEON III., which we publish to-day from our European files. There would be something almost touching in the imbecility which whines, and laments, and vaguely invokes the mystical fulminations of Heaven throughout this deprecatory appeal of a falling monarch, were not very different feelings appropriate to the audacious assumptions which it also contains as to the duty of the Pope in matters temporal and political, as the representative of the principle of Legitimacy in opposition to the principle of Revolution.

abstract: The "boss bakers" of this City are, we have no doubt, a very estimable set of persons, but they are just now engaged in an enterprise which does not argue the possession of very much sound common sense.
lead_paragraph: The "boss bakers" of this City are, we have no doubt, a very estimable set of persons, but they are just now engaged in an enterprise which does not argue the possession of very much sound common sense. They have actually held two or three meetings to take into consideration what means they had better adopt to extinguish one of their number for selling bread cheaper than the rest of the fraternity. The fortunate or unfortunate wight, whose loaves they are thus puffing into notoriety, is Mr. HECKER, of farina celebrity, who, it apappears, is, by the bakers' code, properly, legitimately, and of right, a vender of flour and farina, and nothing more. As long as he confined himself to this harmless vocation, they had no fault to find with him, and were even content to purchase flour of him as cheaply as he could be got to sell it. But in an evil hour he determined to convert his flour into loaves, or, in other words, turn "boss baker," and on doing so, found he could, owing to his flour business, sell bread cheaper than his neighbors, and has ever since been doing so. The other bakers, finding themselves unable to compete with him, and that the bread eaters, with strange perversity, prefer cheap loaves to dear ones, held a meeting, and resolved to call upon HECKER in a formal and solemn manner, either to sell as dear bread as other people, or else stop selling bread altogether. With this modest request we presume he declined to comply, as we rind in yesterday's TIMES the report of another meeting held by the aggrieved bread-makers, in order to combine upon a plan for inflicting summary vengeance upon him. They then and there resolved to not only withdraw their patronage from HECKER themselves, but from every flour-dealer who bought any of his flour.
headline: {'main': 'Cheap Bread and the Bakers.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Cheap Bread and the Bakers.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: In anticipation of the return of the Regiment extensive preparations were made in the City for giving them a hearty reception.
lead_paragraph: In anticipation of the return of the Regiment extensive preparations were made in the City for giving them a hearty reception. As it was expected that they would arrive here between 6 and 7 o'clock yesterday, the Twelfth Regiment, under command of Col. BUTTERFIELD, and the Ninth, under Col. VAN BUREN, were ordered to form on Broome and Spring streets at 6 o'clock A.M. That portion of the Seventh Regiment which did not make the jaunt to Washington also joined in the parade, and by 9 o'clock all the Regiments were in the Park "armed and equipped as the law directs." Owing to the early hour at which they were ordered to assemble, there was some tardiness in forming the lines, but it occasioned no harm, inasmuch as dispatches had been received during the night by Col. BUTTERFIELD, stating that the long train required for the Seventh Regiment caused much delay on the railroads, and that the Regiment would not arrive in the City until after the time telegraphed before. On the strength of these dispatches, the Regiments were dismissed until 11 o'clock, at which time they reassembled and marched down Broadway to Cortlandt-street, the Twelfth Regiment leading, the Ninth next, while the domestic Seventh, under Col. DURYEA, brought up the rear. After turning down Cortlandt-street, they formed on the side of the street to await the coming of the travelers.

abstract: -- We had hoped, from the signs of the day, that there was to be an abatement of the sectional war which has given rise to so much commotion. Throughout the country at large there is a manifest subsidence of the heated passion lately so rife. But the Abolitionists continue true to their aim, and their organ for the South -- the Herald -- is unwearied in its labors. In its yesterday's "issue it prints two speeches made in Boston by GARRISON and PHILLIPS, -- the most inflammatory harangues to which this fresh crusade has given rise, -- glorying in the prospect of a speedy renewal of attempts at slave insurrection, and stimulating the most intense hatred of the Southern people. But for their transfer to the columns of the Herald, these incendiary documents would never have been seen beyond the limits of Boston; now they will penetrate the most remote limits of the Slave States. The Abolitionists have good cause for passing resolutions of thanks to the Herald for its efficient service in their cause.

abstract: A number of petty swindles have been perpetrated recently upon residents of the West side of the City, by two men who represented themselves as carriers for a California Express Company having its office at No. 5 Bowling-green. The rogues, with a sleigh well filled with packages, would drive up before the house of the intended victim, and, while one remained in the vehicle, his confederate would present a letter to the person who answered his summons at the door, and demand the payment of twenty-five cents. A few days since, one of the fictitious missives was left at the residence of Mr. Charles Anderson, a Clerk in the office of the Superintendent of the Outdoor Poor, which purported to have come from California, and contained the information, from the executors of an estate in San Francisco, that a note of hand given by Mr. Anderson had been found among the effects of deceased, and that it had been forwarded to the Park Bank for collection. Upon inquiry at the Bank, however, the statement of the letter was found to be fabulous, and further investigation revealed the fact that no Express Company has an office at No. 5 Bowling-green. The Police have been notified by-several parties who have been swindled by these rogues.
lead_paragraph: A number of petty swindles have been perpetrated recently upon residents of the West side of the City, by two men who represented themselves as carriers for a California Express Company having its office at No. 5 Bowling-green. abstract: Mr. SENNOTT, who went from Boston to Virginia the other day for the second time, to defend STEVENS on his trial for aiding and abetting in JOHN BROWN'S conspiracy, and made on that occasion a very bold and vigorous speech on the national relations of the Harper's Ferry affair, and of the general question of Slavery, is now doing his best to secure the pardon of his convicted client from Gov. LETCHER.
lead_paragraph: Mr. SENNOTT, who went from Boston to Virginia the other day for the second time, to defend STEVENS on his trial for aiding and abetting in JOHN BROWN'S conspiracy, and made on that occasion a very bold and vigorous speech on the national relations of the Harper's Ferry affair, and of the general question of Slavery, is now doing his best to secure the pardon of his convicted client from Gov. LETCHER. There would seem to he some reason to expect that his efforts will be successful, and it is certainly to be hoped that they may be so. Virginia has at least sufficiently vindicated the outraged majesty of her laws; and as she has exchanged a ruler who was merely wise by name, for one who is believed to be really wise by nature, we may trust that she will practically recognize the folly of manufacturing martyrs for other people to use. Mr. WENDELL PHILLIPS, in a speech at the meeting of the Anti-Slavery Society in Boston the other day, called for the purpose of indorsing Mr. SEWARD as a man "fit to be President," and for other objects, useful and ornamental, announced his belief that the echoes of JOHN BROWN's foray "will be repeated further West and further South, till the great organ-hymn of insurrection ascends to God." Of course every fresh execution of one of JOHN BROWN's accomplices will give a fresh, argument to such orators as Mr. PHILLIPS, towards convincing the people of the North that the terror of insurrection is busy at the heart of the South, and that it is idle to talk of dealing justly by men who can be coerced by their fears into accepting the Union at any price. For the cry of Northern, like the cry of Southern Disunionists, means, in nine cases out of ten, not Disunion at all, but simply supremacy in the Union, and the power of overriding all constitutional guarantees to establish a fanatical creed.

abstract: The announcement that a very eloquent preacher of this City--Rev. T.L. HARRIS--in a public discourse, recently delivered in London, had abjured Spiritualism, of which, for years past, he has been reputed a burning and a shining light, has been followed by a fearful fluttering in the "circles."
lead_paragraph: The announcement that a very eloquent preacher of this City--Rev. T.L. HARRIS--in a public discourse, recently delivered in London, had abjured Spiritualism, of which, for years past, he has been reputed a burning and a shining light, has been followed by a fearful fluttering in the "circles." The Spiritual Magazine, published in London, denies the truth of the statement, and says that the misapprehension of Mr. HARRIS' position originated in a report of one of his discourses, in which "the delinquent writer entirely misrepresented its purport and statements." The reverend gentleman, it asserts, is still a firm believer in Spiritual manifestations, though he fully appreciates and fearlessly exposes the terrible abuses to which they are liable.
headline: {'main': 'The Imposture of Spiritualism.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Imposture of Spiritualism.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The public was some months since apprised of the intention, and to some extent of the plans, of Mr. NORMAN WIARD and his associates, in the matter of transporting passengers and goods over the almost boundless expanse of our Western frozen rivers in steam-propelled cars or sleighs.
lead_paragraph: The public was some months since apprised of the intention, and to some extent of the plans, of Mr. NORMAN WIARD and his associates, in the matter of transporting passengers and goods over the almost boundless expanse of our Western frozen rivers in steam-propelled cars or sleighs. The extent and amount of the Winter commerce thus proposed, together with the fact that the average thickness and smoothness of the ice for at least five months would render such a project feasible, has excited the liveliest interest among the commercial men of the Northwest and common carriers generally.

abstract: In no branch of literature has America gained more durable laurels than in that treating of the peculiar province of legal medicine. The Elements of Medical Jurisprudence, by JOHN B ...
lead_paragraph: In no branch of literature has America gained more durable laurels than in that treating of the peculiar province of legal medicine. The Elements of Medical Jurisprudence, by JOHN B. BECK, late of Albany, has been frequently reprinted in Europe, where it is considered as authority at their highest tribunals. Dr. RAY's treatise has also received similar commendations. The annotations of Dr. LEE and others to the American reprints of GUY's, TAYLOR's and CHRISTISON's treatises on Forensic Medicine, or some of its branches, have been equally approved by European Courts and medical authorities, and are now embodied into their digests.

abstract: A correspondent of the London Times, signing himself "A Voyageur," writes, on the above subject, a long letter which is honored with "official type."
lead_paragraph: A correspondent of the London Times, signing himself "A Voyageur," writes, on the above subject, a long letter which is honored with "official type." The writer sketches the history of the territory from the sixteenth century to 1815, when, at the Congress of Vienna, it was leid down as a principle by the great Powers that the absolute neutrality of the Swiss Republic was a European necessity, and that in that view it was important to give her a strong natural boundary. In fact, the question of Savoy, he says, is a question of physical geography. The Genevese Commissioners represented that the arrangements under the first treaty of Paris did not gain those ends; they therefore proposed that, subject to the sovereignty of Sardinia, Chablias and Faucigny should be included in the neutrality of Switzerland, and accompanied the details necessary to carry out this plan by the suggestion that Sardinia should engage never to cede nor exchange these possessions, and negotiations were in existence when the landing of NAPOLEON I from Elba caused a renewal of the alliance of the great Powers, to which Switzerland gave her adherence, with a force of 40,000 men, and opened the short campaign terminated by the second peace of Paris. The Swiss and Sardinian questions were taken up, and by a treaty signed on the 20th November, 1815, by Austria, France, Great Britain, Portugal, Prussia, Russia, Sweden and Spain, it was agreed that the portion of Savoy which, at the first peace of Paris had been retained by France, should be restored to Sardinia, and the article of March 29, 1815, of the Congress of Vienna, by which, "in the event of war," those portions of Sardinian Savoy called Chablais and Faucigny were declared to participate in the neutrality of Switzerland, was confirmed. A treaty was entered into in 1816 between Switzerland and Sardinia, by which the necessary details for placing Chablais and Faucigny under Swiss military occupation in the eventuality of war, for withdrawing the Sardinian troops, and for settling a well defined boundary to the neutral portion of the territory, were agreed on.

abstract: In the House of Commons, on the 10th instant, the Chancellor of the Exchequer rose to make his financial statement. The House having resolved itself into Committee of Ways and Means, he said that the year 1860 had long been marked out as an importent epoch in British commerce.
lead_paragraph: In the House of Commons, on the 10th instant, the Chancellor of the Exchequer rose to make his financial statement. The House having resolved itself into Committee of Ways and Means, he said that the year 1860 had long been marked out as an importent epoch in British commerce. The long annuities, amounting to £2,146,000, fell in; the war duties on tea and sugar, unless renewed, relapsed. Finally, the commercial treaty with France compelled the Government to adopt a new and unusual course. In making the financial statement before taking votes in supply, the result of the past financial year, inasmuch as that year had not been completed, must be given partly in the form of estimate; but the House might rely on the figures. Exceptional cases had affected the estimates. There was the expedition to China, and the additional cost of our military preparations. There was the French Treaty to be provided against in addition. Coming to the actual state of affairs, he showed that the total result of the revenue of the last year showed an increase over the estimate. The revenue had been estimated at £69,460,000; it had produced £70,578,000. On the other hand, the expenditure, estimated at £68,953,000, had been £69,270,000. It thus appeared that, under existing arrangements, there was an excess of income over expenditure. The excess, though it was already absorbed by disturbing causes, showed the wisdom of the arrangements of Parliament. The expedition to China, and excess of navy and army expenditure, had cost an additional £900,000 for the army, and £270,000 for the navy. The commercial treaty would, he calculated, cause a deduction of £640,000. This would cause a total deduction of £1,810,000, and would place us rather on the wrong side of the balances. But to compensate for this, he had received, most unexpectedly, part of a debt from Spain, in the shape of bills, to the amount of £500,000, half of which would fall due in the present financial year. In this way the balance would be reestablished. The estimated expenditure for the coming year involved an increase in the army and navy of £3,618,000. The total expenditure is estimated at £70,100,000. The estimated income for the coming year would not, in the first instance, be satisfactory; but, at all events, it would compel their attention to those matters which most require examination. He should estimate the revenue as the law at present stood, taking the duties on tea and sugar at the minimum and reduced rates, the income tax as it would stand under existing arrangements -- upon these terms the estimate of revenue for the coming year would give a total of £60,700,000, showing a deficit of £9,400,000. He did not ask them to provide for the payment of Exchequer bonds soon becoming due. Without this they had the deficit of £9,400,000. If they had not the treaty to deal with, they would know precisely what they had to face. They might keep the duties of tea and sugar at the present rate, which would leave the deficit at £7,300,000. Even this would involve an income tax of 9d. in the pound. To fill up the deficit as it stood, this would require the neat and intelligible income tax of ls. in the pound. Now came the question, what had become of the estimates of 1853? He had a clear answer to give. The succession duty had failed from causes due to the actual law. The debt caused by the Russian war entailed a large charge on the consolidated fund and the army and navy expenses now entailed upon us. The deficit thus caused was, however, fully compensated by the financial measures they had since adopted. The real cause was the immense increase of expenditure. Had that expenditure remained as it was in 1852, they would now have had a surplus of two millions. That increase amounted to no less than £14,720,000, equivalent to an income tax of 13 1/2d. in the pound. It would not, however, be fair to consider the increase of expenditure without taking into account the increase of its means. This was especially shown by the results of the income tax He went through the results of several years, showing an increase in the wealth of the country of 12 per cent, in the twelve years between 1842 and 1853, and of 16 1/2 per cent, in the six years from 1863 to 1859. No schedule shows a larger increase than that of the agriculturist, whose income had exceeded nineteen percent. Meanwhile, the expenditure has interested in a still greater proportion. In the years from 1842 to 1852 it had increased 4 1/2 per cent and in the years 1862 to 1856 it increased to 26 1/2 per cent. The increase was still more evident in that expenditure which was under the control of Parliament, and which he might call the optional expenditure; in that the increase, during the last six years, was not less than 58 per cent. Recurring to the means of meeting the deficit, he owned, that no was not satisfied with our system of expenditure; still, all changes must, of necessity, be gradual. There were again, commercial reforms and improvements. There were those who considered, that these reforms ought to be kept for fair weather and a flourishing exct[???]quer. Against that doctrine be earnestly protested He declared, on the part of the Government, that they were ready and prepared to go forward in commercial improvement. It was only by means of these reforms that the country was enabled to bear high taxation I Could the country have borne the High income tax of the last eighteen months if it had not been for increased taxation He showed from figures that the relaxation and reform of the commercial system had given the country not only this disposition but the power to pay this, inasmuch as the revenues of the departments were increased as the duties were relaxed. It thus appeared that indirect taxation should be relaxed in favor of direct taxation, and it only remained to us to say upon what principle. The Government did not at present intend to deal with tea and sugar. These were merely revenue duties, and involved none of the complexities of differential duties. The tailoring classes were more benefited by an enlarged system of tree trade than by relaxing individual duties, as creating higher price for labor. It was upon this principle the Government intended to act. They proposed to retain the tea and sugar duties at the present late for a year. He then gave an outline of the French Commercial Treaty. France reduces, from July 1, 1860, duties on coal; from Oct. 1, on iron; from Dec 1, on tools; from June 1, 1861, on goods manufactured from flax, hemp and jute; from Oct. 1, 1861, France removes all prohibitions on all English manufactured goods, placing on them an ad vstorem duty not exceeding 30 per cent. This maximum is, after three years, to be reduced to 25 per cant. On the other hand, England, on her part, abolished immediately and without exception all duties on manufactured goods. We reduce the duty on brandy from 15s. a gallon to the colonial duty of 8s. 2d.; and the duty on wine from 5s.10d. to 3s.; to be further reduced from April, 1861, upon a scale depending upon the strength of the wine. As to the effect of these reductions, he estimated from wine relief to the consumers of £830,000, and a loss to the revenue £515,000; on brandy, a revenue to the consumers of £446,000, and a loss to the revenue of £225,010; and the loss to the revenue on manufactured goods at £432,000, He declared that the treaty showed no subserviency to France. They had given nothing to France which they had not given as a rich gift to themselves, and they had made no sacrifices except what they would have made in any case under an enlightened system of trade. The system had answered its purpose of political estrangement, but political estrangement, but the new system answers its purpose by political amity. The union which had been in former days between France and England -- a union of the Governments -- should now be the union of the nations, He defended commercial treaties, when not arounded upon principles of exclusion, and gloried in avowing that the treaty was a consummation of free trade. He, entered into an elaborate defence of the treaty, declaring that we shall do equal good to ourselves and to France by the introduction of a liberal system, and declaring that wine, which, like tea in the last century, was the rich man's luxury, would, like tea, be the poor man's comfort. He denied that any of the duties repeated were revenue duties. As a proof they were only opposed by interested parties. He entered at great length into the wine trade, to show how injuriously the present system operated and what good effect might be expected by the alteration we had now done with France, what we had been laboring to do for years past. He paid a warm tribute to Mr. COBDEN, who as the apostle of free trade, had twice in his life achieved so signal a triumph. He stated that the immediate repeal of duties on French articles was not dressed by the French Government. On the contrary, it was the device of our own. He then came to a supplemental reform in the customs, giving a relief to the consumers of a[???] a million, and a less to the revenue of £010,000. He proposed to abolish the duties on butter, cheese, oranges, and eggs, and to recu[???]e those on timber and currants and hops. In return he proposed to levy on all articles exported or imported a registration due of one penny per packet. It gave a great [???]tea of the transactions of the country, that they would produce £300,000 per annum. He further proposed to lay moderate charges upon certain warehousing proceedings performed in the customs' offices for the benefit of the importer. By this they expected; £120,000. He then proposed a duty of 6s. per cwt. on chicory, as a protection, the coffee revenue. This, with an improvement on the coffee revenue which it would cause would profuse £90,000, Again, he proposed a penny stamp in brokers' contracts; a 3d. stamp upon dock warants; licenses to eating houses to sell wine and beer; a reduction in game certificates, which would increase the sale, granting those certificates for a few months at a reduced cost; to remove the execution from stamps or on checks drawn to self. He likewise repeated some other small stamp exemptions. He thus obtained an increase of £510,000 in the Customs, and £3;6,000 in the Inland Revenue. In management they hope to save £50,000 in Customs and £36,000 in the Inland Revenue. The total would be £981,000; thus compensating the second part of these Customs reforms. Thus, on the whole, including the loss on the French treaty, the new arrangements involved a loss of about £1,000,000. He next came to a larger item. He proposed to repeal the paper duty. That duty has already been condemned by a direct vote of that House. The actual duty not only operated unjustly against publications for the masses, but prevented the manufacture of paper from an enormous quantity of fibrous substances. So many articles might be made out of paper that a vast impulse would be given to rural labor. The Inland Revenue itself admitted that the present Jaw was untenable, and fully agreed with the Abolitionists that it ought to be repealed. The next repeal was that of the improved stamp upon newspapers, which involved great trouble and inconvenience. For the convenience of the newspapers who paid a three halfpenny stamp he proposed to introduce a three halfpenny book postage. He next proposed to abolish the hop credits, while on the other hand, he reduced the duty, which, including the paper duty, was a remission of one million, and considering the increase of consumption, which he valued at £840.000, the total loss to the revenue would be £3,000,000. while the relief to the consumers would be £3,931,000. Making further allowance for the new charges, and the saving in management, the net loss to the revenue would be £28,000. Thus, in the present year only forty six articles remained on the tariff, and only forty-four would remain in 1861. The tariff would be relieved of all its remaining deformities. He had proposed to take up hop and malt credits, which would give $1,400,000 to the Treasury in the present year. The account then stood thus for the coming year; expenditure, £70,000,000; income, made actual law, £60,700,000. From this deduct loss by remission of duty, which would reduce it to £58,592,000. But he proposed to retain the present tea and sugar duties, which raised the income to £60,002,000. This leaves a deficit of nine millions and a half. Against this there was the £140,000 of the malt and hop credits. To provide for the remainder, he proposed an income tax of 10d. in the pound on incomes above £150, and of 7d. on incomes under that sum, which would produce £8,481,000, and thus completely fill up the deficiency. This tax, and the present duties on tea and sugar, to continue only for the year. He concluded by a warm eulogium on the blessings of improved laws and a well regulated finance. A formal vote for imposing a duty upon chicory was then proposed.

abstract: James B. Wilson, Trustee, &c., vs. Ann Stryker. -- This was an appeal from an order made by Justice INGRAHAM, denying a motion made by the defendant to vacate an injunction order grafted ex parte. The injunction order restrained the defendant from collecting the rents of certain premises which originally formed a part of the estate of John Hopper. The counsel for the defendant insisted that the injunction should be vacated, as it appeared that the defendant had been in the quiet and sole possession of the property for nearly 40 years; and that during that time she had had the exclusive control and management of her portion of the estate; that the defendant came into possession in 1821, under proceedings in partition and a deed of release executed to her by one Winfred Mott and G.H. Stryker; that by the will of John Hooper, dated in 1815, said Winfred Mott, G.H. Stryker and the defendant, grandchildren of the testator, took a devise in fee; that the executors named in the will had only a naked trust to lease the property and pay over the rents to the said grandchildren; and that as these trustees had neglected to execute any of the trusts created in the will, until the present time and proceeding, it was not a proper case for such an injunction order, the effect of which was to deprive the defendant of her patrimony.
lead_paragraph: James B. Wilson, Trustee, &c., vs. Ann Stryker. -- This was an appeal from an order made by Justice INGRAHAM, denying a motion made by the defendant to vacate an injunction order grafted ex parte. The injunction order restrained the defendant from collecting the rents of certain premises which originally formed a part of the estate of John Hopper. The counsel for the defendant insisted that the injunction should be vacated, as it appeared that the defendant had been in the quiet and sole possession of the property for nearly 40 years; and that during that time she had had the exclusive control and management of her portion of the estate; that the defendant came into possession in 1821, under proceedings in partition and a deed of release executed to her by one Winfred Mott and G.H. Stryker; that by the will of John Hooper, dated in 1815, said Winfred Mott, G.H. Stryker and the defendant, grandchildren of the testator, took a devise in fee; that the executors named in the will had only a naked trust to lease the property and pay over the rents to the said grandchildren; and that as these trustees had neglected to execute any of the trusts created in the will, until the present time and proceeding, it was not a proper case for such an injunction order, the effect of which was to deprive the defendant of her patrimony.

abstract: CITY OF MEXICO, Thursday, Jan. 19, 1860. Since the departure of the mail for abroad, on  the 1st inst., the people of this Capital have been devoting themselves almost exclusively to doing honor to their military chief, MIRAMON, who has recently returned from a campaign into the interior, and to making all manner of manifestations of disgust for the Anglo-Saxon race, most especially that branch known as "Yankees."
lead_paragraph: CITY OF MEXICO, Thursday, Jan. 19, 1860. Since the departure of the mail for abroad, on the 1st inst., the people of this Capital have been devoting themselves almost exclusively to doing honor to their military chief, MIRAMON, who has recently returned from a campaign into the interior, and to making all manner of manifestations of disgust for the Anglo-Saxon race, most especially that branch known as "Yankees." The clergy are furious. Through their political chiefs, they pour out the vials of their wrath upon those natives who have espoused the cause of the Liberal or Constiutional Party, as well as upon all foreign residents of the country, who are blamed for many of the progressive ideas that have got into the heads of the natives. Public dinners have been given to the officers of MIRAMON's Army, known now as the "Army of the Cross," at which speeches against the Yankees have been made, of the most violent and warlike character. The street corners are now covered with patriotic appeals "to all good Mexicans" to arm and prepare for the terrible conflict that must commence at once with the Yankees. It is plainly stated that Mexico must crumble to pieces under the heel of the overbearing Anglo-Saxon, or her victorious banner must be carried on, even to making conquests. At a dinner given by MIRAMON the other evening, one of the many Generals who adorn his table said:

abstract: We hale already announced the recent death, at Florence, Italy, of THOS. A. TEFFT, Esq., of Richmond Rhode Island, at the early age of 32--a man who, if he had lived, would have achieved marked distinction in the special department of science to which he had devoted liimself, and would have proved inferior to few in the genial sister-branch of literature, or in the less attractive domain of social science.
lead_paragraph: We hale already announced the recent death, at Florence, Italy, of THOS. A. TEFFT, Esq., of Richmond Rhode Island, at the early age of 32--a man who, if he had lived, would have achieved marked distinction in the special department of science to which he had devoted liimself, and would have proved inferior to few in the genial sister-branch of literature, or in the less attractive domain of social science. Little more than three years ago Mr. TEFF[???] sailed for Europe. He was then in excellent health, and had the promise of a fine career before him. In early boyhood his taste for architecture attracted the notice of his friends, and he was placed under the tuition of Messrs. TALLMAN & BUCKLIN, of Providence. While under their care he found, or rather made, an opportunity for the study of the Greek and Roman classics, with other branches of collegiate study, and graduated at Brown University in 1851. Already he had made designs for several public buildings, and before he had attained his twenty-first year the Depot in Providence was erected from one of these, and has ever since been considered one of the handsomest edifices of which that city can boast. "Later in life," writes one of his numerous friends, "he designed and superintended the erection of numerous edifices, public and private, and in many of the villages of the State (Rhode Island) will be found the graceful spires of churches and attractive school houses, built under his direction, and which are always referred to as models of good taste. He lived in a world of art, and it was the study of his life how best to promote a love for that which to him was so worthy of devotion." Several public buildings in Massachusetts, and at Richmond, Virginia, were erected by him. But his ambition tempted him to higher achievments, and to complete his architectural education, he resolved to study the cathedrals and temples of the greatest masters in the Old World.

abstract: There is a good deal of vigor, boldness and originality in this book--the title of which conveys no notion of its character or contents.
lead_paragraph: There is a good deal of vigor, boldness and originality in this book--the title of which conveys no notion of its character or contents. It is, in fact, an imitation SOUTHEY's "Doctor," -- the author availing himself of that style and method of communicating his opinions on various controverted questions of the day. It is not necessary to say that it lacks the learning, the copiousness and the wit of its great prototype; but it is clearly the work of a scholar and a man of thought -- one who does not yield in the least to the current of popular sentiment on religious, social or political questions, but who has his own opinions, and clings to them with the defiant tenacity of well-settled conviction. His style is clear and forcible, seldom inelegant, though marked rather by vigor and strength than by polish or brilliancy. His opinions on very many topics will encounter vigorous protests from various influential quarters; but they are not to be sneered out of sight, and will be found generally to deserve consideration. We shall embody some of them in such a cursory statement of the character and scope of the book as our space may enable us to give.

abstract: COUNTERFEIT MONEY. -- Two women were arrested Saturday night, while attempting to pass counterfeit $5 bills on the Citizens' Bank of Worcester, Mass. H.Q. COTTON was arrested in the Third Precinct, for passing counterfeit $3 bills on the Hudson County Bank of Jersey City, and counterfeit $3 bills on the Fairfield County Bank of Norwalk, Conn. WILLIAM BUCK, machinist, was arrested in the Sixth Precinct, for attempting to pass a $2 counterfeit bill on the State Bank, Boston, Mass.

abstract: Members come back from their constituents loaded down with all kinds of papers known to legislation. Petitions, remonstrances, notices, bills, etc., lay around loose everywhere. abstract: The year 1860 certainly comes in like a lion. Not yet two months old, it has written its name in blood and fire all over the world; and professing to be a year of peace, it threatens to rival its warlike predecessor in the destruction of human life by violence. Mills crash in upon their busy tenants; hideous dens miscalled ...
lead_paragraph: The year 1860 certainly comes in like a lion. Not yet two months old, it has written its name in blood and fire all over the world; and professing to be a year of peace, it threatens to rival its warlike predecessor in the destruction of human life by violence. Mills crash in upon their busy tenants; hideous dens miscalled homes shrivel up in the flames with a holocaust of peaceful citizens. January shocked our civilization with the loss of the Royal Charter, the catastrophe at Lawrence, and the Elm-street massacre. February brings us in the total wreck of a splendid ocean steamer, the Hungarian, with the probable loss of all on board -- a disaster which it is hardly premature to stigmatize as a fresh crime against humanity. As in the case of the Royal Charter, dashed to pieces after a successful passage from Australia, upon the familiar coast of Wales, and within a few hours' sail of her home harbor, so in this of the Hungarian we have a right to insist that nothing but the most positive recklessness or carelessness on somebody's part can honestly account for such a calamity.

abstract: EDWARD QUIGLEY, an infant three months old, whose parents live at No. 323 East Thirtieth-street, was fatally poisoned on Friday night, by his grandmother administering to him some liniment containing Croton oil, under the supposition that it was a cough remedy which the doctor had prescribed. The inquest was held by Coroner JACKMAN.

abstract: -- Notwithstanding the resistance they encounter everywhere, horse railroads are rapidly becoming the favorite means of locomotion in all the principal cities of the Union. Philadelphia is traversed by them in every direction. In Cincinnati the first one was opened in September, but several have been since constructed. In St. Louis they not only run through the streets, but connect the City with the most remote suburbs -- extending three or four miles from the town. In Chicago the omnibuses are making desperate efforts to hold their ground, or else compel the railroads to buy them off; but the latter clearly have the advantage.

lead_paragraph: The steamship Baltic, of the North Atlantic Steamship Company, having sailed from Aspinwall on the 19th inst., with the treasure and passengers which left San Francisco on the 6th, arrived here yesterday morning. There were $1,393,179 upon her treasure list; and the Vanderbilt steamer, it is understood, will bring forward $420,000 additional. Among the passengers of the Baltic is the Hon. MILTON S. LATHAM, the recently elected Senator from California. The news from California, the Isthmus, and from Central and South America by the Baltic, is later and interesting.

abstract: In response to a call from the Committee that has been at work during the past year to secure a better and more general observance of the Sabbath, there was a very large assemblage at Cooper Institute last evening. abstract: Soon after 10 o'clock on Saturday night, John J. Wagner, the night watchman employed in the silk and fringe warehouse of Messrs. Dexter, Lambert & Co., No. 540 Pearl-street, was alarmed at hearing a noise in the upper part of the building. Suspecting that burglars were at work, he secured the assistance of Officers Huggins, Maguire and Porcher, of the Sixth Precinct, who, on making investigation, found two men overhauling the goods on the second floor of the warehouse As soon as the thieves were aware that they had been detected, Charles Murphy, one of them, endeavored to escape by jumping from a window to the sidewalk. Officer Huggins ordered him to surrender, and as he refused to do so, discharged one barrel of his revolver in the direction in which he stood, with the object of intimidating him. At this Murphy darted up stairs, and reaching the upper story, got through the skylight to the roof of the building, which is 80 feet above the ground. Louis Bernowski, a Pole, the other burglar, who had been secured, united with the policemen in advising Murphy to descend from the roof and submit to arrest. He would not heed them, however, but jumped from where he stood, a distance of 30 feet, to the peaked roof of the adjoining building, and sliding down, was precipitated an additional distance of 50 feet, to the ground, striking upon the pavement, in an alleyway between the two stores. The officers, on searching for him, found him lying on the pavement, perfectly insensible, with his right thigh fractured in such a manner that the bones protruded from the flesh at right angles, his left leg broken near the knee, and his race and head shockingly cut. He was at once removed to the Hospital, where he lies at present in an extremely precarious condition. The surgeon says that it will be necessary to amputate both his legs, and that it is probable he will not survive the operation. The injured man is represented by the Police to be a desperate character. He is a Canadian, and not more than twenty-two years of age. His confederate Bernowski was taken before Justice OSBORN, by whom he was committed to prison. In the possession of the prisoners were found a loaded five-barreled pistol, a dirk knife, a gold watch and chain, two large "jimmies," a brace and bit, a dark lantern and six skeleton keys. An examination of the premises showed that entrance had been effected through the basement, the door of which had been forced, and that by cutting away the heavy plank of the floor above an aperture had been made large enough to admit the body of a man. The goods on this floor had been thoroughly overhauled by the burglars, but none seemed valuable enough to them to pay for the trouble of removal. To get into the hallway from Messrs. DEXTER, LAMBERT & Co.'s store the thieves had broken through a slight partition and forced the door of Messrs. HAMILL & BOOTH's store in the floor above, where they selected about $4,000 worth of silk goods which were packed ready for removal. Next they visited the store of Mr. JOHN STODERMAN, on the third floor, but nothing there had been disturbed.

Next they visited the store of Mr. JOHN STODERMAN, on the third floor, but nothing there had been disturbed.

abstract: The Commonwealth of North Carolina is fortunate in the possession of a Common School Superintendent, who finds nothing more natural than to step aside from the legitimate functions of his office and expound great questions of State. Mr. Superintendent WILEY has just rendered to Gov. ELLIS the annual report of the School Department ...
lead_paragraph: The Commonwealth of North Carolina is fortunate in the possession of a Common School Superintendent, who finds nothing more natural than to step aside from the legitimate functions of his office and expound great questions of State. Mr. Superintendent WILEY has just rendered to Gov. ELLIS the annual report of the School Department -- a document perspicuous and sensible enough, so far as it relates to the educational interests of the State, and full of pleasant reports of the joy of apt scholars and the gladdened hearts of satisfied teachers. But Mr. WILEY goes a step further than ordinary School Superintendents usually do. He addresses the Governor a long homily upon the questions at issue between the North and the South, indulges in flights of fancy, and rounds his periods with the skill of an accomplished rhetorician. "This report," he says, "is made to your Excellency at a time of trial, to you and to all patriotic guardians of the public interests." He portrays the agitation of the popular heart, deplores the bitter hatreds and fraternal strifes of the day, and finds cause to apprehend a general split of society into "innumerable hostile fragments," and the "setting of every man's sword against his fellow." After painting a gloomy picture of the chaos toward which he considers the country to be rapidly tending, he calls upon the Governor to "adhere to those principles of benevolence which have governed us in the past, and to remember that though our race is a fallen one, it is not forsaken by a gracious Creator, nor wholly abandoned to its evil instincts;" and, with a passing allusion to Harper's Ferry, winds up with a generous laudation of North Carolina and a special puff for his Excellency the Governor -- whom Mr. WILEY regards as one of the wisest and purest of living statesmen.

abstract: -- The Boston Courier of Saturday, says: "A telegraphic despatch to the Merchants' Exchange last evening, from Salem, states that the schooner California, of and eighty days from Salem, arrived at Go[???]ee, on the West Coast of Africa, Jan 4, and reported that, on the night of Dec. 27, it being the captain's watch on deck, the man at the wheel called out that the Captain was overboard. The vessel was hove to, but it being very dark, nothing could be seen or heard of him. At daylight, large quantities of blood being discovered about the vessel, suspicion was aroused that the master had been murdered and his body thrown overboard. On the arrival of the schooner at Coree, the sailor was put in irons, and will probably be sent to the United States. The Captain's name was JOHN PRENTISS, and he belonged in Boston. The Captain and the man at the wheel were the only persons on deck at the time; consequently, the sailor must be the one who committed the deed.

abstract: WILL OF THE LATE STEPHEN WHITNEY.--The will of the late STEPHEN WHITNEY has been offered for probate in the Surrogate's Court, the citation being returnable on the 5th proximo. WILLIAM WHITNEY, the son of the deceased, his sons-in-law, FERDINAND SUYDAM AND JOHN DORE, and his grand-sons, PHILIPS PHOENIX and GEORGE HENEY WARREN of Troy, are appointed executors of the will. After the payment of all just ...
lead_paragraph: WILL OF THE LATE STEPHEN WHITNEY.--The will of the late STEPHEN WHITNEY has been offered for probate in the Surrogate's Court, the citation being returnable on the 5th proximo. WILLIAM WHITNEY, the son of the deceased, his sons-in-law, FERDINAND SUYDAM AND JOHN DORE, and his grand-sons, PHILIPS PHOENIX and GEORGE HENEY WARREN of Troy, are appointed executors of the will. After the payment of all just [???]oems and funeral and testamentary charges, the wife of the deceased is to receive all stocks and moneys which stand credited to her on his books; the dwelling house at the corner of State street and Bowling Green, together with its furniture, and the sum of $100,000 which shall be invested for her benefit in stocks within the State of New-York or in those of the United States. The daughter of the deceased, EMELINE, the wife of JOHN DORE, is to receive $125,000, which shall be invested in a similar manner. SUSANNAH WHITNEY, his sister, is to receive $6,000. The residue of the estate is bequeathed to the executors, who shall collect and receive the rents and profits thereof for the benefit of MARY, the wife of JONAS P. PHOENIX; CAROLINE, the wife of FERDINAND SUYDAM; WILLIAM, the son of deceased; and the family of the late HENRY WHITNEY; each one of these parties to receive one-fourth of such profits. The last bequest is subject to a reservation of one thousand dollars. which shall be paid quarterly to the widow of Mr. HENRY WHITNEY. On the death of either one of the children to whom the bequests are made directly, his or her share is to be distributed among his or her children. By the nineteenth clause of the will each one of the children of the deceased is released from all debts which they may have incurred to their late father. The executors are empowered to sell real estate belonging to the deceased situated out of the City of New-York, and that within the City which is unimproved, and to lease all buildings which he owns for a period not exceeding five years. The dwelling-house, which falls to the relict of Mr. WHITNEY, is not to be sold without her consent given in writing.

abstract: The title of the party of "Peace-at-anyprice," originally invented for the French deputies who shrank from a collision with Europe on the Oriental question in 1840, and afterwards fastened upon the partisans of BRIGHT and COBDEN in England for their opposition to the war with Russia in 1857, may at last be matched with a fair equivalent and contrast.
lead_paragraph: The title of the party of "Peace-at-anyprice," originally invented for the French deputies who shrank from a collision with Europe on the Oriental question in 1840, and afterwards fastened upon the partisans of BRIGHT and COBDEN in England for their opposition to the war with Russia in 1857, may at last be matched with a fair equivalent and contrast. There exists in England at the present day a party which may be justly described as the "Panic-at-any-price" party. Whatever the French Emperor may do, or forbear to do, wears to these consistent tremblers all the certain indications of a coming storm of war, whereof the first furious gust will unquestionably sweep the green shores of Britain. When NAPOLEON III. marched his armies over the Alps, it was plain to these people that he was only taking Milan on the way to London. When he made peace at Villafranca, it was equally plain that an Austro-French alliance, involving the conquest of Malta, Gibraltar and the Ionian Islands, was instantly to be looked for. And now, in the very moment when a commercial treaty has lulled financial England for a season into a fatal confidence, comes "the evil Emperor's latest and most subtle design of mischief; and the impending annexation of Savoy to France portends that practical conversion of the Mediterranean into a French lake, which has given the theme of so many leaders, orations, speeches, reviews and jeremiads to the British mind for scores of years.

lead_paragraph: On Saturday Judge INGRAHAM rendered his decision on the motion of Messrs. Holmes and Brady on the previous day for a new trial in the case of W. J. Lake, Jr., convicted on one out of thirty indictments for forgery and embezzlement. Lane, it will to remembered, was a clerk in the Foltos Bank of this City, and, as is alleged, managed to defraud that institution to the amount of $60,089, by means on false entries. His highly fashionable style of living was exposed at the time of his arrest, and at the subsequent sale at auction of his horses, carriages, furniture, jewels, &c., for the benefit of the bank he had defrauded. The Judge on Saturday denied the motion of the counsel for a new trial, and the Assistant District-Attorney, Mr. Sedgwick, moved for sentence.

abstract: Hon. ABRAHAM LINCOLN, who is to speak this evening before the Republican Association at Cooper Institute, is a lawyer and distinguished politician in Illinois, where he is exceedingly popular. He won his principal distinction in the canvass against Mr. DOUGLAS in that State a year ago. He will be warmly urged by the Republicans of Illinois, as their candidate for the Presidency. They believe that with him that State may be carried even against Judge DOUGLAS. He is a man of unimpeachable character, a good lawyer, and an excellent speaker.

abstract: -- This City needs, absolutely and imperatively, one good, smooth, well-paved avenue upon which to drive out of town. We don't mean to say or imply that this is all we need, nor have we any intention of making out a catalogue of the manifold reformations necessary to the comfort and convenience of our citizens. But our City Government is doing something towards repaving some of our principal streets, and while they are engaged in this good work, it may be of some service to direct attention to this specific point.

abstract: By the letter of our Albany correspondent it will be seen that an organized attempt is likely to be made at that seat of wisdom and of purity to interfere with the management and to endanger the existence of the Central Park in this City. It is desirable, certainly, that sums so large as those involved in the becoming ...
lead_paragraph: By the letter of our Albany correspondent it will be seen that an organized attempt is likely to be made at that seat of wisdom and of purity to interfere with the management and to endanger the existence of the Central Park in this City. It is desirable, certainly, that sums so large as those involved in the becoming completion of a work so nobly commenced as this, should not be inconsiderately voted away; and as we of New-York are to pay for our Park ourselves, we ought not, perhaps, to refuse our fellow-citizens of the State at large the privilege of telling us just how much we shall pay for it, and just what sort of a park it shall be.

abstract: The United States vs. Twelve Cases Cigars and Four Casks marked F.W., containing White Wine. -- This was an action to forfeit the goods for undervaluation. They were received here by the ship Golden Rule, and were delivered up to the claimant. An additional duty by way of penalty was imposed on them and paid by the importer. On appraisement the goods were raised some 100 [???] cent. and some 150 [???] cent. in value, and they were thereupon seized, part in his store and part on shipboard. The claimant proved that he had been a small farmer in Germany, and raised and manufactured the goods himself, as was customary there, making the wine out of grapes and some brandy out of potatoes. He produced testimony to show that the articles were not undervalued in the invoice, and the jury after a short absence found a verdict in his favor and against the Government. For the United States, Mr. Hunt and Mr. McLane. For claimant -- Mr. Joachimsen and Mr. Kaufmann.
