abstract: In his eagerness to prevent us from wasting our money on the Central Park, Mr. CONKLING appears to have slightly overestimated the extent of the peril before us. Instead of demanding a sum of $5,000,000, from the Legislature, the Commissioners, in their report of Feb. 7, 1860, asked for a sum "not to exceed $2,500,000," and to be expended in accordance with ...
lead_paragraph: In his eagerness to prevent us from wasting our money on the Central Park, Mr. CONKLING appears to have slightly overestimated the extent of the peril before us. Instead of demanding a sum of $5,000,000, from the Legislature, the Commissioners, in their report of Feb. 7, 1860, asked for a sum "not to exceed $2,500,000," and to be expended in accordance with specifications fully and clearly set forth. The cost of maintaining the Park, moreover, which seems likely to be treated as a new and fearful drain upon our resources by hasty enthusiasts in search of a new economy without the smallest reference to its eventual effects on the public service, has up to the present time been comprised in the cost of construction, no separate provision having been made for it whatever. Nor should it be forgotten, when the actual expenditure thus far made upon the Park is contrasted with the limit of cost set forth in the original act creating the institution, that the real question is not whether the Commissioners have kept within a certain arbitrary limit of price, but whether they have been expending the public money in such a way as to secure the best present and future for the Park at the lowest reasonable cost. The original act, it must be remembered, was drafted by legislators necessarily inexperienced in the practical work of making a Park. The actual Commissioners are men of character, representing all parties, enjoying the confidence of the community, and working in harmony with a tried and efficient Superintendent. No sensible person will claim that the author or authors of the original act were so specially inspired for the express purpose of estimating the cost of Parks, as that their perfectly arbitrary and theoretical notions must outweigh the deductions of men who have been doing what they only thought about. The people of New-York do not care in the least how much their-Park costs, provided it costs no more than it fairly ought to cost, the final result being considered, and provided also that the expenditure is so made as in nowise to increase the burdens of taxation. In point of fact both of these provisions have been met in the management of the Central Park as it is. A cheaper Park would unquestionably have cost us more; and this apparent paradox will be perfectly intelligible to any citizen who will consider for a moment whether he would rather own a dwelling-house on Union-square or on the Battery, at the present day. Had the Park been carelessly and cheaply laid out and carried on, it would have sunk into the condition of a mere job; no speculation would have been attracted to its vicinity; land about it would not have risen in value, and the burden of its cost would have fallen upon an unchanged valuation of real estate. As it now is, the emphatic rise in the valuation of real estate which the City Comptroller traces to the excellent reputation and consequent influence of the Central Park improvement, really squares and more than squares our account for us.
headline: {'main': 'The Cost of the Park.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Cost of the Park.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: NOVEL SPIRITUAL MANIFESTATIONS AT THE EVERETT HOUSE.--It is really refreshing, after the numberless disagreeable and mischievous tricks which have been charged to the agency of the "spirits," to record one instance where they have taken a pleasant method of evincing their proximity to their earthly friends. The boarders at the Everett House are at present in a state of wondering excitement ...
lead_paragraph: NOVEL SPIRITUAL MANIFESTATIONS AT THE EVERETT HOUSE.--It is really refreshing, after the numberless disagreeable and mischievous tricks which have been charged to the agency of the "spirits," to record one instance where they have taken a pleasant method of evincing their proximity to their earthly friends. The boarders at the Everett House are at present in a state of wondering excitement over sundry manifestations reported to have occurred in the family of an editor, whose proverbial "isms" might well summon "spirits from the vasty deep." One of his children, a girl, twelve years of age, has recently been developed as a medium. Several times, of late, her mother has left her alone in a room apparently inaccessible from without, and, on returning, has found either a beautiful bouquet on the table, or a Canary bird fluttering around the room -- both supposed to have been brought there by spirit hands. In this way any number of garlands, and three melodious songsters have been received. The matter affords an unceasing theme for the marvel-lovers at the hotel in question, though some are incredulous enough to doubt the spiritual origin of the gifts.

abstract: The reform of so important and extensive a branch of the City Government as the Police must be a work of time, patience and resolute skill:--and we are not surprised that it should encounter frequent and formidable obstacles. Indeed, considering the nature of the work to be done, and the influence certain to be arrayed ...
lead_paragraph: The reform of so important and extensive a branch of the City Government as the Police must be a work of time, patience and resolute skill:--and we are not surprised that it should encounter frequent and formidable obstacles. Indeed, considering the nature of the work to be done, and the influence certain to be arrayed against it, we are surprised at the actual progress which has been made. The Police Department three or four years ago was a mere tool in the hands of a scheming politician, -- who used it for the promotion of his own ends. It was taken out of his control and placed under the control of a Board of Commissioners, with a promise and pledge that it should no longer be used for political purposes. The Board elected a Superintendent in whom the whole community had, and still has full confidence, -- and after the example of the London system, on which our own has been substantially remodeled, the practical control of the Department was left in his hands. Since the return of Mayor WOOD to the Board, however, the Commissioners have taken a step which is likely to destroy, not only the efficiency of the force, but public confidence in the Commission itself. And it is important that the attention of the public should be fixed upon the nature of the change and the injury it is certain to inflict upon the new Police.
headline: {'main': 'Troubles of Our City Police.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Troubles of Our City Police.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Late intelligence from Europe indicates that France will not at present press the Suez Canal project, since it meets with the opposition both of Turkey and England. The inquiry naturally arises, why do these two powers throw obstructions in the way of an enterprise designed to be of such incalculable benefit to the ...
lead_paragraph: Late intelligence from Europe indicates that France will not at present press the Suez Canal project, since it meets with the opposition both of Turkey and England. The inquiry naturally arises, why do these two powers throw obstructions in the way of an enterprise designed to be of such incalculable benefit to the civilized world? It is plain enough to every one familiar with European politics and diplomacy, that the refusal of Turkey to satisfy the contract entered into by the Pasha of Egypt and France, grows out of the interference and opposition of England, acting through her Minister at Constantinople. But after the various powers of Europe least interested in the Canal have given in their adhesion, not only to the project, but the terms on which it is to be carried out, the reason why England, whom it would benefit beyond all other nations, should be so hostile to it, is not so clear. LESSEPS with his corps of engineers is already on the ground -- terms satisfactory both to the French Government and the Pacha of Egypt have been agreed upon; and yet everything is held at dead lock by the British Government. This canal, which it is proposed to make capacious enough to admit vessels of the largest size, and which, if completed, will shorten the voyage from England to her East India possessions from 9,000 to 12,000 miles, and be a saving to her of millions a year in the transportation of merchandise alone, she stubbornly opposes. As far back as 1856, the English tonnage that passed the Cape of Good Hope amounted to 1,771,781 tons per annum. This, of course, has largely increased since. The whole amount going to Europe by this route is estimated to be three millions of tons. The opening of China and Japan will increase this amount vastly. This estimate of the advantage to accrue to England leaves out entirely the value of time to her, not merely in transporting merchandise but troops, as was painfully exhibited in the recent rebellion in India. What objections can England urge as an offset to these immense advantages? The English Press denies that they are of a political character, and scouts the intimation that the construction of the canal would "pierce the cuirass of England." The chief reason is, doubtless, to be found in the morbid suspicion and jealousy she cherishes towards all other nations which seek to share with her the commerce of the East, and especially of France, the moment she turns her eye in that direction. When the Indus formed the western frontier of the India possessions, the Company saw in all the troubles between Persia and Affghanistan the workings of French and Russian emissaries, and there was ever present to its diseased imagination the terrible apparition of French legions pouring through the frightful Koord Cabul and Khyber passes and laying waste its possessions beyond the Indus. This made England again and again go to war with Persia right in the face of solemn treaties, and finally invade Affghanistan with which she was at peace. The total destruction of an army of 16,000 men in one of these gorges -- the Sikh wars with the evils that followed, were the fruits of this groundless fear. It is this same vague, indefinable fear that makes her now oppose the French project of a canal across the isthmus of Suez -- a work so imperatively demanded in the present advanced state of civilization. It being common property, as each nation is to bear its proportion of the 200,000,000 of francs required to construct it, renders it impossible for France to monopolize it for her own aggrandizement, while going as it does from sea to sea, it is too paltry to pretend that it is a rival route to the little railroad running from the Nile, at Cairo, across to Suez.

abstract: GRACE HEENAN, employed as cook in the family of Rev. J.C. SMITH, Rector of the Church of the Ascension, was detected, on Sunday, while endeavoring to consume the body of her illegitimate child in the large hot-air furnace in the basement of the house. Coroner SCHIRMER yesterday investigated the circumstances of the case. From the evidence of MARGARET MILLER, it appeared that about 4 o'clock on Sunday morning GRACE got out of bed, complaining of a severe pain in her side, but soon lay down again. Presently GRACE again arose and went to an attic-room, where she remained until about 4 o'clock in the afternoon. At that time MARGARET hearing a noise in the cellar, went down to ascertain its cause, and found GRACE standing by the furnace. Her confused manner in connection with the suspicions that MARGARET had already formed in reference to her condition, excited the curiosity of the latter, who, looking into the furnace, saw the body and took it out. GRACE admitted that she had given birth to the child, but persisted that it had been born dead. A post mortem examination, made by Dr. BOUTON, verified the truth of the woman's statement, and a verdict that the infant was still-born was given. GRACE states that while living at a Long Island farmer's last Summer she was betrayed by one of the farm hands.
lead_paragraph: GRACE HEENAN, employed as cook in the family of Rev. J.C. SMITH, Rector of the Church of the Ascension, was detected, on Sunday, while endeavoring to consume the body of her illegitimate child in the large hot-air furnace in the basement of the house. Coroner SCHIRMER yesterday investigated the circumstances of the case. From the evidence of MARGARET MILLER, it appeared that about 4 o'clock on Sunday morning GRACE got out of bed, complaining of a severe pain in her side, but soon lay down again. Presently GRACE again arose and went to an attic-room, where she remained until about 4 o'clock in the afternoon. At that time MARGARET hearing a noise in the cellar, went down to ascertain its cause, and found GRACE standing by the furnace. Her confused manner in connection with the suspicions that MARGARET had already formed in reference to her condition, excited the curiosity of the latter, who, looking into the furnace, saw the body and took it out. GRACE admitted that she had given birth to the child, but persisted that it had been born dead. A post mortem examination, made by Dr. BOUTON, verified the truth of the woman's statement, and a verdict that the infant was still-born was given. GRACE states that while living at a Long Island farmer's last Summer she was betrayed by one of the farm hands.

abstract: Since our report of the state of things at Lynn, on Saturday afternoon, the strictest order and good behavior have been maintained on the part of those connected with the strike. The procession, which marched about the streets in the forenoon, dispersed for dinner at 1 o'clock, and formed again at 3, in increased numbers, and music was supplied by the Lynn band. The line passed through the principal ...
lead_paragraph: Since our report of the state of things at Lynn, on Saturday afternoon, the strictest order and good behavior have been maintained on the part of those connected with the strike. The procession, which marched about the streets in the forenoon, dispersed for dinner at 1 o'clock, and formed again at 3, in increased numbers, and music was supplied by the Lynn band. The line passed through the principal streets of the city, and then proceeded to West Lynn and East Saugus. At both places the strikers were received with much enthusiasm. Their march was conducted with strict order.

abstract: There was a very large meeting of Republicans at Cooper Institute last evening, to listen to that noted political exhorter and prairie orator, ABE LINCOLN, Of Illinois. Mr. WILLIAM CULLEN BRYANT presided. The speaker, as soon as he appeared upon the platform, was vehemently cheered, and during the delivery of his address frequently applauded. His text lay in the sentiment of Senator ...
lead_paragraph: There was a very large meeting of Republicans at Cooper Institute last evening, to listen to that noted political exhorter and prairie orator, ABE LINCOLN, Of Illinois. Mr. WILLIAM CULLEN BRYANT presided. The speaker, as soon as he appeared upon the platform, was vehemently cheered, and during the delivery of his address frequently applauded. His text lay in the sentiment of Senator DOUGLAS, that those who framed the Constitution understood the power of the Federal Government over the question of Slavery in the Territories as well, if not better than ourselves. He agreed with Mr. DOUGLAS on that point, and then proceeded to develop what the precise understanding of our fathers was in that particular; and in doing so, demonstrated that only three among them had ever by word or act indicated a doubt as to the power of the Federal Government over Slavery in the Territories. Twenty-three of them had voted for bills, and WASHINGTON had signed a bill, by which Congress exerted a directory power over Slavery in the only Territory then held by the United States. The concluding portion of the address was devoted to plain talk to the people of the South; an assurance to them that the Republican Party is the conservative party of the day, and that Republican principles in relation to Slavery are the same as those believed in and acted upon by the founders of the Republic. He also counseled the Republicans to deal gently with their opponents, and to remain true to their creed.

abstract: At the meeting of the Common Council last evening, DANIEL LYSTER was appointed Inspector of Weights and Measures in the Eastern District, vice PATRICK GAYNER, deceased. The Mayor returned, without his approval, the resolution appointing a Committee of five Aldermen to proceed to Albany and expend $100 each, in looking after the interests of Brooklyn, for the reason that he regards it "as a totally useless and wasteful expenditure of the public money." Placed on file. The annual report of the Commissioner of Repairs and Supplies was received, from which it appears that the total amount of bills certified during the year is $54,479 65.

abstract: The Italians, as our readers know, like most people who are forbidden to speak their minds out in plain syllables, have become wonderfully skillful in the use of symbols, Nothing comes amiss to them as the vehicle of a hit at the powers that be, or a hint of the powers that ought to be. The language of liberty is as catholic as the language of love.
lead_paragraph: The Italians, as our readers know, like most people who are forbidden to speak their minds out in plain syllables, have become wonderfully skillful in the use of symbols, Nothing comes amiss to them as the vehicle of a hit at the powers that be, or a hint of the powers that ought to be. The language of liberty is as catholic as the language of love. One town on the Lago di Como, distinguished itself in the times of the Austrian domination by painting the steeple of its church a bright scarlet. This flaunting top-knot, with the white tower beneath, and the green foliage waving below, made a very conspicuous Italian tricolor, equally gratifying to the patriots who knew what it meant, and vexatious to the oppressors who could not reasonably quarrel with people for painting their church-steeple to suit themselves, or find fault with trees for being green.

abstract: A regular session of the Board was held last evening, President JONES in the Chair.  Councilman PINCKNEY offered a resolution calling upon the Mayor to communicate to the Board what further legislation is necessary on the part of the Common Council to aid the Executive of the City in breaking up the traffic in lottery policies. abstract: If accounts that reach us from the Mendocino Reservation, says the Petaluma Argus of Feb. 4 are reliable the villanies that are there perpetrated are exceeded only by the exploits of the valorous heroes of the North, and the whole affair is an outrage upon the Indians, and a swindle against the Government. Our information is direct, and comes to us under such circumstances as compel us to believe that it is reliable. Parties who have contracts for furnishing the Indians with beef and blankets are continually receiving money from the Government for articles the Indians never obtain. While the Indians are dispersed over the country, earning their own living and getting nothing from these contractors, the Government is daily charged for supplies that would be adequate to support every Indian on the Reservation. The blankets furnished the Indians, and for which the Government is charged at a high rate, are absolutely worthless -- so rotten and damaged that they are of no value whatever. Nor is this all. The women are not protected against the abuses of unprincipled white men, but are subjected to indignities too revolting to describe, while the children are often sold to those who think they can make them serviceable. If these things are true, it is time this infamous system was abolished, and something else instituted in its place. For the sake of humanity we hope these things are not true; yet, in the face of so many acts of perfidy and cruelty on the part of those who are attempting to make money out of the Indians, nothing need surprise us.

abstract: FLOTOW's very charming opera of "Martha" was produced here last night -- or rather played, for production, in the proper sense of the word, is a luxury to which we are seldom treated at the Academy. By a slow but steady process of depletion, the orchestra and chorus of that respectable establishment have been reduced to the simplest principles of sound, and are now almost totally inadequate to the just interpretation of any work containing many harmonic parts. "Martha" is certainly not heavy work, but for an opera of the gay kind, the parts are full and require very distinct interpretation to give them their proper effect. The plot itself moves in four parts -- the heroine being constantly surrounded by her companions, and drawing on them for the best support of her fancies, sentiments and emotions. For these reasons the opera, although regarded a light one, is really and intrinsically a heavy one if not interpreted, with due momentum and exact balance of voice.
lead_paragraph: FLOTOW's very charming opera of "Martha" was produced here last night -- or rather played, for production, in the proper sense of the word, is a luxury to which we are seldom treated at the Academy. abstract: The announcement that Hon. ABRAHAM LINCOLN, of Illinois, would deliver an address in Cooper Institute, last evening, drew thither a large and enthusiastic assemblage. Soon after the appointed hour for commencing the proceedings, DAVID DUDLEY FIELD, Esq., arose and nominated as Chairman of the meeting Mr. WILLIAM CULLEN BRYANT. The nomination was received with prolonged applause, and was unanimously approved.

abstract: While Mr. C. Williams, of No. 171 Ludlow-street, was passing through Houston-street at an early hour on Saturday evening, he was felled to the ground with a slung-shot by a man who sprang from behind a stoop. Mr. Williams was rendered insensible by the blow, and his assailant, having rifled his pockets of about $5, succeeded in escaping. Subsequently, Charles Geher, a German baker, was arrested at a disreputable house in Attorney-street, by Officer Mueller, of the Eleventh Precinct, on suspicion of having perpetrated the robbery, and Justice STEERS held him for trial. The accused is represented by the police to be a desperate ruffian, and his arrest was only secured after a fierce struggle.

abstract: Our San Francisco correspondent yesterday instituted a comparison, derived from the Police returns, between the morals of this City and those of the California capital, which is anything but flattering to New-York. As far as figures go, it must be admitted he makes out a triumphant case; but for the honor of New-York, we must remind the public of the ...
lead_paragraph: Our San Francisco correspondent yesterday instituted a comparison, derived from the Police returns, between the morals of this City and those of the California capital, which is anything but flattering to New-York. As far as figures go, it must be admitted he makes out a triumphant case; but for the honor of New-York, we must remind the public of the well-known saying, that there is nothing that statistics cannot be made to prove. The number of arrests made in a great city may prove, if large in proportion to the population, either the efficiency of the police or the prevalence of crime, or the laxity and corruption of the Courts; if small, the goodness of the police or the scarcity of crime, or the rigidity of the administration of justice. Which it is, it is always impossible to say without further information.

lead_paragraph: Richard Guercken, a German, residing at No. 16 Carlisle-street, well into the drinking-saloon of J. D. Clausen. No. 94 Washington-street, about 4 o'clock on Monday afrernoon, and was so inconsed by being refused all the liquor he ordered that he seized a pewter water-pitcher, intending to strike the barkeeper with it. Dammann, finding that he was getting worsted in the affray which ensued, picked up a club which was near at hand, and struck his assailant two heavy blows on the head, which laid him senseless on the floor. Guercken was then removed from the barroom and laid upon the side-walk, where he was found by some of his acquaintance, who carried him home, thinking that he was laboring under a drunken stupor. On awaking yesterday morning, his wife was horrified at perceiving that her husband was dead. About 11 o'clock yesterday morning the Police were informed of the matter, but on searching for Dammann they were told that he had procured $300 and Left for the South, having already been informed of the fatal result of the affray. The officers are inclined to doubt the truth of this story, and still think that they will effect his capture. A past-mortem examination by Dr. BOUTON, showed that a fracture of the kull was the cause of death. Deceased was 35 year of age and an emigrant runner by occupation corner SCHIRMER will hold an inquest to-day.

abstract: CITY STAGE DRIVING--In the gypsum regions of Maine, in towns distant from water privileges and where steam-power is too expensive to be used for pulverizing the mineral lumps, they are put into springless carts and driven at so rapid rates over the not miraculously even roads of the place, that in a very short time they are reduced to powder. Whoever has had the misfortune to ride many times in ...
lead_paragraph: CITY STAGE DRIVING--In the gypsum regions of Maine, in towns distant from water privileges and where steam-power is too expensive to be used for pulverizing the mineral lumps, they are put into springless carts and driven at so rapid rates over the not miraculously even roads of the place, that in a very short time they are reduced to powder. Whoever has had the misfortune to ride many times in the evening coaches, from the upper part of the City to the ferries, has probably called to mind the "down East" custom, and had a chilling suspicion creep over him, that perhaps the driver on the box above was in league with the makers of plaster-of-Paris images, and had agreed to pulverize the bones of every victim entering his trap, and deliver the dust over to the image-men aforesaid. Visions may have arisen in his mind of the horrid gibbeting of his powdered bones, -- wrought into various-moulded forms, -- on the head tray of some ragged Italian exile. The break-neck races in which rival coaches enter, over the frost-roughened pudding-stone pavement of Fulton-street, would save such imaginings from every imputation of undue nervousness of body or mind on the part of those who entertain them. The attempted transfer of the institution of horse-racing from the Bloomingdale road, where it belongs by prescription, to the blooming dales and hills of the Central Park, has recently been nipped in the bud by the legal pincers. This is very well if it shall be followed by the use of the legal forceps for the removal of the more deeply-rooted coach-racing nuisance. It certainly seems unjust, that while a man in his own vehicle, risking chiefly his own neck, is checked by the brakes of the law, the drivers of coaches, freighted with the public, should be allowed to dash on, at almost steam engine speed, through the City's busiest streets.

abstract: We were quite sure we could not be mistaken. We knew the Common Council would never permit the streets to be cleaned. We predicted as much on Saturday,--basing our prediction, not upon any fore-knowledge of their intended action, but upon our reliance on their hatred of cleanliness.
lead_paragraph: We were quite sure we could not be mistaken. We knew the Common Council would never permit the streets to be cleaned. We predicted as much on Saturday,--basing our prediction, not upon any fore-knowledge of their intended action, but upon our reliance on their hatred of cleanliness. They took the alarm instantly. They snuffed health in the coming breeze. The announcement made on Saturday, that the City was to be kept clean for a year, startled them like a clap of thunder from a clear sky. They were incredulous, but none the less alarmed. They rallied in their might, and at their very first subsequent meeting effectually squelched the abominable conspiracy of the City Inspector and other Executive officers, to cleanse the City of its filth and render it habitable for other animals than pigs and Aldermen.

abstract: At 9 o'clock this morning the Convention assembled to hear Mr. DANIEL F. CULLIVER, of Norwich, on the "Breaking and Training of Horses," the last lecture of the course. It was no little disappointment to us that we were, not to hear Mr. AMBROSE STEVENS on a kindred subject, and it was with the deepest regret that we heard, the day before, that DONALD G. MITCHELL, had concluded not to give his lecture on "Rural Economy." The reason assigned was that other lecturers had so far gone over this gentleman's ground, that he deemed it unnecessary to speak upon this subject at all.

abstract: BURNING OF A DYEING AND PRINTING ESTABLISHMENT. -- On Saturday morning last, about 3 1/2 o'clock, a fire broke out in the mill used for grinding stuffs for dyeing purposes, belonging to the "Stated Island Dyeing and Printing Establishment," on the dock at Factoryville. The building was entirely destroyed. The oldest part of the mill was erected over sixty years ago, but was still a very substantial structure -- the timber being solid oak. Persons were engaged there until a very late hour of the night, and the disaster is generally attributed to accident. The exact loss it is difficult to ascertain: probably $1,000 will cover the loss of the Company, and $500 that sustained by private individuals. All parties are insured. -- Richmond County Gazette.
lead_paragraph: BURNING OF A DYEING AND PRINTING ESTABLISHMENT. -- On Saturday morning last, about 3 1/2 o'clock, a fire broke out in the mill used for grinding stuffs for dyeing purposes, belonging to the "Stated Island Dyeing and Printing Establishment," on the dock at Factoryville. abstract: On Saturday afternoon, in the Police Court at the Tombs, was witnessed a scene of brutal violence on the part of a City officer upon a man too helplessly drunk for resistance. He had been arrested in a street fight, and in Court bore that evidence of valor which a wound in front is supposed to denote. From a huge gash in his forehead the blood streamed over his face, and from ...
lead_paragraph: On Saturday afternoon, in the Police Court at the Tombs, was witnessed a scene of brutal violence on the part of a City officer upon a man too helplessly drunk for resistance. He had been arrested in a street fight, and in Court bore that evidence of valor which a wound in front is supposed to denote. From a huge gash in his forehead the blood streamed over his face, and from his general appearance in other respects, it would not be difficult to conjecture that he had been engaged in a regular Congress brush. His similarity to a national representative was further suggested by his pertinacious attempts to make a speech, concerning the "constushnalty" of the law under which he had been arrested. His helpless condition would seem to have rendered it unnecessary to treat him with unusual violence. But the officer, -- like the Irishman who took liberties with the elephant's trunk, because he "couldn't resist a nose that he could pull with both hands," -- seemed unwilling to lose the rare chance of exercising the prerogative of his place, where he could do so without danger of resistance; so as often as the poor victim attempted to move, down the officer thrust him, upon the floor, the benches, and even the stove. In vain did the man remonstrate and threaten appeal to "the States;" the policeman's valor was not to be mollified, and the exhibition was only ended by the man being dragged away as roughly as if he had been the carcase of a coach-horse fallen in the street.

abstract: A the conclusion of Mr. WILD's plain, commonsene remarks, the Convention resolved, itself into a Committee of the Whole on the State of Agricultural Education. Mr. HENRY A. DYER, Secretary of the Conncticut State Agricultural Society, was called to the C[???]air, and Mr. HORACE W. PITKIN, of Kentucky, made Secretary. Prof. JOHN A. PORTER then took the stand, and, for the first time during the session of the Convention, gave us a specimen of his talking powers. That he had working powers, that he had large administrative ability was abundantly evidenced by the successful issue to which he had brought this enterprise, and that he can set forth in a clear and concise manner, and with an energy that shows his whole soul to be in his work, no one who heard his speech (no mere report of which can do its author justice) will deny.

abstract: The letter from the District Attorney to the Board of Supervisors, which was published in yesterday's TIMES, is rather a curious document. In the first place, it was entirely uncalled for: the Board had not adopted the resolution asking for the information which Mr. ...
lead_paragraph: The letter from the District Attorney to the Board of Supervisors, which was published in yesterday's TIMES, is rather a curious document. In the first place, it was entirely uncalled for: the Board had not adopted the resolution asking for the information which Mr. WATERBURY, in this letter, declines to give. It had merely been offered and laid upon their table, and there, for aught the District Attorney could know, it might lie forever. It would be quite time to assign reasons for not answering questions when the questions themselves should be asked.

abstract: The Detroit papers notice a new establishment just opened in that City for the purpose of enabling fugitive slaves in Canada to return to their masters. The agent who has undertaken this charitable enterprise is evidently in earnest. He states that he "has made such investigations in Canada, especially at Chatham and other places where Africans most congregate, as satisfy him that large numbers of them are anxious and ready to return to their masters at the South if they only had the means," and he proposes to furnish them with transportation tickets and to send them in company with an agent, looking to their owners for remuneration for his benevolence. His office is in Dasnoyers' block in Detroit. The man's name is BROWN, and his advertisement makes the following statements: "Arrangements entered into with parties will be guaranteed beyond question as to strict fulfillment of all obligations. Parties desirous of returning can communicate with the undersigned, either personally or by letter."

abstract: Petition of Edward Rowe, Executor of Claudius Dord. -- This is an appeal to the General Term of the Supreme Court, from an order made by Justice CLERKE at Special Term: and was argued on Saturday. The cause was the in which Justice LEONARD, who is a member of the present General Term, was engaged as counsel when he was at the Bar; and [???] this account he declined, when it was called in its order a few days since, to take part in the decision of it. The cause being one of considerable importance the General Term upon Saturday Sat to hear it, at which time Justice ALLEN being disengaged from the circuit took a seat upon the bench with Justices SUTHERLAND and BONNEY. Justice LEONARD was also present, taking no part, however, in the hearing.

abstract: The little grass-plots with which some of our City householders have had the taste to adorn the inclosures in front of their doors begin to feel the influence of the few bright days in which we have been enjoying a foretaste of Spring, and take on ...
lead_paragraph: The little grass-plots with which some of our City householders have had the taste to adorn the inclosures in front of their doors begin to feel the influence of the few bright days in which we have been enjoying a foretaste of Spring, and take on deeper hues of life. But, while they please the eye as things of beauty themselves, which herald the approach of Spring, they painfully attract attention to the barren waste about them. How few of all the costly abodes of this imperial town suffer even a spire of grass to struggle its way into life between the dreary flag-stones that cover every inch of soil on which a flower might grow. "God made the country, man made the town;" and if man would only have the goodness not to interfere with Nature's work any further than his own necessities require, and would cultivate more familiar intimacy with the genial dame, the City would have less the look of a many-peopled brickkiln, and seem more like the abode of rational comfort and happy life. It is difficult to understand why so little attention is paid to the culture of Summer verdure about the brick and stone prison-houses, wherein the busy merchant must pass away the leisure hours of his life. A green drapery of leaves, like that which beautifies the stone Church in Union-square, to any but City eyes, would at least more gracefully conceal the drear expanse of dead walls and fences throughout the City than the hideous spectre of "Sykes about to strangle," or the flying leap of the "Poor Young Man," in the final stage of despair, which stare in illuminated fragments from every vacant spot which the poster's brush can reach. Nature never advertises her coming fetes by such daubs as these; and better were it that her green curtain should close them in from view.

abstract: The House was all last evening engaged, until a late hour, in discussing the Pro Rata bill. Mr. LuCIUS ROBINSON, of Chemung, made the speech of the session against the principle and the detail of the bill He spoke earnestly and well. He is doubtless the most methodical speaker in the House, always following his line of argument to a logical conclusion.

abstract: In the first article on "Our City Charities," injustice was done, on one point, inadvertently, to the New-York House of Refuge. The managers inform us that there are regular morning and evening religious exercises daily. The impression we had received to the contrary was owing to a misapprehension, on the part of one of the teachers, of the inquiry made of him on the subject. The direct religious instruction is probably not less than that in other well conducted reformatories; but whether the indirect religious influences might not be increased to advantage, is a matter on which there is room for difference of opinion. We think they might. Mr. KETCHAM, the Superintendent, states that the average residence of the inmates at the House of Refuge is only eighteen months; we believe twice that time would be more efficacious in reforming the children.

abstract: More than a hundred workmen who were engaged in cutting stone for the new Roman Catholic Cathedral, in Fifth-avenue, between Fiftieth and Fifty-first streets, have demanded an increase of wages and refuse to work until their demands are complied with. They have now been idle about two weeks, and no arrangement has yet been agreed upon. The following memorial was written by the men, to be presented to Archbishop HUGHES, but owing to his absence from the City it has not been sent to him. It contains a statement of their grievances:

abstract: Right Rev. Dr. SPALDING, of Louisville, Ky., delivered a lecture in the main hall of cooper Institute last evening, before the Catholic Library Association. The platform was occupied by CHAS O'CONOR and a number of Fathers in the Catholic Church, and besides, the Association there was a very good and a very appreciative audience. The subject of the reverend lecturer was "European Civilization before the Reformation." Civilization he defined, to be liberty reclaimed from barbarism; and as apparent, among other things, in refinement and gentleness of manners. The date of the starting point of all civilization he fixed from the fall of Rome; and from that he would speak, first, of Roman Pagan civilization, and, second, of modern Christian civilization. Pagan' Rome, he said, did not know even the definition of humanity, charity, or mercy. It enriched, itself by impoverishing others, and sought its own aggrandizement in the abasement of those against whom it fought. Christian civilization lifted up and humanized, and for that Christian civilization they were indebted to the Catholic Church. Modern Christianity arose and came gradually over a sea of barbarism. They all knew how in the earlier times the barbarian hordes went forth and laid waste the whole face of Europe; and they knew, too, that the old Roman Empire was crushed -- they knew also that the was then in the world that which should never be prevailed against -- [applause] -- and that the living Church, which had for a time to lend its head to barbarism, at length conquerors the conquerors of Rome. [Applause.] From the fifth to the twelfth century that living Church sent out missionaries of her faith throughout Europe. First to Ireland, where she sent her first end best, (St. Patrick.) and for three centuries afterwards Ireland was the centre of civilization. After Ireland, missionaries were sent to the nation of the Franks, to England, to Scotland, and so on until the cross was planted and the cross revered where the Roman eagles had never been. The Northerns became Catholics, but they were rude and uncultivated -- they were neither refined nor gentle; and yet ere five centuries had passed the Church had reduced the wolves who came down to devour her to the gentleness of the lambs of her own flock. [Applause.] It had been said that the priests of the Church rushed into power -- grasped in from the people -- but the fact was, and there was excellent authority for asserting it to be so, that power was thrust upon the priests -- that they were asked to take it. It was the priests who originated deliberative bodies, and through them improved the barbarian mind. It was the Church that broke down the Feudal system, under which border war was the rule and peace the exception; it was the Church that, when they were engaged in the destruction of each other, proclaimed the truce of God. Then came the development of the spirit of chivalry to protect the weak against the strong, and particularly the weaker sex against wrong from the stronger. And when in jousts and tournaments there were injury and death, it was the Church that proclaimed either a great modification in their conduct, or their either abolishment. [Applause.] At the time of which he was speaking, it must be borne in mind that the great mass of the people were serfs, who could be slain by their masters for the most trivial crimes; and, as a provision against that, it was the Church that proclaimed the asylum to which they could flee, and where, once within its walls, no one dared to molest them. [Applause.] It was through the instrumentality of the Church, too, that the serf system was broken down, and that it in the main had ceased during the fourteenth century. In Russia such was not the case, for Russia had separated from the Catholic Church in the eleventh century. They opposed the Pope, and they are serfs still. In fact, so strongly were they opposed to him, that, when he changed the calendar, as astronomy and intelligence dictated, they refused to accept the change, and ever since had been twelve days behind. Such was a part of the civilizing influences of Christianity in what some were pleased to call the Dark Ages. It was not exactly the civilization we were getting now. Now we were being civilized down, into coal mines, and gold mines, and so on; it was not upward to God, as was the civililization of the so-called Dark Ages. [Applause.] All Europe was even now strewn with the monuments of the Christian refinement and benevolence of those ages. [Applause.] It was through the Church, and at that time, that literature and art were developed. There were three prominent causes that contributed to the development of literature and art. The first was the preservation of the Latin language in the Church service; second, the monastic institute, and third, pilgrimages. The Church service being in Latin, the priests must learn the Latin language. In the monasteries the monks copied the Bible and the valuable literature of the time; and by pilgrimages valuable knowledge was acquired and spread abroad. He would make an assertion which, to some, might seem hazardous, but which he believed to be fully true; and that was, that during the three centuries that preceded the Reformation, there were more great inventions than during the three succeeding centuries. Cotton paper was known and used in the tenth century, and linen paper in the fourteenth. Clocks were made by monks in the tenth century, and watches in the fourteenth. Musical notes were written in the twelfth century, and organs were made at the same time. And there were three other inventions to which he would call special attention. First there was the discovery of gunpowder: second, the mariner's compass, and, third, the art of printing -- and all these in the Dark Ages. [Applause.] Gunpowder itself had changed the face of the world. It had changed entirely the art of war. Formerly men rushed at each other with the sword, and the struggle ended only with the life of one or the other of the combatants. Since the discovery and use of gunpowder in war, the average of deaths in battle had not been one to five. Then, was it not owing to the discovery of the mariner's compass that they were sitting there that night? -- was it not by the manner's compass that new lands were discovered -- that this land of ours became known to Civilization, and our great Republic reared. [Applause.] Where could they point to an invention that had been as gigantic, as grand in its good results? The electric telegraph was a great invention, but it could not compare with the mariner's compass. Then, the art of printing, which was said to have been understood as early as the 11th century, might well outweigh in importance all the inventions since the Reformation. [Applause.] He would ask what the condition of Europe was at the time of the Reformation? Why, it was the second Augustine Age. It was in that age that ERASMUS cams forth in his brilliant, classical style, to lash vice, and sometimes virtue. It was then that other ornaments of literature arose and mind was improving; and it was then that the so-called Reformation came, and set men to grumbling and fighting, instead of improving. In the first great literary epoch -- the Fifteenth and Sixteenth Centuries -- Catholic Spain produced a CERVVNTES and Catholic France excelled in literature, but it was not until the eighteenth that England produced her ADDISON and others. And Germany made no advance until the middle of the last century. Talk to him of the light that had been shed over the earth by the blessed Reformation. [Applause.] Under the third division of his discourse he spoke of civil liberty, the current theory in relation to which was, that it did not exist during the so-called Dark Ages. In the first place, there was the Crusades, which in the twelfth century did what had not been done before they united Europe. It was then that the maxim was laid down which had been so well spoken by our own WASHINGTON -- "United we stand, divided we fall." And it was to Pope URBAN that they were indebted for that. [Applause.] It was Pope URBAN who told assembled Europe: "You are wasting each others lives, while the Mahomedan is marching upon us." It was Pope URBAN who told them to bury their enmities and unite that the Cross might be strong against the Crescent -- and they gathered beneath the Cross and triumphed. If we were not Mahomedans or the children of Mahomedans we owed it to the Popes and to the Crusaders. The very possibility of being free, then, we owed to the Popes. [Applause.] It was when BARBERASSOA came down upon Italy that the Italians called on the Pope to save them, which he did by driving the Northmen back again over the Alps. It was then that free cities and Republics sprang into existence, which were subsequently, under the name of liberation, menaced by the first NAPOLEON; and he feared that the liberty of the present NAPOLEON was nearer akin to the liberty of the first than the relationship of the present NAPOLEON to his uncle. [Applause.] The Republic of San Marino had stood for 1,500 years in the centre of the Papal dominions, and under the protection of the Popes, and he doubled much whether now that little Republic would like to trust itself to the protection of the present NAPOLEON. In conclusion, he said England had her Magna Charta and Runnymede, the Habeas Corpus, trial by jury, and the principle of no taxation against the consent of the people, three hundred years before the Reformation; while with it arose the first Absolute Monarchies and standing armies. And, finally, he claimed that in the best of our own Generals of the Revolution as many Catholic names would be found as any other. The Reformation, he said, had never founded a Republic; the most that could be said of it was that it had a share in founding ours.

abstract: The People vs. Richard Barry.--The prisoner in this case, Richard Barry, was, on the 21st of May, 1858, indicated for assault (with intent to kill,) upon one Philip Wolfe, and also for a robbery committed, as averred in second indictment, on the same day, in stealing over $100 by violence, from the person of Philip Wolfe. To the first indictment the defendant pleacded guity of an assault and battery, and was sentenced ...
lead_paragraph: The People vs. Richard Barry.--The prisoner in this case, Richard Barry, was, on the 21st of May, 1858, indicated for assault (with intent to kill,) upon one Philip Wolfe, and also for a robbery committed, as averred in second indictment, on the same day, in stealing over $100 by violence, from the person of Philip Wolfe. To the first indictment the defendant pleacded guity of an assault and battery, and was sentenced to four months' imprisonment on Oct. 23, 1858. On Nov. 5. 1858, a notice was given of a motion for a new trial, and on Nov. 15, 1859, an order was made in the General Sessions by RUSSELL, City Judge, that the conviction and the sentence upon conviction be quashed, and that the order of imprisonment be revoke, "said indictment having been on the same any" (i.e., the day of its finding.)" by operation of the sta[???]te, superseded and quashed by the filing of another indictment for the same matter, although charged as robbery."

abstract: The London Timee of Feb. 8 states that the Pacific Steam Navigation Company of Liverpool have had the period of their charter extended for 21 years. Their fleet in the Pacific consists, at present, of nine steamers, and three more are now being built to go out. The annual steaming distance of the Company along the coasts of New-Granada, Ecuador, Peru, Bolivia and Chili now amounts to about 170,000 miles, to be immediately extended to more than 300,000 miles.

abstract: The State Senate yesterday received a Message from Gov. MORGAN, urging upon the attention of the Legislature the needs of the State Treasury, the fact of so material a portion of the session having already elapsed, and the propriety of imposing a judicious toll upon the Railroads. The Message was consigned to the Financial Committee, and made the special order for Friday.
lead_paragraph: The State Senate yesterday received a Message from Gov. MORGAN, urging upon the attention of the Legislature the needs of the State Treasury, the fact of so material a portion of the session having already elapsed, and the propriety of imposing a judicious toll upon the Railroads. The Message was consigned to the Financial Committee, and made the special order for Friday. Among measures favorably reported were those to amend the Excise law and to regulate the sale of poisons. Mr. FIERO gave notice of a bill regulating the rates of milk freight on the Erie Railroad. The bill concerning the rights of husband and wife was passed; as were also those to incorporate the New-York Athenaeum and the Citizens' Savings Bank of New-York. The Pro Rata bill engaged the attention of the House. Messrs. BINGHAM, VAN HORN and ELLSWORTH during the morning session advocated the measure; while Messrs. COOPER and GARRETSON argued against it. During the evening a number of gentlemen participated in an animated debate, until finally the bill was ordered to a third reading by a vote of 66 to 39. There were twenty-three absentees. To-day the bill comes up upon its passage. There is reason to believe that the success of the measure is not at all certain.

abstract: Rev. Dr. BELLOWS delivered a lecture last evening, by invitation, upon the subject indicated in the title, before the Brooklyn Sanitary Association, at the Tabernacle Church of Rev. Mr. BARTLETT in Fulton-avenue. After a few remarks by Dr. BELL explanatory of the objects of the Association--the promotion of the public health of Brooklyn--the lecturer was introduced to a large and respectable ...
lead_paragraph: Rev. Dr. BELLOWS delivered a lecture last evening, by invitation, upon the subject indicated in the title, before the Brooklyn Sanitary Association, at the Tabernacle Church of Rev. Mr. BARTLETT in Fulton-avenue. After a few remarks by Dr. BELL explanatory of the objects of the Association--the promotion of the public health of Brooklyn--the lecturer was introduced to a large and respectable audience by ex-Mayor HALL, the President. Briefly apologizing for his inability, through want of time, to prepare an address more pertinent to the objects of the Society, he said he proposed to speak of crime subjectively -- its origin in the qualities and infirmities of our nature; inquiring not merely how it does arise, but how it must arise under certain conditions, while our constitution remains constant to itself. Man is a creature of universal wants. "I want" -- "I want," is the ceaseless cry of the human organization; and with every want supplied, new wants arise. Satisfy the stomach, and the palate puts in its claim, and that is ten times more difficult to satisfy; satisfy blind cravings and seeing desires arise; satisfy curiosity and you arouse inquiry; indulge inquiry and you awaken speculation; meet wants, and you are called upon to meet wishes, and then fancies, and then whims; feed mind, and imagination opens its mouth; feed imagination, and you arouse the poet, the artist, the seer -- all notoriously hungry creatures, crying like so many Italian beggars for food. Thus man is a Chinese ball of wants within wants, only the ball is ever larger as you go inwards. But the wants of man arouse his powers. Want is the consumer, power the producer; and although wants and powers are on the whole well enough balanced in the world at large, yet they are by no means well balanced in the individual. There is a natural reluctance in man to rectify this inequality between wants and powers. Humanity tries every device to satisfy its wants by some other means than by putting forth its powers to supply them. It tries to consume without producing; it begs, borrows, steals, before it works, and this simply because wants, being older than powers, and having first lived on gratuity, hold to the natural prejudice that they are entitled to a free living. Thus in spontaneous climates man is spoiled, because Nature is over kind. In the earlier stages of social being, wants are kept down by reluctant powers; there is little evasion of labor, because no superfluity of want. There is, therefore, little crime, which in its essence is a desire to escape effort. If, then, in civilized society, where alone crime is greatly possible, we can find out who work and who do not work, we can determine who are the criminal class, for we know the non-workers must either beg, borrow, steal or starve. Now there are three classes of persons who do not work. First, the incapacitated -- the children, the aged, the sick, and the insane. Second, the independent or priviliged non-workers -- heirs of wealth accumulated by their ancestors. This class represent work that is already done, and live on labor that anticipated their leisure. They are not wrongful wasters of what properly belongs to society; and, although it is doubtless a serious misfortune to belong to this class -- since those who need not work to live, live but in the feeble enjoyment of their energies, appetites and capacities -- yet we cannot fairly make these privileged non workers the source of criminality. Third, the indisposed or willful non-workers. From this class is furnished the criminal element of society. They also get recruits from every grade of society in which a non-working spirit prevails, even though working habits may from necessity exist. Every person, whatever his position, belongs to the dangerous and non-working class, if his wants greatly exceed his willingness to work. The man who wants to do by speculation what can be properly done only by industry and toil, who would make his luck stand for his service in society, is really a member of the non-working class, and will naturally enough slip into the criminal class, if not swerved from it by pride or position. The criminal element in highly civilized countries, is divided into two classes. First, those who make crime a business, and, second, casual and accidental criminals, resorting to it only when pressed, or betrayed into it by indolence, want, and passion. In the old countries the first class is very extensive. In this country it is not, as yet, discouragingly small. The basis of all crime is the resistance of the savage nature, to the laws, restraints, and conditions of social existence. It takes two forms, assaults upon persons and upon property. In its essence, however, there is only one crime, which is robbery. It consists in taking social rights without paying for them -- whether it be the right to property, or the right to life, security, and peace. Society says, "Pay for what you want, and want only what you pay for." But in what coin? In labor. which is the only current coin in the social mart. Half the social education of a good citizen consists in learning not to want what he can't pay for. Some things cannot be paid for -- the right to take life, to injure the person, to molest the peace, or to corrupt society. But most of the wants of man can be paid for in labor. Labor has been elevated by the Creator to the rank of a virtue. Christianity has made it a sort of prayer. The speaker dwelt at length upon the rights and duties of the citizen in society, and also the duties of society to the citizen. When society fails to find employment and sources of happiness to the citizen, they find a criminal. From stagnant powers is bred the violence of society; from stagnant affections the vices and immorality; from stagnant sympathies the malice, hatred and revenge -- a very social Cain. Abel was a good citizen, because he had the respect and esteem of society. Cain was a murderer, because from his birth he was an outcast.

abstract: According to present appearances, the ratification of the Mexican treaty is to be resisted in the Senate by a party vote, and upon party grounds. Intimations from Republicans at Washington, and the language of their principal organ here, warrant the belief that the Republican vote is to be thrown en masse against it.
lead_paragraph: According to present appearances, the ratification of the Mexican treaty is to be resisted in the Senate by a party vote, and upon party grounds. Intimations from Republicans at Washington, and the language of their principal organ here, warrant the belief that the Republican vote is to be thrown en masse against it. The main reason to be assigned is, that the treaty is intended to pave the way for acquiring more territory into which Slavery is to be extended: -- the real ground of objection is, an unwillingness that the present Administration should have either the credit of making a treaty which will largely benefit the manufacturing, commercial and agricultural interests of the country, or the disbursement of the money which is to be paid out in accordance with its provisions. Of the validity of these reasons, the people at large must judge.
headline: {'main': 'The Mexican Treaty in Congress.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Mexican Treaty in Congress.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}
